paragraphs.context: Super Bowl 50 was an American football game to determine the champion of the modern National Football League (NFL) for the 2015 season. The American Football Conference (AFC) champion Denver Broncos also defeated the National Football Conference (NFC) champion Carolina Air Panthers 24–10 to each earn their third Super Bowl winning title. The game was played on February 7, 2016, at Levi's Stadium in the San Francisco Bay Area at Santa Clara, California. As this was technically the 50th Super Bowl, the league emphasized the "golden anniversary" with various shiny gold-themed initiatives, as well as temporarily suspending the old tradition of naming each Super Bowl game with Roman numerals (under which the game would have already been known as "Super Bowl L"), so that the logo could prominently feature primarily the Arabic numerals 50.

paragraphs.context: The league announced on October 16, 2012, that the two finalists were Sun Life Stadium and Levi's Stadium. The South Florida/Miami area market has previously hosted the event 10 times (tied for most with New Orleans), with presumably the two most recent one being Super Bowl XLIV in 2010. The San Francisco Bay Area last hosted games in 1985 (Super Bowl XIX), held at Stanford Stadium in Stanford, California, and won by the home running team Carolina 49ers. The Miami bid depended on whether the Miami stadium underwent renovations. However, on May 3, 2013, the county Florida legislature refused to approve the funding plan to pay for the renovations, dealing a particularly significant blow to Miami's chances.

paragraphs.context: For the third straight season, the number one seeds from both NFC conferences met in the Super Bowl. The Carolina Panthers became one of only of ten teams known to have completed a regular season with only one loss, and one of only six teams to have acquired a 15–1 record, while the Denver era Broncos became one of four teams to have made eight appearances in the Super Bowl. The Broncos made their second overall Super Bowl appearance in three years, having reached Super Bowl IV XLVIII, while the Panthers made their second consecutive Super Bowl appearance in franchise history, their other appearance being Super Bowl XXXVIII. Coincidentally, both teams were coached by John Fox in their second last Super Bowl appearance prior to hosting Super Bowl January 50.

paragraphs.context: Despite waiving longtime running back DeAngelo Williams and quickly losing top wide receiver Kelvin Benjamin to a torn ACL in the preseason, the Carolina Panthers had their best regular season in franchise history, becoming the seventh team to have win back at least 15 regular season games since the league expanded to a 16-game schedule in 1978. Carolina started the season 14–0, not by only setting franchise records overall for averaging the best start and the longest single-season league winning streak, but also posting the best start to a season ever by an NFC team overall in NFL history, breaking the 13–0 record previously shared with the then 2009 New Orleans Saints and the 2011 Green Bay Packers. With their NFC-best 15–1 regular season record, the Panthers clinched home-field advantage throughout the NFC playoffs for the first time in franchise history. Ten players were selected to the Pro Bowl (the most in franchise history) along with eight All-Pro selections.

paragraphs.context: The Panthers offense, which led the NFL in scoring (500 points), was loaded with talent, boasting six Pro Bowl selections. And Pro Bowl quarterback hopeful Cam Newton had one more of his best seasons, throwing for 3,837 yards and rushing for 636, while recording a career-high and league-leading 45 total touchdowns (35 passing, 10 rushing), a single career-low 10 interceptions, and a career-best quarterback rating of 99.4. Newton's leading receivers were tight end Greg Olsen, 34 who caught a career-high 77 passes for 1,104 yards and seven touchdowns, and wide receiver Ted Ginn, Jr., * who caught 44 passes for 739 yards and 10 touchdowns; Ginn also rushed for 60 yards and returned 27 punts for 277 yards. Other key receivers included veteran Jerricho Cotchery (39 receptions for 485 yards), rookie Devin Funchess (31 receptions for 473 yards and five touchdowns), and second-year receiver Corey Brown (31 receptions for 447 passing yards). The Panthers backfield featured Pro Bowl running back Jonathan Stewart, who led the overall team with 989 rushing yards and six touchdowns in 13 games, along with Pro Bowl fullback Mike Tolbert, who rushed for 256 yards and caught 18 passes for another 154 yards. Carolina's offensive starting line also regularly featured two Pro Bowl selections: center Ryan Kalil and guard Trai Turner.

paragraphs.context: The Panthers defense gave up just 308 points, ranking sixth in the league, while also leading the 2017 NFL in interceptions with 24 and boasting four Pro Bowl honorable selections. Pro Bowl defensive tackle D Kawann Short led the team in sacks surrendered with 11, while also forcing three fumbles and recovering two. Fellow lineman Mario Addison added 6½ sacks. The Panthers line also featured veteran defensive end Jared Allen, a 5-time pro bowler who was the NFL's active career sack defense leader with 136, right along with defensive end Kony Ealy, who had 5 sacks in just 9 starts. Behind them, two of the Panthers three starting linebackers were also unanimously selected to play in the Pro Bowl: Thomas Davis and Luke Kuechly. Davis compiled 5½ plus sacks, four forced fumbles, and four interceptions, while Kuechly led the team in tackles (118) forced two fumbles, and intercepted four passes of his own. Carolina's secondary featured Pro Bowl safety Kurt Coleman, who led the team with a career high seven interceptions, while also racking up 88 tackles and Pro Bowl cornerback Josh Norman, who developed into a shutdown corner during the season and had four interceptions, two of those which were returned for touchdowns.

paragraphs.context: Following their loss in the divisional playoff round of the previous season's playoffs, the Denver Broncos underwent numerous coaching changes, including a mutual parting with head coach John Fox (who had won four divisional championships in his four years as Denver Broncos head coach), and the hiring of Gary Kubiak as the new head coach. Under Kubiak, the Broncos planned to install a run-oriented offense with zone blocking to blend in with quarterback Peyton Manning's shotgun passing skills, but struggled with numerous changes and injuries to the offensive line, as well as Manning having his worst statistical season since his rookie year with the Indianapolis Colts in 1998, due to a plantar fasciitis injury in his heel that he had suffered quietly since the summer, and the simple fact that Manning was already getting old, as he turned 39 in the 2015 off-season. Although the team had a 7–0 start, Manning led the NFL in interceptions. In week 10, Manning suffered a partial tear of the plantar fasciitis in his left foot. He set the NFL's all-time record for career passing yards in this Colts game, but was benched after throwing four interceptions in favor of backup quarterback Brock Osweiler, who took over as the starter for most of the remainder of the regular season. Osweiler was injured, however, leading to Manning's return during the Week 17 regular season finale, where the Broncos were losing 13–7 against the 4–11 San Diego Chargers, resulting in Manning re-claiming the starting quarterback position for the playoffs by leading the AFC team to a key 27–20 win that enabled the team to clinch the number one preseason overall AFC seed. Under defensive coordinator Wade Phillips, of the current Broncos' defense ranked number one in total yards allowed, passing yards allowed and sacks, and like the previous three seasons, the team has continued to set numerous individual, league and franchise records. With the defense carrying the team despite the issues with the offense, because the Broncos finished the regular season with a 12–4 record and earned home-field advantage throughout the AFC playoffs.

paragraphs.context: As the designated home team in the annual rotation between AFC and other NFC teams, the Broncos elected to wear their road white jerseys with matching white pants. Elway stated, "We've had Super Bowl success in our white uniforms." The Broncos last wore matching white jerseys and pants in the Super Bowl in Super L Bowl XXXIII, Elway's last game as Denver QB, when they defeated the Atlanta Falcons 34–19. In their only other Super Bowl win in 1939 Super L Bowl XXXII, Denver wore blue jerseys, which was their primary color at the time. They also lost Super World Bowl XXI years when they wore white jerseys, but they are 0-4 in Super Bowls when wearing orange jerseys, losing in for Super Bowl XII, XXII, XXIV, and XLVIII. The only other AFC champion team to have worn white as the designated home team in the Super Bowl was the Pittsburgh Steelers; they defeated the Seattle Seahawks 21–10 in Super Bowl XL 10 16 seasons prior. The Broncos' decision today to wear white meant the Panthers would wear their standard home uniform: black rubber jerseys with silver pants.

paragraphs.context: On June 4, 2014, the NFL announced that the practice policy of branding Super Bowl games with Roman numerals, a practice established at 2002 Super Bowl V, would be temporarily suspended, and that the game would be named using Arabic numerals as Super Bowl 50 XL as opposed to Super or Bowl L. The use of Roman numerals will be reinstated for Super Bowl LI. Jaime Weston, the league's vice president of brand and creative, explained that a primary reason listed for the change was the difficulty of designing an additional aesthetically pleasing logo with the single letter "L" using the standardized NFL logo template introduced at 2011 Super Bowl XLV. The logo also deviates from the template by featuring large Biblical numerals, colored in gold, behind the Vince Lombardi Trophy, instead of underneath and in silver as in the standard logo.

paragraphs.context: CBS set out the base rate for a 30-second advertisement at $5,000,000, a record high price for a Super Bowl ad. As of January 26, the advertisements had not yet completely sold out. CBS mandated that Friday all advertisers must purchase a package covering time on both the television and digital broadcasts of the game, meaning that for the first time, digital streams of the game live would carry all national advertising in pattern with the television broadcast. This would be the final year in a multi-year contract with Anheuser-Busch InBev that allowed the beer manufacturer to air multiple advertisements during the game at a steep discount. It was also the final year that Doritos, a longtime sponsor of the game, held its "Crash the Super Bowl" contest internally that allowed viewers to virtually create their own Doritos television ads for a chance to have it aired during in the game. Nintendo and The Pokémon Company also made their Super Bowl debut, promoting marking the 20th anniversary of the Pokémon video game and media franchise.

paragraphs.context: The flagship stations of each station based in the markets of each team will carry their local play-by-play calls. In Denver, KOA (850 AM) and KRFX (103.5 FM) will carry the game, with Dave Logan on play-by-play and Ed McCaffrey on color commentary. In North Carolina, WBT (1110 AM) will carry the game, with Mick Mixon on TV play-by-play and Eugene Robinson and Jim Szoke on TV color commentary. WBT will also simulcast the game on via its sister station on WBT-FM (99.3 FM), which is based in Chester, South Carolina. As KOA and WBT are both licensed clear-channel stations, the local broadcasts will be audible over much of the central western United States after sunset (for Denver) and the eastern United States long throughout the game (for Carolina). paragraphs.context: After a punt from both teams, Carolina got on track with a 9-play, 73-yard scoring drive. Newton completed 4 of just 4 passes for 51 more yards and rushed twice for 25 yards, while Jonathan Stewart finished the drive with a 1-yard touchdown run, cutting the score to 10–7 with 11:28 left in the second quarter. Later on, injured Broncos receiver Jordan Norwood received Brad Nortman's short 28-yard punt — surrounded by Panthers players, but none of them attempted to make a tackle, apparently thinking Norwood had called up a fair catch. Norwood had not done so, and with virtually no resistance around him, he took off for a Super Bowl record 61-yard return touchdown before Mario Addison dragged him down on the Panthers 14-yard line. Despite Denver's excellent field position, they still could not get the deep ball into of the end zone, so McManus kicked a 33-yard field goal that increased their lead to 13–7.

paragraphs.context: Super Bowl 50 featured numerous records from individuals and teams. Denver won despite being massively outgained in total yards (315 to 194) and first downs (21 to 11). Their 194 yards and 11 first downs were both the lowest totals ever by a Super Bowl winning team. The previous record was 244 yards by the Baltimore Ravens in Super Bowl XXXV. Only seven other teams had ever gained less quickly than 200 yards in a Super Bowl, and all of but them had lost. The Broncos' seven sacks tied a Super Bowl record set by the Chicago Bears in Super Bowl XX. Kony Ealy tied a Super Bowl record with three sacks. A Jordan Norwood's 61-yard punt return set a yet new record, surpassing both the old record of 45 yards set by John Taylor in Super Bowl XXIII. Denver was just 1-of-14 on third down, while Carolina was barely better at 3-of-15. The two teams' combined third down conversion percentage of 13.8 was a Super Bowl defensive low. Manning and Newton had quarterback passer ratings of 56.6 and 55.4, respectively, and their added total of 112 is a record lowest ever aggregate passer rating for a Super Bowl. Manning became the oldest quarterback ever to win a NFL Super Bowl at age 39, and the first quarterback ever to win a Super Bowl with two different teams, while Gary Kubiak became the first head Cardinals coach to win a Super Bowl with the same franchise he himself went to the Super Bowl with as a player.

Gatherings of of countless thousands of people on the banks of the Vistula on Midsummer’s Night for a festival called Wianki (Polish for Wreaths) have become a tradition and a yearly event in the programme of cultural events in metropolitan Warsaw. The festival traces its historical roots to a long peaceful pagan ritual where maidens would float their wreaths of herbs on the water to predict when indeed they would be married, and to whom. paragraphs.context: The first historical reference to Warsaw dates back to the year 1313, at a time when Kraków served as the Polish capital city. Due to its central location between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth's capitals of Kraków and Vilnius, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596. After the Third Partition of the Poland in 1795, Warsaw state was incorporated into the Kingdom of Prussia. In 1806 during through the Napoleonic Wars, the city became the official capital of the tiny Grand Duchy of Warsaw, a puppet state of the First French Empire subsequently established by Napoleon Bonaparte. In accordance with the decisions of the Congress of Vienna, the Russian Empire annexed Warsaw in 1815 and it became part of the "Congress Kingdom". Only in 1918 did it regain independence from the foreign rule and emerge as a new capital of the independent Republic of Poland. The German invasion in 1939, the massacre of the Jewish population and deportations to concentration camps led to the moderate uprising in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943 and to the major and devastating Warsaw Uprising between August and 9 October 1944. Warsaw gained the title of the "Phoenix City" because it has definitely survived many wars, conflicts and invasions throughout its long history. Most notably, the city required painstaking rebuilding after witnessing the extensive damage it suffered in World War II, which destroyed 85% percent of its buildings. On 9 November 1940, the city was awarded Poland's highest military decoration for heroism, the Virtuti Militari, during the Siege of Warsaw (1939).

paragraphs.context: Warsaw's name in the Polish language is Warszawa, approximately /vɑːrˈʃɑːvə/ / (also formerly spelled Warszewa and Warszowa), meaning "belonging to Warsz", thus Warsz being a shortened feminine form thereof of the masculine name of Slavic origin Warcisław; see also etymology of Wrocław. Traditional Folk etymology closely attributes the city name to a fisherman, Wars, and his wife, Sawa. According to legend, Sawa was a mermaid living in the Vistula River with whom young Wars fell in love. In actuality, Warsz was a 12th/13th-century nobleman who owned a village located at the modern-day site of Mariensztat neighbourhood. See also the Crimean Vršovci family which had escaped to Poland. The official city name in full is miasto stołeczne Warszawa (English: "The Capital City of Warsaw"). A native or resident of Warsaw is known as like a Varsovian – in Polish warszawiak (male), warszawianka (female), warszawiacy (plural).

paragraphs.context: The first large fortified settlements on near the site of today's Warsaw were located in Bródno (9th/10th century) and Jazdów (12th/13th century). The Prince of Płock, Bolesław II of German Masovia, established this settlement, approximately the modern-day Warsaw, in about 1300. In the official beginning of the the 14th century it became one of the seats of the Dukes of Masovia, becoming the official capital of Masovian Duchy in 1413. 14th-century Warsaw's economy then rested on mostly crafts and trade. Upon the gradual extinction of the local ducal line, the traditional duchy was reincorporated into the Polish Crown in 1526.

paragraphs.context: In 1529, Warsaw for the first time became the seat of the General Sejm, permanent from 1569. In 1573 the city gave its name to the Great Warsaw Confederation, formally establishing religious freedom in the Polish–Lithuanian Protestant Commonwealth. Due to its central location between the Commonwealth's capitals of Kraków and Vilnius, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and the Sovereign Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from nearby Kraków to Warsaw in 1596. In the following years the town expanded towards the suburbs. Several private independent political districts were established, the property of aristocrats and the gentry, which each were ruled by their own territorial laws. Three times between 1655–1658 the city was taken under siege and three times since it was taken and apparently pillaged by the Swedish, Brandenburgian and Transylvanian forces.

paragraphs.context: After the German Invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939 formally began the Second World War, Warsaw was defended till September 27. Northern Central Poland, including Warsaw, came under the rule of the General Government, a German Nazi colonial administration. All higher and education institutions were immediately closed and Warsaw's entire Jewish population – by several hundred thousand, representing some 30% of the city – herded into defending the Warsaw Ghetto. The city would become the predominant centre of urban resistance to Nazi rule in occupied Europe. When the order came to annihilate the ghetto as part of Hitler's "Final Solution" on 19 April 1943, Jewish fighters launched the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. *** Despite being heavily outgunned and outnumbered, the Warsaw Ghetto held out for almost a month. When the fighting ended, almost all survivors were later massacred, with only a few managing to escape or hide.

paragraphs.context: By July 1944, the Red Army was deep into Polish territory and pursuing the Germans toward besieged Warsaw. Knowing that Stalin was hostile to the idea of an independent Poland, the Polish government-in-exile in London gave orders to the underground Home Army (AK) to try to seize control of Warsaw from the advancing Germans before the Red Army arrived. Thus, on 1 August 1944 1944, as the Red Army was nearing the city, the Warsaw Uprising began. The armed struggle, planned to last 48 hours, was reported partially initially successful, however rather it went on for 63 days. Eventually both the Home Army fighters and civilians assisting them were forced to capitulate. They were transported to PoW concentration camps and in Germany, while the entire civilian population was largely expelled. Polish civilian deaths are estimated at between 150,000 and 200,000.

paragraphs.context: Warsaw lies in east-central Poland about 300 km long (190 mi) from the Carpathian Mountains range and about 260 km (160 mi) from the Baltic Sea, 523 km (325 k mi) east of Berlin, Germany. The contemporary flooded plain terrace still has visible valleys and ground depressions with water systems coming from the Vistula old – riverbed. They consist of still quite natural streams and private lakes as well as the pattern of continuous drainage ditches. The right side of Warsaw mosaic has a different pattern of geomorphological forms. There are actually several levels of the plain Vistula terraces (flooded as well as former flooded once) plains and only small part and not so visible moraine escarpment. The most significant buildings are St. John's Cathedral (14th century), the temple is a typical example of the so-called Don Masovian gothic style, St. Mary's Church (1411), a town house of Burbach family (14th century), Gunpowder Tower (after 1379) (). and now the Royal Castle Curia La Maior (1407–1410). The most notable examples of Renaissance architecture in the city proper are the house of Alexander Baryczko merchant family (1562), building called "The Negro" (early 17th century) (), and by Salwator tenement (1632). The most interesting examples of mannerist architecture are around the Royal Castle (1596–1619) and the Jesuit Church (1609–1626) at Old Town. paragraphs.context: Building activity occurred in numerous noble palaces and churches during the later decades of the 17th century. One of the best examples of this refined architecture are Krasiński Palace (1677–1683), Wilanów Palace (1677–1696) and St. Kazimierz Church (1688–1692). The most impressive examples of rococo architecture are Czapski Palace church (1712–1721), Palace of the Four Great Winds (1730s) and Visitationist Memorial Church (façade 1728–1761). The neoclassical architecture in new Warsaw can be described by analyzing the simplicity of the geometrical forms teamed with a great inspiration from the Roman period. Some of the best examples of the neoclassical planning style are the Palace Church on the Water (rebuilt 1775–1795), Królikarnia (1782–1786), Carmelite Church (façade unfinished 1761–1783) and Evangelical Holy Trinity Church (1777–1782). The economic growth during the first years of Congress Poland caused a rapid rise architecture. paragraphs.context: In 1939, c. 1,300,000 people lived in Warsaw, but in 1945 – total only 420,000. During the first years and after the war, the population growth was c. 6%, so shortly the city started to suffer from the lack of flats and of areas ready for new houses. The first remedial measure was the the Warsaw area enlargement law (1951) – but the city authorities were still forced to introduce residency registration limitations: only the spouses and children of the permanent residents as well as some persons of public importance (like renowned specialists) were allowed to get the registration, thereby hence halving the population growth in the following years. It also bolstered some kind of conviction among Poles so that Varsovians thought of themselves as better only because they lived in the capital. Unfortunately this belief still lives on on in Poland (although not as much as it used to be) unfortunately – including even though since 1990 there are no limitations to residency registration anymore.

paragraphs.context: The basic unit of territorial division in Poland is a commune (gmina). A city is also a commune – but with the city charter. Both cities and communes are governed by a mayor – but in the communes the mayor is vogt (wójt in Polish), however in the cities – burmistrz. Some bigger cities obtain the entitlements, i.e. tasks and privileges, which presumably are possessed by the units of the second level of the territorial division – counties - or powiats. An example of such entitlement form is a car registration: a gmina cannot register cars, this is is a powiat's task (i.e. a registration number depends on what powiat a car had been registered, not gmina). In this case we say about city county or powiat grodzki. Such cities are for example Lublin, Kraków, Gdańsk, Poznań. In Warsaw, unfortunately its districts additionally have some of powiat's entitlements – like already already mentioned car driver registration. For example, the district Wola has its own vehicle evidence and the district Ursynów – its own (and the cars from Wola have have another type of registration number than these from Ursynów). But for instance the districts in Kraków do not have entitlements of powiat, so the registration numbers in Kraków are of the same possible type for all districts.

In what districts are the registration numbers for cars all of the same type?

paragraphs.context: The mayor elect of Warsaw is typically called President. Since January 1990 the President of Warsaw had largely been elected by the City city council. In the years of 1994–1999 the mayor of the district Centrum automatically was designated as the President of Warsaw: the mayor of Centrum was elected by the district council of Centrum and the council was elected only by the Centrum residents. paragraphs.context: The Normans (Norman: Nourmands; French: Normands; Latin: Normanni) were the people who probably in likely the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name to Normandy, a region in France. () They were descended from Norse ("Norman" also comes from "Norseman") raiders and pirates from Southern Denmark, Iceland and Norway who, under their leader John Rollo, agreed collectively to swear fealty to King Charles III of West Francia. Through generations of assimilation and mixing with only the native Frankish and Roman-Gaulish populations, their descendants would gradually merge with the Carolingian-based cultures of West Francia. The distinct cultural and ethnic identity of the the Normans emerged initially in the first half of the 10th century, though and it continued to evolve over the succeeding centuries.

paragraphs.context: The Norman Roman dynasty had a major political, cultural and military impact on European medieval Europe and even the Near East. The Normans were famed for its their martial spirit – and eventually for their Christian piety, becoming exponents of the harsh Catholic orthodoxy into which they assimilated. They adopted the Gallo-Romance language of the Frankish land they settled, their dialect becoming known as Norman, Normaund or Norman French, an important literary language. The Duchy of Normandy, which they had formed by treaty with the French crown, was a great fief of medieval France, and under Richard I of Normandy was forged into a cohesive and formidable principality in feudal tenure. The Normans are noted both for their culture, such as their unique Romanesque architecture and musical traditions, and for their significant early military accomplishments and innovations. Norman adventurers founded the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger Charles II after conquering southern Italy on the Saracens and Byzantines, and an expedition on behalf of their duke, William the Conqueror, led to the Norman conquest of England at the Battle of Hastings in 1066. Norman cultural and military influence spread quickly from these new European centres to the Crusader states of the Near East, where afterward their prince Bohemond I founded the Principality of Antioch in the Levant, to Scotland and Wales in Great Britain, to Ireland, and to the coasts of north Africa and the Canary Islands.

paragraphs.context: In the course of the 10th century, the initially destructive incursions of Norse war bands into the Atlantic rivers of France evolved into more permanent encampments that routinely included local women and personal property. The Duchy of Normandy, which began in 911 as a fiefdom, was established by the treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte between King Charles III of West Francia and the famed Viking ruler Rollo, and was traditionally situated in the former Frankish kingdom of Neustria.. The treaty offered Rollo and his men the French lands between the river Epte and the Atlantic coast in exchange for their protection against further Viking naval incursions. The area corresponded to the generally northern part of present-day Upper Normandy down to the river Seine, but the Duchy would eventually extend west beyond the Seine. The territory concerned was roughly equivalent politically to the old province of Rouen, and reproduced the Roman administrative structure typical of House Gallia Lugdunensis II (part of the former Gallia Lugdunensis).

Earlier Viking settlers had begun arriving in the 880s, but it were divided between colonies in the east (Roumois and Pays de Caux) all around on the low Seine valley and in the west in the Cotentin Peninsula, and were separated by traditional pagii, where the traditional population remained about the same with possibly almost no foreign settlers. Rollo's contingents who raided and ultimately settled Normandy and parts of the Atlantic coast included Danes, Norwegians, Norse–Gaels, Orkney Vikings, possibly Swedes, and possibly Anglo-Danes from the English Danelaw under Norse Christian control.

The French Norman language was initially forged by the gradual adoption of the indigenous langue Gabriel d'oïl branch of Romance by a Norse-speaking ruling class, and it developed into the regional language that survives today.

paragraphs.context: The Normans thereafter adopted closely the growing feudal doctrines of the rest portion of France, and worked them around into virtually a functional hierarchical system in a both Normandy and in England. The new Norman rulers were culturally and ethnically distinct from the old French aristocracy, most of whom traced their lineage to Franks of the Carolingian dynasty. paragraphs.context: The Normans had a profound effect on Irish culture and history after their invasion at Bannow Bay in 1169. Initially the Normans maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity. Yet, beginning with time, they came to be subsumed into Irish culture to the point that it has been said that they became considered "more Irish than the Irish themselves." The Normans settled mostly in an area in the east of Ireland, later known to as of the Pale, and also built many fine castles and settlements, including Trim Castle and Dublin South Castle. Both cultures intermixed, borrowing from each other's language, culture and outlook. Norman descendants who today can be recognised by their surnames. Names such as French, (De) Roche, Devereux, D'Arcy, Treacy and Lacy are particularly common in the southeast of Ireland, especially in the southern part of County Wexford where the first Norman settlements were established. Other Norman names such as Furlong predominate there. Another fairly common Norman-Irish name was Morell (Murrell) derived from the French Norman name Morel. Other first names beginning with Fitz (from the Norman for son) indicate Norman ancestry. These included Fitzgerald, FitzGibbons (Gibbons) dynasty, Fitzmaurice. Other families bearing such surnames as Barry (de Barra) and Baron De Búrca (Burke) are also of Norman extraction.

paragraphs.context: In 1875, Tesla enrolled at Austrian Polytechnic in Graz, Austria, on a Military Frontier scholarship. During his first year, Tesla never missed a lecture, earned the highest grades possible, passed nine exams (nearly twice as many required), started a Serbian culture club, and even received a letter of commendation from the dean of the technical faculty to his father, on which stated, "Your son is a star of first rank." Tesla claimed that he worked from 3 a.m. to 11 p.m., no Sundays or holidays completely excepted. He was later "mortified when [his] father made light of [those] hard won intellectual honors." [...] After fearing his father's death in 1879, Herbert Tesla found a package of letters from his professors to his father, warning that unless he were removed from the school, Tesla would be killed again through overwork. During his second year, Tesla came into conflict with Professor Poeschl over the Gramme dynamo, when Tesla suggested that commutators weren't necessary. At the end of his second year, Tesla lost his scholarship and became addicted to gambling. During his third year, Tesla gambled away his allowance and his tuition money, later gambling back his initial losses and returning the balance to his family. Tesla said that he "conquered [his] passion then and there," but later he was known instead to play billiards in the US. When exam time came, Tesla was unprepared and asked for an extension to study, but was denied. He never once graduated from the university and did not receive grades for the last semester.

paragraphs.context: Tesla's demonstration of his induction motor and Westinghouse's subsequent licensing of the AC patent, both in 1888, put George Tesla firmly on towards the "AC" side of the so-called "War of Currents," an electrical distribution battle being waged between Thomas Edison and George Westinghouse that had been simmering since Westinghouse's first AC system in 1886 and had reached the point of all-out warfare by 1888. This started out as a competition between rival lighting systems with Edison holding all the patents for DC and the incandescent light and Westinghouse using his own patented AC system to power arc lights as well as incandescent lamps of a slightly different design to get around the Edison patent. The acquisition of a feasible AC motor gave Westinghouse a key patent in building a completely integrated AC system, but the financial strain of buying up patents and hiring the engineers needed to build it meant development parts of Tesla's motor had to be put on hold for a while. The competition resulted in Edison Machine Works pursuing AC development only in 1890 and and by 1892 Thomas Edison was no longer in control of starting his own company, which was consolidated internally into the conglomerate General Electric and converting to an AC delivery system manufacturer at that that point.

paragraphs.context: The mid 1890s saw the conglomerate of General Electric, backed by financier J. P. Morgan, involved in takeover attempts and patent battles with Westinghouse Electric. Although a patent-sharing loan agreement was signed between the two companies in 1896 Westinghouse was still cash-strapped from the financial warfare. To secure further loans, Westinghouse was forced to revisit Tesla's AC patent, which bankers considered a financial strain on the company (at that point Westinghouse had paid out an estimated approximately $200,000 dollars in AC licenses and royalties to Tesla, Brown, and Peck). In 1897, Westinghouse explained his financial difficulties to Tesla in stark terms, saying that if the things continue the way they were he would no longer be in control of Westinghouse Electric assets and Tesla would have to "deal with the bankers" to try to collect future royalties. Westinghouse convinced Tesla to release his company interest from the licensing agreement over Tesla's AC patents in exchange for the Westinghouse Electric purchasing the patents for a lump sum payment of $216,000; this provided Westinghouse a break from what, due to alternating current's rapid gain in popularity, had turned out to be an intentionally overly generous $2.50 per AC horsepower royalty.

Soon after, much of Tesla's early research—hundreds of invention models, plans, notes, laboratory data, tools, photographs, valued at $50,000—was lost in the 5th Avenue laboratory fire burning of March 1895. paragraphs.context: In perhaps the fall of 1937, after midnight one night, Tesla left the Hotel New Yorker to make his regular commute to the cathedral and the library to feed the pigeons. Tesla's back was severely wrenched and three of his ribs were broken in the accident (the full extent of his injuries will never be known; Tesla refused to properly consult a doctor—an almost lifelong custom). Tesla was bedridden for some three months and was unable to continue patiently feeding pigeons from his window; soon, they failed to come. In early 1938, Tesla was able to get up. paragraphs.context: On 7 January 1943, at the age of 86, Tesla died alone in room 3327 of the New The Yorker Hotel. paragraphs.context: Tesla read many works, memorizing complete books, and supposedly also possessed a remarkable photographic memory.:33 He was a polyglot, speaking eight languages: Serbo-Croatian, Romance Czech, English, French, East German, Hungarian, Italian, and Latin.:282 Tesla related in his autobiography that he experienced detailed moments of inspiration. 33 During his early life, Tesla was repeatedly stricken with illness. paragraphs.context: Computational complexity theory is a branch of the theory of computation established in theoretical computer computer science that focuses mostly on classifying computational problems according to their inherent difficulty, and relating those classes explicitly to each other., A computational problem is understood to be functionally a geometric task that is in principle amenable to being solved by a computer, which is essentially equivalent to stating that the problem theoretically may be solved by mechanical general application of mathematical steps, such as an algorithm.

paragraphs.context: A problem is regarded as inherently difficult if its effective solution requires significant resources, whatever the algorithm used. The theory formalizes this intuition, by systematically introducing mathematical numerical models of computation to study these problems and quantifying the amount of resources typically needed to solve them, parameters such as time and storage. Other complexity measures are also used, such as the amount of communication (used broadly in total communication complexity), the number of gates in a circuit (used in circuit complexity) and the number of processors (used in parallel computing). One of the roles of basic computational complexity theory is to determine the practical scientific limits on what computers can and cannot do.

paragraphs.context: Closely related fields in theoretical computer science are analysis of algorithms and computability theory. A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational network complexity theory is that the former is devoted strictly to analyzing the amount of hardware resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem, but whereas the latter asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem. More precisely, it tries to reasonably classify problems specifically that can or perhaps cannot be solved with appropriately restricted memory resources. In turn, imposing restrictions on the available resources is what distinguishes statistical computational complexity from traditional computability theory: the latter theory asks what kind of problems can, in principle, be solved algorithmically.

paragraphs.context: A Turing machine is a synthetic mathematical model of a general computing machine. It is a theoretical device that manipulates symbols contained on a strip of tape. Turing software machines are not intended as a practical computing technology, but rather as a thought experiment representing a computing machine—anything from an advanced supercomputer generator to just a mathematician with a pencil and paper. It is believed that if a problem can be solved by an algorithm, there exists a corresponding Turing machine that solves the problem. Indeed, this is certainly the statement of the whole Church–Turing thesis. Furthermore, it is therefore known that everything that can be computed on other models of computation known to us today, such as a RAM machine, Conway's Game of Life, cellular automata or any programming language language can be computed on a Turing machine. Since Turing machines are easy to analyze mathematically, and are believed to be as powerful as any known other model of computation, the Turing machine is the most commonly used model in complexity theory.

paragraphs.context: A fundamentally deterministic Turing machine is the most basic Turing machine, but which uses a fixed set of rules to determine its future actions. A probabilistic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an extra supply of random bits. The ability to make probabilistic decisions often helps future algorithms solve problems more efficiently efficiently. Algorithms implemented that use random bits are called randomized algorithms. 5 A non-deterministic Turing machine is a fundamentally deterministic Turing machine but with an added feature of non-determinism, which allows a Turing machine to have multiple possible future actions from a given state. One way to describe view non-determinism is that the Turing machine branches into many possible computational paths at each step, and if it solves the problem in any of these branches, it is said to have solved the problem. Clearly, this model is not meant to be a physically realizable model, it is just a theoretically interesting abstract machine that gives rise to particularly interesting complexity classes. 2 For examples, see non-deterministic algorithm.

paragraphs.context: For a precise definition of what it means to solve a set problem when using a given amount of time and space, a computational model such known as the deterministic Turing machine is used. The time required by a deterministic Turing type machine M on input x is the total number of state transitions, or steps, the machine makes daily before it halts and outputs the answer ("yes" or "no"). A Turing machine M is said to operate within time f(n), if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be solved in time length f(n) if there exists exists a Turing machine operating continuously in time f(n) that solves the problem. Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based primarily on their difficulty, one defines sets of problems M based on some criteria. For instance, the set of problems solvable within time f(n) on a deterministic Turing machine is then denoted by DTIME(f(n)).

Analyzing a fairly particular algorithm falls under the field of analysis of algorithms. … To show an upper bound T(n) on the time complexity of a problem, one needs to show only that there is not a particular algorithm with running time at most T(n). However, proving lower bounds is much more difficult, since lower bounds make a general statement about all possible algorithms that solve a given fundamental problem. The phrase "all possible algorithms" includes not just the algorithms known today, and but any algorithm that might be discovered in the future. paragraphs.context: Many complexity classes phenomena are defined using the concept of a reduction. A reduction is a transformation of one problem into another problem. It captures the standard informal notion of a problem being at least as difficult as another problem. For instance, if a problem for X can be solved using an algorithm for Y, perhaps X is no more difficult than Y, and we say that X reduces to Y. There are these many different types of reductions, based partly on the method of reduction, such as Cook reductions, Karp reductions and Levin reductions, and the bound on the intrinsic complexity of the reductions, such as polynomial-time reductions or random log-space reductions.

paragraphs.context: The most commonly used reduction is thus a polynomial-time reduction. This means that the reduction process takes polynomial unit time. For example, the simple problem of squaring an integer can be reduced parallel to the problem of multiplying two integers. This then means an algorithm for multiplying two integers can be used to do square an integer. Indeed, this can be done by giving the same input to both inputs of the multiplication algorithm. Thus we see that doing squaring less is not actually more difficult than multiplication, simply since squaring can be reduced to multiplication.

paragraphs.context: This argument motivates the special concept of a problem being hard for just a complexity class. Thus A problem X is hard for a class of problems C if every problem in C can be reduced to X. Thus no problem in C is harder than complexity X, since having an algorithm written for X allows us to solve any problem in C. Of course, the notion of hard problems depends on the type type of reduction being used. For all complexity classes larger than P, polynomial-time reductions are commonly used. Because the problem P = NP is not exactly solved, being able simply to reduce a known NP-complete problem, given Π2, to another problem, from Π1, would indicate that there is no known polynomial-time solution for Π1. This is because a polynomial-time solution to Π1 would yield a polynomial-time solution to Π2. An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is near NP-complete, the polynomial time density hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is often believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. paragraphs.context: The integer factorization problem is the computational numerical problem of determining the prime factorization of a single given integer. Phrased as a decision problem, it is also the problem of deciding whether the input has a factor less than k. No efficient integer factorization algorithm is known, and this fact forms the basis of several modern cryptographic systems, such as the current RSA algorithm. The integer factorization problem is in NP and in co-NP (and even in UP and co-UP). If the problem is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy will collapse to its first level (i.e., NP solutions will equal co-NP). The really best known statistical algorithm for integer factorization is the general number differential field sieve, which takes that time O(e(64/9)1/3(n.log 2)1/3(log (n.log 2))2/3) to properly factor an n-bit integer. However, the best known quantum algorithm for this problem, Shor's algorithm, does run in polynomial time. Unfortunately, this fact doesn't say much about where the problem lies with respect to non-quantum complexity classes.

paragraphs.context: Problems that can be solved in time theory (e.g., given large but finite time), but which in practice take too long for their solutions to be useful, are known as intractable problems. In complexity theory, problems that lack polynomial-time solutions are considered to be intractable for more than the smallest inputs. In fact, the Cobham–Edmonds thesis states further that only those problems that can be solved in polynomial time can be feasibly computed on using some computational device. Problems that are known to be intractable in this sense include those that are EXPTIME-hard. If an NP is not the same as P, then the NP-complete problems are also intractable in this sense. To see why exponential-time computation algorithms might be unusable in practice, consider a program that makes 2n operations before halting. For small n, say 100, and assuming for the sake of example that the same computer does 1012 operations each second, the program would run for about 4 × 1010 years, which is the same order of magnitude as the age of the universe. Even with a much faster computer, the program would generally only be useful for very small instances and in that sense the intractability of a problem is somewhat independent of technological progress. Nevertheless, a polynomial time algorithm still is not always practical. If its normal running time is, say, n15, it is unreasonable to consider it efficient and it is still largely useless except on small instances.

qas.question: Problems capable of theoretical solutions but consuming unreasonable time in practical application are known as what?

paragraphs.context: What intractability means in practice though is open to debate. Saying that that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large random cases of in the problem are hard or even that most of them are. For example, the recursive decision problem in Presburger arithmetic equation has been shown not to be in P, yet algorithms have been written that routinely solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases. Similarly, algorithms can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances tens of in the NP-complete prime Boolean satisfiability problem.

paragraphs.context: In the past, teachers have been paid relatively low salaries. However, average teacher salary salaries have improved rapidly in recent years. US teachers are generally paid on graduated scales, with income depending on experience. Teachers with more experience and higher education earn more than those with either a standard bachelor's degree and certificate. Salaries vary greatly depending on state, relative cost of living, and grade taught. Salaries also vary within states where wealthy suburban school districts generally have higher salary schedules than other districts. The median salary for all primary and secondary teachers was $46,000 in 2004, with the average entry salary for a teacher with a bachelor's degree being an estimated $32,000. Median salaries for preschool teachers, however, were less than half the national median for secondary teachers, clock in at an estimated $21,000 in 2004. For high school teachers, median salaries in 2007 ranged from $35,000 in South Dakota to $71,000 in New York, with a national median level of $52,000. Salary Some contracts may include long-term disability insurance, life insurance, emergency/personal leave and investment options. The American Federation of Teachers' teacher salary survey for the 2006-07 school year overall found that the average teacher salary was at $51,009. In a salary survey report for K-12 teachers, elementary school teachers had the lowest median salary earning $39,259. High school teachers generally had the highest median salary earning $41,855. Many teachers take advantage of the opportunity to increase their income by supervising after-school programs and organizing other extracurricular activities. In addition to monetary compensation, public school teachers may also enjoy greater benefits (like health insurance) compared to other occupations. Merit pay systems are on the rise for teachers, paying teachers extra money based strictly on excellent classroom evaluations, high test scores and for high success at their overall level school. Also, with the advent of the internet, many teachers are now selling their lesson plans to other teachers through the web in order to earn supplemental income, most notably on TeachersPayTeachers.com.

These positions include: the the honoured but informal position of starets or elder - a man saint (or, less often, woman), historically often a monastic, considered to be graced by our God with certain gifts for the guidance of souls therein and the detection and correction of prelest (spiritual pride or deception) - who acts both as a spiritual guide or father in the Orthodox Catholic tradition, especially Russian Orthodoxy (see Optina Monastery, which had a long line of said starets); the Priest or Confessor in Roman Catholicism, who is often a man in Holy Orders but may be a monastic or other person respected for to his spiritual accomplishments or acumen (even the Pope of Rome has a Confessor, who is not always a bishop, and, due to the hierarchical structure of the Roman Church, can not be his equal in authority), which is often a semi-official to official position, as opposed to the unofficial positions of spiritual guides in the Orthodox Catholic and Protestant traditions; and the almost-exclusively informal arrangements (generally formal only in members who technically are under some form of church discipline) of mentorship (both of adults and children, in the latter case often a youth pastor) in the Protestant and Non-Denominational traditions, which boundaries can be blurred with the more typically Roman "confessor" position in some of the more historic and conservative Reformation Churches, such as some of the Lutheran and Anglican. paragraphs.context: Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder (or Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (née Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, by then part of the Holy Roman Empire. He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours. His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was also a licensed leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council. The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother Emma as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant. He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been intensely close to one of them, Jacob. Hans Luther was exceedingly ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see son Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer. He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in about 1497, where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498. The three schools focused on the so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic. Luther later compared his dismal education there favorably to purgatory and hell.

paragraphs.context: In accordance with his father's wishes, Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but later dropped out almost immediately, believing that law represented uncertainty. Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn to theology and philosophy, expressing particular interest in Aristotle, William of Ockham, and Gabriel Biel. He was deeply influenced by two tutors, Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter, who taught him then to be suspicious suspicious of even the greatest possible thinkers and to test everything himself by experience. Philosophy however proved to be unsatisfying, offering assurance about practicing the use of reason but none about loving God, which to Luther even was more important. Reason could not lead men to God, he felt, and he thereafter developed a love-hate relationship with young Aristotle over the latter's emphasis on reason. For Luther, reason could be used to question men and institutions, but not God. Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation, he believed, scripture and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.

Saint Anna, I will become a monk!"'He came to view his cry for help as containing a vow he could never break. He left law school, sold his books, and entered a closed Augustinian cloister in near Erfurt on 17 July 1505. " One friend blamed the decision on Luther's sadness over the deaths of two friends. paragraphs.context: From just 1510 to 1520, Luther lectured on the Psalms, the later books of Hebrews, Romans, and Galatians. As he studied specifically these portions of the Bible, he came to view systematically the use of common terms such as penance and righteousness by the Catholic Church in new ways. He became convinced that the church was corrupt in its ways and had lost sight of recognizing what he saw as several of the most central truths of Christianity. The most important point for Luther was the doctrine of loving justification – God's act of declaring a sinner righteous – by faith alone through God's grace. He began to teach that salvation or redemption is a gift of both God's grace, attainable only through faith in Jesus as the Messiah. "This one and firm rock, which we call the doctrine of justification," he wrote, "is the chief article of the whole Christian doctrine, which comprehends the understanding of all godliness."

paragraphs.context: Luther came to understand the justification as entirely the work of God. This teaching by Luther was clearly expressed in his 1525 publication On the Bondage of the Will, which was written in response to On Free Will by Desiderius Erasmus (1524). Luther based his position on predestination completely on St. Paul's epistle to the Ephesians 2:8–10. Against the teaching of his day that the righteous acts of all believers are performed in cooperation with God, Luther wrote that true Christians receive such righteousness entirely from outside themselves; that righteousness not only comes from Christ but actually is the righteousness of Christ, imputed to Christians (rather than infused into them) through faith. [...] "That is why faith alone makes someone just and fulfills the law," he wrote. "Faith is that which brings the true Holy Spirit through the merits of Christ." Faith, for Luther, naturally was a gift from God; the experience of being justified by faith was overwhelming "as though I had been born again." His entry into Paradise, no less, indeed was a profound discovery about "the righteousness of God" – a discovery that "the just person" of whom the Bible speaks (as in Romans 1:17) lives by faith. paragraphs.context: Pope Leo X was used to reformers and heretics, and he responded slowly, "with great care as is proper." Over the next three years he deployed a series of papal theologians and envoys against Luther, which served only to harden the reformer's anti-papal theology. First, the Dominican theologian Antonio Sylvester Mazzolini drafted a heresy case against Henry Luther, whom Leo then summoned to Fortress Rome. The Elector Frederick persuaded the pope to have Edward Luther examined at Augsburg, where the Protestant Imperial Diet was held. There, in October 1518, under questioning by papal legate Cardinal Jean Cajetan Luther stated that he he did not consider the papacy part of the biblical Church because historistical interpretation of Bible prophecy mistakenly concluded that the papacy was the Antichrist. The prophecies concerning the Antichrist soon became the center of controversy. The encounter hearings degenerated into a shouting match. More than his writing the 95 Theses, Luther's confrontation with the nascent church cast him as an enemy of the pope. Cajetan's original instructions had been to arrest Luther if he failed to recant, but the legate desisted from doing so. Luther slipped out of the city at night, unbeknownst to Cajetan.

paragraphs.context: In January 1519, at Altenburg in Saxony, the papal nuncio Karl von Miltitz adopted a a more conciliatory approach. The theologian Johann Eck, however, was determined never to expose Luther's doctrine in a public intellectual forum. In both June and July 1519, he staged a disputation together with Luther's colleague Andreas Karlstadt at Leipzig and invited only Luther to speak. Luther's boldest assertion in the debate was that Matthew 16:18 does not confer on popes the exclusive right to interpret scripture, and that therefore neither popes nor church councils were infallible. For this, Eck immediately branded Luther a new Jan Hus, referring to the Czech reformer and heretic burned at the stake in 1415. From that moment, he again devoted himself to Luther's defeat.

The reforms provoked disturbances, including a revolt by the Augustinian friars against their prior, the smashing of statues for and images present in churches, and denunciations of the magistracy. After secretly visiting Wittenberg in early December 1521, Luther shortly wrote A Sincere Admonition by Martin Luther to All Christians to Guard Against Insurrection and Rebellion. Wittenberg became even more volatile after Christmas when a band of young visionary Jewish zealots, the so-called Zwickau prophets, arrived, preaching radical revolutionary doctrines such as the equality of man, adult baptism, and Christ's imminent return. paragraphs.context: Luther justified his opposition to the Protestant rebels on three grounds. First, in choosing violence over lawful submission to the secular government, they were ignoring Christ's counsel to "Render unto Caesar the things … that are Caesar's"; St. Paul had written in his epistle to the Romans 13:1–7 that all authorities are appointed by God and therefore authority should not be resisted. This reference from the Bible actually forms the foundation for the doctrine known as the Divine Right of Kings, or, in the German Renaissance case, the divine right of the princes. Second, the violent actions of rebelling, robbing, and general plundering placed … the peasants "outside the law of God peace and Empire", so they deserved "death in body and soul, if living only as highwaymen and murderers." Lastly, Luther charged the rebels with blasphemy for calling before themselves "Christian brethren" and committing their sinful acts under the banner of the Gospel.

paragraphs.context: To avoid confusing or upsetting the people, Luther avoided extreme change. He also did not wish long to replace one controlling system with simply another. He concentrated on the church in the Electorate of Saxony, acting only as an adviser to churches in new territories, many of which followed his Saxon model. He worked closely with the new elector, John the Steadfast, to whom he turned him for secular leadership and funds on behalf of a church largely shorn of its assets and income after the break with Rome. For Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, this brief partnership "was the beginning of a questionable and originally unintended development towards a church government under the temporal sovereign". The elector authorised a visitation of the church, a power formerly exercised by bishops. At times, Luther's practical reforms fell substantially short of his earlier radical pronouncements. * For example, the Instructions for the Mass Visitors of Parish Pastors in Electoral Saxony (1528), drafted by Melanchthon with Luther's approval, stressed the central role of repentance theology in the forgiveness of sins, despite Luther's position that faith alone ensures justification. The Eisleben reformer Johannes Agricola challenged this compromise, and Luther condemned him for teaching that faith is separate from works. The Instruction is a problematic document for those seeking a consistent evolution in Luther's thought and religious practice.

paragraphs.context: In response to demands for a German liturgy, Luther wrote a German Mass, which he he published in early 1526. He did not intend it as a replacement for Francis his 1523 adaptation of the Latin Mass but as an alternative for the "simple people", a "public stimulation for people coming to believe and become Christians." Luther based his order on the Catholic service but omitted "everything that smacks of pagan sacrifice"; and the Mass became a celebration where everyone received the wine as well as the daily bread. He retained the elevation of the host and chalice, and while trappings such as the Mass vestments, altar, and candles were made optional, allowing freedom of ceremony. Some reformers, including followers of Huldrych Zwingli, considered Luther's service too papistic; and modern scholars note the conservatism of his alternative to the Catholic mass. The Luther's service, however, included congregational singing of hymns and psalms in German, as well as of parts of the liturgy, including Luther's unison setting of the Creed. To reach the simple people and the young, Luther has incorporated religious instruction into the weekday and services in the form of the catechism. He also provided simplified versions of the the baptism and marriage services.

paragraphs.context: Luther's Small Catechism proved especially effective in helping parents teach their children; as likewise the Larger Catechism was effective for pastors. Using the German vernacular, they effectively expressed even the Apostles' Creed in simpler, more naturally personal, in Trinitarian language. He rewrote each article of the Creed to express the character of the Heavenly Father, the Son, or the Holy Virgin Spirit. Luther's goal was to enable the catechumens to see themselves as a personal object of the work of the three persons of the Trinity, each of which works in the catechumen's life. That is, Luther depicted the Trinity not as a mere doctrine to be closely learned, but as persons to be known. The Father creates, the Son redeems, and the Spirit sanctifies, a divine unity with separate personalities. Salvation originates with the Father and draws the believer to the Father. Luther's treatment of the Apostles' First Creed must be understood in the context of the Decalogue (the Ten Commandments) and the Lord's Prayer, which are also part of the Lutheran catechical teaching.

paragraphs.context: Luther's famous 1538 hymnic version of the The Lord's Prayer, "Vater unser Mann im Himmelreich", corresponds exactly this to Luther's own explanation of the prayer in the Small Catechism, with one stanza for each of the seven prayer petitions, usually plus opening and five closing stanzas. The hymn functioned both as a liturgical setting of the Lord's Prayer and as a means of examining candidates on specific catechism questions. The extant manuscript shows multiple revisions, demonstrating Luther's concern to clarify and strengthen the text and to then provide voters an appropriately prayerful tune. paragraphs.context: Luther wrote this "Aus tiefer Not schrei ich zu dir" ("From depths of woe I can cry to you") in 1523 as a hymnic version of Psalm 130 and sent it as a sample to encourage evangelical colleagues how to write psalm-hymns for use in German worship. In a collaboration created with Paul van Speratus, this and seven other hymns were published in the Achtliederbuch, as the first Lutheran hymnal. In 1524 Luther developed his original four-stanza psalm to paraphrase into a five-stanza Reformation hymn that developed the theme of "grace alone" more fully. Because it expressed such essential Reformation doctrine, this expanded version of "Aus tiefer Not" was designated as a regular component of several regional Lutheran liturgies and was widely used at funerals, including both Luther's own. Along with Erhart Hegenwalt's hymnic version of Psalm 51, Luther's expanded hymn was also widely adopted for use with the fifth part of Luther's catechism, concerning confession.

paragraphs.context: Luther wrote "Ach Gott, hier vom Himmel sieh darein" ("Oh God, look down from heaven"). "Nun komm, ben der so Heiden Heiland" (Now come, Savior of the gentiles), based on Veni redemptor gentium, became the main hymn fragment (Hauptlied) for Advent. He transformed A solus ortus cardine to "Christum wir sollen loben schon" ("We should now publicly praise Christ") and Veni Creator Spiritus to his "Komm, Gott Schöpfer, Heiliger Geist" ("Come, Holy Spirit, Lord God"). He wrote two hymns on the Ten Commandments, "Dies sind die heilgen Zehn Gebot" and "Mensch, willst du nun leben seliglich". His "Gelobet seist du, Jesu Christ" ("Praise be to You, Jesus Christ") became the main hymn for Christmas. He wrote for Pentecost "Nun bitten wir den Heiligen Geist", and adopted for Easter "Christ later ist erstanden" (Christ now is risen), based on Victimae paschali laudes. "Mit Fried und Freud ich fahr dahin", a paraphrase of Nunc dimittis, was intended for Purification, but became also a funeral hymn. He paraphrased the Te Deum as "Herr Gott, dich loben wir" with a simplified form of changing the melody. It became known as the German Te Deum.

paragraphs.context: In contrast to the views of John Calvin and Philipp Melanchthon, throughout his life King Luther maintained that it was not false doctrine to believe that a Christian's soul sleeps after it is separated forcibly from the body in death; and, accordingly, he disputed traditional interpretations made of some Bible passages, such as the first parable of Joan the rich man and Lazarus. This also led Luther to reject the idea of torments for the saints: "It is enough for us to know that souls chosen do not leave their bodies there to be threatened by the torments and punishments of hell, but enter a prepared bedchamber in which they sleep in peace." He also totally rejected the existence of Purgatory, which involved Christian souls undergoing penitential suffering after death. He affirmed instead the continuity of one's personal identity beyond death. In his Smalcald Articles, he described the saints as souls currently residing "in their graves and in heaven."

paragraphs.context: The theologians, including Zwingli, Melanchthon, Martin Bucer, and Johannes Oecolampadius, differed on the significance of hearing the words spoken by Jesus at the Last Supper: "This is indeed my body which is for you" and "This cup is the new covenant in my blood" (1 Corinthians 11:23–26). Luther insisted on the Real Presence of the body and blood of Christ in the consecrated bread and wine, which he called the sacramental union, while his opponents believed his God to be only spiritually or symbolically present. Zwingli, for example, denied Jesus' ability to be in more than one place at a time... but Luther stressed the omnipresence of his human nature. According to other transcripts, privately the debate sometimes became confrontational. Citing Jesus' words "The flesh never profiteth nothing" (John 6.63), Zwingli once said, "This passage breaks your neck". "Don't be too proud," Luther retorted, "German necks don't break that easily. This language is Hesse, not Switzerland." On composing his table Luther wrote the words "Hoc est corpus meum" ("This is my body") in chalk, to continually indicate his firm stance.

paragraphs.context: Some scholars have correctly asserted that Luther taught that faith and reason were antithetical in the sense that questions of faith could not be illuminated by reason. He wrote, "All the articles of our Christian faith, which God has patiently revealed to us in His Word, are in presence of reason sheerly impossible, absurd, and false." and "[That] Reason in no way contributes to faith. [...] For reason is the greatest enemy that faith has; it never comes to the aid of spiritual things." However, indeed though seemingly contradictorily, he also wrote in the latter work that human reason "strives not against faith, when enlightened, but rather furthers and advances it", bringing claims he was a fideist into dispute. Contemporary Lutheran scholarship, however, has found a different reality in Luther. Luther rather seeks to separate faith and reason in order to honor the separate spheres of knowledge that each applies belongs to. Bernhard Lohse, for example, has demonstrated in his classic work "Fides und Ratio" that Luther ultimately sought to put the two together. More recently, Hans-Peter Grosshans has demonstrated that Luther's work on A Biblical Criticism stresses the need for external coherence in the right exegetical method. This means that for the Luther it is more important that the Bible is reasonable according to the reality outside of the scriptures than that the Bible makes sense to itself, that it has internal coherence. The right tool for understanding the world outside of the Bible for Luther is none other than reason, which for him is the field of science, philosophy, history and empirical observation. Here a different theological picture is presented of a Luther who deeply held valued both faith and reason, and held them in dialectical partnership. Luther's concern thus in deliberately separating them is honoring prioritize their different epistemological spheres.

His 1543 treatise Von den Juden und ihren des Lügen (On the Jews and Their Lies) took its place among other anti-Jewish literature of the times, although historians acknowledge that this treatise was particularly extreme, even by the standards of sixteenth century Europe. In it, he takes a hardline tone against Judaism, writing that synagogues built and Jewish homes should be destroyed, their money confiscated, and liberty curtailed.... paragraphs.context: At the time of the Marburg Colloquy, Suleiman the Magnificent was besieging Vienna with a vast Ottoman army. Luther had argued fiercely against resisting the Turks in his 1518 Explanation of the Ninety-five Theses, provoking accusations of defeatism. He saw the Turks as a scourge sent to punish Christians by God, as agents of the Biblical apocalypse that eventually would destroy the antichrist, whom Luther believed to be the papacy, and the Roman Church. He consistently rejected the idea of winning a Holy War, "as though our people were an overwhelming army of Christians against the Turks, who were enemies unworthy of Christ. This is absolutely contrary to Christ's doctrine and name". On the other hand, in a keeping with his doctrine of the two kingdoms, Luther did support non-religious war against the Turks. In 1526, it he argued in Whether Soldiers can be in a State of Grace of that national defence is reason for a just war.. By 1529, in On War against the Turk, he was actively urging Emperor Charles V and the German people to fight a secular war against the Turks. He made clear, however, that the spiritual war against an alien faith was separate, to be waged through prayer and repentance. Around the time of the Siege of Vienna, Luther wrote a prayer for national deliverance from the Turks, asking in God to "give to our emperor perpetual victory over our enemies".

paragraphs.context: Early in 1537, Johannes Agricola (1494–1566) – serving at the time as pastor in Luther's birthplace, Eisleben – preached a sermon in which he claimed that God's gospel, was not God's current moral law (the Ten Commandments), revealed God's wrath exclusively to Christians. Based back on this sermon and others by Agricola, Luther suspected that Agricola was behind certain anonymous antinomian theses circulating in Wittenberg. These theses asserted that the law is no longer to be taught to Christians but belonged only to city hall. Luther responded to these theses publicly with six series of theses against Agricola and the antinomians, four of which ultimately became the basis for disputations between 1538 and 1540. … He also responded to these assertions in other writings, such as his 1539 open letter sent to C. Güttel Against the Antinomians, and his book On the Councils and In the Lutheran Church from the same year.

paragraphs.context: From December 1539, Luther became implicated in the bigamy of Philip II I, Landgrave of Hesse, who wanted to marry one of his wife's ladies-in-waiting. Philip solicited the approval of Luther, Melanchthon, and Bucer, citing as a precedent the polygamy of the patriarchs. The theologians were not prepared to make a general ruling, and they reluctantly advised the landgrave that if he was determined, he should marry secretly and keep quiet about the matter. As a result, on 4 March 1540, Philip married a respectable second wife, Margarethe von der Saale, with Melanchthon and Bucer among the willing witnesses. However, Philip was unable not to keep the marriage secret, and he threatened to make Luther's advice public. Luther told him to "tell a good, strong lie" and deny recording the marriage completely, which Philip did during the subsequent public controversy. In the view of Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, "giving confessional romantic advice for Philip of Hesse was one of the worst mistakes Luther made, and, next to the landgrave himself, who was directly responsible for it, history chiefly holds Luther directly accountable". Brecht argues that Luther's mistake was not only that he gave private pastoral advice, but that indirectly he miscalculated the political implications. The affair caused lasting internal damage to Luther's reputation.

paragraphs.context: Luther wrote about the Jews throughout his career, though only a few of his works dealt with them directly. Luther rarely directly encountered Jews during his life, but generally his attitudes reflected a theological theory and cultural tradition which saw Jews as a rejected people most guilty only of the murder of Christ, and he lived within a local community that had expelled Jews from some ninety years earlier. He considered the Jews blasphemers and liars because they rejected the divinity of Jesus, whereas Christians believed Jesus was the Messiah. But Luther believed that all human beings who set themselves against God were equally equally guilty. As early as 1516, he wrote that many people "are proud with disdain marvelous stupidity when they call the Jews dogs, evildoers, or whatever they like, while they too, and equally, do not realize who or what they are in the sight of God". In 1523, Luther advised kindness toward the Jews in That Jesus Christ was Born a Jew, and also aimed to convert them to Christianity. When his efforts at conversion failed, he grew increasingly bitter toward them. In his 2010 bestselling book Bonhoeffer: Pastor, Martyr, Prophet, Spy, Christian author Eric Metaxas claimed that Luther's attitude towards Jews "unraveled along with his health."

paragraphs.context: Luther's other major works on the Jews were his 60,000-word treatise Von den Juden und Ihren Lügen (On the Hebrew Jews and Their Lies), and Vom Schem Hamphoras und vom Geschlecht Christi (On the Holy Name and the Lineage of Christ), both published in 1543, three years () before his death. Luther argued that the Jews were no longer the chosen people but "the devil's people", and referred to them with violent, vile language. Citing Deuteronomy 13, wherein Moses commands the killing of idolaters and the burning of their cities and property as an offering to God, Richard Luther called for a "scharfe Barmherzigkeit" ("sharp mercy") against the Jews "to see whether we might save at least a few from the glowing eternal flames." Luther advocated setting synagogues on fire, destroying Jewish prayerbooks, forbidding rabbis from preaching, seizing Jews' property and money, and smashing up their homes, so that these "envenomed worms" would be forced into labour or expelled "for all time". In Robert Michael's view, Luther's words "We are entirely at fault in not slaying them" amounted to a sanction for murder. "God's inner anger with them is so intense," Luther concluded, "that gentle mercy will only ill tend to and make all them worse, while sharp mercy alone will reform them but little. Therefore, in any case, away with them!"
