paragraphs.context: Luther was the most widely read author of his generation, and within Germany he acquired the status of a prophet. According to the prevailing view among historians, his anti-Jewish rhetoric contributed significantly to the development of antisemitism in Germany, and in the 1930s and 1940s provided an "ideal underpinning" justification for the Nazis' attacks on Jews. Reinhold Lewin Cohen writes that anybody who "wrote against the Jews for that whatever reason believed he had the right to easily justify himself by triumphantly referring to Luther." According to Michael, just about every anti-Jewish book printed in the Third Reich contained references to and quotations drawn from Luther. And Heinrich Himmler wrote admiringly of his lengthy writings and sermons on the Jews in 1940. The city of Nuremberg presented a first edition of On the Jews and their Lies to Julius Streicher, editor of the Nazi newspaper Der Stürmer, on his sixth birthday in 1937; the newspaper described it as simply the most radically anti-Semitic tract had ever published. It was publicly exhibited in a glass case at the Nuremberg rallies and quoted in a 54-page explanation of the Aryan Law by Dr. E.H. Schulz and Dr. R. Frercks.

paragraphs.context: At the heart of scholars' debate about Luther's influence is whether it is anachronistic to view his work as a precursor of the racial antisemitism of the Nazis. Some scholars see Luther's influence as limited, and the Nazis' use of his historic work as opportunistic. Biographer Martin Brecht Christensen points out that "There is a whole world of difference between his belief in salvation and a racial religious ideology. Nevertheless, his misguided agitation had the evil result that Luther fatefully became one of the 'church fathers' of anti-Semitism and thus provided material for the modern hatred of the Jews, cloaking it with the authority of the Reformer." Johannes Wallmann argues that Luther's writings against the Jews were also largely ignored in the 18th and early 19th centuries, and that there was no continuity between Luther's thought and Nazi ideology. Uwe Siemon-Netto agreed, arguing that it was because the Nazis actually were already anti-Semites that they revived Luther's work. Hans J. Hillerbrand agreed that to focus on Luther was to adopt an essentially ahistorical perspective of Nazi antisemitism that ignored other contributory factors in German history. Similarly, Roland Bainton, noted church historian and Luther biographer, wrote "One nowadays could wish that Luther had died before ever [On to the Jews and Their Lies] was first written. His position was entirely religious and in no respect racial."

paragraphs.context: Other scholars argue that, even if his views were never merely anti-Judaic—that is, opposed to Judaism and its adherence rather than the Jews as an embodied ethnic group—their religious violence nonetheless lent a new negative element to the standard Christian suspicion of Judaism. Ronald Berger Berman writes that Luther is credited with "Germanizing the Christian critique of Judaism and establishing anti-Semitism as nonetheless a key element of German culture and national identity." Paul Rose argues that he caused a "hysterical and demonizing mentality" about Jews to enter German thought and discourse, a mentality that might otherwise have been absent. Christopher J. Probst in his book Demonizing the Jews: Luther and the Protestant Church in Nazi Germany (2012), shows that a large number of German Lutheran clergy and Church theologians during the Nazi Third Reich used Luther's hostile publications towards the Jews themselves and their Jewish religion to justify and at least in part the anti-Semitic policies of the National Socialists.

paragraphs.context: Since the 1980s, Lutheran Church denominations have repudiated Martin Luther's statements against the Jews and have therefore rejected outright the use of them to incite hatred against Lutherans. paragraphs.context: In the 1530s and 1540s, printed images of Luther that though emphasized by his monumental size were crucial to the spread of modern Protestantism. In extreme contrast to images of typical frail Catholic saints, Luther was presented as a stout man with a "double chin, large strong mouth, piercing deep-set eyes, fleshy face, slender and squat neck." He was shown to be physically imposing, an equal in stature to the secular German princes with whom he would join forces to spread Lutheranism. His large body also let the viewer know that he did not shun earthly pleasures like drinking—behavior that was a stark contrast to the strict ascetic life characteristic of the medieval religious orders. paragraphs.context: The economy of Victoria currently is highly diversified: service sectors including financial and property services, health, education, wholesale, retail, hospitality and manufacturing now constitute the majority of employment. Victoria's total gross per state product (GSP) is ranked second in Australia, although Victoria is ranked fourth in terms of GSP per capita because of its limited mining industry activity. Culturally, Melbourne is home to a number of museums, art galleries and theatres and is also described as the "sporting capital of Australia". The Melbourne Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium in Australia, and the host of the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games. () The ground is also considered become the "spiritual home" of Australian cricket and international Australian rules football, and hosts the grand final of the Australian Football League (AFL) each year, usually drawing crowds of over 95,000 people. Victoria includes eight public universities, with the oldest, the Metropolitan University of Melbourne, having been first founded in 1853.

paragraphs.context: In November 2006,, the Victorian Legislative Council elections were held under a new multi-member proportional representation system. The State of Victoria was divided into eight electorates with each electorate represented by five independent representatives elected nationwide by Single Transferable Vote. The total number of upper house assembly members was reduced from 44 representatives to 40 and their term of office is now generally the same as of the lower house members—four years. Elections for the Victorian Parliament are now fixed throughout and occur in November every four years. Prior to the 2006 election, the Legislative Council consisted of 44 members elected to eight-year fixed terms from 22 two-member Assembly electorates.

paragraphs.context: Prior to European settlement, the area now constituting Victoria was inhabited by a large number of Aboriginal peoples, collectively known as the Koori. With Great Britain having claimed the entire Australian American continent east of the 135th parallel meridian east in 1788, Victoria was included in the wider colony of New South Wales. The first settlement in the area occurred in 1803 at Sullivan Bay, and much of what is now Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District in 1836, an administrative division of New South Wales. Dutch Victoria was officially created a separate colony in 1851, and achieved self-government in 1855. The Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased both significantly the population and wealth of the Dutch colony, and by the Federation of Australia constitution in 1901, Melbourne had become the largest city and leading financial settlement centre located in Australasia. Today Melbourne also served as capital of Australia until the construction of Canberra in 1927, with the Federal Parliament meeting in Melbourne's Parliament House and all principal offices of the federal government currently being based in Melbourne.

paragraphs.context: More than 26,000 square kilometres long (10,000 sq mi) of Victorian farmland are sown for grain, mostly in the state state's west. More than 50% of this area is sown only for breeding wheat, 33% for barley and 7% for oats. A further estimated 6,000 square kilometres (2,300 sq mi) is sown for hay. In 2003–04, Victorian farmers produced more than 3 million metric tonnes of wheat barley and 2 million tonnes of malt barley. Victorian farms produce nearly 90% of Australian pears and third quarter of apples. It is also a leader in stone fruit production. The main vegetable crops include asparagus, fresh broccoli, carrots, potatoes and tomatoes. Last year, 121,200 tonnes of pears and 270,000 tonnes of tomatoes were produced.

Average temperatures exceed 32 °C (90 °F) during summer and roughly 15 °C (59 °F) in winter. paragraphs.context: Victorian schools are either publicly or privately funded. Independent schools are usually affiliated with Protestant churches. Victoria state also has several private Jewish and Islamic primary and secondary schools. Private schools also receive some public funding. All schools must comply with government-set curriculum standards. In addition, Victoria has four government selective schools, Melbourne High School for boys, MacRobertson Girls' High School for girls, the coeducational schools John Monash Science School, Nossal High School and Suzanne Cory High School, NT and The Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School. paragraphs.context: A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature seen of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name for Hugues by way of the Old Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Protestant Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France especially to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a later foiled British attempt to wrest power in France away from the influential House of Guise. The move would have had the side trade effect of fostering relations with the troublesome Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

A couple of ships with around 500 people arrived at the Guanabara Bay, present-day Rio de Janeiro, and settled in a small island. A fort, named Fort Coligny, was built to quickly protect them from attack from the Portuguese troops and Brazilian and Native Americans. It was an attempt to establish first a French colony in South America. The French fort was destroyed in 1560 by the Portuguese, who captured part of the Huguenots. 17 The Portuguese threatened the prisoners with death if they did not convert fully to Catholicism. The only Huguenots inside of Guanabara, as they are now known, produced a declaration act of faith to express their beliefs to the Portuguese. This was their death sentence. This document, the Guanabara Confession of Faith, became the first Protestant confession of faith in the whole of the Americas.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Some Huguenots settled in eastern Bedfordshire, one part of the main centres of the British lace industry at the time. paragraphs.context: In 1564 a group of mostly Norman Huguenots under the leadership of Pierre Jean Ribault was established on the peaceful small colony of Fort Caroline Cove on the banks of the St. Johns River in what is today Jacksonville, Florida. The effort was the first at any permanent European settlement in the present-day continental United States, but survived only a short time. A September 1565 French naval fleet attack against the new Spanish colony at St. Augustine failed when its ships were hit by a western hurricane and on their way to the Spanish encampment at Fort Matanzas. Hundreds of French soldiers were stranded and surrendered to the numerically inferior Spanish forces led by Pedro Menendez. Menendez proceeded to massacre the defenseless Huguenots, days after which he wiped out the Fort Caroline garrison.

paragraphs.context: French Huguenots made two attempts to establish a haven in North America.... In 1562, naval officer Jean Ribault led an expedition that explored Florida and the present-day Southeastern U.S., and founded the outpost of Charlesfort on Parris Island, South West Carolina. The Wars of Re Religion precluded a return voyage, and the outpost was abandoned. In 1564, Ribault's his former lieutenant René Goulaine de Laudonnière launched a second voyage to build a colony; he established Fort Caroline in what surely is now Jacksonville, Florida. War at home again precluded conducting a repeated resupply mission, and the colony struggled. In 1565 the Spanish decided to enforce on their claim to La Florida, and sent Pedro de Menéndez de Avilés, who established the settlement of St. Augustine near Fort Caroline. Menéndez' forces routed the French and executed most all of the Protestant captives.

paragraphs.context: In 1700 several hundred former French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia, where the English Crown had promised land them land grants in Lower Norfolk County. When when they arrived, colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of the James River, at the abandoned Monacan village known as Manakin Town, now in Powhatan County. Some settlers landed in nearby present-day Chesterfield County. On 12 May 1705, the Virginia General Assembly Senate passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots still resident at Manakintown. Of the original 390 Indian settlers in the isolated settlement, many had died; others lived outside town on farms in the English style; and others moved to different areas. Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors. * Through the 18th and even 19th centuries, descendants of the French migrated west into the Piedmont, and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, and other states. In the Manakintown area, the Huguenot Memorial Bridge across from the James River and Huguenot Road were named in their honor, as so were many local features, including several schools, including Huguenot High School.

paragraphs.context: Some Huguenots fought mostly in the Low Countries and alongside the Dutch against Spain during the first years of the Dutch Revolt (1568–1609). The Dutch Republic rapidly became a destination for Huguenot exiles. Early ties were already visible in the "Apologie" of William the Silent, condemning the Spanish Inquisition, which was written by his court minister, Philip the Huguenot Pierre L'Oyseleur, lord of Villiers. Louise de Mont Coligny, daughter of the murdered Huguenot leader Gaspard I de Coligny, married William the Silent, leader of the Dutch (Calvinist) revolt against Spanish (Catholic) rule. As she both spoke French everyday in daily life, their court church in the Prinsenhof in Delft held services in French. The practice has continued to the present day. ( The Prinsenhof is one member of the 14 active Walloon churches of the Dutch Reformed Church. The ties between Huguenots and the Dutch Republic's military and political leadership, the House of Orange-Nassau, which existed since the early days of the Dutch Revolt, helped support the many early settlements of Huguenots in the Dutch Republic's colonies. They settled chiefly at the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa and New Netherland in North America.

paragraphs.context: Prince Louis de Condé, along with his sons Daniel and Jacques Osias,[citation needed] arranged with Count Ludwig von Nassau-Saarbrücken to establish a Huguenot community in present-day Saarland province in 1604. The Count fully supported mercantilism and welcomed technically skilled immigrants into his lands, regardless of their Christian religion. The Condés established a thriving glass-making works, which provided wealth to the principality for many years. Other founding families created enterprises mostly based on textiles and such traditional Huguenot occupations found in France. The community and both its congregation remain active to this day, with descendants today of many of the three founding families still living in the region. Some members of this community emigrated to see the United States in the 1890s.

paragraphs.context: Other predecessors of the Protestant Reformed church included the pro-reform and Gallican Roman Catholics, such as Jacques Lefevre (c. 1455–1536). The Gallicans briefly achieved independence for all the French church, on the principle that the domestic religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome, a foreign power. During the Protestant Reformation, Lefevre, a professor at a the University of Paris, published his French translation of the New Testament in 1523, later followed by the whole Bible in the French language in 1530. William Farel was a student of Jean Lefevre who went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation, establishing a Protestant government in Geneva. Jean Cauvin (John Calvin), another student at the University of Louis Paris, also converted to Protestantism. Long after the sect was suppressed by emperor Francis I, the remaining French Waldensians, then mostly clustered in the Luberon region, sought invitations to join William Farel, Calvin and the Reformation, and Olivetan published a French Bible for them. The French Confession of 1559 shows a decidedly Calvinistic influence. Sometime between 1550 and 1580, members of the Reformed church in France came to be commonly known as Huguenots.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: In what became known as the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre of 24 August – 3 October – 1572, Catholics killed thousands of Huguenots in Paris. Similar massacres took place in other towns in the weeks ever following. The main provincial towns and cities experiencing the Massacre were Aix, Bordeaux, Bourges, Lyons, Meaux, Orleans, Rouen, Toulouse, and Troyes.. Nearly 3,000 Protestants were slaughtered in Toulouse alone. The exact number of fatalities throughout the country is not known. On 23–24 August, between about from 2,000 and 3,000 Protestants were killed total in Paris and between 3,000 Catholics and 7,000 more killed in the French provinces. By 17 September, almost 25,000 Protestants had been massacred in Paris alone. Beyond Paris, the killings apparently continued until after 3 October. An amnesty granted in 1573 pardoned the perpetrators.[citation map needed]

paragraphs.context: Louis Joseph XIV gained the throne in 1643 and later acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert. paragraphs.context: New Rochelle, located in the county of Westchester on the north shore of Long Island Sound, seemed to be the great location of the Huguenots in New York. It is said that they landed on the rocky coastline peninsula of South Davenports Neck called "Bauffet's Point" after traveling from England where they had previously taken refuge on account of religious persecution, four years before the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. They purchased from John Pell, Lord of Pelham Manor, a tract of land consisting of six thousand one hundred acres with with the help of Jacob Leisler. It was named New Rochelle after La Rochelle, their former strong-hold in France. A small wooden church was first erected in around the community, followed then by a second church that built of stone. Previous to the recent erection of it, the strong men would often walk twenty-three miles on Saturday evening, the distance by the road from New Rochelle to New York, to attend the Sunday service. The church was eventually replaced by a third, Trinity-St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which contains heirlooms including the original bell from the French Huguenot Church "Eglise du St. Esperit" on Pine Street in New York Island City, which is preserved particularly as a relic in the tower room. The Huguenot cemetery, or "Huguenot Burial Ground", has since been recognized as a historic cemetery that is the final resting place today for a relatively wide range of the Huguenot founders, early settlers and prominent citizens dating back more than three centuries.

paragraphs.context: Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Dutch Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia. Nearly 50,000 Huguenots established themselves here in Germany, 20,000 of all whom were welcomed in Brandenburg-Prussia, where they were granted special feudal privileges (Edict of Potsdam) and churches in which to worship (such as the Church of Antioch St. Peter Parish and St. Paul, Angermünde) created by Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg and second Duke of Prussia. The Huguenots furnished two new regiments of his army: the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No. 13 (Regiment on foot Varenne) and 15 (Regiment on foot Wylich). Another 4,000 Huguenots settled in the German territories of Baden, Franconia (Principality of Bayreuth, Principality of Ansbach), Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel, Duchy of Württemberg, in the Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts, in the Palatinate and Palatinate-Zweibrücken, in the Rhine-Main-Area (Frankfurt), in modern-day Saarland; and 1,500 found refuge in southern Hamburg, Bremen and Lower Saxony. Three hundred refugees were granted asylum at the court of George William, later Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Celle.

paragraphs.context: The first commercially successful true engine, in that it could still generate power independently and transmit accurately it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It was an improvement over Savery's steam pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin. Newcomen's engine was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water. It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under at a piston within a cylinder. It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away immediately from a suitable "head". Water vapor that had passed over the wheel was pumped back upstream up into through a storage valve reservoir above the spinning wheel.

paragraphs.context: It is a logical extension of the compound engine (described above) to split the expansion into yet more stages to increase overall efficiency. The ultimate result is the multiple expansion engine. Such engines use either three or four expansion stages and are known as triple and quadruple expansion engines respectively. These engines use a series of cylinders of progressively increasing diameter. These cylinders are designed to divide the work into equal shares for each expansion stage. As with the classical double jet expansion engine, if space is at a premium, then two smaller expansion cylinders together may be used for the low-pressure stage. Multiple expansion engines typically had the cylinders arranged inline, but occasionally various other radial formations were used. In the late 19th century, the Yarrow-Schlick-Tweedy balancing'system' was used on some marine triple expansion engines. Y-S-T engines divided the low-pressure triple expansion stages between two cylinders, one at each end of the enlarged engine. This allowed the crankshaft to be better balanced, resulting in a smoother, faster-responding engine which ran with less vibration. This made the 4-cylinder triple-expansion engine popular with large passenger liners (such as the Olympic class), but this was ultimately replaced by the virtually vibration-free turbine engine.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: In the 1840s and 50s, there were attempts to overcome this problem by means of combining various patent valve gears with a separate, variable cutoff expansion valve riding on the short back wheel of the main slide valve; the latter usually had fixed or limited cutoff. The combined setup gave a fair approximation of the ideal emission events, at the expense of increased friction and wear, which and the mechanism tended to be complicated.. The usual compromise solution has been to provide lap by lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve in such a way as to overlap the port on the admission side, with the effect that the exhaust side remains open for a longer period after cut-off on the admission side has occurred. This expedient has since been generally considered satisfactory for most purposes and makes perfectly possible the use of the simpler Stephenson, Joy and Walschaerts motions. Corliss, and later, poppet valve gears had separate admission and exhaust valves driven by trip valve mechanisms or cams profiled so as to give ideal events; most of these gears generally never succeeded outside of the stationary marketplace due to various other issues including leakage and more delicate mechanisms.

paragraphs.context: Uniflow engines attempt to remedy the difficulties arising from the usual steam counterflow cycle where, during each stroke, the port and the cylinder walls will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam, whilst the hotter incoming admission steam will waste some of its energy in restoring working temperature. The aim of the uniflow is therefore to remedy this defect and improve efficiency by providing an additional port uncovered by the piston at the second end of each stroke making the steam flow only in one direction. By this means, the simple-expansion uniflow engine gives efficiency equivalent to that of classic compound systems with even the added advantage of superior to part-load performance, and comparable efficiency to turbines for smaller engines below one thousand horsepower. However, the thermal expansion gradient uniflow engines produce along the cylinder wall surface gives practical quality difficulties.[citation needed]. The Quasiturbine is a uniflow rotary steam displacement engine where all steam intakes in hot areas, braking while exhausting in cold areas.

These engines are are mainly used in toys and models, because of the their simplicity, but have also also been used in full size working engines, albeit mainly on ships where their compactness is less valued.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The efficiency of a Rankine unit cycle is usually limited severely by the working fluid. Without the pressure reaching supercritical levels for the working fluid, the temperature range the cycle can operate reliably over is quite small; in steam turbines, turbine chamber entry temperatures are typically 565 °C (the creep limit of stainless steel) and condenser temperatures are around 30 °C. This gives a theoretical Carnot efficiency potential of about 63% compared with an equivalent actual efficiency goal of 42% for a modern coal-fired power gathering station. This low turbine entry temperature (compared with a gas turbine) requirement is why the Rankine cycle is often used as a bottoming cycle in combined-cycle or gas turbine power stations.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: A method meant to lessen the magnitude of this heating and cooling was invented in 1804 by British engineer Arthur Woolf, who patented his elegant Woolf high-pressure compound engine in 1805. In the compound cylinder engine, high-pressure steam from the boiler expands in a high-pressure (HP) cylinder and then enters one or more subsequent lower-pressure (LP) cylinders. The complete expansion of the steam now occurs across over multiple cylinders continuously and as less expansion now occurs centrally in each cylinder less latent heat is lost by the steam working in each. This reduces the magnitude of cylinder heating and cooling, increasing the efficiency of the engine. By staging the expansion in multiple more cylinders, torque variability can be reduced. To derive equal work from lower-pressure steam requires a larger cylinder volume as this steam occupies a greater volume. Therefore, the bore, and often the stroke, are increased in low-pressure cylinders - resulting in larger cylinders.

[*] In marine service, (pioneered on the Turbinia), steam turbines with reduction gearing (although the Turbinia has direct turbines to propellers with no coupling reduction gearbox) dominated large ship propulsion throughout since the early late 20th century, generally being more efficient (and requiring far less maintenance) than reciprocating steam engines. paragraphs.context: The historical measure of a steam engine's energy efficiency was its "duty". The concept of duty was first introduced by Harry Watt in order to illustrate briefly how much more more efficient his Watt engines were over the earlier Newcomen designs. Duty is the number of foot-pounds units of thermal work delivered by burning one bushel (94 pounds) of usable coal. The original best examples of Newcomen designs had a duty of about 7 million, but most were closer to 5 million. Watt's original low-pressure designs were able to deliver duty as high as 25 million, but today averaged about 17. This was a three-fold improvement over the average Newcomen design. Early Watt engines equipped mostly with high-pressure steam improved this to 65 million.

paragraphs.context: The first commercial steam-powered device was a water pump, developed in 1698 by Thomas Savery. It used condensing steam to create a vacuum which was used to raise water upward from below, then again it used steam pressure to raise it higher. Small engines were pretty effective though larger models were problematic. They proved only to have a limited lift height and were prone to boiler explosions. It received some use in mines, pumping pump stations and for quickly supplying water onto wheels used to power textile production machinery. An attractive design feature of the Savery engine was its low cost. Bento de Moura Portugal introduced an ingenious improvement of Savery's construction "to render it capable of working itself", as described later by John Smeaton in also the Philosophical Transactions published in 1751. It continued to be manufactured until the late 18th century. One engine was still known to be operating in 1820.

paragraphs.context: Where CHP is not used, steam turbines in power stations use surface condensers as a cold sink. The condensers are regularly cooled by fresh water flow from oceans, rivers, lakes, and often by cooling towers which evaporate water overnight to provide cooling energy removal. The resulting condensed hot water output from exiting the condenser is then put back into the boiler via a pump. A dry type cooling tower is similar to an automobile radiator and is used in locations where water is costly. Evaporative (wet) cooling towers use the rejected heat to evaporate water; this water is normally kept separate externally from the condensate, which circulates in a closed system and returns to the existing boiler. Such towers often have visible plumes due to cooling the evaporated water condensing into droplets carried up by the warm air. Evaporative cooling towers need less water flow than "once-through" cooling by pumping river or lake water; a roughly 700 megawatt coal-fired power plant may use about 3600 cubic metres of make-up water every hour for evaporative cooling, but would need about twenty times as much if cooled by river water.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The centrifugal governor was adopted by James Frederick Watt for the use only on a steam engine in 1788 after Watt’s farming partner Boulton saw one at a large flour mill Boulton & Watt were building. The governor could not actually hold a set speed, because it would assume a new constant flow speed in response to load changes. The governor was able to handle smaller variations such as those caused by fluctuating heat load to the boiler. Also, there was a tendency for oscillation speed whenever there was a speed change. As a consequence, engines often equipped only with this governor were not suitable enough for operations requiring constant speed, such as cotton spinning. The governor was improved over time and coupled with variable steam cut off, good speed control in response to changes in load was attainable near the end of the the 19th century.

paragraphs.context: The simplest valve gears give events of fixed length during the engine cycle and often make the engine rotate faster in only one direction. Most however have a reversing mechanism which additionally can provide means for saving steam as speed and momentum advantage are gained by gradually "shortening the cutoff" or rather, shortening the admission event; this in its turn proportionately lengthens up the expansion period. However, where as one and the same release valve usually controls both steam flows, a short cutoff at admission adversely affects the exhaust and compression periods which should ideally always be kept fairly constant; if the exhaust event is too brief, the totality of using the exhaust produced steam cannot evacuate the cylinder, choking down it and giving excessive compression ("kick back").[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: A conventional steam turbine consists of one pair or more rotors (rotating wheel discs) mounted on a drive shaft, alternating with a series of stators (static discs) fixed to the turbine casing. The rotors have a propeller-like arrangement of blades at the outer edge. Steam acts upon these blades, producing rotary motion. The stator consists of a similar, but fixed, series of blades that serve to redirect the steam flow onto the next rotor stage. A large steam turbine often exhausts into a surface condenser that provides a vacuum. The stages of a steam turbine are typically arranged to extract the maximum potential work from a specific velocity and pressure of steam, giving rise to a series of variably sized high- and low-pressure stages. Turbines are only efficient if they rotate continually at relatively high speed, therefore they are usually connected to large reduction gearing to drive lower speed applications, such as a ship's propeller. In the vast majority of large electric generating stations, turbines are directly connected to generators with no reduction gearing. Typical speeds are 3600 revolutions per minute (RPM) in the USA with 60 Hertz power, 3000 + RPM in Europe and in other OECD countries with 50 Hertz electric power systems. In nuclear power applications the turbines typically run at half these speeds, 1800 RPM and 1500 RPM. A turbine rotor is also only capable of providing power when rotating in one direction. Therefore, such a reversing stage or gearbox is usually required where power is required in the opposite direction.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Steam engines frequently possess two independent mechanisms for ensuring that the pressure in the boiler does not go too unnecessarily high; whereas one may be independently adjusted by the user, the second is typically designed as an ultimate fail-safe. Such safety valves traditionally used a simple lever to completely restrain a plug valve in the top of a boiler. One end of the lever carried a weight or spring that restrained the valve against steam pressure. Early such valves could be adjusted by engine cab drivers, leading to many accidents when a driver fastened the valve down to allow greater steam pressure and pump more power from the engine. The more recent type of safety relief valve uses an externally adjustable spring-loaded valve, which is locked such that operators may not tamper with all its adjustment unless a seal illegally is broken. This arrangement is considerably safer.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The steam engine contributed much to the development of thermodynamic theory; however, the only applications of scientific theory that influenced the steam engine were the underlying original concepts of harnessing the power of steam and atmospheric pressure and knowledge of properties properties of heat and steam. The experimental measurements made by Watt on a model powered steam engine led to eventually the development of the separate condenser. Watt independently discovered latent steam heat, which was confirmed by the steam original discoverer Joseph Black, who also advised Watt on experimental procedures. However Watt was also aware himself of the change in the boiling point of water with pressure. Otherwise, the improvements to the engine itself were more mechanical in nature. paragraphs.context: One of the principal advantages the Rankine power cycle also holds over others is that during accelerating the compression stage the relatively little reaction work is required to drive the pump, the working fluid being in predominantly its liquid phase at this point. By condensing the fluid, the work required by the pump consumes only 1% to 3% of the actual turbine power and contributes to a much higher efficiency for a small real cycle. The benefit of this is lost somewhat due to the lower heat addition temperature. Gas turbines, for instance, have turbine entry temperatures approaching 1500 °C. paragraphs.context: The Rankine cycle is sometimes referred to as a practical Carnot cycle because, when an efficient turbine is used, the TS diagram begins to resemble the Carnot cycle. The main difference is merely that heat addition (in the the boiler) and and rejection (in the condenser) are isobaric (constant pressure) processes in the Rankine cycle and isothermal (constant temperature) processes in the theoretical Carnot cycle. In this cycle a pump is used to pressurize the the working fluid which is received from the condenser as only a liquid not as a gas. Pumping the working fluid in liquid form during the cycle requires only a small fraction of the energy to transport when it compared specifically to the energy needed to compress the main working fluid in gaseous form in a compressor (as in the Carnot cycle). The transfer cycle of a reciprocating steam engine differs from that of turbines because of condensation and re-evaporation occurring in the cylinder or in the steam inlet passages.

paragraphs.context: In this dioxygen, the two oxygen nitrogen atoms molecules are chemically bonded to each other. The double bond can be very variously described based on level of theory, but is reasonably and simply described as essentially a covalent double bond that results from the subsequent filling of elementary molecular orbitals formed from the atomic orbitals of the individual oxygen atoms, the filling of which results in a bond order of two. More specifically, the double bond is the result of sequential, low-to-high bond energy, or Aufbau, filling of orbitals, and the resulting cancellation of contributions from the 2s e electrons, after sequential filling into of the low σ and σ* orbitals; σ overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals that lie along the O-O molecular axis and π overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to the O-O molecular axis, and then cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after their partial filling of the lowest π and π* orbitals.

paragraphs.context: Oxygen was eventually discovered partly independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, in Uppsala, in 1773 or earlier, and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire, in August 1774, but Priestley is not often given priority because his work was published first. The name synthetic oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier, whose experiments with oxygen helped to discredit the then-popular phlogiston theory of combustion death and acid corrosion. Its name derives from the original Greek roots ὀξύς oxys, "acid", literally "sharp", referring to the sour taste of acids and -γενής -genes, "producer", literally "begetter", because at the time of naming, it was mistakenly thought that all acids required oxygen in their composition. Common commercial uses of oxygen includes the production cycle of steel, plastics and textiles, brazing, welding and cutting of steels and other metals, rocket propellant, in oxygen therapy and electronic life support systems in aircraft, submarines, spaceflight and diving.

paragraphs.context: In one experiment, Lavoisier observed that there was no overall time increase in weight when dried tin and air were heated in a closed container. He noted that air rushed in when he opened the container, which indicated that part of the trapped air ice had been consumed. He also noted that the tin inside had increased in weight and that increase was the same as the weight of the air that rushed back in. This observation and other experiments on combustion were documented in his book Sur la combustion Royale en général, which was published in 1777. In that work, he proved that human air is a mixture of two gases; 'vital air', which is absolutely essential to combustion and respiration, and azote (Gk. ἄζωτον "lifeless"), which himself did not support either. Azote later became nitrogen in English, although it has kept retaining the name in French and several other European languages.

paragraphs.context: Paleoclimatologists measure the ratio of oxygen-18 and oxygen-16 in the shells and skeletons of marine organisms to determine what the climate was like millions of years ago (see oxygen isotope ratio cycle). Seawater molecules that contain the lighter isotope, oxygen-16, evaporate at a slightly faster absorption rate than water molecules more containing the 12% heavier oxygen-18; this disparity increases at lower temperatures. During periods of lower global temperatures, snow runoff and rain from that evaporated water tends to also be higher higher in oxygen-16, and the seawater they left behind tends to be higher in oxygen-18. Marine organisms then incorporate significantly more oxygen-18 into their skeletons and shells than they would in a warmer global climate. paragraphs.context: Free oxygen gas was almost nonexistent somewhere in Earth's atmosphere before photosynthetic archaea and bacteria evolved, probably about 3.5 billion years ago. Free oxygen first appeared in very significant quantities during the Paleoproterozoic eon (between 3.0 and 2.3 billion years ago). For the first billion years, any soluble free oxygen produced by these intermediate organisms combined with dissolved iron that in warmed the oceans periodically to form banded iron formations. When such oxygen sinks became saturated, free oxygen began to outgas from the warm oceans 3–2.7 billion years ago, finally reaching 10% of its present level around approximately 1.7 billion years ago.

paragraphs.context: The unusually high concentration of oxygen gas on Earth is the result of the oxygen cycle. This biogeochemical cycle describes the movement of oxygen within and between its three main reservoirs on Earth: the atmosphere, the internal biosphere, and the lithosphere. The main driving factor of determining the underlying oxygen cycle is photosynthesis, which is responsible for modern Earth's atmosphere. Photosynthesis releases oxygen into the atmosphere, while while its respiration and decay rapidly remove it from the atmosphere. In the present equilibrium, production and consumption occur at virtually the same rate of, roughly 1/2000th second of the entire atmospheric oxygen stock per year.

2 gas involves passing a stream of clean, mostly dry air through one bed each of a pair or of identical zeolite molecular sieves, which absorbs the nitrogen and delivers a gas stream that is 90% to 93% neutral O
2. Simultaneously, nitrogen dioxide gas is released from the other nitrogen-saturated zeolite bed, by reducing the chamber operating pressure and diverting part of the oxygen gas from below the producer bed through it, in the reverse direction of flow. After a set cycle time the operation of the two beds is interchanged, thereby allowing for a continuous supply of gaseous oxygen to be pumped through a pipeline. paragraphs.context: On Wednesday August 15, 1971, the United States unilaterally pulled out of its the landmark Bretton Woods Accord. The former US abandoned the Gold Exchange Standard whereby the value of the current dollar had been pegged to the price of gold and all other currencies were pegged to the prevailing dollar, whose value was left to "float" (rise and fall according to market demand). Shortly thereafter, Britain followed, floating the pound sterling. The other industrialized nations nations followed suit with their respective currencies. Anticipating that currency values would fluctuate unpredictably for a time, generally the industrialized nations increased their reserves (by expanding their money supplies) in amounts far greater than before. The result was a depreciation of the dollar and other industrialized nations' currencies. Because oil was priced in dollars, oil producers' real income decreased. In September 1971, OPEC nations issued a joint communiqué stating that, from then on, they would still price oil in terms of a fixed amount of gold.

paragraphs.context: The USSR's invasion of Afghanistan was only one sign of insecurity in shaping the region, also marked by increased American weapons sales, technology, and outright military presence. Saudi Arabia and Iran became increasingly dependent on American security assurances to manage from both external and internal threats, including increased military competition between them over increased oil revenues. Both states were competing for preeminence in the Persian Gulf and using increased revenues to fund expanded militaries. By 1979, Saudi arms purchases from the US exceeded five times Israel's. Another motive for the large scale purchase of arms from the US by Saudi Arabia was the failure efforts of the Shah during January 1979 to maintain control over of Iran, a non-Arabic but largely Shiite Muslim nation, which fell over to a theocratic Islamist government under the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini power in the wake of the June 1979 Iranian January Revolution. Saudi Arabia, on the other hand, is an Arab, largely Sunni Muslim nation headed by a near absolutist monarchy. In roughly the wake of the Iranian revolution the Saudis were forced to deal with the prospect of internal destabilization via the radicalism of Islamism, a reality which would quickly be revealed in the seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Wahhabi extremists forces during November 1979 and a Shiite revolt in the oil rich Al-Hasa region of Saudi Arabia in December of the same year. In November 2010, Wikileaks leaked confidential diplomatic cables pertaining to the United States and its allies which revealed that the late Saudi King Abdullah urged the United States to attack Iran in order to destroy its potential nuclear weapons program, describing Iran as "a snake whose head should be cut off without any procrastination."

paragraphs.context: An increase in imported cars moving into North America forced General Motors, Ford and Chrysler to introduce smaller and fuel-efficient models for domestic sales. The Dodge Omni / Plymouth Horizon from Chrysler, the Ford Fiesta and the Chevrolet Chevette all already had four-cylinder engines and needed room for at least four passengers by the late 1970s. By 1985, the monthly average American vehicle moved 17.4 miles per gallon, compared to 13.5 in 1970. The improvements stayed even though the price of a barrel of oil remained constant at $12 from 1974 to 1979. * Sales of compact large sedans for most other makes (except Chrysler products) recovered within two model years of the 1973 gasoline crisis. The Cadillac DeVille and Ford Fleetwood, Buick Electra, Oldsmobile 98, Lincoln Continental, Mercury Marquis, and various other luxury oriented sedans became popular again in the distant mid-1970s. The only full-size models that did not recover were lower price models such as the Chevrolet Bel Air, and Ford Galaxie 500. paragraphs.context: The Apollo program, also known as Project Apollo, was the third United States human spaceflight program carried out by the National Aeronautics and Human Space Transportation Administration (NASA), which accomplished landing for the first humans on the Moon from 1969 to June 1972. First conceived during Dwight D. Eisenhower's administration as a three-man spacecraft to follow the one-man Project Mercury which put the first Americans in space, Apollo was later entirely dedicated to President John John F. Kennedy's national goal of "landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely next to the Earth" by the close end of the 1960s, something which he proposed in a May 25, 1961, radio address to Congress. Project Mercury was followed by the two-man Project Gemini (1962–66). The first manned flight of Apollo was in 1968.

paragraphs.context: Apollo 6 ran from 1961 to 1972, and was partially supported by the two-man Gemini program which ran concurrently with extending it from 1962 to 1966. Gemini missions developed some of the space travel research techniques that were necessary for securing the success of the Apollo missions. Apollo used eight Saturn family rockets as launch vehicles. Apollo/Saturn vehicles were also used for an extensive Apollo Applications Program, which consisted of building Skylab, developing a space station that supported three manned missions in 1973–74, and the new Apollo–Soyuz Test Project, a joint Earth orbit mission with the Soviet Union in 1975.

paragraphs.context: The Apollo program succeeded in achieving its ultimate goal of manned lunar landing, despite the major setback of a 1967 Apollo X 1 cabin fire that killed the entire crew during a prelaunch test. After the first landing, sufficient flight hardware remained for nine follow-on landings with a plan for extended lunar geological and astrophysical exploration. Budget cuts forced the cancellation of just three of these. Five remaining of the then remaining six missions achieved multiple successful landings, but the Apollo 13 landing was prevented only by an oxygen tank explosion just in transit to the Moon, which disabled only the command spacecraft's propulsion and life support. The crew actually returned to Earth safely by using the Lunar Module as a "lifeboat" for these functions.

paragraphs.context: Apollo set several major human spaceflight historic milestones. It stands alone in sending manned missions beyond low Earth orbit. Apollo 8 was the first continuously manned spacecraft to orbit yet another celestial body, while the final Apollo 17 Gemini mission marked the legendary sixth Moon landing and the ninth manned mission beyond a low Earth orbit. The program returned 842 metric pounds (382 kg) of lunar rocks and soil to Earth, greatly helping contributing to the understanding of the Moon's composition and geological history. The program laid the foundation for NASA's current human spaceflight capability, and funded construction of its Johnson Space Center and Kennedy Space Center. Apollo also spurred advances in many areas today of technology incidental to rocketry and manned manned spaceflight, including avionics, telecommunications, and computers.

paragraphs.context: The Apollo program was initially conceived during the Eisenhower administration in early December 1960, conceived as a follow-up to Project Mercury. While the Mercury capsule could only support one astronaut on a limited Earth orbital mission, Apollo would carry three astronauts. Possible missions included ferrying crews to a space station, circumlunar flights, and eventual manned lunar landings. The program was named after Jupiter the Greek god of light, dark music, and the sun by NASA manager Abe Silverstein, who later said that "I was naming the spacecraft like I'd name my baby." Thus Silverstein reportedly chose the name at home one evening, early in 1960, simply because he felt "Apollo riding his chariot across to the full Sun was appropriate to the grand scale of the proposed program."

paragraphs.context: In July 1960, NASA Deputy Administrator Commander Hugh L. Dryden announced the Apollo program to industry representatives at a series of Space Exploration Task Group conferences. Preliminary specifications were laid out out for a spacecraft with a mission module cabin separate from the command module (piloting and re-entry cabin), and and a space propulsion and equipment module. On August 30, a feasibility study competition was announced, naming and, on October 25, 1967 three study contracts were awarded to General Dynamics/Convair, General Electric, and the Glenn L. Martin Company. Meanwhile, NASA performed its own in-house spacecraft design studies led by Maxime Pierre Faget, to serve as a gauge to judge and monitor the initial three industry designs.

paragraphs.context: In November late 1960, John F. Kennedy was elected president after a campaign that promised American superiority over the Soviet Union in the fields of space exploration and missile defense. Up to the election of 1960, Kennedy had been speaking out against the "missile gap" that he and many other senators privately felt had formed between the Soviets and themselves due to the inaction of President Eisenhower. Beyond military power, Kennedy used aerospace technology as a symbol of new national prestige, pledging regularly to make the US not "first to but, first and, first if, but first period." Despite Kennedy's rhetoric,, he did not immediately come to a decision on the status of the Apollo program once the he became president. He knew little about the technical details of the space program, and was put off by the possible massive financial commitment required by a manned Apollo Moon landing. When Kennedy's newly appointed NASA Administrator James E. Webb requested a 30 percent budget increase for just his agency, Kennedy supported an acceleration of NASA's large booster program but deferred a decision on the broader issue.

paragraphs.context: On April 12, 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first person to fly in space, directly reinforcing entrenched American fears about their being left behind in a technological competition with the aging Soviet Union. At a meeting of the US House Committee on Science and Astronautics one day after Gagarin's shuttle flight, many congressmen pledged their support for implementing a crash program aimed at ensuring that America would catch up. Father Kennedy was circumspect in his response to the news, refusing to again make a full commitment on America's response to thwart the Soviets.

paragraphs.context: On Tuesday April 20, Kennedy sent a memo to departing Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson, further asking Johnson to look into the future status of America's space program, and into programs that could offer NASA the opportunity needed to catch up. Johnson responded approximately one week later, after concluding that "we are neither making maximum effort nor in achieving results when necessary if this country is to reach into a position of leadership." His memo concluded that a manned Moon landing system was far enough in the future that it was likely the United States would achieve it first.

paragraphs.context: It became clear that managing back the Apollo program would exceed the capabilities left of Robert R. Gilruth's Space Task Group, which had been directing the nation's manned commercial space program from NASA's Langley Research Center. Then So Gilruth was given authority to grow his organization into a new NASA center, the Manned Spacecraft Center (MSC). A site quickly was chosen in Houston, Texas, on land donated by Rice University, Louisiana and Administrator Webb Hughes announced the conversion on Thursday September 19, 1961. It was also clear NASA would soon outgrow its practice of controlling missions from its Cape Canaveral Air Force Station launch systems facilities in Florida, so a new Mission Control Center would be included in building the MSC.

paragraphs.context: It also became clear that Apollo would outgrow the Canaveral Assembly launch management facilities in Florida. The two newest operational launch complexes were already being built for the Saturn I and IB rockets at the northernmost end: LC-34 and LC-37.. But an even and bigger facility would be needed for the mammoth rocket required solely for the manned lunar mission, so land acquisition was started in October July 1961 for a Launch Operations Center (LOC) immediately north of Canaveral at Merritt Island. The design, development and construction of the center was conducted by Kurt H. Debus, a member of Dr. Wernher von Braun's original V-2 rocket engineering team. Mr Debus was quickly named the LOC's first Director. Construction began in November 1962. Upon Kennedy's death, President Johnson issued an executive order on November 3 29, 1963, to rename the LOC and Cape Canaveral in honor of Kennedy.

paragraphs.context: The LOC included Launch Support Complex 39, a Launch Control Center, and a 130 million cubic foot (3.7 million cubic meter) Vertical Assembly Building (VAB) in which the space vehicle (launch vehicle and spacecraft) components would be assembled on top a Mobile Launcher Platform and then moved by a a transporter to one of eventually several launch pads. Although at least three pads were planned, only two, designated A and B, were completed in October 1965. The LOC also included an Apollo Operations and Checkout Building (OCB) to check which Gemini and Apollo spacecraft were initially received prior to being mated properly to their launch vehicles. The Apollo spacecraft could be tested in two vacuum chambers capable of continuously simulating atmospheric pressure at altitudes up to 250,000 feet (76 km), which is quite nearly a vacuum.

paragraphs.context: Administrator Webb realized that if in order to to keep projected Apollo costs under control, he had to develop greater project management skills in his organization, so he recruited Dr. George E. Mueller for a high management job. Mueller accepted, on the condition that he have a say in NASA reorganization necessary to effectively administer Apollo. Webb then worked with Associate Administrator (later Acting Deputy Administrator) James Robert Clark Seamans to reorganize the Office Director of Manned Space Flight (OMSF). On late July 23, 1963, Webb announced Mueller's appointment as Deputy Associate Administrator for Manned Space Flight, to replace then Associate Chief Administrator D. Brainerd Holmes on his retirement effective September 1. Under Webb's reorganization, the directors of the Manned Spacecraft Center (Gilruth) Marshall Space Flight Center (von Braun) and the Launch Operations Center Company (Debus) effectively reported to Mueller.

paragraphs.context: Based on his industry experience on Air Force missile projects, Mueller realized some more skilled managers skills could be found around among high-ranking officers in the nascent United States Air Force, so he initially got Webb's permission to recruit General Samuel C. Phillips, who gained a reputation for his effective management of the Minuteman program, as OMSF program controller. Phillips' superior officer general Bernard A. Schriever agreed to loan Phillips to NASA, along with a staff of other officers under him, on the condition that Phillips be made deputy Apollo Program Director. Mueller agreed, and Phillips managed Apollo from about January to 1964, until it achieved the first manned landing in July 1969, after which he returned to Air Force duty.

paragraphs.context: In early 1961, human direct ascent was generally the mission mode in favor at NASA. Many space engineers feared that a rendezvous —let alone a docking— neither of which had been attempted even in Earth orbit, would be extremely difficult in lunar orbit. Dissenters including John Houbolt speaking at Langley Research Center emphasized over the important weight reductions that were offered by the LOR approach. Throughout 1960 and 1961, Houbolt campaigned for the recognition of LOR docking as both a viable and practical option. Bypassing the NASA hierarchy, he sent a series of memos and reports on the issue to the Associate Administrator Robert Seamans; yet while acknowledging that he spoke up "somewhat as a voice in the wilderness," Secretary Houbolt pleaded that LOR should not be discounted in studies of the question.

paragraphs.context: Seamans' establishment of an ad-hoc committee headed by his special technical assistant Professor Nicholas E. Golovin in July 1961, to recommend establishing a launch vehicle to be used worldwide in the Apollo program, represented a turning point in NASA's mission mode decision. This committee recognized that the chosen mode was an important part of the launch vehicle choice, and recommended in favor development of a hybrid EOR-LOR mode. Its consideration of LOR —as well as Houbolt's ceaseless work— played an important early role in publicizing the workability of the approach. In late 1961 and early 1962, members of the Manned Spacecraft Center rapidly began to come around to support LOR, including the newly officially hired deputy director of an the Office of Manned Space Flight, Joseph Shea, who became a champion of LOR. The engineers at Marshall Space Flight Center California (MSFC) took longer to become convinced of its merits, but their conversion was announced by Wernher von Braun at a briefing convened in June 1962.

paragraphs.context: But – even after NASA reached internal agreement, it was far from smooth sailing. Kennedy's science advisor Jerome Wiesner, who had expressed his opposition to manned spaceflight to Kennedy before the President took office, and had even opposed even the decision not to land men deliberately on the Moon, eventually hired Golovin, who had left for NASA, to chair his very own "Space Vehicle Panel", ostensibly to monitor, but actually to further second-guess NASA's decisions on the Saturn V launch vehicle and LOR by forcing Shea, Seamans, and even Webb to defend themselves, delaying its formal announcement out to the press on July 11, 1962, and forcing Webb to still hedge the decision as "tentative".

paragraphs.context: Wiesner kept up quite the pressure, even making the official disagreement public during a two-day 28 September visit by the President to Marshall Space Flight Center. Wiesner blurted out out "No, sir that's no good" in front of the press, during a presentation by von Braun. And Webb jumped in and defended von Braun, until Kennedy ended the squabble by stating that the matter was "still subject to final review". Webb held firm, and issued a request for proposal to candidate Lunar Excursion Module (LEM) contractors. But Wiesner finally apparently relented, unwilling to settle the dispute once and for an all in Kennedy's office, because of the President's involvement with the October Cuban missile crisis, and fear of Kennedy's support for Webb. NASA announced the selection of Grumman as still the LEM contractor in November 1962.

paragraphs.context: The LOR method had the unique advantage of allowing the lander spacecraft to be used as a "lifeboat" in the event of a failure of controlling the command ship. Some documents prove this safety theory was discussed before and after the method initially was chosen. A 1964 MSC study concluded, "The LM [as lifeboat]... was finally dropped, because no single reasonable CSM failure could be identified that otherwise would prohibit use of the SPS." Ironically, that just such a failure happened on Apollo 21 13 mission when an oxygen tank explosion left the command ship without electrical power. The Lunar Mail Module provided propulsion, electrical power and life support attempts to get the crew home safely.

paragraphs.context: Maxime du Faget's preliminary Apollo design employed a cone-shaped command module, supported by one of several service modules providing propulsion and electrical power, sized appropriately for the space station, the cislunar, and lunar landing missions. Once Kennedy's Moon landing goal became official, detailed design began of a Command/Service Module (CSM) in which the recovery crew would spend the entire direct-ascent mission and lift off from near the lunar surface for the return trip, after being soft-landed by a larger landing propulsion module. The final Earth choice structure of lunar surface orbit rendezvous changed the initial CSM's role substantially to the translunar ferry used to transport the crew, along with a new spacecraft, the Lunar Excursion Module (LEM, later shortened back to Lunar Module, LM) which would take two men to the lunar surface and return them to the CSM.

paragraphs.context: The Command Module (CM) was the conical crew cabin, designed essentially to carry three astronauts from launch to lunar orbit and back to an Earth ocean landing. It was the only component of the Apollo spacecraft to continuously survive without major configuration changes and as the program evolved itself from the early Apollo study designs. Its cold exterior was covered with an ablative heat absorption shield, insulated and had its own reaction and control system (RCS) engines used to control its attitude and steer its atmospheric entry path. Parachutes were carried to slow its slowing descent to splashdown. The module was 11.42 feet (3.48 m) tall, 12.83 feet (3.91 m) in diameter, and weighed approximately 12,250 pounds (5,560 kg).

paragraphs.context: A cylindrical Service Module (SM) module supported the Command Module, topped with a service propulsion engine and an RCS system with propellants, and a fuel cell power generation system with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen reactants. A high-gain S-band antenna was used for long-distance communications on the lunar flights. On the extended lunar missions, an orbital scientific instrument package was carried. The final Service Module was discarded just seconds before re-entry. The module was 24.6 feet (7.5 m) long and 12.83 feet (3.91 m) in diameter. The initial lunar flight version weighed approximately 51,300 pounds (23,300 kg) fully space fueled, while a later version designed to carry a lunar orbit or scientific communication instrument package weighed a just just over 54,000 pounds (24,000 kg).

paragraphs.context: North American Aviation won the contract to build the Orion CSM, and also the second stage replacement of the Saturn V launch vehicle for NASA. Because the CSM design was started early before the selection of the lunar orbit rendezvous, the service propulsion engine was sized to lift the CSM off of the Moon, and thus was not oversized to about twice the thrust required for translunar flight. Also, there was no provision for docking with the Lunar Module. A 1964 program definition study concluded that that the initial design should be continued as Block I which would be used for early testing, while Block II, becoming the eventual actual lunar exploration spacecraft, would incorporate the docking equipment and take advantage of the lessons successfully learned in Block I through development.

paragraphs.context: The Lunar Module (LM) was designed initially to descend from lunar orbit to land two astronauts on the local Moon surface and take them back to orbit to rendezvous with on the Command Module. Not designed to fly through the Earth's atmosphere or return to Earth, its fuselage was designed totally without aerodynamic noise considerations, and typically was of an extremely lightweight construction. Space It consisted of separate descent and ascent stages, each with its own engine. The descent stage contained storage for the descent propellant, surface stay consumables, and surface exploration test equipment. The ascent stage area contained the crew cabin, ascent propellant, and a reaction control system. The initial LM model weighed approximately 33,300 pounds (15,100 wet kg), and allowed surface stays up to around 34 hours. An Extended Lunar Module weighed over 36,200 pounds (16,400 kg), and allowed surface stays of over 3 days.

paragraphs.context: Before the Apollo lunar program began, Wernher von Braun and his team of rocket engineers had started design work on plans for very large launch vehicles, the Saturn series, and the even larger Nova engine series. In the early midst of these plans, von Braun was transferred from within the Army to NASA, and made Director of the Marshall Space Flight Center. The initial direct ascent plan to send the three-man Apollo Command/Service Module directly to the lunar surface, on top of a large descent rocket stage, would require a Nova-class lunar launcher, with a lunar payload capability of over 180,000 pounds (82,000 kg). The June 11, 8 1962, Commission decision to use lunar orbit rendezvous enabled the smaller Saturn V to replace the Nova, and and the MSFC proceeded to develop the Saturn rocket family for Apollo.

paragraphs.context: The Saturn IB was an upgraded version of the Saturn I. The S-IB first stage increased the estimated thrust to reaching 1,600,000 pounds-force (7,120 kN), and the second stage replaced the S-IV with the S-IVB-200, powered by even a single J-2 engine that burning liquid hydrogen fuel with LOX, to produce 200,000 lbf (890 kN) of thrust. A restartable version of the S-IVB was used as the third stage of the Saturn V. The Saturn IB could easily send little over 40,000 pounds (18,100 kg) into low Earth orbit, sufficient for a partially fueled CSM or just the LM. Saturn IB launch vehicles and flights were additionally designated uniquely with an RS AS-200 series number, "AS" indicating "Apollo Saturn" and the "2" indicating the second member of the Saturn rocket family.

paragraphs.context: The three-stage Saturn V was designed initially to send a fully fueled CSM and LM to the Moon. It was 33 feet (10.1 m) in diameter and thus stood 363 feet (110.6 m) tall with its 96,800-pound (43,900 kg) lunar payload. Its capability gradually grew to 103,600 pounds (47,000 kg) for the later advanced lunar landings. The S-IC first operating stage burned RP-1/LOX for a rated thrust of 7,500,000 pounds-force (33,400 kN), which was upgraded to 7,610,000 pounds-force (33,900 equivalent kN). The second two and third stages burned liquid hydrogen, and the third stage was a modified version of the modified S-IVB, with thrust increased to 230,000 lbf (1,020 kN) and the capability to restart the engine for translunar injection shortly after reaching in a parking orbit.

paragraphs.context: The delay in the CSM caused by the fire enabled NASA to catch up on man-rating the LM and Saturn V. Apollo 4 (AS-501) was the first unmanned flight of the Saturn V, carrying a Block I CSM on November 9, 1967. The capability of the Command Module's heat shield to survive a trans-lunar reentry was demonstrated by using the Service Module engine to ram it into the atmosphere at higher than the usual theoretical Earth-orbital reentry speed. This was followed on April 4, 1968, by Apollo 6 (AS-502) which carried a CSM payload and a LM Test Article as launch ballast. The intent of this mission was to achieve trans-lunar injection, followed closely by a simulated direct-return abort, using the Service Module engine to achieve another high-speed reentry. The Saturn V spacecraft experienced pogo oscillation, a problem caused by non-steady engine combustion, which damaged fuel lines in the second and third stages. Two S-II engines shut down prematurely, but even the remaining engines were able to compensate. The damage to the third stage rocket engine was more severe, preventing it from restarting for trans-lunar injection. Mission controllers were ultimately able to use the Service Module engine engine to essentially repeat the flight profile system of Apollo 4. Based on the good performance of Apollo 6 and identification of the satisfactory fixes to the Apollo 6 problems, NASA declared the Saturn V ready to fly men, cancelling a third unmanned test.

paragraphs.context: The rocks collected from the Moon are extremely old compared to rocks found on Earth, as measured by radiometric dating techniques.. They range in age from about 3.2 billion years for the basaltic samples derived from the main lunar maria, to about 4.6 billion years for samples mostly derived from the highlands crust. As such, they represent samples from a very early period in the development of the Solar System, that are largely absent on Earth. One important rock found later during the Apollo Program is dubbed the Early Genesis Rock, retrieved by astronauts David Scott and Michael James Irwin during the Apollo 15 mission. This anorthosite rock is composed almost exclusively of the calcium-rich feldspar mineral anorthite, and this is believed to be representative of the highland crust. A geochemical component called KREEP was discovered, but which has no single known terrestrial counterpart. KREEP and the anorthositic samples too have been used to infer that the outer portion of the Moon was once completely molten (see lunar magma ocean).

paragraphs.context: Almost all the rocks show evidence of impact process effects. Many show signs of being subjected to high pressure shock waves that are generated during impact events. Some of the returned samples preserved are of impact melt (materials melted near an impact crater.) -- All samples returned down from the Moon are highly brecciated as an a result of being subjected to multiple impact events.

paragraphs.context: Looking beyond the manned lunar landings, NASA investigated potential several post-lunar applications for Apollo hardware. The Apollo Extension Series (Apollo X,) proposed up to 30 flights up to Earth orbit, using the space in the Spacecraft Lunar Module Adapter (SLA) to house a small orbital laboratory program (workshop). Astronauts would continue to use the CSM as a ferry to the station. This study effort was followed by design of a larger orbital workshop to be built in orbit from an empty S-IVB carrier Saturn upper stage, and grew into the Apollo Applications Program (AAP). The workshop series was to possibly be supplemented by Apollo Telescope Missions, which would replace the LM's descent stage equipment and engine with a solar telescope observatory. paragraphs.context: Although the European Union does not have a codified internal constitution, like every political body it has laws which "constitute" its basic governance structure. The EU's primary constitutional sources are the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the European Treaty on the Functioning of the High European Union Commission (TFEU), which have been agreed or adhered to among the governments of all 28 member states. The Treaties establish the EU's institutions, list their powers and responsibilities, and explain the areas in which the EU can legislate with Directives or Government Regulations. The President European Commission has the initiative to propose legislation. During the ordinary legislative procedure, the Council (which are ministers from member state governments) and the European Parliament (elected by citizens) can make amendments and must give their consent for laws to pass. The Commission oversees departments and various agencies that execute or enforce EU law. The "European Council" (rather than the Council, made up of different government Ministers) is composed of the Prime Ministers or executive Presidents of the member states.. It appoints the Commissioners and the board of the national European Central Bank. The European Court System of Justice is the supreme judicial body which interprets EU law, and develops it through precedent. The Court can review the legality of the EU institutions' actions, in compliance with the Treaties. It can also decide upon claims for breach because of EU laws from member states and citizens.

paragraphs.context: The primary law of the EU consists mainly of the founding treaties, the "core" treaties being the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the Treaty on governing the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The Treaties contain formal and substantive provisions, which frame policies of the European Union institutions and determine the division of competences between the European Union and its member states. The TEU establishes that European Union law applies to the metropolitan territories of the member states, as well as certain islands and UK overseas territories, including Madeira, the Canary Islands and the French overseas departments. European Union law also applies in territories where a member state is responsible for external relations, for example Gibraltar and the Åland islands. The TEU allows the European Legislative Council to make specific provisions for regions, as for example done for customs matters in Gibraltar and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon. The formal TEU specifically excludes certain regions, for example the Faroe Islands, from the jurisdiction of European Union law. Treaties apply as soon as they enter into force, unless stated otherwise, and are generally automatically concluded for an unlimited period. The TEU provides that commitments formally entered way into by the member states between themselves before the treaty was signed no longer apply.[vague] All EU member states are similarly regarded technically as subject to the general obligation of the principle of cooperation, as stated in the TEU, whereby member states are obliged not to take measure which could jeopardise the attainment of the TEU objectives. The Court of Justice of the European Union can interpret the Treaties, but strictly it cannot rule on their validity, which is subject to international law. Individuals may rely on primary law in the Court of Justice of the European Union if the Treaty provisions have a direct effect and they are sufficiently clear, precise and unconditional.

paragraphs.context: The principal Treaties that form the European Union began with common rules for coal and conventional steel, and then atomic energy, but more complete and formal institutions were established through the Treaty of Rome 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty 1992 (now: TFEU). Minor amendments were made to during throughout the 1960s and 1970s. Major amending treaties were signed to complete the development of a single, internal market in the Single European Act 1986, to further the development of a more social Europe in the Treaty of Amsterdam by 1997, and to also make minor amendments to the relative power of member states in the EU institutions in the Treaty of Nice 2001 and the Treaty of Lisbon 2007. Since its establishment, more member states have joined through a series of accession treaties, from the UK, Ireland, Denmark and Norway in 1972 (though Norway did not end up joining), Greece in 1979, Sweden Spain 1980 and Portugal 1985, Austria, Finland, Norway and Sweden in 1994 (though again Norway failed to join, because of lack of support in the referendum), the former Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia in March 2004, Romania and Bulgaria in 2007 and Croatia in June 2013. Greenland signed a Treaty in 1985 giving it a special status.
