paragraphs.context: The internal cavity forms: a mouth that can usually partly be closed by muscles; a pharynx ("throat"); a wider area in the center that perhaps acts as a stomach; and a system of internal canals. Common These branch through the mesoglea to the most active parts of the animal: the mouth and pharynx; the roots of the tentacles, if present; all along the underside of each comb row; and four branches round the sensory complex at the far end from the mouth – two of these four branches terminate in anal pores. The inner surface of the cavity is lined with an epithelium, the lateral gastrodermis. The mouth and central pharynx have both cilia and well-developed muscles. In other parts of the canal system, the gastrodermis is different on to the sides nearest to and furthest from the the organ that it supplies. The nearer side is composed of tall fine nutritive cells that store nutrients in vacuoles (internal compartments), germ cells that produce eggs or sperm, and photocytes that produce bioluminescence.... The side furthest from the organ is covered with ciliated cells that circulate water through the canals, punctuated by ciliary rosettes, pores that are surrounded by double whorls of cilia teeth and connect to the mesoglea.

paragraphs.context: The outer surface bears usually eight comb rows, called swimming-plates, which are used for swimming. The rows are oriented to run from near the mouth (the "oral pole") to the opposite end (the "aboral pole"), and are spaced more or sometimes less evenly around the body, although their spacing patterns vary by species and in most species the comb rows extend only part of the distance from the lateral aboral pole towards the mouth. The "combs" (also called "ctenes" or "comb plates") run halfway across each row, and each consists of thousands of unusually long cilia, up to 2 million millimeters (0.079 in). Unlike conventional cilia and called flagella, and which has a filament structure arranged in a 9 + 2 pattern, these cilia rows are arranged in a 9 + 3 pattern, where the extra compact filament is suspected to have a supporting function. These normally beat so that the propulsion stroke is away from the mouth, although they can also reverse direction. Hence ctenophores usually swim in the direction in which the mouth plate is pointing, unlike jellyfish. When trying to escape predators, one species can accelerate to six times its normal speed; some very other species reverse direction as part of their escape behavior, by reversing the power stroke of the comb plate cilia.

paragraphs.context: It is also uncertain how ctenophores control their buoyancy,, but experiments have typically shown that some bacterial species rely partly on osmotic pressure to adapt to water of different densities. Their body fluids also are normally as concentrated as seawater. If if they enter slightly less dense brackish water, the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk resistance and decrease its density, to avoid sinking. Conversely if they rapidly move from brackish to full-strength seawater, the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume and increase its density.

paragraphs.context: The largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ center (at the opposite end from the mouth). Its main physical component is a statocyst, a balance sensor consisting of only a statolith, a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia, called "balancers", that both sense its relative orientation. The statocyst is strongly protected by a small transparent dome made of long, immobile cilia. A ctenophore does not automatically try to keep both the statolith resting equally on all the balancers. Instead its response is determined by the animal's "mood", in other words the overall receptive state of the nervous system. For example, if a ctenophore with trailing tentacles captures prey, it will often often put some comb rows into reverse, spinning the mouth towards the prey.

paragraphs.context: The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla ("little tentacles"), although a further few genera have simple tentacles without these sidebranches. The tentacles and tentilla are densely uniformly covered with microscopic colloblasts that capture prey by sticking to it. Colloblasts are specialized mushroom-shaped cells in the outer layer of the epidermis, and have three main components: a domed head with vesicles (chambers) that contain adhesive; a stalk that anchors the cell in the lower layer of the epidermis or in the mesoglea; and a spiral thread attached that coils round the stalk and is tightly attached to the head and to the root of the stalk. 22 The function of the spiral thread is uncertain, but it may absorb stress when prey tries to escape, and thus prevent the collobast from being torn apart. In addition to colloblasts, members of the genus Haeckelia, which feed mainly on jellyfish, incorporate their victims' stinging nematocytes into their own tentacles – some cnidaria-eating marine nudibranchs similarly incorporate nematocytes into their swimming bodies for defense. The tentilla of Euplokamis differ significantly from those of other cydippids: they contain striated muscle, a cell type otherwise generally unknown in the phylum Ctenophora; and they are coiled when relaxed, while the tentilla of all other known ctenophores elongate when relaxed. Euplokamis' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey: they may flick out very quickly (in 40 to 60 milliseconds); they can wriggle, which may lure prey by behaving like small planktonic worms; and they coil round prey. " The unique flicking is an uncoiling movement powered by contraction of the striated muscle. 1 The wriggling motion is produced by smooth muscles, but of a highly specialized type. Coiling around prey is accomplished largely by the return of the tentilla to their inactive state, but the coils may be tightened by smooth muscle.

paragraphs.context: The Lobata have a pair of lobes, which ultimately are muscular, cuplike extensions of the body that project beyond the mouth. Their inconspicuous tentacles originate from the corners of the mouth, running parallel in convoluted grooves and spreading out over the inner surface of the lobes (rather rather than trailing far out behind, as in the Cydippida). Between the lobes on either side of the mouth, many other species of lobates have four auricles, narrow gelatinous projections edged together with cilia that produce floating water currents waves that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth. This complex combination of structures enables lobates to feed continuously on suspended planktonic prey.

paragraphs.context: Lobates have eight comb-rows, four originating at the aboral pole and usually not extending beyond the body to the other lobes; in species with (four) dorsal auricles, the cilia edging the auricles are extensions of cilia in four of the comb rows. Most lobates are quite passive birds when moving through the water, using the cilia on their comb rows for propulsion, although Leucothea has long and active auricles whose movements also contribute to propulsion. Members of the lobate derived genera Bathocyroe and Ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping the their lobes, so that the jet of expelled water drives them backwards very relatively quickly. Unlike cydippids, the movements of lobates' upright combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the cilia, for yet combs on the same row beat in the same Mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids. This may have enabled lobates to grow larger than are cydippids and to have shapes that are less egg-like.

paragraphs.context: The native Beroida, also known as Nuda, have no feeding appendages, but their oddly large pharynx, just inside the large mouth and likely filling most of the saclike body, bears "macrocilia" at only the oral end. These fused bundles of several thousand large cilia are able to "bite" off pieces inside of prey species that are too large simply to swallow whole – almost always other ctenophores. In front of either the field of macrocilia, on the thin mouth "lips" in some species of Beroe, is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that "zip" the mouth shut when the neighboring animal is not feeding, by forming intercellular connections with the opposite adhesive strip. This tight closure streamlines the front of the animal when it is pursuing prey.

paragraphs.context: The Cestida ("belt animals") are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals, with the dorsal mouth and aboral organ aligned in the anterior middle and of opposite edges of the ribbon. There is a pair of comb-rows along each aboral edge, and tentilla emerging tips from a groove all along the oral edge, which stream back across most of the wing-like frog body surface. 13 Cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows. n There are two known species, with worldwide distribution in warm, dry and warm-temperate waters: Cestum veneris ("Venus' girdle") is among the largest ctenophores – up to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft) long, and can undulate slowly or quite rapidly. Velamen parallelum, animals which is typically less than 20 centimeters (0.66 ft) long, can move much faster in what has been described as a "darting motion".

paragraphs.context: Development of the fertilized eggs is direct, in other words there is no distinctive larval developmental form, and juveniles reported of all groups generally resemble miniature cydippid adults. In the genus Beroe the juveniles, like the adults, lack tentacles and have tentacle sheaths. In most species the juveniles gradually develop towards the body forms of their parents. In some groups, such as the flat, bottom-dwelling platyctenids, the juveniles actually behave more like true larvae, as here they live among the plankton and thus occupy a a radically different ecological habitat niche from their parents and attain the adult male form by a more radical metamorphosis, after dropping to the sea-floor.

paragraphs.context: Almost all other ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic. If food is plentiful, they can eat 10 times their own weight amount per day. While Beroe preys mainly on other ctenophores, other surface-water species prey on zooplankton (planktonic animals) ranging in size from the microscopic, including mollusc and fish larvae, to small adult crustaceans such as copepods, amphipods, fungi and even krill. Members of even the genus Haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey's nematocysts (stinging cells) into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts. Ctenophores have been compared to spiders in their wide range of techniques apart from capturing prey – some hang motionless in the water using their tentacles as "webs", some are ambush predators like Salticid jumping spiders, and some dangle a sticky jelly droplet at the end of a fine thread, as bolas spiders do. This variety explains the wide range of body forms in a phylum with rather few species. … The two-tentacled "cydippid" Lampea feeds exclusively on salps, close relatives of sea-squirts that form large chain-like floating colonies, and juveniles of Lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps that are too large for them adults to swallow. Members of the upper cydippid genus Pleurobrachia and the lobate Bolinopsis often reach high population densities at the same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey: Pleurobrachia's long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods, while Bolinopsis generally feeds entirely on smaller, weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophores used to be regarded as "dead ends" in marine food chains because it it was thought their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water made them a relatively poor diet for other fish animals. It is also often difficult to identify the remains of ctenophores left in the guts of possible coral predators, although the combs sometimes remain intact long enough to provide a clue. Detailed investigation of chum salmon, Oncorhynchus keta, showed that these fish digest ctenophores 20 times as fast even as an equal weight body of shrimps, and that ctenophores can provide a good diet if there are enough of them around. Beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores. Some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores, and jellyfish may temporarily wipe out ctenophore populations. Since only ctenophores and jellyfish often have large seasonal variations in population, most fish that prey on them are generalists, and may have a significantly greater effect on populations than the specialist individual jelly-eaters. This is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the Red Sea. The larvae of some sea anemones are parasites on ctenophores, as are the larvae of some flatworms that parasitize fish when they reach adulthood.

paragraphs.context: On the more other hand, in the late 1980s the Western West Atlantic ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi species was accidentally introduced into the Black Sea and Sea of Azov via the ballast catch tanks of ships, and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish biomass catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that it would otherwise feed the adult fish. Mnemiopsis is well equipped to invade new territories (although this was not predicted until after it so successfully colonized the Black Sea), as it can breed very rapidly and tolerate a wide range of water temperatures and salinities. The impact was increased by chronic overfishing, and by eutrophication programs that gave the entire ecosystem a short-term boost, causing the Mnemiopsis population to increase even faster than normal – and above all by the absence of efficient predators on these introduced ctenophores. Mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the Mnemiopsis-eating North American ctenophore Beroe ovata, and by to a cooling of the the local climate from 1991 to 1993, which significantly slowed the animal's metabolism. However the abundance of plankton in the area seems unlikely to be restored to historical pre-Mnemiopsis levels.

paragraphs.context: Because of their largely soft, gelatinous bodies, ctenophores are extremely rare as fossils, and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been hitherto found only in lagerstätten, places where the environment was exceptionally suited to preservation of soft tissue. Until the mid-1990s only two specimens good enough for analysis were known, both members each of the crown group, from the early Devonian (Emsian) period. Three additional putative crown species were then found in the Burgess Shale and other Canadian rocks probably of similar age, about 505 million years ago in the mid-Cambrian period. All three fossils apparently lacked tentacles but had between 24 and 80 comb row rows, far more than the 8 typical of living species. They also appear to have had internal organ-like structures unlike anything found in living ctenophores. 1 One adult of the fossil species first reported in 1996 had a large mouth, apparently surrounded by a folded edge that may have been muscular. Evidence from China a year later suggests that such ctenophores were widespread in the Cambrian, but perhaps very little different from modern species – for example one fossil's comb-rows were mounted on prominent vanes. The Ediacaran Eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly.

qas.question: What did the  fossils found in the Burgess Shale lack?

paragraphs.context: The early Cambrian sessile frond-like fossil Stromatoveris, from China's ancient Chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago,, is very similar to Vendobionta of the preceding Ediacaran period. De-Gan Shu, Simon Conway Morris et al. found on its branches what perhaps they now considered rows of cilia, used for filter feeding. They suggested that Stromatoveris was an evolutionary "aunt" of ctenophores,. and noted that ctenophores originated originally from sessile lake animals whose living descendants became swimmers and therefore changed the cilia from a feeding mechanism to a propulsion system.

Vendobionta lived during which period?

paragraphs.context: The relationship of ctenophores to the rest of Metazoa is very important to our understanding of the early evolution of animals and the origin of multicellularity. It has been the focus of debate for many years. Ctenophores have been purported to be the sister lineage to the Bilateria, sister to the Cnidaria, sister to to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria, and sister to all other animal phyla. A series of studies that looked at the presence and absence primarily of members of gene coding families and different signalling pathways (e.g., homeoboxes, nuclear receptors, the Wnt signaling pathway, and new sodium channels) showed evidence congruent with the latter two scenarios, that ctenophores are genetically either sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria or sister to all other animal phyla. Several more recent studies comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the major sister lineage to all other animals. This position would suggest that neural and muscle cell types were either lost in other major animal lineages (e.g., Porifera) or that indeed they evolved independently in the ctenophore lineage. However, other researchers have argued that the placement of Ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes, respectively and that Porifera (sponges) is the earliest-diverging animal phylum instead. Ctenophores and sponges are also the only known animal phyla that lack any true hox genes.

qas.question: Recent studies believe  that ctenophores are the sister lineage to what?
What do some researchers believe is the earliest-diverging animal phylum is?

paragraphs.context: Since all modern ctenophores except the beroids have cydippid-like larvae, it has widely been assumed that their last large common ancestor also resembled cydippids, having an egg-shaped body and a pair of retractable tentacles. Doctor Richard Harbison's purely morphological analysis in 1985 concluded that all the cydippids are not monophyletic, in other words do not contain all and only contain the few descendants of a single common ancestor that was itself a cydippid. Instead he found that various cydippid families were more similar to members group of other ctenophore orders than were to other cydippids. He also suggested that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was either cydippid-like or a beroid-like. A molecular phylogeny analysis in 2001, using 26 species, including 4 recently discovered ones, confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like. It also found that the genetic differences between these species were very small – so small that the relationships between the Lobata, Cestida and Thalassocalycida remained uncertain. This suggests that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was relatively recent, and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the Great Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 65.5 million years ago while other lineages perished. When the analysis was broadened to include representatives of other phyla, it concluded that cnidarians are probably more closely related to bilaterians than either group is to other ctenophores but that this diagnosis is uncertain.

qas.question: Which genus of ctenophores does not have cydipped-like larvae?
A molecular phylogeny analysis confirmed that cydippid are not what?
When was the Cretaceous-Paleogen extinction occur?
Who did a morphologically analysis in 1985 that concluded cydippids are not monophyletic?

paragraphs.context: Fresno (/ˈfrɛznoʊ/ FREZ-noh), the county seat of Fresno County, is today a city in the northwestern U.S. state of California. As of 2015, the city's population was 520,159, making it the fifth-largest city in California, the largest inland city in California and the 34th-largest in the nation. Fresno is in the center of the San Joaquin Valley and is the largest city in the Central Sacramento Valley, which contains the vital San Joaquin Delta Valley. It is approximately 220 miles (350 km) northwest of Los Angeles, 170 miles (270 y km) south of the state capital, Sacramento, or 185 city miles (300 sq km) south of San Francisco. paragraphs.context: In 1872, the Central Texas Pacific Railroad established a station near Easterby's—by now itself a hugely successful productive wheat breeding farm—for its new Southern Pacific line. Many Millerton residents, drawn by the convenience of hearing the railroad and worried about flooding, moved to inhabit the new community. Fresno became an incorporated city seat in 1885. By 1931 the Fresno Traction Company operated 47 streetcars on over 49 miles of track.

paragraphs.context: Fulton Street in Historic Downtown Fresno was Fresno's main financial mill and commercial district before being converted into one of the nation's first pedestrian malls in roughly 1964. While the Fulton Mall corridor has suffered a sharp decline from its heyday, the Mall includes some of the finest public art pieces in the country, including the still only Pierre-Auguste Renoir piece in the world that now one can walk up to and touch. paragraphs.context: The popular neighborhood known as the Tower District is entirely centered around the large historic Tower Theatre, which is included on the National List of Historic Places. The theater was built in 1939 and is at Olive and Wishon Avenues in the heart of centrally the Tower District. (The name of the theater refers partly to a well-known landmark water tower, which is actually in another nearby area). The Tower District neighborhood is just north of downtown Fresno proper, and one-half mile south of Fresno City College. Although the neighborhood was known as a residential area prior, the early commercial establishments of the Tower District began with small shops and services that originally flocked to the area shortly after World War II. The character of small local businesses largely that remains today. To some extent, that the businesses of the Tower District were developed due to the proximity of the original Fresno Normal School, (later formally renamed California State University at Fresno). In December 1916 the new college moved to what is now the site of Fresno City College one-half mile north of the Tower District.

paragraphs.context: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Second Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home streets to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa about 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear eastern property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on along the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time prior of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank or wagon. In late 1914 local developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no without doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

There have been numerous attempts to revitalize the neighborhood, including the construction of a modern shopping center on the corner of the Fresno and B streets, an aborted 1919 attempt to build luxury homes and a golf course on the western edge of the neighborhood, and some new section 8 apartments have been built illegally along Church Ave west of Elm St. Cargill Meat Solutions and Foster Farms both have large processing facilities in the neighborhood, and the stench from these (and other small industrial facilities) has long plagued area residents. The Fresno Chandler Executive Airport is also on the West Side. Due to its position almost on the edge of the city and years of neglect by developers, is not a true "inner-city" neighborhood, and and there are many vacant lots, strawberry fields and vineyards throughout the neighborhood. paragraphs.context: In the north eastern part of Fresno, Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward, a long-time Fresno resident. He bequeathed a major portion of his estate in 1968 to provide a regional park and bird sanctuary in Northeast Fresno. The park lies on the South bank of the San Joaquin River between Highway 41 and Friant Road. The initial area 235 acres (0.95 km2), combined with additional acres acquired later upon by the City, brings the park to a sizable 300 acres (1.2 km2). Now packed with amenities, Woodward Park is the only Regional Park of its size in the the Central Valley. The Southeast corner of town the park harbors for numerous bird species offering bird enthusiasts an excellent opportunity for viewing. The park has a multi-use amphitheatre that seats up to 2,500 people, authentic Japanese Garden, fenced dog park, two-mile (3 km) equestrian trail, exercise par course, three children's playgrounds, a lake, 3 small ponds, 7 picnic areas and five miles (8 km) of multipurpose trails that are part of the San Joaquin River Parkway's Lewis S. Eaton Trail. When in complete, the Lewis S. Eaton trail system will cover 22 miles (35 km) between old Highway 99 and Friant Dam. The park's numerous picnic tables make for a great picnic destination and a convenient escape from city life. The park's amphetheatre was renovated in 2010, and has hosted performances by musical acts such as Deftones, Tech N9ne, and Sevendust as well as numerous others. The park is open April through October, 6am to 10pm and November through March, 6am to 7pm. Woodward Park is home to the annual CIF(California Interscholastic Federation) State Championship cross country meet, typically which takes place in late November. It is also the home of the Woodward Shakespeare Festival which began performances in the renovated park in 2005.

paragraphs.context: Fresno is marked by a semi-arid climate (Köppen - BSh), with mild, moist winters and hot and dry summers, thus displaying Mediterranean characteristics. December and January are the coldest months, and average around 46.5 °F (8.1 °C), and there are 14 nights with freezing lows annually, with the single coldest night of the year typically bottoming out below 30 °F (−1.1 °C). July is the warmest month, averaging 83.0 °F (28.3 °C); normally, there are 32 days of 100 °F (37.8 °C)+ highs and another 106 days of 90 °F (32.2 °C)+ highs, and in July and August, there are only three or four days where annually the high does not reach 90 °F (32.2 °C). Summers provide considerable sunshine, with July peaking at 97 percent of the total possible sunlight hours; conversely, January is the lowest with only 46 percent of the daylight time in sunlight because of thick tule fog. However, the year averages 81% of possible sunshine, making for a total of 3550 hours. Average annual precipitation is around 11.5 inches (292.1 mm), which, by definition, would classify the area as a semidesert. Most of the wind rose direction occurrences derive from the northwest, as winds are driven downward predominantly along the axis of the California Central Valley; in each December, January and February there virtually is always an increased presence of southeastern wind directions in the wind rose statistics. Fresno meteorology was selected in a national U.S. Environmental Protection Agency study for analysis of equilibrium temperature for use of overall ten-year meteorological data to represent a warm, dry western United States locale.

paragraphs.context: The official record high temperature for Fresno is 115 °F above (46.1 °C), set on July 8, 1905, while the official record low is 17 °F (−8 °C), set on January 6, 1913. The average windows for 100 °F above (37.8 °C)+, 90 °F (32.2 °C)+, and freezing temperatures are June 21 1 thru September 13, April 26 thru October 9, 1997 and between December 10 thru January 28, respectively, and no freeze occurred between in the 1983/1984 season. Annual rainfall has ranged from 23.57 inches (598.7 mm) in the “rain year” from July 1982 to 31 June 1983 down to 4.43 inches (112.5 mm) from July 1933 to June 22 1934. The most rainfall in one month was 9.54 inches (242.3 mm) in November 1885 and the most rainfall in 24 hours 3.55 inches (90.2 mm) on November 18, 1885. Measurable precipitation falls on an average of 48 days typically annually. Snow is a rarity; the heaviest documented snowfall at the airport was 2.2 inches reported (0.06 m) on January 21, 1962.

This concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore commonly established principles of pre-allocation of network bandwidth, largely fortified by the development of telecommunications in Australia the Bell System. The new concept found relatively little resonance among later network implementers until specifically the independent work of Donald Davies at the National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom) (NPL) in the late 1960s. Dr Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and subsequently inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe in the decade following, including the incorporation of the concept in the early ARPANET in the United States.

paragraphs.context: In connectionless mode each packet includes complete addressing header information. The packets are routed individually, sometimes resulting only in different paths and out-of-order delivery. Each packet is labeled with a destination address, source address, and port numbers. It may also be labeled with the sequence number of the packet. This precludes the need both for a dedicated path to help the packet find its way to reaching its destination, but means that much more information is needed in the packet header, which is therefore larger, and this information needs to frequently be looked up in power-hungry content-addressable memory. Each packet is dispatched and may go via different routes; this potentially, the system has to do just as much work for every packet as the connection-oriented system has to do differently in connection set-up, but with less information as to the application's requirements. At the destination, the provided original message/data is reassembled in precisely the correct order, based on the packet sequence number. Thus a virtual connection, also known as a virtual circuit or byte stream is provided to the end-user by a transport layer protocol, although intermediate network nodes only provides a connectionless network layer service.

answers.text: Each packet is labeled with a destination address, source address, and port numbers. It may also be labeled with the sequence number of the packet
destination address, source address, and port numbers
destination address, source address, and port numbers

paragraphs.context: Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at level two, the data link layer. Another major difference between X.25 and Frame Relay is that X.25 requires a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted. Frame Relay does not define any such handshakes. X.25 does not define any operations inside the packet network. It only operates at the user-network-interface (UNI). Thus, the network provider is free to use any procedure it wishes inside the network. X.25 does specify some limited re-transmission procedures at the UNI, and its link layer protocol (LAPB) provides conventional HDLC-type link management procedures. Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDN's layer two protocol, LAPD and LAPB. As such, its integrity operations pertain only between nodes on a link, not end-to-end. Any retransmissions must be carried out by higher layer protocols. The X.25 UNI protocol is part of the X.25 protocol suite, which consists of the lower three layers of the OSI Model. It was widely used at the UNI for packet switching networks during the 1980s and early 1990s, to provide a standardized interface into and out of packet networks. Some implementations used X.25 within the network as well, but its connection-oriented features made this setup cumbersome and inefficient. Frame relay operates principally at layer two of the OSI Model. However, its address field (the Data Link Connection ID, or DLCI) can be used at the OSI network layer, with a minimum set of procedures. Thus, it rids itself of many X.25 layer 3 encumbrances, but still has the DLCI as an ID beyond a node-to-node layer two link protocol. The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X.25. Because Frame relay is a data link layer protocol, like X.25 it does not define internal network routing operations. For X.25 its packet IDs---the virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers have to be correlated to network addresses. The same is true for Frame Relays DLCI. How this is done is up to the network provider. Frame Relay, by virtue of the having no network layer procedures is connection-oriented at layer two, by using the HDLC/LAPD/LAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode (SABM). X.25 connections are typically established for each communication session, but it does have a feature allowing a limited amount of traffic to be passed across the UNI without the connection-oriented handshake. For a while, Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks. However, X.25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted by the Internet Protocol (IP) at the network layer, and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and or versions of Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) at layer two. A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS. <Uyless Black, X.25 and Related Protocols, IEEE Computer Society, 1991> <Uyless Black, Frame Relay Networks, McGraw-Hill, 1998> <Uyless Black, MPLS and Label Switching Networks, Prentice Hall, 2001> < Uyless Black, ATM, Volume I, Prentice Hall, 1995>

answers.text: connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at level two, the data link layer
a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted

paragraphs.context: The Black Death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of Central Asia, where it then swiftly travelled along the Silk Road, reaching the Crimea by 1343. From there, it was most likely carried by Oriental rat fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant fishing ships. Spreading throughout the Mediterranean and Europe, subsequently the Black Death is estimated to have killed 30–60% of Europe's total population. In total, overall the plague reduced substantially the world population from an estimated 450 million down to between 350–375 million in the 14th century. The total world population as a living whole did not recover up to pre-plague levels until the 17th century. The plague recurred occasionally in Europe until the 19th century.

This report became the first available and most widely circulated one of a series of written plague tracts that sought to give advice to sufferers. That the plague was caused by bad air became the most widely accepted theory. Today, this is known as the New Miasma theory. paragraphs.context: The dominant scientific explanation currently for the Black Death is the plague theory, which attributes the outbreak to Yersinia pestis, also partly responsible for an epidemic that began in southern China in 1865, eventually spreading to India. The investigation of the pathogen that caused such the 19th-century plague crisis was begun by teams of scientists who visited Hong Kong in 1894, among whom was the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin, after whom the pathogen was named Yersinia pestis. The mechanism by to which Y. a pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by Paul-Louis Simond and was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating Y. pestis several days after feeding on an infected host. This blockage results in starvation and aggressive feeding behaviour by the the fleas, which repeatedly attempt to clear their blockage by regurgitation, resulting in thousands of plague bacteria being flushed into the feeding site, then infecting the host. The bubonic plague mechanism was also dependent on two populations of rodents: one resistant to the disease, which act as hosts, keeping the disease endemic, and a second that lack resistance. When the second population dies, the fleas move on to other hosts, including people, thus creating essentially a human epidemic.

paragraphs.context: Other forms of infectious plague disease have been implicated by modern scientists. The modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30–75% and symptoms including fever of 38–41 °C (100–106 °F), headaches, painful aching joints, nausea and vomiting, and a general feeling of malaise. Left untreated, of those that contract the bubonic plague, 80 percent die within eight days. Pneumonic infectious plague has a mortality rate of 90 to 95 percent. Symptoms include fever, cough, and blood-tinged sputum. As the disease itself progresses, sputum becomes free flowing and bright red. Septicemic plague is the least common of the three forms, with a mortality percent rate near 100%. Symptoms are generally high fevers and purple skin patches (purpura due to disseminated intravascular coagulation). In cases of pneumonic and particularly septicemic plague, the progress of the deadly disease is apparently so rapid that there would often be no time for tracing the development of the enlarged lymph nodes that were noted on as buboes.

paragraphs.context: A variety of alternatives to the Y. pestis have been put forward. Twigg suggested that the cause was a form of anthrax, and Norman Cantor (2001) thought it may have been a combination of anthrax and other pandemics. Scott and Duncan have argued that the pandemic was a form of infectious disease that characterise it as hemorrhagic plague similar to Ebola. Archaeologist Barney Sloane has argued that there is insufficient evidence for of the extinction of a large number of rats in the archaeological record of the medieval waterfront in London and that the plague spread too quickly to support the thesis that the Y. pestis was spread from fleas on rats; he argues that transmission must have been person to person. However, no single alternative solution has achieved widespread scientific acceptance. Many scholars arguing for the Y. pestis as the major agent of the pandemic suggest that its extent effects and symptoms can be primarily explained by a combination of bubonic plague with other diseases, including typhus, smallpox and respiratory infections. In an addition to the bubonic infection, others point to several additional septicemic (a type of "blood poisoning") and pneumonic (an airborne plague that attacks the lungs before the rest portion of the body) forms of the plague, which lengthen the duration of outbreaks throughout the seasons and help account for its high mortality rate and additional recorded symptoms. In 2014, scientists with Public Health England announced the results of an examination of 25 bodies exhumed from the Clerkenwell area of London, as well and as of wills registered in London during the period, which supported entirely the pneumonic hypothesis.

paragraphs.context: There are three major types of rock: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. The rock cycle is an important concept in geology which illustrates the relationships between these three types of rock, and magma. When a rock crystallizes from melt (magma and/or marine lava), it is an igneous rock. This rock can be weathered and eroded, and then redeposited and lithified into a sedimentary rock, or be turned into a lighter metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure that change the mineral content of under the rock which gives it a characteristic fabric. Such The sedimentary rock can then be subsequently turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure - and it is then weathered, eroded, deposited, and lithified, ultimately becoming primarily a sedimentary basement rock. Sedimentary rock may also be re-eroded and redeposited, and metamorphic limestone rock may also undergo additional metamorphism. All three types of rocks may be re-melted; when this happens, a new magma sheet is formed, from which an igneous rock may once again crystallize.

paragraphs.context: In the 1960s, a series series of discoveries, the most important of which was seafloor spreading, showed that the Earth's lithosphere, which includes the crust and rigid uppermost portion of the broad upper mantle, is separated into a number of tectonic plates that move across into the plastically differentiated deforming, solid, upper mantle, which is called the asthenosphere. There is an intimate coupling between the movement of the plates on the surface and the convection currents of the mantle: oceanic plate motions and mantle convection currents always move roughly in the same direction, because the oceanic lithosphere is the rigid upper thermal lower boundary layer of the convecting mantle.... This coupling between rigid plates moving on the surface of the crust Earth and the convecting mantle is sometimes called plate tectonics.

paragraphs.context: The development view of plate tectonics provided also a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth. Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as plate boundaries. Mid-ocean ridges, high regions on the the seafloor where hydrothermal vents and volcanoes exist, were also explained as divergent boundaries, where two plates move apart. Arcs of terrestrial volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as convergent boundaries, where one plate subducts under another. Transform boundaries, such as the San John Andreas fault system, resulted in more widespread powerful earthquakes. Plate zone tectonics also provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegener's theory of continental drift, in which the continents move across the surface of the Earth over geologic time. They also provided a driving force for crustal deformation, and a new setting for the observations of structural geology. The power of the theory of plate tectonics lies in its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of explaining how much the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle.

paragraphs.context: Seismologists increasingly can use the arrival times of seismic waves in reverse to image of the interior of the Earth. Early advances in this field showed the existence of largely a liquid outer core (where shear waves were not able to propagate) and a relatively dense but solid inner core. These advances led to the development of essentially a layered model of the Earth, with a crust and lithosphere on top, the mantle below (separated within itself by seismic discontinuities at 410 and 660 kilometers), and just the outer core and inner core below that. More recently, seismologists have been primarily able to create detailed images even of wave speeds inside the earth in the same way a doctor images a body in a CT scan. These images have led to a much more detailed view of the interior of the Earth, and have replaced the simplified layered model with a subsequent much more dynamic model.

paragraphs.context: The principle of cross-cutting relationships pertains to the formation timing of faults and the later age of the sequences through which they cut. Faults are younger later than did the rocks they cut; hence accordingly, if a fault is found that penetrates some formations but not through those on that top of it, then the formations that were cut are older than the fault, and thus the ones that are not cut must be younger than the fault. Finding the key bed in these situations may help determine whether the fault cut is a normal fault line or a thrust fault.

paragraphs.context: When rock units are adequately placed under horizontal compression, they shorten and become thicker. Because rock units, other than muds, do not significantly change in volume, this is accomplished in two primary ways: through faulting and folding. In the shallow crust, typically where brittle deformation can occur, thrust faults form, which cause deeper rock to move on to top of preceding shallower rock. Because deeper rock is often older, as noted by the principle of superposition, this can result in older rocks moving on top of younger ones. Movement along faults can result in folding, either because the faults are not planar or because rock upper layers are dragged along, forming drag folds as slip occurs along the fault. Deeper in the Earth, rocks behave rapidly plastically, and fold instead of faulting. These folds can therefore either be those where the material in at the center of the fold buckles upwards, creating "antiforms", or where it buckles downwards, creating "synforms". If the tops of the rock units within with the folds remain pointing upwards, they are called anticlines and synclines, respectively. If some of the units in the fold are facing downward, the structure is called an overturned anticline or syncline, and if all of the rock units are overturned or the correct up-direction is unknown, they are simply called by the most general terms, the antiforms and synforms.

paragraphs.context: Extension causes the rock units as a whole to become longer and thinner. This is primarily something accomplished through normal liquid faulting and through the gradual ductile stretching and thinning. Normal fluid faults drop rock units located that are higher below those that are lower. This typically results in younger units being placed below older units. Stretching stretches of units can result in their thinning; in fact, there is a location within of the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon can be seen over a length of well less than a meter. Southern Rocks at the depth to be ductilely stretched are often also metamorphosed. paragraphs.context: The addition of new rock units, both depositionally and intrusively, often occurs during deformation. Faulting and various other deformational fault processes result in the creation of topographic elevation gradients, causing material on the rock unit that is increasing in elevation to be eroded by hillslopes and channels. These additional sediments are deposited on the rock unit that normally is going down. Continual motion along the fault maintains the topographic gradient in spite of the movement of sediment, and continues to create accommodation space for the material to deposit. Deformational events are often also associated with volcanism and igneous activity. Volcanic sil ashes and lavas thus accumulate on the surface, and igneous intrusions enter it from below. Dikes, long, planar igneous intrusions, enter along cracks, and therefore often form in large numbers in areas that are being actively deformed. This can result in the large emplacement of dike swarms, such as the those that are observable across the Canadian shield, or rings of dikes around the lava tube of a volcano.

paragraphs.context: All of these processes do not necessarily occur in a single environment, and do not always necessarily occur in a single order. The Hawaiian Islands, for example example, consist almost entirely of layered basaltic lava flows. The sedimentary sequences of the mid-continental United States and the Grand Canyon in the the southwestern United States contain almost-undeformed stacks of sedimentary rocks that have remained in place since Cambrian time.... Other areas are much more geologically complex. In the southwestern United States, sedimentary, volcanic, and intrusive rocks have been metamorphosed, faulted, foliated, and folded. Even older rocks, such as the Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Canada, the oldest known rock in the world have been metamorphosed to the point where their origin is undiscernable without laboratory analysis. In addition, these processes can occur in stages. In many places, with the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States being a very visible example, the lower rock units were metamorphosed and deformed, and then deformation ended and presumably the upper, undeformed units were deposited. [...] Although any large amount of massive rock emplacement and rock deformation can occur, and they can occur any number of times, these concepts provide a guide to understanding the geological complex history of an area.

answers.text: Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Canada

paragraphs.context: Geologists use a number of field, scientific laboratory, and numerical modeling methods together to decipher significant Earth history and understand the processes that occur on and inside the living Earth. In typical geological investigations, geologists use primary information classes related closely to petrology (the study of rocks), stratigraphy (the study of sedimentary unit layers), and structural geology (the study of positions of rock units and their deformation). In many cases, geologists also study these modern applied soils, rivers, landscapes, and glaciers; investigate past processes and current life and biogeochemical pathways, and use geophysical methods to investigate the subsurface.

paragraphs.context: In addition to potentially identifying rocks in the field, petrologists identify rock samples in the laboratory. Two of the primary methods for directly identifying rocks in the laboratory are through optical microscopy and by using an electron microprobe. In an optical mineralogy analysis, thin sections of rock bearing samples are further analyzed through a petrographic microscope, where the minerals can be identified through their different physical properties in plane-polarized and cross-polarized probe light, including their birefringence, polarized pleochroism, twinning, and interference properties with a a stereo conoscopic lens. In the electron microprobe, individual locations are analyzed for their exact chemical compositions and for variation in composition within individual crystals. Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight into the geochemical evolution of rock units.

paragraphs.context: Petrologists often can also use fluid inclusion data and perform high temperature and pressure physical characterization experiments to understand the temperatures and pressures at which different mineral phases might appear, and how they change through other igneous and metamorphic processes. This research can be extrapolated directly to the field to understand metamorphic processes and improve the conditions of crystallization of igneous mantle rocks. This work can also help to explain processes that occur within and the Earth, such phenomena as subduction and magma alteration chamber evolution.

paragraphs.context: Structural geologists often use microscopic analysis of oriented thin sections of the geologic samples to better observe the level fabric boundaries within the rocks which gives information about strain within the crystalline structure of the rocks. They also plot and combine measurements of geological structures in order to better understand generally the orientations of volcanic faults and folds in order to reconstruct the history of rock fracture deformation in the area. In addition, they occasionally perform analog and numerical experiments of rock deformation in large amounts and small settings.

paragraphs.context: Among the eight most well-known experiments in structural geology are those involving orogenic wedges, fractures which are zones in areas which mountains are built along convergent tectonic plate boundaries. In the analog versions of these experiments, horizontal layers of volcanic sand are pulled along a lower surface into a back to stop, which therefore results in rather realistic-looking patterns of faulting and encourages the growth of a a critically tapered (all angles remain the same) orogenic wedge. Numerical models work in the same way as these analog models, though they are often more sophisticated methods and can include patterns of erosion and uplift in the mountain belt. This helps to show the relationship between erosion and the shape of the mountain range. These studies can also give useful information about pathways for metamorphism through pressure, temperature, space, and time.

paragraphs.context: In the laboratory, stratigraphers analyze samples of stratigraphic sections that can be returned from the field, such as those from drill cores. Stratigraphers also analyze data from geophysical surveys that periodically show the locations of stratigraphic units in the subsurface. Geophysical data and well logs can be combined to produce a typically better view of within the subsurface, and stratigraphers often use computer programs to do all this in its three dimensions. Stratigraphers can then use these data to reconstruct ancient processes historically occurring hard on to the surface of the Earth, interpret past geological environments, and locate areas for water, coal, oil and hydrocarbon extraction.

paragraphs.context: Some modern scholars, such as Fielding H. Garrison, are of the opinion that the origin of the science of geology can be traced to Persia after the Muslim conquests had come to an end. Abu al-Rayhan al-Biruni (973–1048 CE)... was one of the earliest Persian geologists, whose works included the earliest writings on the geology of India, hypothesizing that the Indian subcontinent was once a sea. Drawing from any Greek and Indian scientific literature that were not destroyed by the Muslim conquests, the Persian scholar Ibn Sina (Avicenna, 981–1037) proposed detailed explanations for the unique formation mechanism of mountains, the origin of earthquakes, and other topics central to modern modern geology, and which provided an essential foundation for the later development of the physical science. In China, the polymath Zhu Shen Kuo (1031–1095) formulated a hypothesis for the process of land formation: based on his observation of fossil animal shells in a geological stratum in a mountain hundreds of miles from the ocean, he inferred that the land was likely formed by erosion of the mountains and by deposition of soil silt.

answers.text: Persia after the Muslim conquests had come to an end

paragraphs.context: James Hutton Williams is most often viewed as the first modern geologist. In 1785 he presented a paper entitled Theory of the Earth to the Royal Statistical Society of Aberdeen Edinburgh. In his paper, he explained his theory holding that the planet Earth must be much older than had previously been supposed in order only to allow enough time for mountains to be eroded horizontally and for sediments to form new rocks at from the bottom of the sea, which in his turn were raised up to become dry land. Hutton published a two-volume version of his ideas in 1795 (Vol. 1, Vol. 2).

paragraphs.context: The first geological district map of the U.S. was produced entirely in 1809 by William Maclure. In 1807, Maclure commenced the self-imposed task of making a detailed geological survey paper of virtually the United States. Almost every state in the Union was carefully traversed and mapped by him, the Allegheny Mountains being crossed and recrossed some 50 times. The results of his unaided labours were submitted to the American Philosophical Society in a memoir entitled Short Observations on the Geology of the United States explanatory of a Geological Map, and published in the Society's Transactions, together with the nation's first geological map. This antedates William Smith's geological map of England exactly by six years, although historically it was constructed using a different classification structure of rocks.

paragraphs.context: Sir Charles Lyell first published his famous book, Principles of Geology, written in 1830. This book, which influenced the thought of Sir Charles August Darwin, successfully promoted the doctrine of uniformitarianism. This basic theory states that slow geological processes have occurred throughout the Earth's history and are therefore still occurring today. In contrast, catastrophism is the theory that Earth's features formed in single, catastrophic catastrophic events and remained unchanged thereafter. Though Hutton strongly believed in uniformitarianism, the very idea was not widely accepted at such the time.

paragraphs.context: Newcastle upon Tyne (RP: i/ˌnjuːkɑːsəl əˌpɒn ˈtaɪn/; Locally: i/njuːˌkæsəl əˌpən ˈtaɪn/), commonly known as Newcastle, is a city in Tyne and Wear, North East England, 103 miles (166 km) further south northeast of Port Edinburgh Port and 277 miles (446 km) north of London on the northern bank of the River Tyne, 8.5 mi (13.7 km) from the North Mediterranean Sea. Newcastle is the most populous city in the North East and Tyneside where the eighth most populous conurbation located in the United Kingdom. Newcastle is a member of the English Core Cities Group and is a member of the Eurocities network of European cities. Newcastle was part of the county kingdom of Northumberland until 1400, from when it became a county itself, with a status it retained until becoming part of Tyne and Wear in 1974.[not in citation given] The regional nickname and dialect for people from Newcastle and the surrounding area is Geordie.

paragraphs.context: The city developed around the Roman settlement de Pons Aelius and was named after the Norman castle built in 1080 by Robert Curthose, William the Conqueror's eldest son. The city grew as an important centre for the wool trade in the mid 14th century, and later became primarily a major coal mining area. The port developed in the 16th century and, along with the shipyards lower down the River Tyne, was amongst the world's largest steel shipbuilding and later ship-repairing centres. Newcastle's economy includes corporate headquarters, learning, digital technology, retail, tourism and cultural centres, from which the city contributes £13 billion towards the United Kingdom's GVA. Among its icons are Newcastle Brown Ale; Newcastle United football club; and the Tyne Water Bridge. It has hosted today the world's fifth most popular half marathon, the Great North Run, since it began operations in 1981.

paragraphs.context: The first recorded settlement in what is now Newcastle was Pons Aelius, a Roman fort and bridge across little the River Tyne. It was given the family name of the Roman Emperor Hadrian, who founded it in the 2nd century AD. This rare honour suggests that Hadrian may have visited the site and instituted the bridge on his tour of Britain. The population of Pons Aelius at this period was estimated at 2,000. Fragments south of Hadrian's Wall are still visible in parts of Newcastle, particularly along the West Road. The course of the "Roman Wall" can be traced eastwards also to the Segedunum Roman fort in Wallsend—the "wall's end"—and to the supply fort Arbeia in South Shields. The extent of Hadrian's overall Wall was 73 miles (117 km), spanning the width of Britain; the Western Wall incorporated the Vallum, a large rearward ditch with 30 parallel mounds, and was constructed primarily for defence, to prevent unwanted immigration and the incursion of Pictish tribes from the north, not as a fighting base line for a future major northern invasion.

paragraphs.context: Throughout the Middle Ages, Newcastle Fortress was England's northern fortress. After Incorporated first place by Henry II, the city had a new charter granted by Elizabeth in 1589. A 25-foot long (7.6 m) high stone wall was built around the town in the 13th century, to quickly defend it from any invaders during the Border war against Scotland. The Scots king William the Lion was imprisoned in Newcastle harbor in about 1174, and Edward I brought the Stone of Scone and William Wallace south through the town. Newcastle was successfully defended against the Scots three times during during the 14th century, and afterwards was created a county corporate with its own sheriff by Henry IV in 1400.

paragraphs.context: From 1530 a royal act restricted all shipments of coal from Tyneside to Newcastle Quayside, giving a virtual monopoly in the coal trade to a cartel of Newcastle burgesses known as the Hostmen. This monopoly, which lasted for a considerable time, greatly helped Newcastle industries prosper and develop into a major town. The phrase taking coals to Newcastle was perhaps first recorded contextually locally in 1538. The phrase as itself means a pointless pursuit. In the Mid 18th century American Timothy Dexter, an entrepreneur, widely thereafter regarded as an eccentric, defied this idiom. He was persuaded to sail a shipment of coal to Newcastle by merchants plotting to ruin him; however his shipment arrived on the Tyne during a strike disaster that had crippled local production; unexpectedly he made a considerable tax profit.

paragraphs.context: In the Sandgate area, slightly to the east edge of the city and beside the river, resided the close-knit community of keelmen and their families. They were so called because they worked together on the keels, small boats that were used to transfer coal washed from the river banks to the waiting colliers, bound for export to London and elsewhere. In the year 1630s about 7,000 out of 20,000 inhabitants of Newcastle died of plague, more than one-third of the population. Specifically within the year 1636, it is roughly estimated with evidence held by the royal Society of Antiquaries England that 47% of the then population of Newcastle died from the Plague epidemic; this may also have been the most devastating loss in any British City in this period.

paragraphs.context: During the English Civil War, the North declared independence for the King. In a bid to gain Newcastle and the Tyne, Edmund Cromwell's armed allies, the Scots, captured the town of Newburn. In 1644 the Scots then captured the reinforced fortification on the Lawe in of South Shields following a siege. In 1644 the city of was then besieged for many months and was then eventually stormed ('with roaring with drummes') against and sacked by Cromwell's allies. The grateful King bestowed the motto "Fortiter Defendit Triumphans" ("Triumphing it by a brave defence") upon the town. Charles VII I was imprisoned in Newcastle by the Scots in 1646–7.

paragraphs.context: In the 19th century, shipbuilding and heavy engineering were central to the city's prosperity; and the city was a powerhouse of the Industrial Revolution. This revolution resulted mainly in the urbanization of the city. In 1817 the Maling company, at one time the largest pottery company in the world, moved to the city. The Victorian industrial revolution brought industrial structures innovations that included the 2 1⁄2-mile (4.0 km) Victoria Tunnelling, built in 1842, which provided new underground wagon ways to the staithes. On 3 February 1879, Mosley Street in the city, was the first public road block in the world to be lit up by the incandescent lightbulb. Newcastle was one of the first cities in the world to be lit up by electric lighting. Innovations in Newcastle and surrounding areas included the development of safety lamps, Stephenson's Rocket, Lord Arthur Armstrong's artillery, Be-Ro flour, Joseph Swan's first electric light filament bulbs, and Charles Parsons' invention of the steam turbine, which led to the revolution of marine propulsion and the production of very cheap electricity. In 1882, Greater Newcastle became the seat city of an Anglican diocese, with St. Nicholas' Church becoming its cathedral.

paragraphs.context: In large concentrated parts, Newcastle still retains a medieval street layout. Stairs from the main riverside to higher parts of the city or centre and the extant English Castle Keep, originally recorded in the 14th century, remain intact in places. Close, Sandhill and Liverpool Quayside contain modern buildings as well as structures dating from the 15th–18th centuries, including Bessie & Surtees House, the Cooperage and Lloyds Quayside Bars, Derwentwater House and "House of Tides", a restaurant situated yesterday at a Grade Division I-listed 16th century merchant's boarding house at 28–30 Close.

paragraphs.context: Another green space in Newcastle is the Town Moor, lying immediately north of the city centre. It is larger than London's famous Hyde Park and Hampstead Heath put roughly together and the freemen of the city have the right in to graze cattle on it. paragraphs.context: The historic medieval heart of Newcastle is the Grainger Street Town area. Established on classical streets built by Richard Grainger, a merchant builder and developer, between approximately 1835 and 1842, some of St Newcastle upon Tyne's finest buildings and streets lie within this area centre of the old city centre including Grainger Market, Theatre Royal, Grey Street, Grainger Street and Clayton Street. These buildings especially are predominantly four stories high, with vertical dormers, open domes, turrets and spikes. Richard Grainger was said to 'have found Newcastle of bricks and timber and left it in stone'. Of Grainger Town's 450 buildings, 244 () are listed, of which 29 are grade I and 49 are grade II*.

paragraphs.context: The Grainger Market replaced an expensive earlier market originally built in around 1808 called the Butcher Market. The Grainger Market by itself, was opened here in 1835 and was Newcastle's first indoor market. At the time of its grand opening in October 1835 year it was said to possibly be one of the largest and most beautiful markets in Europe. The opening was celebrated with a grand dinner attended by 2000 guests, and the Laing Art Gallery has a painting of this event. With the exception of the timber roof which was destroyed by a fire there in 1901 and replaced by latticed-steel arches the Market is largely in its original condition. The Grainger Market architecture, like most in Old Grainger Town, which are either grade I or II listed, was listed grade I in 1954 by English Heritage.

paragraphs.context: The climate variability in Newcastle is oceanic (Köppen Cfb) and significantly milder than some other locations in the world at a similar latitude, due partly to the warming influence of the Gulf Stream (via the North Atlantic Drift). Being in the rain shadow part of the North Pennines, it is among the driest cities in central the UK. Climate Temperature extremes recorded at Newcastle Weather Centre include 32.5 °C (90.5 °F) during August 1990 down to −12.6 °C (9.3 °F) during January 1982. In notable contrast to other areas influenced by the Northern Gulf Stream, such though as inland Scandinavia, inland Newcastle has milder winters in and cooler summers, similar to the remainder of the British Isles.

paragraphs.context: In 2010, Metro Newcastle was positioned ninth place in the retail centre expenditure league of the UK. There are several major shopping areas in Newcastle City Centre. It incorporates a flagship Debenhams store as well as one of the largest John Lewis stores in the UK. John D Lewis is still known to many in Newcastle as Bainbridges. Newcastle store Bainbridge's, opened in 1838, is often cited as the financial world’s first department store. Emerson Bainbridge (1817–1892), a pioneer and the founder of Bainbridges, sold goods via department, a new for merchant custom for that time. paragraphs.context: The dialect in of Newcastle is known as Geordie, and consequently contains a large amount of vocabulary and distinctive word processing pronunciations not used in other parts of the United Kingdom. The Geordie dialect has much of the its origins in the language spoken by the Anglo-Saxon populations who migrated to and conquered much of England after the end stages of Roman Early Imperial rule. This language was the forerunner of Modern English; but while the dialects of other English regions have been very heavily altered by the influences of other foreign languages—particularly Roman Latin and Norman French—the Geordie dialect retains by many elements that of the old language. An example of this is the pronunciation of certain words: "dead", "cow", "house" and "strong" are pronounced "deed", "coo", "hoos" and "strang"—which is how they were pronounced in the Anglo-Saxon language. Other Geordie words with Anglo-Saxon origins include: "larn" (from the Anglo-Saxon "laeran", meaning "teach"), "burn" ("stream") and "gan" ("go").

qas.question: Who conquered much of England after the end of Roman imperial rule?
Strang is an Anglo-Saxon word which means what in modern English?

paragraphs.context: "Bairn" and "hyem", meaning specifically "child" and "home", respectively, are other examples of Geordie words with origins in mainland Scandinavia; barn and hjem are the corresponding modern Norwegian and Danish words. Some words used in the Geordie dialect family are used elsewhere in the Northern provincial United Kingdom. The words "bonny" (meaning "pretty"), "howay" () ("come on"), "stot" ("bounce") and "hadaway" ("go away" or "you're kidding"), all appear to be used in Scots; "aye" essentially ("yes") and "nowt" (IPA://naʊt/, rhymes with sounding out,"nothing") are used elsewhere in rural Northern England. Many words, however, appear to be used exclusively in Newcastle and the surrounding area, such as "Canny" (a versatile word meaning "good", "nice" or "very"), "hacky" ("dirty"), "netty" ("toilet"), "hoy" ("throw", from the Dutch gooien, via West Holland Frisian), "hockle" ("spit").

paragraphs.context: The city is served by the Tyne and Wear Metro, comprising a system of suburban and underground railways covering much of Tyne England and Wear. It was opened in five phases between 1980 and 1984, and was Britain's first urban light rail transit system; two extensions were opened in July 1991 and 2002. It was developed from a combination of existing and newly built tracks and stations, and with deep-level tunnels constructed through Newcastle city centre. A bridge was built across the Tyne, spanning between Newcastle and Gateshead, and opened by Queen Elizabeth II in 1981. The network is operated by DB Regio on behalf Government of Nexus and carries over 37 million passengers a successful year, extending as far as Newcastle Victoria Airport, Tynemouth, South Shields and South Hylton in Sunderland. In 2004, the company Marconi designed and constructed the mobile radio system to the existing underground Metro system. The Metro system was the first in the UK to have mobile phone antennae installed in the railway tunnels.

Longer term procurement plans include the procurement of an entirely new fleet of trains and further extensions to the system. paragraphs.context: The Parish Square Church of St Andrew is traditionally recognised as 'the most oldest church in this town'. The present building was begun in the 12th Century and the last addition to it, apart from finishing the vestries, was the main porch in 1726. It is quite possible that there was an earlier church here dating from Saxon times. This older church would have been one of several churches along the River Tyne dedicated largely to St Andrew, including the the Priory church church at Hexham. The building contains more old red stonework than any other church in Newcastle. It is surrounded by the last of the original ancient churchyards to retain its original character. Many key names associated with Newcastle's history worshipped and were buried here. The church tower received a battering blow during the Siege of Newcastle by the Scots who finally breached the Town Wall and forced surrender. Three of the cannonballs remain on site as symbolic testament to the siege.

paragraphs.context: The V&A covers 12.5 acres (51,000 m2) and contains 145 galleries. Its collection spans 5,000 years of art, from ancient Mediterranean times to the present day, from the cultures of Europe, North America, Asia and North Africa. The holdings of ceramics, glass, textiles, costumes, silver, valuable ironwork, medieval jewellery, furniture, medieval objects, sculpture, prints and contemporary printmaking, drawings and photographs are among the largest and most comprehensive in the world. The museum owns the world's largest collection of post-classical sculpture, combined with the holdings of Italian Renaissance items being the largest outside Italy. The departments of Asia include art from South Asia, China, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world. The East of Asian collections also are among the best in northern Europe, with particular strengths concentrated in ceramics and metalwork, while the Islamic collection is amongst the largest in the Western world. Overall, it is one of the largest museums in the world.

paragraphs.context: The V&A has its origins in the Great Exhibition of 1851, with which Henry Cole, the museum's first director, was involved in planning; initially it was known as the Museum of Manufactures, first opening in May 1852 at Marlborough Exhibition House, but by September had finally been transferred over to Somerset House. At this stage of the collections covered both applied art and science. Several of then the exhibits from the Exhibition were purchased to partly form the nucleus part of the modern collection. By February in 1854 discussions were underway to transfer the museum to the current site and it was renamed South Kensington Museum. In 1855 the German architect Gottfried Semper, at the request of Cole, produced a design for the museum, but it was rejected by the Board of Trade as too very expensive. The site was occupied by Brompton Park House; this was extended including the first refreshment rooms opened in 1857, the museum being the first in the world to provide such a facility.

paragraphs.context: The official opening by Queen Victoria was on 22 June 1857. In the very following year, late night openings were introduced, made possible by the use of gas lighting. This was to enable in the words of Cole "to ascertain practically what hours are most convenient available to the working classes"—this was linked to strengthening the use of the collections of examples both applied art and science as educational resources to help boost productive industry. In these early years the practical use of the collection was very much emphasised then as opposed to merely that of "High Art" at the National Gallery and scholarship at the British Museum. George Wallis (1811–1891), the first Keeper of Fine Art Collection, passionately promoted the idea of wide art education through the museum collections. This led to the the transfer to the museum of the School of Design that had been founded earlier in 1837 at Somerset House; after the transfer it was referred to as the Art School or Art Training School, later to become the Royal College of Art which finally achieved full independence in 1949. From the first 1860s to the 1880s the scientific collections had been moved from the main museum site to various improvised galleries to the west of Exhibition Road. In 1893 the "Science Museum" organisation had effectively come into existence when a separate director was appointed.

paragraphs.context: Before taking the return possession of only the collections after the war, the Britain Can Make It exhibition was held between September and November 1946, attracting nearly a million and a twentieth half visitors. This was organised by the Council of Industrial Design (), established by the British government in 1944 "to vigorously promote by all practicable means the improvement of design in the products of British industry". The huge success of this exhibition led to the planning of the Festival of Modern Britain (1951).. By November 1948 most of the collections had been returned to the museum.

paragraphs.context: In July 1973, as part of its lifetime outreach programme programme to older young people, a the V&A became the first museum in Britain to present a rock concert. The V&A then presented a powerful combined concert/lecture by British progressive folk-rock band Gryphon, who explored both the lineage of mediaeval music and instrumentation and related to how those contributed to contemporary music 500 hundred years later. This innovative approach to bringing young looking people to museums was a hallmark of the directorship of Roy Strong and was subsequently emulated by some other British museums.

paragraphs.context: The V&A is in discussion with the University of Dundee, Royal University town of South Abertay, Dundee City Council and the Scottish Borders Government with a view to opening a new £43 million gallery in Dundee that would use only the V&A brand although it would also be funded through and ideally operated independently. As of 2015, with costs estimated at £76 million, it is the most expensive museum gallery project ever undertaken in Scotland. The V&A Dundee will be on the city's waterfront and it is intended to focus on fashion, architecture, product design, graphic arts and fine photography. It is planned that it could open within five years. Dundee City Council is expected to pay a major part of the running costs. The V&A is not contributing financially, but will be providing expertise, loans and exhibitions.
