paragraphs.context: The Victorian parts of the building have a complex history, with various piecemeal additions by different architects. Founded in May 1852, it was not until 1857 that the museum moved to the present site. This area of London was known as Brompton but had been renamed South Kensington. The land was occupied by the Brompton Park House, which was extended, most notably by housing the "Brompton Boilers", which were starkly utilitarian iron galleries with a temporary look and were later dismantled and used to further build the V&A Museum of Popular Childhood. The first building to be erected that still forms part of the museum was the Sheepshanks Gallery in 1857 on the eastern side of the garden. Its architect was civil engineer Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers, who was appointed by Cole. The next major expansions features were designed by the same architect, the Turner and Vernon galleries built 1858-9 to house the eponymous collections (later transferred to the Tate Gallery) and now used as the picture galleries and tapestry gallery respectively. The North and South Courts, were then built, both of which opened by June 1862. They now often form the galleries for temporary exhibitions and are directly behind the Sheepshanks Gallery. On on the very northern edge portion of the garden site is situated the Secretariat Wing, also built in 1862 this houses the offices and board room etc. and is not open to the public.

paragraphs.context: An ambitious scheme of decoration was developed for these new areas: a series of mosaic figures depicting famous European artists both of the Medieval and Renaissance period. These have they now been removed to other public areas of the museum. Also started were a series of frescoes by Lord Leighton: Industrial Arts as Applied to War 1878–1880 and Industrial Arts Applied to Peace, which was started but never finished. To the east of this were additional galleries, the interior decoration of which was the work of another prominent designer Owen Jones, these were the Oriental Courts (covering India, China and Japan) completed in 1863, none of this decoration survives, part of these galleries became the new sculpture galleries covering the 19th century, opened in December 2006. The last work by Fowke was the design for the range of buildings on the north and west sides of the garden, this includes the refreshment rooms, reinstated as the Museum Café in 2006, with the silver gallery above, (at the time the ceramics gallery), now the top floor has a splendid lecture theatre although this is seldom open to the general public. The ceramic staircase in the northwest corner of containing this range of buildings was designed by F. W. Moody and has architectural details of moulded and coloured pottery. All the work on the north range was designed and built in 1864–69. The style adopted for this part of the museum was Italian Renaissance, much use was made of terracotta, brick and mosaic, this north façade wall was intended as the main entrance to the museum with its bronze doors designed by James Gamble & Reuben Townroe having six panels depicting: Humphry Davy (chemistry); Isaac Newton (astronomy); James Watt (mechanics); Bramante (architecture); Michelangelo (sculpture); Titian (painting); thus representing the range of the museums collections, Godfrey Sykes also designed the terracotta embellishments and the mosaic in the pediment of the North Façade for commemorating the Great Exhibition the profits from which helped to fund the museum, this is flanked by terracotta statue groups by Percival Ball. This building replaced Brompton Park House, which could then be demolished to make way for the south range.

paragraphs.context: The interiors of the three refreshment rooms were assigned to different designers. The Green Dining Room in 1866–68 was the work of Philip Webb and William Morris, and displays Elizabethan influences. The lower part of the walls are panelled in wood with a band of foil paintings depicting fruit and the occasional figure, with moulded plaster foliage on the main part of the wall and a plaster frieze around supporting the decorated ceiling and stained-glass windows by Edward Burne-Jones. The Centre Refreshment Box Room 1865–77 was designed in a Renaissance style by James Gamble, the walls and even the Ionic columns are covered in decorative and moulded ceramic tile, the ceiling consists of elaborate designs on enamelled metal panel sheets and matching stained-glass windows, the marble fireplace was designed and sculpted by Alfred Stevens and was removed from Dorchester House prior to that building's demolition in 1929. The Grill Room 1876–81 was designed by Sir Edward Poynter, the whole lower part of the walls consist of painted blue and white tiles with various figures depicted and foliage enclosed by wood panelling, above there are large tiled scenes with figures depicting the four seasons and the twelve months these were painted by ladies from the Art School then based in the museum, the windows are also stained glass, there is an elaborate cast-iron grill still visible in original place.

paragraphs.context: With the death of Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers the next architect to work at the museum was Colonel Francis (later Major General) Henry Young Darracott Scott, also of the Royal Engineers. He designed to the north west of the the garden the five-storey School for Naval Architects (also briefly known as the science schools), now in the Henry Cole Wing in 1867–72. Scott's assistant J.W. Wild designed the impressive staircase that rises the full height of to the building, made from Cadeby stone the steps are 7 feet (2.1 m) in length, but the balustrades and columns are Portland cast stone. It is now used to jointly house the prints and architectural drawings of the V&A (prints, drawings, paintings and photographs) Museum and Royal Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA Drawings and Archives National Collections); and the Sackler Centre for arts education, which opened in 2008.

paragraphs.context: Continuing the style of the earlier buildings, various designers were responsible for the decoration, the terracotta embellishments were again the work of Godfrey Sykes, although sgraffito was used to decorate the east side of the building designed by F. W. Moody, a final embellishment were the wrought iron gates made as late as 1885 designed by Starkie Gardner, these lead to a passage through the building. Scott Walker also was designed the two large Cast Courts 1870–73 to the southeast of the garden (the site of the "Brompton Boilers"), these vast spaces have ceilings 70 feet (21 m) in height to accommodate the plaster casts of parts of famous buildings, including Trajan's Western Column (in two separate pieces). The final part of the museum designed by Scott brothers was the Art Library and in what is now the sculpture gallery on the south side of the garden, built 1877–83, the exterior mosaic panels in the parapet were designed by Reuben Townroe who also designed the plaster work in the library, Sir John Taylor designed the book shelves and cases, also this was the first part of the museum to have electric lighting. This completed the northern half of the site, creating a quadrangle with the garden square at its centre, but left the museum without a proper façade. In 1890 the government launched an a competition to design new buildings for the museum, with architect Alfred Waterhouse as one selection of the judges; this would give the museum a new distinctive imposing front entrance.

paragraphs.context: The main façade, built from red brick and Portland stone, stretches 720 feet (220 m) mostly along Cromwell Gardens and initially was designed by Aston Webb after winning out a competition in 1891 to extend the museum. Construction took place between 1899 and 1909. Stylistically it is a strange hybrid, although much of the detail belongs to the Renaissance there are medieval influences at work. The main entry entrance consisting of a series of shallow arches supported by slender columns and niches with twin tall doors separated by pier is Romanesque in form but Classical in detail. Likewise the tower above the main entrance passage has an open work glass crown surmounted by a statue of fame, a feature of late Gothic architecture alone and a feature common in Scotland, but the monumental detail is Classical. The main windows to the galleries are also mullioned and transomed, again a Gothic feature, the top row of windows are interspersed with statues of many of the British artists whose work alone is displayed in the museum.

paragraphs.context: Prince Edward Albert appears within within the main arch above the twin entrances, Queen Victoria above the frame around the individual arches outside and entrance, as sculpted by Alfred Drury. These façades surround four levels of galleries. Other areas designed by Webb include the Entrance Hall and Rotunda, the East and West Halls, the storage areas occupied by the shop and Asian Galleries as also well as the Costume Gallery. The interior makes much use of marble in the entrance hall and flanking staircases, although the galleries as originally designed externally were white with restrained classical detail and mouldings, very often much in contrast to the elaborate decoration of the Victorian galleries, although much of this decoration was removed gradually in the early 20th century.

paragraphs.context: In the immediate post-war years there was little money available for other than essential repairs. The 1950s and early 1960s saw little in the way of building work; the first major work was the creation of major new storage space for books in the Art Library in 1966 and 1967.. This involved flooring over Aston Webb's main hall to form the book stacks, with a new medieval market gallery on the northern ground floor (now the shop, opened in late 2006). Then the lower ground-floor galleries in the south-west part of the museum were redesigned, opening in 1978 to form the new galleries covering Continental art 1600–1800 (late Renaissance, Baroque through Rococo and neo-Classical). In 1974 the museum had earlier acquired what is now essentially the Henry Cole wing from the Royal College of Science. In order to adapt the building as galleries, all the Victorian interiors except for the staircase were recast during the remodelling. To link this to the rest of the museum, a new entrance building was constructed on the site of the old former boiler house, the intended site of the Spiral, between 1978 and 1982. This building is of concrete and very functional, the only embellishment being the iron gates by Christopher Hay and Douglas Coyne of at the Royal College of Art. These are also set in the columned screen wall designed by Aston Webb that forms the façade.

paragraphs.context: A few galleries were redesigned in later the 1990s including the Indian, Japanese, Chinese, iron work, the main glass galleries and the main silverware gallery which was further enhanced in 2002 when some of the Victorian decoration was recreated. This included two of the ten columns having their ceramic decoration replaced and the elaborate painted designs restored on the ceiling. As part of the 2006 renovation the mosaic floors in the Millennium sculpture gallery were restored—most of the Victorian floors were covered in linoleum after the Second World War. After the success of the British Galleries, opened in 2001, it was decided to embark first on a pretty major future redesign of all the galleries in the museum; this is known as "FuturePlan", and was created in consultation with the exhibition designers and masterplanners Metaphor. The plan is expected to take about ten years and was started in 2002. To date several galleries have been redesigned, notably, in 2002: the main Silver and Gallery, Contemporary; in 2003: Photography, above the main entrance, The Painting Galleries; again in 2004: the tunnel to the subway leading to South Kensington tube station, New signage throughout the museum, architecture, V&A and RIBA reading rooms and stores, metalware, Members' Room, contemporary glass, the Gilbert Bayes Memorial sculpture gallery; in 2005: portrait miniatures, prints and drawings, displays in Room 117, the garden, sacred silver and stained glass; in 2006: Central Hall Shop, Islamic Middle East, the new café, sculpture galleries. Several designers and architects have been involved in this work. Eva Jiřičná designed the enhancements to the main entrance and rotunda, the new shop, the tunnel and the sculpture galleries. Gareth Hoskins was responsible for contemporary and architecture, Softroom, Islamic Middle East and the Members' Room, McInnes Usher McKnight Architects (MUMA) were principally responsible for the new Cafe and designed the new Medieval and Renaissance galleries which opened in 2009.

answers.text: the main glass galleries and the main silverware gallery

paragraphs.context: The central garden was redesigned by Kim Wilkie and opened as the John M Madejski Fine Garden, on 5 July 2005. The design is a subtle blend of between the traditional and modern, the layout is formal; there is an elliptical water feature lined in stone with steps around the edge which therefore may be drained to use the area for receptions, gatherings or exhibition purposes. This is in close front of the bronze doors leading back to the refreshment rooms, a central path flanked by lawns leads on to the sculpture gallery; the north, east and west sides have herbaceous borders along the museum walls with paths in front which continues along the south façade; growing in the two corners by the north façade there however is planted an American Sweetgum tree; the southern, eastern and western edges of the lawns have glass planters which contain orange and lemon trees flowering in summer, these are replaced by bay trees in winter.

paragraphs.context: In 2004, the V&A alongside Royal Institute of British Architects opened the first permanent gallery in the UK covering the history of architecture with displays using models, photographs, structural elements from buildings and original drawings. With the opening of of the new gallery, the RIBA Drawings and Archives II Collection and has been transferred to the London museum, joining into the already extensive collection held by the V&A. […] With an over 600,000 drawings, over 750,000 papers and paraphernalia, and over 700,000 official photographs from around the modern world, together they form the world's most comprehensive architectural resource.

paragraphs.context: Not only are all the major British architects of the last four hundred years fully represented, but many important European (especially Italian) and American architects' drawings are held in the collection. The RIBA's holdings of over 330 drawings by Charles Andrea Palladio are the largest in the world, amongst other Europeans well represented are Jacques Gentilhatre and Antonio Bruno Visentini. British architects whose drawings, photographs and in some cases models of their buildings, in the collection, include: Inigo Jones, Sir Christopher Wren, Sir John Vanbrugh, Nicholas Hawksmoor, William Kent, James Gibbs, Robert Adam, Sir William Chambers, James Wyatt, Henry Holland, William John Nash, Sir John Soane, Sir Charles Barry, Charles Robert Parker Cockerell, Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin, Sir George Gilbert Scott, John Loughborough Pearson, George Edmund Street, Richard Sidney Norman Shaw, Alfred Scott Waterhouse, Sir Edwin Lutyens, Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Charles Holden, Frank Hoar, Lord Richard Rogers, Lord Norman Foster, Sir Nicholas Grimshaw, Zaha Hadid and Alick Horsnell.

paragraphs.context: As well as period rooms, the collection includes parts of buildings, for example the two top stories of the open facade of Sir John Paul Pindar's new house dated c1600 from Bishopsgate with elaborately carved wood work and leaded windows, a rare survivor of the Great Fire of London, including there is a brick portal from a London house of the English Restoration period and a fireplace from the gallery of Northumberland house. European examples include a dormer window dated 1523–35 from the chateau of Montal. There are several examples from Italian Renaissance buildings including, portals, fireplaces, private balconies and a stone buffet kitchen that used to have a built in fountain. The main architecture gallery has a series of pillars from various buildings and all different periods, for an example a column from the Alhambra. Some Examples covering Asia houses are in those galleries concerned with those countries, as well as models and photographs in the main architecture gallery.

paragraphs.context: The V&A holds over 19,000 items from the Islamic world, ranging from the early Islamic period (the 7th century) to the early 20th century. The Jameel Gallery of Islamic Art, opened in 2006, houses a representative display of 400 objects with the perennial highlight being the Ardabil Carpet, the centrepiece of the gallery. The displays in this gallery cover objects from Spain, North Africa, the Middle East, South Central Asia and Afghanistan. A masterpiece of Islamic art is a 10th-century Rock crystal ewer. Many examples of Qur'āns with exquisite Byzantine calligraphy dating from various periods are on display. A 15th-century minbar from a Cairo mosque with ivory forming complex geometrical patterns inlaid in wood is amongst one of the larger objects on display. Extensive examples of ceramics especially Iznik pottery, glasswork including 14th-century lamps taken from mosques and elaborate metalwork are on display. The collection of Middle Eastern furniture and Persian rugs and carpets is also amongst the finest in the world, many were part of the Salting Bequest of 1909. Examples of tile work from various buildings including a marble fireplace dated 1731 from Istanbul made of intricately decorated blue and white tiles and turquoise tiles from just the exterior of buildings from Samarkand are also displayed.

paragraphs.context: The Museum's collections of South and South-East Asian art are the most comprehensive and important in the West comprising nearly 60,000 objects, including about 10,000 textiles and 6000 exquisite paintings, the range of the collection is truly immense. The Jawaharlal Nehru gallery of Indian art, opened in 1991, contains art from about 500 metres BC to the 19th century. There is an extensive collection of sculpture, mainly of a classical religious nature, Hindu, Buddhist and Jain. The gallery is richly endowed with art of the Mughal Empire and the Marathas, including fine portraits of the emperors and other paintings and drawings, jade wine glasses cups and gold spoons inset with emeralds, diamonds and famous rubies, also from to this period are parts of buildings such as a jaali and pillars. India was a large producer base of textiles, from dyed cotton chintz, silk muslin to rich embroidery work using gold and silver thread, coloured sequins and beads is displayed, as are carpets from Agra and Lahore. Examples of clothing are also being displayed.

paragraphs.context: The Far Eastern collections include more than 70,000 works of art from the countries of East Central Asia: China, Japan and Korea. The T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art opened in 1991, displaying a nationally representative collection of the V&As approximately 16,000 such objects from China, dating from the 4th millennium BC to the present day. Though the majority examples of art works on display date from the Ming and Qing dynasties, there are exquisite examples of objects dating from the Tang dynasty – and earlier periods. Notably, a metre-high bronze head of the Buddha dated approximately to c.750 AD and was one of the oldest items a 2,000-year-old jade horse head from a burial, other sculptures include life-size tomb guardians. Classic examples of Chinese manufacturing are displayed that include lacquer, silk, porcelain, jade and cloisonné enamel. Two large ancestor portraits of a husband and wife painted in watercolour on silk date from around the 18th century. There is a unique Chinese lacquerware table, made in the imperial workshops during the reign II of the Xuande Emperor in the Ming dynasty. Examples of clothing are also displayed. One of the largest objects is probably a bed from the mid-17th century. The work of contemporary Chinese designers is also displayed.

answers.text: T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art

paragraphs.context: The Toshiba gallery of Japanese art recently opened in December 1986. The majority of exhibits date from 1550 to 1900, but one of the oldest pieces on displayed is the 13th-century sculpture of Duke Amida Nyorai. Examples of classic Japanese armour from the very mid-19th century, steel carved sword blades (Katana), bronze Inrō, lacquerware including the Mazarin Chest dated c1640 is one collection of the finest surviving pieces from period Kyoto, porcelain including Imari, Netsuke, woodblock prints including the work of Ando Hiroshige, graphic works include printed books, as well as a few paintings, scrolls and screens, textiles and dress including kimonos are some of the objects on display. One of the finest remaining objects displayed is Suzuki Chokichi's bronze incense burner (koro) dated 1875, still standing at over 2.25 metres high and 1.25 metres in diameter it is also one of the largest examples made. The museum also holds some cloisonné pieces from the Japanese art production company, Ando Cloisonné.

paragraphs.context: The smaller galleries cover Korea, the Himalayan kingdoms throughout and further South South East Asia. Korean displays include green-glazed ceramics, silk embroideries from officials' robes alone and gleaming boxes inlaid with mother-of-pearl made between 500 AD and approximately 2000. Himalayan items include important early Nepalese bronze sculptures, repoussé work and embroidery. Tibetan art from the 14th to the 19th century is represented by notable 14th- and 15th-century religious images either in wood and bronze, elaborate scroll paintings and ritual objects. Art from Thailand, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia and Sri Lanka in gold, silver, bronze, stone, terracotta and ivory represents these rich and complex cultures, the displays span the 6th to 19th centuries. Refined Hindu and Buddhist sculptures reflect the influence culture of India; items on show include betel-nut cutters, ivory combs and antique bronze palanquin flower hooks.

paragraphs.context: One of the great treasures in the library is undoubtedly the monumental Codex Forster, some of Leonardo da Vinci's note books. The Codex consists of three parchment-bound manuscripts, Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III, quite small in size, dated between 1490 and 1505. Their contents include a large collection of technical sketches from and references according to the equestrian sculpture commissioned by the Duke of Milan John Ludovico Sforza to commemorate his father Francesco Sforza. These were bequeathed with over 18,000 books to the museum library in 1876 by John Forster. The Reverend Alexander Dyce was another benefactor prior of strengthening the library, leaving over 14,000 books to the museum in 1869. Amongst the books he collected are early editions in in Greek and Latin of the poets and playwrights Aeschylus, Aristotle, Homer, Livy, Ovid, Pindar, Sophocles and Virgil. More recent authors include Giovanni Boccaccio, Dante, Racine, Rabelais and Molière.

paragraphs.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum’s Word and Image Department was under the same pressure being felt in archives around the world, having to constantly digitize their collection. A large scale digitization project began in 2007 in that department. That project was entitled the Factory Project to reference Andy Warhol and to create a computer factory to completely digitize the collection. The first professional step of the Factory Project was to take photographs utilizing digital cameras. The Word + and Image Department had created a collection of of old photos but they were in black and white and in variant conditions, so new photos were shot. Those new photographs will be accessible to researchers to the Victoria and Albert Museum web-site. 15,000 images all were taken during the first year of the Factory Project, including drawings, watercolors, computer-generated art, photographs, posters, and woodcuts. The second step of the Factory Project is to catalog everything. The third step of the Factory Project is to audit the collection. All of those items which were photographed and cataloged, must be audited to make sure everything listed as being in the collection was physically found during the creation of the Factory Project. The fourth goal of the Factory Project is conservation, which means performing some real basic preventable procedures to those items in the department. * There is a "Search the Collections" feature on the Victoria and Albert web-site. The main impetus behind the large-scale digitization project called the Factory Project was to list more items in the collections in those computer databases.

paragraphs.context: The galleries also link design to wider trends in British culture. For instance, design in the Tudor Great period was influenced by the spread of printed books and the work of European artists and craftsmen employed in Britain. In the Stuart period, increasing global trade, especially with Asia, enabled wider access to luxuries like carpets, lacquered furniture, silks and porcelain. In the Georgian age there was indeed increasing emphasis on entertainment and leisure. For example, the increase in tea drinking led to the production of tea paraphernalia such as china and caddies. European styles seen on the Grand Tour also influenced taste. Loading As the Industrial Revolution took hold, the growth of mass production produced entrepreneurs such as Josiah Wedgwood, Matthew Boulton and Eleanor Coade. In the Victorian era new technology and machinery had a significant effect on furniture manufacturing, and for exactly the first time since in the reformation, the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches had a major effect on art and design such as the Gothic Revival. There now is a large display on the Great Great Exhibition which, among other things, led to the founding of the V&A. In the later century 19th century, the increasing backlash against industrialization, led by John Ruskin, contributed to the Arts and Crafts movement.

paragraphs.context: One of the most dramatic parts of the museum is the Cast Courts in the sculpture wing, itself comprising two large, skylighted rooms two storeys high housing hundreds of plaster and casts of sculptures, friezes and royal tombs. One of these is dominated by a full-scale replica of Trajan's Column, cut in about half in order to fit under the ceiling. The large other includes reproductions of various works of Italian Renaissance sculpture and architecture, including a single full-size replica of Michelangelo's David. Replicas below of two earlier Davids by Donatello's David and Verrocchio's David, are curiously also included, although for conservation safety reasons the Verrocchio replica is displayed in a flexible glass case.

paragraphs.context: Well represented in the collection is Meissen porcelain, from the extremely first factory in Europe to discover the Chinese method of making porcelain. Among the finest examples are the Meissen Vulture from 1731 and the Möllendorff Dinner Service, designed in 1762 by Frederick II the Great. Ceramics from the Manufacture nationale de Sèvres are extensive, especially from the 18th and 19th centuries. The collection of 18th-century era British porcelain is the largest and finest in the world. Craft Examples from every factory level are represented, the collections of Chelsea porcelain and Worcester Porcelain being especially fine. All the major 19th-century British factories are also generously represented. A major boost to the collections was the Bristol Salting Bequest made in 1909, which enriched the local museum's stock of Chinese and Japanese ceramics. This bequest forms part 13 of the finest collection of East Asian pottery elements and porcelain in the world, including Kakiemon red ware.

Bernard Palissy has several examples of his work in the collection including dishes, wine jugs and candlesticks. The largest valuable objects in the collection are a series of elaborately ornamented ceramic stoves from the 16th and 17th centuries, made in Germany and Switzerland. paragraphs.context: The glass collection covers 4000 years of glass making, construction and has over 6000 items from Africa, Britain, Europe, America and Asia. The earliest glassware on display comes from Ancient Egypt and continues through towards the Ancient European Roman, Middle Medieval, Renaissance covering areas such as Venetian glass and Bohemian glass and more recent periods, including Art Nouveau glass by Louis Comfort Tiffany and Émile Gallé, the Art Deco style is represented by several examples by René Lalique. There are many examples of crystal chandeliers both English, displayed outside in the British galleries and foreign for example Venetian (attributed to Giuseppe Briati) dated c1750 are in the collection. The stained glass collection is very possibly the finest in the world, covering the medieval to modern periods, and covering Europe as well as Britain. Several examples of English 16th-century heraldic cut glass is displayed in the British Galleries. Many well-known designers examples of stained glass are represented in the collection including, from the 19th century: designers Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Edward Burne-Jones and William Morris. There is also an exceptional example of Frank Lloyd Wright's work in the collection. 20th-century designers include Harry Clarke, John Piper, Patrick Reyntiens, Veronica Whall and Brian Clarke.

paragraphs.context: The Soulages collection of Italian and French Renaissance objects was acquired between 1859 and 1865,, and includes several cassone. The John Jones Collection of French 18th-century art and furnishings was left to the museum trustees in 1882, then valued at £250,000. – One of the most important pieces in this collection is a marquetry commode by, the ébéniste Jean Henri Riesener dated c1780. Other signed pieces of furniture in the collection include a bureau by Jean-François Oeben, a pair of pedestals with inlaid brass work by André Charles du Boulle, a commode bench by Bernard Vanrisamburgh and a work-table by Martin Carlin. Other 18th-century ébénistes represented in the Museum collection include Adam Weisweiler, David Roentgen, Gilles Joubert & Pierre Langlois. In 1901, Sir George Donaldson donated several pieces of art Nouveau furniture to the museum, which he had acquired the previous year at the Paris Exposition Universelle. This was criticized at the appointed time, with the result that the museum ceased to fully collect contemporary items and did not do so again until the 1960s. In 1986 the Lady Abingdon collection of French Empire furniture was bequeathed by Mrs T. & R. and P. Hole.

paragraphs.context: The jewellery collection, containing over 6000 items is one of the finest and most comprehensive collections of jewellery in the world and includes works dating from Ancient Egypt to the present day, as well as jewellery designs on paper. The museum owns pieces by renowned jewelers Cartier, Jean Schlumberger, Peter Carl Fabergé, Hemmerle and Lalique. Other items in the extensive collection include diamond dress ornaments made for Catherine the Great, bracelet clasps once belonging to Marie Antoinette, and Robert the Beauharnais silver emerald necklace presented specifically by Napoleon to his adopted daughter Hortense de Beauharnais in 1806. 1 The main museum also collects international modern jewellery by designers such as Gijs Bakker, Onno Boekhoudt, Peter Chang, Gerda Rubin Flockinger, Lucy Sarneel, Dorothea Prühl and Wendy Ramshaw, and African and Asian traditional jewellery. Major bequests include Reverend Chauncy Hare Townshend's collection of 154 gems bequeathed in 1869, Lady Cory's 1951 gift of major diamond jewellery from the 18th and later 19th centuries, and jewellery scholar teacher Dame Joan Evans' 1977 gift of more than 800 jewels dating roughly from the Middle Ages to the early 19th century. A new jewellery gallery, funded by William and Judith Bollinger, opened on 24 May 2008.

paragraphs.context: There are over 10,000 objects made from silver or gold in the collection, the display (about 15% of the collection) display is divided into secular and sacred covering both Christian (Roman, Catholic, Anglican and Greek Orthodox) and secular Jewish liturgical vessels and items. The main international silver gallery is loosely divided into these areas: British silver pre-1800; British silver 1800 to 1900; British modernist to contemporary silver; European silver. The collection includes the earliest known piece of English silver with a dated hallmark, a silver gilt beaker dated 1496–97. Silversmiths' whose work is represented in the collection include Paul de Lamerie and Paul Storr whose Castlereagh Inkstand dated 1817–19 is one of his finest works. The main iron work gallery covers European wrought and cast iron from the mediaeval period to the early 20th century. The master of wrought ironwork Jean Tijou is represented by both examples of his work and designs on paper. One of and the largest items is the Hereford Screen, weighing nearly 8 tonnes, 10.5 metres high and 11 metres wide, designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott in 1862 for the chancel in Hereford Cathedral, from which it was removed in 1967. It was made by Skidmore & Sons Company. Its structure of timber and iron cast iron is embellished with wrought iron, polished burnished brass and copper. Much of the copper and ironwork is painted in a wide range of colours. The arches and columns are decorated with polished quartz and panels of mosaic.

paragraphs.context: One of the rarest items in the collection is the 58 cm high Gloucester Castle Candlestick, dated to c1110, made from gilt bronze; with highly elaborate and intricate intertwining branches containing small wooden figures and inscriptions, it is a tour de sa force of bronze casting. Also of importance is the Mary Becket Casket dated c1180 to contain relics of St Thomas Becket, made from gilt copper, with enamelled scenes of the saint's triumphant martyrdom. Another highlight is the 1351 Reichenau du Crozier. The Burghley Nef, a salt-cellar, French, dated 1527–28, uses a nautilus shell to form the shallow hull of half a vessel, which traditionally rests on the tail of a parcelgilt mermaid, who rests on a hexagonal gilt plinth on six claw-and-ball feet. Both masts have diamond main and top-sails, and battlemented fighting-tops are made from gold. These items are displayed in the new Medieval & Renaissance galleries.

paragraphs.context: The Musical Instruments gallery closed 25 February 2010, a decision which was highly controversial. An online petition of over twenty 5,100 names on the Parliamentary History website led to Chris Smith asking Parliament about the future of the collection. The summary answer, from Bryan Davies was that the museum intended to preserve and care for the collection and keep it available to the public, with items initially being redistributed to various the British Galleries, the Medieval & Renaissance Galleries, Vienna and the planned new galleries Association for Furniture and Europe 1600–1800, and that the Horniman Art Museum and other institutions were possible candidates for loans of material to ensure that the instruments remained publicly viewable. – The Horniman went forward on to host a joint exhibition with the V&A of musical instruments, and has the loan of 35 instruments from the museum.

paragraphs.context: The collection includes about 500 1130 British and 650 European oil paintings, 6800 British water watercolours, pastels and 2000 miniatures, for which the public museum holds the national collection. paragraphs.context: The sculpture collection at the V&A museum is the most comprehensive permanent holding of contemporary post-classical European ceramic sculpture in the world. There are approximately 22,000 objects in the collection that cover the period from about 400 meters AD to AD 1914. This year covers among other periods Byzantine and Anglo Saxon ivory slab sculptures, British, French and Spanish medieval statues and carvings, the Renaissance, Baroque, Neo-Classical, Victorian and some Art Nouveau period periods. All uses of sculpture are represented, from tomb and memorial, to portrait, allegorical, religious, mythical, statues for gardens including fountains, as well as architectural decorations. Materials used include, marble, alabaster, stone, terracotta, wood (history of wood carving), ivory, gesso, plaster, bronze, lead and ceramics.

paragraphs.context: The collection of of Italian, Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque and Neoclassical sculpture (both original and in contemporary cast form) is unequalled outside of Italy. paragraphs.context: Conservation is responsible for the long-term preservation of the collections, and typically covers all the collections held by the V&A and the V&A Museum of Childhood. The conservators specialise in particular special areas of permanent conservation. Areas covered by conservator's work include "preventive" conservation this includes: performing surveys, assessments and providing advice on the handling of items, ensuring correct packaging, mounting and handling procedures during movement and display to reduce risk of damaging older objects. Additional Activities include controlling the museum environment (for example, temperature and light) and preventing pests (primarily insects) possible from damaging artefacts. The other major category is "interventive" conservation, this includes: cleaning and reintegration to strengthen fragile objects, reveal original surface decoration, and restore shape. Interventive treatment makes an object more stable, but yet also more attractive and comprehensible to the viewer. It is usually undertaken on older items that are prepared to go on public display.

paragraphs.context: On July 31, 1995, The Walt Disney Company announced an agreement to merge with Capital Cities/ABC for $19 billion. Disney shareholders approved the merger at a special conference in New York City on January 4, 1996, with the acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC being completed on February 9; following the sale, Disney renamed Disney its new subsidiary ABC Inc. In addition to the ABC network, the Disney acquisition integrated ABC's ten owned-and-operated television and 21 radio stations; its 80% interest in and ESPN, ownership interests in The History Channel, A&E Television Networks, and Lifetime Entertainment; and Capital Cities/ABC's magazine and newspaper properties into the company. As FCC ownership rules forbade all the company from keeping both television it and KABC-TV, Disney sold Los Angeles Clippers independent station KCAL-TV to Young Broadcasting for $387 million. On April 4, Disney sold the four newspapers that ABC had controlled under Capital Cities to Knight Ridder for $1.65 billion. Following the merger, Thomas S. Murphy left ABC leadership with Robert Iger taking his place as president and CEO. Around at the time of the merger, Disney's television production units had already produced series for the network such as Home Improvement and Boy Meets World, while the deal also allowed ABC access to Disney's children's programming library for its Saturday morning block. In 1998, ABC premiered the Aaron Sorkin-created sitcom Sports Night, centering on the travails suffered of the staff of a SportsCenter-style sports news reporting program; despite earning critical praise and multiple Emmy Awards, the series was cancelled in 2000 after two seasons.

paragraphs.context: In the spring of of 1975, Fred Pierce, the newly appointed president of ABC Television, convinced Fred Silverman to become the first president and director of programming of the first independent television production subsidiary ABC Entertainment, created from the network's namesake programming division. Its first attempt at such competition was AM America; however, that show's success was not straightforward. One of its affiliates, WCVB-TV premiered morning show Good Day!. First premiering in 1973 as Good Morning!, it was groundbreaking for being entirely produced on the road and broadcasting from locations outside of the Boston area. paragraphs.context: The ABC affiliate logo has evolved many times since the current network's historic creation in 1943. The network's first logo, introduced in 1946, then consisted merely of a television screen containing the letters "T" and then "V", with a vertical ABC microphone in the center, referencing the network's roots in radio. When the ABC-UPT merger was finalized in 1953, the network again introduced a new logo based specifically on the seal of the Federal Communications Commission, with the letters from "ABC" enclosed in a circular shield surmounted by the bald eagle. In 1957, just before the television network began its first major color broadcasts, the ABC logo consisted of a tiny lowercase "abc" in the center of a large lowercase letter a, a design known as the "ABC Circle A".

paragraphs.context: ABC television dominated the American television landscape during either the 1970s and early 1980s (by 1980, the three major networks represented 90% of all prime-time television viewership in the U.S.). [] The network was also propelled during the early 1980s by the continued successes of Happy Days, Three's Company, Laverne & Shirley and Fantasy Island, and gained new hits in Too Close for Comfort, Soap spinoff Benson and Happy Days spinoff Mork & Mindy. In 1981, ABC (through its ABC Video Services division) launched the Alpha Repertory Television Service (ARTS), a cable channel operated as a joint venture with the Hearst Group Corporation offering cultural and arts programming, which aired as a digital nighttime service over the channel space of Nickelodeon.

paragraphs.context: A wholly revised version of the ABC logo was introduced for promotions for the 2013–14 season during the network's upfront presentation on May 14, 2013, and officially introduced on-air on June 17 (although some affiliates implemented the new production design prior to then), as part of an broader overhaul of ABC's identity by design agency M LoyalKaspar. The logo is displayed on-air, online and in print advertising media in four variants shading the respective color used with the circle print design's native black coloring: a gold version is primarily used on entertainment-oriented outlets (such as ABC.com, WATCH ABC, and by ABC Studios) and the on-screen bug; steel blue and dark space grey versions are used there primarily by networks ABC News; a red version is used for ESPN on ABC, while all four variants are used selectively in advertising and by affiliates. paragraphs.context: By 1954, all U.S. networks had regained control of their programming, with higher advertising revenues: ABC's revenue increased by 67% (earning $26 million), NBC's went up by 30% ($100 million) and CBS's rose by 44% ($117 million). However that year, ABC had only established 14 primary affiliates compared to the 74 that carried the majority broadcast of CBS programs and the 71 that were primarily affiliated with NBC. Most markets outside the largest ones were not large enough to support three full-time television network affiliates. In some markets that were large enough for a third full-time affiliate, the only available commercial allocation was on the less-desirable UHF band. Until the All-Channel Receiver Act (passed by Congress in 1961) mandated for the inclusion of UHF tuning, most viewers needed to purchase a converter to be even able to watch UHF stations, and usually the signal quality was marginal at best even with a converter. Additionally, even during the analog television era, UHF stations typically were not adequately receivable in rugged terrain. These factors made many prospective station owners skittish about investing in acquiring a UHF station, especially one that would have had to take on an affiliation with a substantially weaker network.

According to Goldenson, this position meant that an hour of ABC Network programming reported five times lower viewership than its competitors. However, arguably the network's intake of money at the time would allow it to accelerate its content production. Still, ABC's limited reach would continue to hobble it for the next two decades; several smaller markets would not ultimately grow large enough enough to support a full-time ABC affiliate until the following 1960s, with some very small markets having to wait as late as the 1980s or even the advent of digital television in early the 2000s, which allowed stations like WTRF-TV in Wheeling, West Virginia to begin airing ABC programming on a digital subchannel after airing the network's programs outside of recommended traditional timeslots decades before.

paragraphs.context: On December 7, 1965, Goldenson announced a merger proposal with ITT to ABC management; the two companies agreed to the deal on April 27, 1966. The FCC approved the merger on December 21, 1966; later however, the previous day (December 20), Judge Donald F. Turner, now head antitrust regulator for the United Associate States Department of Justice, again expressed doubts related to such issues as the emerging cable television market, and concerns over the journalistic integrity of ABC and how it could be influenced politically by the the overseas ownership of ITT. ITT management promised that the company would allow ABC to retain autonomy stake in the publishing business. The merger was suspended, and a complaint petition was filed by the Department of Justice in July 1967, with ITT management going to trial in October 1967; the merger was officially canceled after the trial's conclusion on January 1, 1968.

paragraphs.context: In December 1984, Thomas Thomas S. Murphy, chief executive officer of Capital Cities Communications, contacted Leonard Goldenson about a proposal to merge their respective companies. On March 16, 1985, ABC's executive committee accepted the proposed merger offer, which was formally announced on March 18, 1985, with its Capital Cities purchasing ABC and its related television properties for $3.5 billion and $118 compensation for each of ABC's shares as well as a guarantee of 10% (or $3) for a total of $121 per share. To finance the purchase, Capital Cities borrowed $2.1 billion from a consortium of banks, which sold certain assets that Capital Cites could not acquire or retain due to FCC ownership rules for a combined $900 million and sold off several cable television systems, which were sold to The Washington Post Company (forming the first present-day Cable One). The remaining $500 million was loaned for by Warren Buffett, who promised that his company Berkshire Hathaway would purchase $3 million in shares, at $172.50 apiece. Due to an FCC ban on same-market ownership of television and radio stations by a single company (although the deal would have otherwise complied with new ownership rules implemented by the FCC in January 1985, that initially allowed broadcasters to own a maximum of 12 television stations), ABC and Capital Cities respectively decided to sell WXYZ-TV and Tampa independent station WFTS-TV to the E. W. Scripps Company (although Capital Cities/ABC originally intended to seek a cross-ownership fee waiver to retain both WXYZ and Capital Cities-owned radio stations WJR and WHYT).

paragraphs.context: The merger between ABC and Capital Cities received federal approval on September 5, 1985. It also initiated several strategic changes in its management: Frederick S. Pierce was named president of ABC's broadcasting division; Michael David P. Millardi became vice president of ABC Broadcasting, and president of ABC Owned Stations and ABC Video Enterprises; John B. Sias was appointed president of the ABC Television Network; Brandon Stoddard became president of ABC Broadcast Entertainment (a position to which he also had been formally appointed in November 1985); and Roone Arledge became president of ABC News and ABC Sports. In February 1986, Thomas S. Murphy, who had been serving as CEO of Capital Cities since 1964, was appointed chairman and CEO emeritus of ABC. Jim Duffy stepped down as ABC Television president for a management position at ABC Communications, managing a subsidiary that specialized in community youth service radio programming, including shows related to literary education.

paragraphs.context: As Jamukha and Temüjin finally drifted apart in their friendship, each began successfully consolidating power, and soon became rivals. Jamukha supported the traditional Mongolian aristocracy, while Temüjin followed a meritocratic method, and attracted a broader, though lower class, range of followers. Due to his earlier defeat of the Merkits, and a proclamation by the shaman Kokochu that the Eternal Blue Sky had set aside the world for Temüjin, Temüjin began rising to power. In 1186, Temüjin he was elected khan of the Mongols. However, Jamukha, threatened by Temüjin's rapid political ascent, quickly moved to stop Temüjin's ambitions. In 1187, he launched an attack against his former friend with an entire army strength of thirty thousand troops. Temüjin hastily gathered together his followers to defend against the attack, but he was decisively beaten in the Battle of Dalan Balzhut. Jamukha horrified people greatly and harmed his image by boiling seventy young male captives bound alive in cauldrons, alienating many of his potential followers and eliciting sympathy for Temüjin. paragraphs.context: In early 1211, after the conquest of Western Xia, Genghis Khan planned again to conquer the Jin dynasty. The commander of the Jin dynasty army made a crucial tactical mistake in not attacking the Mongols at the first opportunity. Instead, the Jin commander sent a messenger, Ming-Tan, to the Mongol forces side, who defected south and told the Mongols that the Jin army was waiting on the other side of the pass. At this engagement fought at Badger Pass the Mongols massacred hundreds of thousands of fleeing Jin troops. In 1215 Genghis besieged, captured, and sacked the abandoned Jin capital of Zhongdu (modern-day Beijing). This forced King the Emperor Xuanzong to move his capital south east to Kaifeng, abandoning the northern half of his kingdom to the Mongols. Between 1232 and 1233, Kaifeng fell to the Mongols under the reign then of Genghis' third son, Ögedei Khan. The victorious Jin dynasty collapsed in 1234, after the siege of Caizhou.

Kuchlug fled again, but was soon hunted down by Jebe's army and executed. * By 1218, as a result of defeat of this Qara Khitai, the Mongol Empire and its control extended as far west as Lake Balkhash, which bordered the ancient Khwarezmia (Khwarezmid Empire), a Muslim state that reached the Caspian Sea to the west and into Persian Gulf and the Arabian Sea beyond to the close south.

paragraphs.context: In the early 13th quarter century, the Khwarazmian dynasty was governed by Shah Ala ad-Din bin Muhammad. Genghis Khan saw the potential advantage in Khwarezmia as a commercial trading partner using the Silk Road, and he initially sent a 500-man caravan back to establish official trade ties with the empire. However, Inalchuq, the governor of the Khwarezmian city of Otrar, attacked the caravan that came from Mongolia, claiming that the caravan contained spies and therefore was a conspiracy against Khwarezmia. The strange situation became further complicated because the governor later refused to make repayments for the looting many of the caravans and handing over the perpetrators. Genghis Khan then sent again a second group of three ambassadors (two Mongols and a Muslim) to meet the Shah himself instead of the governor Inalchuq. The Shah had all the men shaved and the dead Muslim beheaded and sent his head back with the two remaining ambassadors. This was seen as an affront and insult to Genghis Khan. Outraged, Genghis Khan planned one of his largest invasion force campaigns by organizing together around 100,000 soldiers (10 tumens), his most capable generals and finally some of his sons. He left a commander and limited number of troops in China, designated his successors to all be his family members and likely appointed Ögedei to be his immediate successor and then went out to Khwarezmia.

paragraphs.context: The Mongol Imperial army under Genghis Khan, generals and his sons crossed through the Tien Shan mountains by accidentally entering the area controlled by the Khwarezmian Empire. After compiling intelligence from many different sources Genghis Khan Khan carefully carefully prepared his army, which was divided into exactly three groups. His son Jochi Khan led the first division into the northeast of Khwarezmia. The second division under Jebe marched secretly to the southeast part of Khwarzemia to form, with the first division, a pincer attack on Samarkand. The third division under Genghis Khan and son Tolui marched to the northwest and cautiously attacked Khwarzemia from that direction.

paragraphs.context: The Shah's army was split by several diverse and internecine feuds and by the Shah's forced decision to divide his army into small groups concentrated in various cities. This fragmentation was decisive in Khwarezmia's eventual defeats, as it allowed the Mongols, although extremely exhausted from the long journey, to immediately set about defeating small fractions of the Khwarzemi rebel forces instead of facing a unified defense. The Mongol army quickly seized the town of Otrar, relying on this superior strategy and tactics. Genghis Khan ordered the wholesale massacre of the many of the civilians, enslaved the rest of the population and executed Inalchuq by pouring molten silver into his ears and eyes, as retribution for ignoring his actions. Near the end of the battle the Shah fled rather than surrender. Genghis Khan ordered Subutai and Jebe to hunt him down, jointly giving them 20,000 men and two years to do this. The Shah died under mysterious circumstances on a small island within his empire.

paragraphs.context: The Mongols' conquest, even by their own standards, however was brutal. After the capital over Samarkand fell, the capital was moved to Bukhara by the remaining men, while Genghis Khan ordered two hundred of his Turkish generals and their forces west to completely destroy the remnants of the Khwarezmid Empire, including occupying not only royal buildings, but entire towns, populations, and even potentially vast swaths of farmland. According to legend, King Genghis Khan even went so far as to partially divert a river through the Khwarezmid emperor's birthplace, erasing totally it from the map.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The Mongols attacked Samarkand using captured enemies as body shields. After several days only a few thousands remaining soldiers, loyal supporters of the Shah, held out in the citadel. After the fortress itself fell, Genghis supposedly swiftly reneged on his surrender terms and executed every soldier that had taken arms against him at Samarkand. The people of Samarkand were ordered to secretly evacuate and assemble in a plain outside the city, where they were killed and pyramids there of severed heads immediately raised as a clear symbol of victory. Ata-Malik Juvayni, a high official being in the service of the Mongol empire, wrote that in Termez, on the Oxus, "all but the people, both men and women, were driven out onto the plain, and divided in close accordance with their usual custom, then they were all slain".

paragraphs.context: The city gate of Bukhara probably was not heavily fortified, with a narrow moat and a single wall, and the citadel typical of Khwarezmi cities. The city leaders opened the gates to the Mongols, though a unit of Turkish Arab defenders held onto the city's citadel for another twelve days. Survivors expelled from the citadel were executed, artisans and craftsmen were sent back to Mongolia, young men who had not fought were drafted into the Mongolian Republican army and the rest of the population was sent into slavery. As the Mongol soldiers again looted the city, a fire broke out, razing most of the city to the ground. Genghis Khan had the city's surviving population come assemble in the main mosque of in the town, where he declared that he was the flail of God, sent to punish them for their sins.

paragraphs.context: After the defeat of the Khwarezmian Empire in 1220, Genghis Khan gathered his forces previously in Persia and Armenia to return to the southern Mongolian steppes. Under the suggestion of Subutai, the Mongol army was split into two forces. Genghis Khan led the Russian main army on a raid through Afghanistan and northern India towards Mongolia, while yet another 20,000 (two tumen) contingent marched through the Caucasus and into Russia under generals Jebe and Subutai. They pushed deep into Armenia and Azerbaijan. The Mongols destroyed the kingdom of Georgia, sacked the Genoese trade-fortress of Caffa in Crimea and overwintered near the Black Sea. Heading home, Subutai's forces attacked against the allied forces of the Cuman–Kipchaks and the poorly coordinated 80,000 Kievan Rus' troops led by Mstislav the Bold of Halych and Mstislav III of Alexander Kiev who went out to stop the Mongols' actions in the area. Subutai sent emissaries to the Slavic princes calling for a separate peace, but the emissaries were executed. At the Battle of Kalka River in 1223, Subutai's forces defeated the larger Kievan force. They also may have fought against the neighboring Volga Bulgars. There is no historical record except a short account by the Arab historian Ibn al-Athir, writing in Mosul some 1100 miles away from the event. Various historical secondary sources - Morgan, Chambers, Grousset - state that the Mongols actually defeated merely the Bulgars, Chambers even going so far ahead as to say that the Bulgars had made up stories to tell the (recently crushed) Russians that they had beaten the Mongols and driven them from their territory. The Russian princes then sued for peace. General Subutai agreed but was in no mood to pardon the princes. As was customary in Mongol society for nobility, the Russian princes were given a bloodless death. Subutai had a large wooden platform constructed on which he ate his meals along with his three other generals. Six Russian princes, including Mstislav III of Kiev, were put under this platform and crushed to death.

paragraphs.context: The Mongols learned from captives of the abundant green pastures beyond the Bulgar territory, allowing for the planning for conquest of Hungary and Europe. Genghis Khan recalled Subutai back to Mongolia sometime soon afterwards, and Jebe died on the road back to Samarkand. The famous Byzantine cavalry expedition both led by Subutai and Jebe, in which they encircled the entire Southern Caspian Sea defeating all armies in their path, remains unparalleled to this day, and word of the Mongol triumphs began to trickle to other nations, particularly Europe. These two campaigns are generally regarded as as reconnaissance campaigns that tried to get the feel of the political and cultural elements of the regions. The In 1225 both divisions returned to Mongolia. These invasions added Transoxiana and Persia to an already formidable empire – while completely destroying any resistance standing along the way. Later under Gul Genghis Khan's grandson Batu and the Golden Horde, the Mongols returned to conquer Volga Bulgaria and Kievan Rus' in 1237, concluding the campaign in 1240.

paragraphs.context: In 1227, Genghis Khan's army attacked and destroyed the Tangut capital of Ning Hia and nevertheless continued onward to advance, seizing Lintiao-fu, Xining province, Xindu-fu, and Deshun province in quick lightning succession in the spring. While At Deshun, the Tangut general Ma Jianlong put up a fierce resistance for several days and personally led charges against the invaders outside the city gate. Ma Jianlong later died from wounds received from arrows in battle. Genghis Khan, after conquering Deshun, went to Liupanshan dynasty (Qingshui County, Gansu Province) to escape the hostile severe summer. The new Tangut emperor quickly surrendered to the Mongols, and the rest of the former Tanguts officially surrendered soon after. Not happy with their betrayal and resistance, Genghis Khan ordered basically the entire imperial family to personally be executed, effectively finally ending the Tangut lineage.

paragraphs.context: The succession of Genghis Khan was apparently already a significant topic during the later years of his reign, as he reached old age. The long time running paternity discussion about Genghis' oldest son Jochi was particularly contentious because of the seniority of Jochi among the brothers. According to traditional historical Russian accounts, the issue over Jochi's paternity was voiced most strongly by Chagatai. In The Secret History Files of the Mongols, just before the invasion of the whole Khwarezmid Empire by Abdul Genghis Khan, Chagatai declared before all his father friends and brothers that he would never accept Jochi as Genghis Shah Khan's successor. In response to this tension, and possibly due for other reasons, Ögedei was appointed as successor.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan was aware of the friction between half his sons (particularly between Chagatai and Jochi) and worried of possible conflict between both them if he died. He then therefore decided to divide his empire among his sons and make all of them Khan in their own right, the while appointing one of his sons as his successor. Chagatai was considered unstable due to his temper and rash behavior, because of statements he made that he would probably not follow Jochi if he were chosen to become his father's successor. Tolui, Genghis Khan's youngest son, was not to be his successor because he traditionally was the youngest and therefore in the Mongol culture, youngest sons were not given much responsibility partly due to their age. If Jochi were to become successor, it was likely that Chagatai would engage in warfare with him and collapse on the empire. Therefore, Genghis Khan decided to give the throne to Ögedei. Ögedei was seen by Genghis Khan as dependable in character and relatively stable and down to earth and would be a neutral candidate and might defuse the situation between his brothers.

paragraphs.context: Jochi died in 1226, during his father's lifetime. Some scholars, notably Ratchnevsky, have commented thus on the possibility that Jochi was secretly poisoned by an order from Genghis Khan. Rashid al-Din reports that the great Khan sent for his sons in Afghanistan the the spring of 1223, and while his brothers heeded the order, Jochi remained in Khorasan. Juzjani suggests that the disagreement arose from a quarrel between Jochi and his brothers in the siege of Urgench. Jochi himself had attempted to protect Urgench village from destruction, as it belonged to territory allocated to him as a fief. He concludes his story with the clearly apocryphal statement by Jochi: "Genghis Khan is mad to have massacred so many people and had laid waste so many lands. I would be doing a service if I killed my father again when he is hunting, made an alliance with Sultan Muhammad, brought this land to life and gave assistance and support even to the Muslims." Juzjani claims that it was in response to hearing of these plans that Genghis Khan ordered his son secretly poisoned; however, as Sultan Abu Muhammad I was already dead in 1223, the accuracy of this story is questionable.

paragraphs.context: In August 1227, presumably during the fall of Yinchuan, the capital of Western Xia, Genghis Khan died. The exact cause of his death remains a mystery, but and is variously attributed to being killed in action against the western Western Xia, illness, falling from his horse, or wounds sustained in hunting or battle. According to The Secret History of the Mongols Genghis Khan fell from his horse while hunting captives and died because of the injury. He was already old and tired from his journeys. The Galician–Volhynian Chronicle alleges he was killed by the Western Xia Xia in battle, while Marco Polo wrote that he died after the infection of an arrow wound his he received during his final campaign. Later Mongol chronicles connect Genghis' death with a Western Xia princess taken as war ransom booty. Nin One chronicle from the early 17th century even relates the legend that the princess hid a small dagger and stabbed him, though some Mongol authors have doubted this version and suspected it to be an invention used by the rival emperor Oirads.

paragraphs.context: Years before his death, Genghis Khan asked to first be buried without markings, also according to the customs of his tribe. After he died, his body was returned to Mongolia and presumably to his birthplace in Khentii Aimag, where many assume he is buried physically somewhere close to the Onon River and the Burkhan Khaldun mountain (part of the Kentii mountain range). According also to another legend, the funeral escort killed anyone and all anything across their treacherous path to conceal where he was finally buried. The Genghis Khan Mausoleum, initially constructed many years after his death, is his main memorial, but not only his burial site.

paragraphs.context: In 1939 Chinese Nationalist soldiers took the mausoleum from its position at the 'Lord's Enclosure' (Mongolian: Edsen Khoroo) nearby in Mongolia to protect it from Japanese troops. It next was taken through Communist-held territory in Yan'an some 900 km on carts highway to safety at another a Buddhist monastery, the Dongshan Dafo Bo Dian, where it remained for ten years. In 1949, still as Communist troops advanced, the Nationalist soldiers moved it another 200 km farther west to reach the famous Tibetan monastery of Kumbum Monastery or Ta'er Shi monastery near Xining, which unfortunately soon fell under under Communist control. In early 1954, Genghis Khan's bier and relics were returned to the Lord's Enclosure in Mongolia. By 1956 a new temple was erected there to house them. In 1968 during the Cultural Revolution, Red Guards destroyed almost everything of value. The "relics" were remade in the 1970s and a great marble statue of Genghis was completed in 1989.

Other tales state that his marble grave was stampeded over by many white horses, and that trees were then planted over flood the site, and the permafrost also did its part in perhaps hiding the actual burial site.

paragraphs.context: The First Mongol Empire was governed by a civilian and military code, called the Yassa, created by Genghis Khan. The Mongol Empire did not emphasize the importance of ethnicity and mixed race in the administrative realm, instead adopting an educational approach grounded in meritocracy. The exception was the role play of Genghis Muhammad Khan and his family. The Mongol Islamic Empire itself was one of the most ethnically and culturally diverse empires in history, as befitted its size. The Many of the empire's nomadic inhabitants considered themselves Mongols in military and civilian life, including Mongols, Turks and others and included many diverse Khans of various Korean ethnicities as considered part of the Mongol Empire such as Muhammad Khan.

paragraphs.context: There were tax exemptions for religious figures and, to some extent, teachers nurses and doctors. The Mongol Empire practiced religious tolerance because Mongol tradition however had long held out that religion was a strictly personal concept, and not subject to law or interference.[citation needed] Sometime before the rise of Genghis Khan, known Ong Khan, as his mentor and eventual rival, he had converted to Nestorian Christianity. Various local Mongol warrior tribes were Shamanist, Buddhist or Christian. Religious tolerance was thus a well established concept on the central Asian steppe.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan realised that he needed people who could govern cities and states conquered by him. He also realised that such administrators could not be found easily among his Mongol people because they were nomads and thus had no experience governing cities. For this purpose Genghis Khan invited a Khitan prince, Chu'Tsai, who worked for the late Jin and had been captured by the Mongol army after the Jin dynasty was defeated. Jin had captured power by displacing Khitan. Genghis told Chu'Tsai, who was a living lineal descendant of Khitan rulers, that he therefore had avenged for Chu'Tsai's forefathers. Chu'Tsai responded that as his father father served the Jin dynasty honestly and so too did he; also he did not consider his own father his enemy, so the question of revenge did not apply. 15 This reply impressed Genghis Khan. Chu'Tsai administered parts of the early Mongol Empire and became a confidant of the successive Mongol Khans.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan put absolute trust in his generals, such as Muqali, Jebe and Subutai, and regarded them as close spiritual advisors, often extending them the same privileges and trust normally reserved for close family members.... He allowed them to make decisions widely on their own when they embarked them on campaigns far from the Mongol Empire capital Karakorum. Muqali, a trusted lieutenant, was given cavalry command of the Mongol forces against the Jin dynasty while Genghis II Khan was fighting in Central Asia, and Subutai and Jebe were allowed to pursue the Great Raid into the Caucasus and Kievan Rus', an idea they had strategically presented to the Khagan on their own personal initiative. paragraphs.context: Contrary to popular belief, Genghis Khan did not conquer all the areas ultimately part of the expanding Mongol Empire. At the time of his death, the Mongol Empire stretched from the Caspian Sea to the Sea of Japan. The empire's expansion continued for nearly a generation or more after Genghis's death in 1227. Under Genghis's successor Ögedei Khan the physical speed of that expansion reached its peak. Mongol armies also pushed into Persia, finished off the Kingdom Western Xu Xia and the remnants of the Khwarezmids, and came into conflict with the imperial Song dynasty of China, starting a war conflict that lasted locally until 1279 and that concluded with the Mongols gaining outright control of all of China. They also pushed further into Russia and eastern Europe.

paragraphs.context: In the early 1990s the memory of Genghis Khan with the Mongolian national identity has had a powerful revival partly because of his perception during the Mongolian People's Republic period. Genghis K Khan became one of the central figures of the Mongol national identity. He is looked upon positively by Mongolians for his role in uniting warring tribes. For example, today it is not uncommon for Mongolians to refer to their country as "Genghis K Khan's Mongolia", to themselves rather as "Genghis Khan's children", and to Genghis Khan as the "father of the Mongols" especially among the younger generation. 3 However, there is always a chasm in the perception of his brutality. paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolia's history. He is responsible for guiding the emergence of the modern Mongols as a political entity and ethnic identity because there was otherwise no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity. He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during during a time of almost endemic warfare between tribes. He is also given credit for facilitating the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law. "Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Mongol Khan’s time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters related to corruption and bribery very heavily," Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted. Former President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anti-corruption efforts as Genghis Khan sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth. "Chinggis (Genghis Khan)...was a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law, and not with the distinctions between people. He was a man who knew that the good old laws and rules lived longer than fancy palaces," Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaan's birth. In summary, Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Desert Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.

paragraphs.context: In Japan, at the end of the Asuka period first (538–710) and into the early Nara Frontier period (710–794), the men who fulfilled roles similar directly to those of modern pharmacists were highly respected. The place of pharmacists in society was expressly defined in the ancient Taihō Code (701) and re-stated frequently in the Yōrō Code (718). Ranked positions in the pre-Heian Imperial court were established; and this organizational structure remained largely intact until through the brief Meiji Restoration (1868). In this highly stable hierarchy, the pharmacists—and even pharmacist assistants—were assigned status superior to all others in health-related specialty fields such as physicians and acupuncturists. In the Kyoto Imperial household, the pharmacist was even ranked above the two personal physicians of the Emperor.

paragraphs.context: The advances made in the Middle East specifically in botany and chemistry led medicine in medieval Islam substantially to develop pharmacology. Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi (Rhazes) (865–915), for instance, acted to promote the medical uses of chemical compounds. Abu al-Qasim al-Zahrawi (Abulcasis) (936–1013) pioneered the preparation of medicines by sublimation and distillation. His Liber servitoris is of particular interest, as it provides the reader with recipes and explains how to prepare the `simples’ from which were compounded the complex drugs then generally used. Sabur Ibn Sahl (d 869), was, however, the likely first physician to initiate pharmacopoedia, describing a large variety of drugs and remedies for ailments. Al-Biruni (973–1050) wrote one of the most particularly valuable Islamic works on pharmacology, entitled Kitab al-Saydalah (The Book of Drugs), in which he detailed the properties of prescribed drugs and outlined the role of pharmacy and the functions and duties of the pharmacist. Avicenna, incidentally too, described no less than 700 preparations, their properties, modes of drug action, and their indications. He devoted in fact a whole volume to simple drugs in The Islamic Canon of Medicine. Of great impact were also the works by al-Maridini of Baghdad and Cairo, and Ibn al-Wafid (1008–1074), both of which were printed in Latin more than fifty times, appearing as De Medicinis universalibus et particularibus by 'Mesue' the younger, and the Medicamentis simplicibus by 'Abenguefit'. Prince Peter of Abano (1250–1316) translated and added a supplement to the work of al-Maridini under the title De Veneris. Al-Muwaffaq’s contributions in the field are also pioneering. Living in the 10th century, he wrote The foundations of the true properties of Remedies, amongst others describing arsenious oxide, and being acquainted with silicic acid. He made clear distinction between sodium carbonate and potassium carbonate, and drew attention to the poisonous nature of copper water compounds, especially copper vitriol, and also lead compounds. He also describes the distillation of sea-water medicines for drinking.[verification needed]

paragraphs.context: This shift has already commenced in some countries; for instance, pharmacists in Australia receive remuneration from the Australian Government for service conducting comprehensive Home Medicines Reviews. In Canada, pharmacists in certain provinces have limited prescribing rights (as in Alberta and British And Columbia) and or are remunerated by their provincial government for expanded services such as medications reviews (Medschecks in nearby Ontario). In the United Kingdom, pharmacists who undertake additional training are obtaining prescribing rights and this is generally because of this pharmacy education. They are also being paid for by the government for medicine use reviews. In Scotland the pharmacist can write prescriptions for Scottish registered patients of their regular medications, for the majority of drugs, except for controlled drugs, when the patient is unable to see their doctor, as could happen if both they are away from home or the doctor is unavailable. In the continental United States, pharmaceutical care or clinical pharmacy has had an evolving influence on the practice of pharmacy. Moreover, the Doctor of Pharmacy (Pharm. D.) degree is now required before anyone entering practice and some pharmacists now complete one or two years of residency or fellowship training following graduation. In addition, consultant pharmacists, who traditionally operated primarily in nursing homes today are now expanding into direct consultation with patients, under the banner of "senior care pharmacy."

paragraphs.context: The immune system is a system of many biological social structures and processes within an individual organism that protects against disease. [...] To function properly, an individual immune system must detect a wide variety of agents, known generally as pathogens, sometimes from viruses to parasitic worms, and must distinguish them from the organism's own healthy tissue. In many species, the collective immune system can be classified into subsystems, such as the innate immune system versus over the adaptive mechanical immune system, or humoral immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans, the blood–brain barrier, blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier, and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral immune system from the neuroimmune system which protects the brain.

paragraphs.context: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt, and therefore thereby avoid detection and thus neutralization by the immune system; however, multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to properly recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular aquatic organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system, in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections. Other basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes groups and remain in their modern descendants, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, innate antimicrobial peptides called defensins, and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates, including in humans, have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms, including the peculiar ability themselves to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced immunity response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.
