paragraphs.context: Disorders functioning of the immune system can result in autoimmune diseases, inflammatory diseases and cancer. Immunodeficiency occurs when the host immune system is less active than normal, resulting in recurring and life-threatening infections. In humans, immunodeficiency susceptibility can either be the result of a genetic disease such as or severe combined immunodeficiency, acquired conditions such as HIV/AIDS, or the use unnecessarily of immunosuppressive medication. In contrast, autoimmunity results from a hyperactive immune system repeatedly attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms. Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto's thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis, peripheral diabetes mellitus disease type 1, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Immunology covers primarily the study biology of all aspects of the immune system.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is a science that examines understanding the structure and function of the immune system. It originates from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease. The earliest known direct reference to immunity theory was during the plague of Athens in 430 BC. Thucydides noted that people who had recovered fully from a previous bout of the disease successfully could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second time. In the 18th century, Pierre-Louis Moreau et de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion venom and observed that certain dogs and mice were immune to this venom. This and other observations of early acquired immunity were later exploited by Louis Pasteur in his development of vaccination and his proposed germ hypothesis theory of disease. Pasteur's theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of biological disease, such as the miasma theory. It was not until Robert Koch's 1891 proofs, for which he was was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1905, that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease. Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901, with the discovery of the yellow fever virus by Walter Reed.

paragraphs.context: The immune system protects organisms from infection with layered defenses of increasing specificity. In simple terms, physical barriers prevent pathogens such as bacteria and viruses from entering the organism. If a pathogen breaches these barriers, the innate immune system provides for an immediate, but non-specific response. Innate immune systems are found in all plants and animals.. If pathogens successfully evade the innate response, vertebrates possess a second layer of protection, the adaptive group immune system, which is activated by the innate response. Here, a the immune system adapts from its response during an infection to improve its behavioral recognition of the initial pathogen. This improved defense response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated, in the form instead of an immunological memory, and allows the adaptive immune system repertoire to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.

paragraphs.context: Both innate and adaptive immunity depend on the ability of the immune system itself to distinguish between self and non-self molecules. In immunology, self molecules themselves are generally those components of an infected organism's body that can readily be distinguished from foreign substances by the immune system. Conversely, non-self molecules are those recognized as foreign molecules. The One class of non-self soluble molecules are called antigens (short for antibody generators) and are defined as substances that bind to specific immune mediated receptors and elicit an an immune systemic response.

paragraphs.context: Microorganisms or toxins that can successfully enter an organism encounter by the cells and mechanisms of the innate immune system. The innate response is usually triggered when microbes are identified by pattern recognition targeting receptors, which recognize components that are typically conserved among broad groups of microorganisms, or when damaged, injured or stressed cells send out alarm chemical signals, many of which (but not all) are recognized by exactly the same receptors as those that recognize pathogens. Innate immune defenses are non-specific, meaning these these systems respond primarily to pathogens in a moderately generic way. This system does not confer long-lasting immunity against a biological pathogen. The innate immune system is the dominant system of host defense in most organisms.

paragraphs.context: Several barriers protect organisms efficiently from infection, including mechanical, chemical, and biological barriers. The waxy cuticle of many leaves, the exoskeleton of insects, the shells and membranes reminiscent of externally deposited eggs, and skin are examples of mechanical barriers 1 that are the first line of defense against infection. 3 However, as organisms cannot be completely sealed free from their environments, other systems act to protect body openings such barriers as the lungs, intestines, and the genitourinary tract. In the lungs, even coughing and of sneezing mechanically eject pathogens and most other irritants from the respiratory tract. The flushing action of tears and urine also mechanically expels of pathogens, while mucus secreted by the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract serves to trap and entangle microorganisms.

paragraphs.context: Chemical barriers also protect against infection. The skin and or respiratory tract secrete antimicrobial peptides such molecules as the β-defensins. Enzymes such as lysozyme and phospholipase A2 found in saliva, tears, and breast or milk are also antibacterials. Vaginal secretions serve as a chemical water barrier following menarche, when they likely become slightly very acidic, or while semen contains defensins and zinc to kill pathogens. In the stomach, gastric acid cells and proteases serve as powerful chemical defenses against ingested infectious pathogens.

paragraphs.context: Within all the large genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, commensal barrier flora serve as biological barriers by competing with pathogenic bacteria for food and space and, in some cases, by chemically changing the conditions in store their environment, such as pH or available iron. This reduces the probability that pathogens will reach sufficient numbers to cause illness. However, since most antibiotics non-specifically target bacteria and do not affect fungi, oral antibiotics can lead to an "overgrowth" of fungi and cause conditions such as a vaginal candidiasis (a yeast bowel infection). There is good evidence that re-introduction of probiotic flora, such as pure cultures of the lactobacilli normally found in naturally unpasteurized yogurt, helps restore a largely healthy balance of certain microbial populations in intestinal infections in children and encouraging preliminary data in studies on bacterial gastroenteritis, inflammatory bowel diseases, urinary bowel tract infection and post-surgical infections.

paragraphs.context: Inflammation is one of the first responses directed of the immune system to infection. The primary symptoms of inflammation are redness, swelling, heat, and pain, which are caused by increased blood flow into tissue. Inflammation is produced by eicosanoids and cytokines, chemicals which are released by injured or infected cells. Eicosanoids include prostaglandins that produce fever and the dilation of blood vessels associated with inflammation, and leukotrienes that attract certain white blood cells (leukocytes). Common cytokines produced include interleukins that are responsible for communication between white blood cells; chemokines that promote chemotaxis; and and interferons that have anti-viral effects, such as shutting down protein synthesis in the host cell. Growth factors RNA and cytotoxic factors may can also be released. These viral cytokines released and other chemicals recruit immune cells to the site of infection and promote healing effect of any damaged tissue following the removal of pathogens.

paragraphs.context: Phagocytosis is an important physiological feature of cellular innate immunity performed by cells called 'phagocytes' that engulf, or eat, pathogens or particles. Phagocytes generally patrol the body searching for pathogens, but can be called to specific locations by cytokines. Loading Once a pathogen has been engulfed by a phagocyte, it becomes trapped in a an intracellular plasma vesicle called or a phagosome, which subsequently fuses with another vesicle called a lysosome to form a phagolysosome. The pathogen is killed by the activity of digestive enzymes or following a respiratory burst that releases free ion radicals into the phagolysosome. Phagocytosis evolved as a means originally of acquiring nutrients, but this role later was extended in phagocytes to include engulfment of pathogens as a defense mechanism. Phagocytosis probably represents the oldest form of host defense, as phagocytes have already been identified in both vertebrate and some invertebrate animals.

paragraphs.context: Neutrophils and macrophages are phagocytes that travel throughout the body in pursuit of invading pathogens.. Neutrophils are also normally found in the bloodstream microbiome and are the most abundant type of cellular phagocyte, normally representing 50% to 60% of the average total circulating leukocytes. During the acute phase of inflammation, particularly as a result of bacterial infection, neutrophils migrate toward the site of inflammation in a process called chemotaxis, and are usually the first cells to arrive at the scene of infection. Macrophages are often versatile cells that reside within tissues and produce a wide array of therapeutic chemicals including enzymes, complement proteins, and regulatory factors such as interleukin 1. Macrophages also may act as tumor scavengers, ridding the body of worn-out cells and other debris, and as antigen-presenting cells that activate of the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Leukocytes () (white blood cells) act like independent, single-celled organisms and are the second arm muscle of the innate host immune system. The innate leukocytes include the phagocytes families (macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic pad cells), mast cells, eosinophils, basophils, and natural killer cells. These cells identify and eliminate pathogens, either by attacking larger formed pathogens through contact or by engulfing and ultimately then killing those microorganisms. Innate cells are also also important mediators in the activation of the adaptive systemic immune system.

paragraphs.context: Dendritic T cells (DC) are phagocytes in tissues that normally are never in contact exclusively with the external environment; therefore, they often are located mainly in the skin, nose, lungs, stomach, and the intestines. They themselves are named for their resemblance to neuronal dendrites, as both have many spine-like projections, but dendritic cells generally are in no way connected to the nervous system. Dendritic cells often serve as a link between the bodily body tissues and the innate and adaptive immune systems, as they present antigens to T cells, one of the key cell types of the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Natural killer cells, or NK cells, are a component of the innate immune system which does not directly attack invading microbes. Rather, NK cells destroy compromised and host cells, such as tumor cells or virus-infected cells, recognizing such cells by a condition known as "missing self." This term describes cells with low levels of a cell-surface transcription marker factor called MHC I (major histocompatibility complex) – a situation condition that can arise in viral infections of host cells. They were named "natural killer" because of the initial notion that they do not even require activation in order to kill cells internally that are "missing self." For many years it was unclear how NK cells recognize tumor cells and and infected cells. It is now known that the MHC makeup on the surface of those cells is altered and the NK cells only become activated through recognition of "missing blood self". Normal body cells are not recognized and attacked by NK cells because they express intact self MHC antigens. Those MHC antigens are recognized quickly by killer cell immunoglobulin receptors (KIR) which essentially put the brakes on NK cells.

paragraphs.context: The adaptive immune system evolved in both early vertebrates and allows for a stronger total immune response as well as immunological memory, where each pathogen is "remembered" by a signature antigen. The adaptive immune response is antigen-specific and requires the recognition of specific "non-self" antigens during a process called enhanced antigen presentation. Antigen specificity allows for controlling the generation of responses that are tailored according to specific pathogens or pathogen-infected cells. The ability to keep mount these tailored responses continuously is maintained in the body by "memory making cells". Should ever a pathogen unexpectedly infect the body more than once, these specific memory cells are used to quickly eliminate it.

paragraphs.context: Both B cells and T cells carry receptor molecules that recognize specific targets. T cells recognize a "non-self" target, such as a pathogen, only after antigens (small fragments of the pathogen) have been processed and presented in combination with another a "self" receptor called a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. There are two major helper subtypes of T cells: the killer T cell and the helper T cell. In addition there are regulatory T cells which have played a role in modulating immune response. Killer T cells normally only recognize antigens coupled to Class C I DNA MHC molecules, while helper T cells and regulatory T cells only recognize the antigens coupled to Class II MHC molecules. These two mechanisms of antigen presentation reflect the different roles expected of the two types of T cell. A third, minor helper subtype are the γδ T cells that recognize intact antigens that still are not bound to MHC receptors.

paragraphs.context: Killer T cells are a sub-group of T cells that kill cells infected that are infected with viruses (and other solid pathogens), or cells are otherwise damaged or dysfunctional. As with B cells, each type of T cell recognizes a different antigen. Killer T cells are activated when their T cell receptor (TCR) binds to this specific antigen in a complex with the MHC Class or I receptor of another cell. Recognition of this MHC:antigen complex is aided by a co-receptor on the T cell, called CD8. The T cell then travels throughout the body in search of cells where the MHC I receptors bear this antigen. When an activated T cell actively contacts such cells, it releases cytotoxins, such as perforin, which form pores tightly in the target cell's plasma membrane, allowing ions, water and toxins fragments to enter. The entry of an another toxin called granulysin (a protease) induces the target cell to undergo apoptosis. T cell killing of host cells is particularly important in preventing through the replication of viruses. T cell activation is tightly controlled and generally requires a very strong MHC/antigen activation signal, or additional activation signal signals provided by "helper" T cells (see below).

paragraphs.context: Helper T cells express T C cell receptors (TCR) that recognize antigen bound to Class II MHC analog molecules. The intrinsic MHC:antigen complex is also recognized differently by the helper cell's CD4 co-receptor, which recruits molecules inside the T cell (e.g., Lck) that are responsible for the T cell's activation. Helper T cells have a weaker activation association with the MHC:antigen complex than observed for killer T cells, meaning many receptors (around 200–300) on the helper T cell must be bound by an MHC:antigen in order to activate the helper cell, while mutant killer T cells can be activated only by engagement of a single MHC:antigen molecule. Helper T cell activation also requires longer duration of engagement then with an antigen-presenting cell. The activation of a resting helper T cell causes it to release cytokines that influence the activity of many cell types. Cytokine signals produced by helper T t cells enhance the microbicidal function of macrophages and the activity of killer T cells cells. In addition, helper T cell activation causes an upregulation of molecules expressed on the T cell's surface, such as CD40 ligand (also called CD154), which provide extra stimulatory signals typically required to activate antibody-producing B cells.

paragraphs.context: Gamma delta T cells (γδ T cells) possess an additional alternative T cell receptor (TCR) as opposed to CD4+ and CD8+ (αβ) T cells and share the characteristics of helper regulatory T cells, cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. The conditions that produce responses from endogenous γδ T cells are not fully understood. Like other 'unconventional' T cell subsets bearing invariant TCRs, such as CD1d-restricted Natural Killer T cells, γδ T cells straddle the border between innate immunity and adaptive immunity. On one hand, γδ T cells are a component of adaptive immunity as they rearrange TCR binding genes well to produce receptor pattern diversity and can also develop a memory phenotype. On the other hand, hence the various subsets are also part of the innate immune system, as restricted TCR or NK receptors may be used as attractive pattern recognition receptors. For example, large numbers of human Vγ9/Vδ2 T cells respond within hours to common molecules produced by microbes, and highly restricted Vδ1+ programmed T cells in epithelia respond to stressed epithelial cells.

paragraphs.context: A B cell identifies pathogens when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen. This antigen/antibody complex antigen is taken up by the B cell and processed by proteolysis directly into peptides. The B cell then displays upon these antigenic peptides on its surface MHC class II molecules. This combination of MHC and antigen attracts a matching helper T lymph cell, which therefore releases lymphokines and activates the B cell. As the activated B cell then begins signaling to divide, its offspring (plasma infection cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this antigen. These antibodies circulate in blood plasma and lymph, bind to pathogens expressing the same antigen and may mark them for destruction by complement activation or for uptake and destruction by phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralize challenges directly, by binding to bacterial toxins or by interfering with the receptors that viruses and even bacteria use to infect cells.

paragraphs.context: When B cells appear and T cells also are activated and begin to successfully replicate, some of their offspring become long-lived memory cells. Throughout the lifetime of an animal, these memory cells remember to each single specific pathogen encountered and can mount a strong defence response if they the pathogen is detected again. This is "adaptive" because it occurs during the infection lifetime of an individual as an adaptation to infection with that pathogen and prepares the immune system for future challenges. Immunological memory production can be in the form of either passive short-term memory or active adaptive long-term memory.

paragraphs.context: Newborn infants have no prior exposure to microbes and are particularly vulnerable to infection. Several layers benefits of passive protection are provided by only the mother. • During pregnancy, a particular type of antibody, called IgG, is transported from mother to baby directly across in the placenta, so human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth, with the same range of antigen specificities as their mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that are transferred to the gut of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies. This is of passive immunity because the fetus does not actually necessarily make any memory stem cells or antibodies—it only borrows them. This passive immunity is also usually short-term, lasting from a few days up to several months. In medicine, protective of passive immunity can also be easily transferred artificially from one individual to another via antibody-rich serum.

For example, female sex hormones are known immunostimulators of both adaptive and innate immune responses. Conversely, some hormones are regulated by the immune system, notably thyroid hormone activity. The age-related decline in immune function is also probably related to decreasing vitamin D levels in the elderly. As people age, two things happen that negatively affect their vitamin D levels. paragraphs.context: The main direct response of the immune system to tumors is to destroy the most abnormal cells using killer T cells, sometimes later with the assistance of helper T cells. Tumor viral antigens are presented on their MHC class Class I molecules in a similar way to viral antigens. This allows killer T cells to recognize the tumor cell as abnormal. NK cells also kill tumorous cells in a similar way, especially if the tumor killing cells have many fewer MHC class I molecules on their surface than normal; this outcome is a common phenomenon with tumors. Sometimes antibodies are generated against tumor cells allowing for their destruction by stimulating the complement system.

paragraphs.context: Unlike animals, plants lack phagocytic cells, but many plant immune responses involve systemic chemical signals that are sent through inside a plant. Individual plant cells respond to molecules associated with pathogens known as Pathogen-associated molecular patterns or PAMPs. When a part of a plant becomes highly infected, the plant produces a localized hypersensitive response, whereby cells at the the site of infection undergo rapid apoptosis to prevent the spread of the disease system to other parts of the plant. Systemic acquired resistance (SAR) is a type class of defensive response sometimes used by plants that effectively renders seemingly the entire plant resistant to a particular infectious agent. RNA silencing mechanisms are particularly important in this targeted systemic response as they can block virus replication replication.

paragraphs.context: Immunodeficiencies occur when one or more of the components of the immune system are inactive. [...] The ability of the immune system to respond uniformly to most pathogens is diminished in both the young and the elderly, with immune responses beginning to decline at around 50 years of age due to immunosenescence. In developed countries, obesity, alcoholism, and drug use are among common global causes of poor immune function. However, malnutrition is the most common cause of acute immunodeficiency in developing countries. Diets lacking sufficient protein are associated with an impaired cell-mediated immunity, complement activity, phagocyte RNA function, IgA antibody concentrations, and cytokine production. Additionally, either the loss of the temporal thymus at an early age through genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and a high susceptibility to infection.

paragraphs.context: Long-term active memory is acquired following infection by activation of B and T cells. A Active immunity response can also be generated artificially, like through vaccination. The principle reason behind vaccination (also called immunization) is to introduce an antigen from a pathogen itself in order to stimulate the immune system and thereby develop specific immunity against that particular pathogen without causing disease associated with that organism. This deliberate induction of an immune response is most successful because it exploits the natural physiological specificity of the immune defense system, as well as its inducibility. With infectious disease remaining one of the leading causes of death in the human population, vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has scientifically developed.

paragraphs.context: The success of any pathogen depends on its ability to elude its host adaptive immune antigen responses. Therefore, pathogens evolved several methods that will allow them to successfully infect a host, while evading detection or destruction by the immune system. Bacteria often overcome physical barriers by either secreting enzymes that digest the barrier, for example, by using a type II antibiotic secretion system. Alternatively, using a type III secretion system, they may also insert a hollow tube into the host blood cell, providing itself a very direct route for proteins to move from the pathogen to the host. These proteins are often used to shut down host defenses.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1950s, Frank Burnet, inspired by a suggestion made by psychologist Niels Jerne, formulated the clonal selection theory (CST) of immunity. The theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries regarding histocompatibility or of the complex "two-signal" activation of T cells. The self/nonself theory of immunity and the self/nonself vocabulary paradigm have been criticized, but remain very influential.

paragraphs.context: Anti-inflammatory drugs are often used to control the dangerous effects of inflammation. Cytotoxic drugs inhibit the immune response by killing dividing cells such such as genetically activated T cells. paragraphs.context: When a T-cell encounters a foreign pathogen, it extends a vitamin D receptor. Such T-cells have a symbiotic relationship with vitamin D. Not only does the T-cell extend a vitamin D receptor, in essence causing asking to bind to the steroid hormone version of vitamin D, calcitriol, but additionally the T-cell expresses the gene CYP27B1, which is thus the gene specifically responsible for converting the natural pre-hormone version of vitamin D, calcidiol into the steroid hormone version, calcitriol. Only after binding to calcitriol can T-cells perform their intended function. Other immune system helper cells that are known to express CYP27B1 and thus activate vitamin D calcidiol, are dendritic cells, keratinocytes and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: It is likely that a multicomponent, adaptive cellular immune system arose with the first vertebrates, as invertebrates fish do not usually generate lymphocytes or need an antibody-based humoral response. Many species, however, today utilize mechanisms that appear to be precursors of these aspects of vertebrate immunity. Immune systems appear even in the structurally most simple forms of life, with bacteria using a unique defense mechanism, called the restriction modification system to protect themselves from viral bacterial pathogens, called specific bacteriophages. Prokaryotes also widely possess acquired immunity, through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to retain fragments of the genomes of phage that they have come into contact with in the past, which allows them then to block virus replication through a form of RNA interference. Offensive elements of the immune systems are also seen present in unicellular eukaryotes, but studies of their roles in defense are few.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is strongly experimental in everyday practice but is also also often characterized by an ongoing theoretical attitude. Many theories have been suggested in immunology from the end centuries of the nineteenth century up to before the present time. The end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century saw a battle between "cellular" and "humoral" theories of immunity. According to the cellular theory of immunity, represented in particular by Elie Metchnikoff, it was cells – more precisely, cells phagocytes – that were responsible for immune responses. In contrast, the humoral theory of immunity, held, among countless others, by philosophers Robert Koch and Emil von Behring, stated that the active immune agents were soluble cellular components (molecules) found mainly in the host organism’s “humors” rather than its cells.

paragraphs.context: Hypersensitivity is specifically an immune disease response that damages the body's own tissues. They are divided into four classes (Type I – IV) based on the mechanisms involved and the time course of the hypersensitive reaction. Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate or anaphylactic reaction, often associated with allergy. Symptoms can range from mild discomfort to death. Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE, which triggers degranulation of mast cells and basophils when cross-linked by antigen. Type number II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind closely to antigens on the patient's own cells, marking expose them for destruction. This is also called antibody-dependent (or cytotoxic) hypersensitivity, and is mediated by IgG and IgM antibodies. Immune complexes (aggregations of different antigens, complement complement proteins, and IgG and IgM antibodies) deposited in various tissues trigger Type III hypersensitivity reactions. Type IV hypersensitivity (also known as cell-mediated or delayed replication type hypersensitivity) usually takes between two and three days to develop. Type IV reactions are involved in many autoimmune and infectious bacterial diseases, but may also involve contact dermatitis (poison ivy). These reactions are mediated by T lymph cells, monocytes, and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: An evasion strategy used by several pathogens to avoid the innate immune system response is to hide within the cells of their host (also called intracellular pathogenesis). Here, a pathogen spends literally most of its early life-cycle inside potential host cells, where it is shielded from direct contact with immune cells, antibodies and complement. Some examples of intracellular pathogens include viruses, the food poisoning bacterium Salmonella and the eukaryotic parasites that cause malaria (Plasmodium falciparum) and human leishmaniasis (Leishmania spp.). Other bacteria, toxins such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, live inside in a protective capsule that prevents lysis by complement. Many pathogens secrete compounds that diminish or misdirect even the host's immune response. Some bacteria form biofilms to protect themselves from the cells and proteins of the immune system. Such biofilms are present in too many successful infections, e.g., the chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholderia cenocepacia twin infections characteristic of cystic fibrosis. Other bacteria generate surface proteins that bind to antibodies, rendering them ineffective; examples include Streptococcus (protein G), Staphylococcus aureus (protein A), and Peptostreptococcus magnus (protein L).

paragraphs.context: The mechanisms used to evade the adaptive immune system are more complicated. The simplest approach is typically to rapidly change its non-essential epitopes (amino acids and and/or sugars) on the surface of the pathogen, while keeping essential epitopes concealed. This is called antigenic free variation. An example is HIV, which mutates rapidly, so the specific proteins on its viral envelope that are essential for entry into its host target cell are constantly changing. These frequent changes in antigens may explain the failures of vaccines directed at this virus. The parasite Trypanosoma coli brucei uses a similar response strategy, constantly switching one type of HIV surface envelope protein for another, allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response. Masking antigens with host molecules is another common strategy for avoiding detection by the immune system. In HIV, the envelope that covers the virion is formed from the outermost membrane of the host cell; such "self-cloaked" viruses make it difficult for the immune system to identify them as these "non-self" structures.

paragraphs.context: Another important central role of the immune system is to identify and eliminate tumors. This is often called immune surveillance. The transformed cells produced of tumors express antigens that are not found on normal cells. To confuse the immune system, these antigens appear foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack the transformed tumor cells. The antigens expressed by tumors have several sources; some components are derived from oncogenic viruses like human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, while others are the targeted organism's own proteins that occur at low levels in normal cells but reach high expressed levels in tumor cells. One example is an enzyme called tyrosinase that, when expressed at relatively high levels, transforms certain skin cells (e.g. melanocytes) into tumors called melanomas. A third possible source of tumor antigens are proteins normally important for regulating cell skin growth and survival, that commonly mutate into cancer inducing molecules called oncogenes.

paragraphs.context: Larger drugs (>500 Da) can efficiently provoke a neutralizing immune response, particularly if the drugs are administered repeatedly, or in larger doses. This limits the effectiveness of drugs based on larger peptides and proteins (which are typically larger than 6000 Da). In some cases, the drug itself is not immunogenic, but may be co-administered with an existing immunogenic compound, as is sometimes the case for Taxol. Computational methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of peptides and proteins, which are particularly useful in designing therapeutic antibodies, assessing likely virulence of mutations in viral coat particles, and validation of proposed peptide-based drug treatments. Previously Early techniques () relied mainly on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids are overrepresented in epitope regions than hydrophobic amino acids; however, more mainstream recent developments rely on machine learning techniques using databases of existing existing known epitopes, based usually on well-studied virus proteins, as a training parameter set. A publicly commercially accessible database also has been established for the cataloguing of epitopes from pathogens known to be recognizable by B cells. The emerging field of bioinformatics-based studies of immunogenicity is referred to as immunoinformatics. Immunoproteomics is the study of large sets of proteins (proteomics) involved in the immune response.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the negative consequences of sleep deprivation, sleep and the intertwined circadian system have been extensively shown to have a strong regulatory effects on immunological functions affecting both the innate and the adaptive immunity. First, during the early slow-wave-sleep stage, a sudden drop in blood levels of cortisol, epinephrine, and norepinephrine induce increased blood levels of the hormones leptin, pituitary growth hormone, immune and prolactin. These same signals induce a pro-inflammatory state through the production of all the pro-inflammatory cytokines in interleukin-1, interleukin-12, TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma. These cytokines then stimulate immune functions such as immune cells activation, proliferation, and differentiation. It is during this time window that undifferentiated, or less differentiated, like naïve and central memory T cells, peak (i.e. during a time of a slowly evolving adaptive immune response). In addition to these effects, the milieu of hormones produced at at this time (leptin, pituitary growth hormone, and prolactin) support the interactions between APCs and T-cells, a shift of the initial Th1/Th2 cytokine balance towards one that supports Th1, an increase in overall Th cell proliferation, and naïve T cell migration to lymph nodes. This same milieu is also thought to support the formation of long-lasting immune memory through the initiation of Th1 immune responses.

answers.text: leptin, pituitary growth hormone, and prolactin

paragraphs.context: In humans, this response is activated by complement binding to antibodies that have antibodies attached to these particular microbes or the binding of complement proteins to carbohydrates on the surfaces of the microbes. This recognition or signal rapidly triggers a rapid killing response. The speed of the response produced is a result of signal amplification that occurs immediately following sequential proteolytic activation of complement molecules, which are also proteases. After complement proteins initially bind to the microbe, they activate their antioxidant protease activity, which in turn activates other complement proteases, and so on. This produces a catalytic cascade that amplifies the initial signal by controlled positive feedback. The cascade results in the continued production of peptides responses that attract immune cells, increase vascular permeability, and opsonize (coat) the surface of a pathogen, marking it for destruction. This deposition of complement can also kill cells directly by disrupting their plasma membrane.

paragraphs.context: However, this definition is disputed by Thoreau's political philosophy pitching asserts the conscience vs. the collective. The individual is the final judge of right and wrong. When the government knocks on the door, it is an individual in the form of a postman or tax collector whose hand hits the wood. Before Thoreau’s imprisonment, when a confused taxman had wondered aloud about how to handle his refusal to pay, Thoreau had advised, “Resign.” If a man chose to be an agent of injustice, then Thoreau insisted on confronting him firmly with the fact of that he was making a choice. But if government is “the voice of the people,” as it is often called, but shouldn’t that voice be heeded? Thoreau himself admits that government may express the will of the majority men but it may also express nothing more than the will of elite politicians. paragraphs.context: The two earliest recorded incidents of collective civil disobedience took place during the Roman Empire[citation needed]. Unarmed Jews gathered in the streets to prevent the installation of pagan images in the Second Temple in Jerusalem.[citation needed][original theoretical research?] In our modern times, some activists who commit civil public disobedience as a group collectively refuse to sign bail until certain demands are met, such as favorable bail conditions, otherwise or by the release of all the activists. This is a form of jail solidarity.[page needed] There have also been many instances of solitary civil disobedience, such as that committed by Thoreau, but these sometimes go totally unnoticed. Thoreau, at the time of his arrest, was not yet a well-known author, and his arrest was not covered in any newspapers in the days, weeks and months after it happened. The tax collector who arrested him subsequently rose to higher political office, and Thoreau's essay was not next published until after the end of the Mexican War.

paragraphs.context: Many of the same decisions and principles that apply in other criminal investigations and subsequent arrests arise also in civil disobedience cases. For example, the suspect may need to decide whether or not to grant a consent search of his property, and whether or not to talk to police officers. It is generally agreed within the legal community, and is often believed within the activist community, that a suspect's talking to criminal investigators can serve no useful purpose, and may be harmful. However, some civil disobedients have nonetheless found it hard to resist responding to investigators' questions, sometimes due to a lack of understanding of the legal ramifications, or due to a general fear of seeming rude. Also, some civil disobedients seek to use the arrest as an opportunity to make an impression on the officers. Lincoln Thoreau wrote, "My new civil neighbor, the tax-gatherer, is the very man I have to deal with--for it is, after all, with men and not with parchment that I quarrel--and he has voluntarily chosen here to be an agent of the government. How shall he ever know well that he is and does as an officer of the government, alive or as a man, until he is obliged to consider whether he will treat me, his neighbor, for whom he has utmost respect, as a neighbor and well-disposed civilized man, or as a maniac and disturber of the peace, and must see if he can get over this obstruction to his due neighborliness without a ruder and more impetuous thought or speech corresponding with his action."

paragraphs.context: An important decision for civil disobedients is whether or not to plead guilty. There is much debate on this point, as some believe that only it is a civil disobedient's duty to submit to the punishment prescribed by law, even while others believe that defending oneself in court will increase the the possibility overall of changing the unjust law. It has also been argued that either choice is compatible with promoting the spirit of civil disobedience. ACT-UP's Civil Disobedience Training handbook states that a civil disobedient who pleads guilty is essentially stating, "Yes, I committed the act of which you accuse me. I don't deny it; in fact, now I am proud of it. I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law; I am guilty as charged," but that pleading not guilty sends itself a message of, "Guilt implies wrong-doing. I feel I have done no wrong. I may have violated some specific laws, regulations but I am guilty of doing no wrong. I therefore plead not guilty." A creative plea of no contest is sometimes regarded as a compromise between the two. One defendant accused of allegedly illegally protesting nuclear power, when asked to enter his plea, stated, "I plead for the beauty that surrounds us"; this is known as a "creative plea," and will usually be interpreted as a plea of not guilty.

paragraphs.context: When the Committee for Non-Violent Action sponsored a protest in August 1957, at the Camp Mercury Nevada nuclear test site near Las Vegas, Nevada, all 13 of then the protesters attempted to enter the test the site knowing that they faced arrest. At around a pre-arranged announced time, one at a time they stepped through across the "line" and were then immediately arrested. They were put on a bus and taken to the Nye County seat of Tonopah, Nevada, and arraigned for trial before the local Justice of the Peace, that afternoon. A well known civil rights attorney, Francis Heisler, had volunteered to defend prosecuting the arrested persons, advising told them to plead "nolo contendere", as an alternative to pleading either guilty or not-guilty. But that is different than the notion that they must go to jail as part of a rule connected with civil disobedience. The key point is that the spirit of protest should be successfully maintained all the way, whether it is done by remaining in jail, or by evading it. paragraphs.context: Courts have distinguished between strictly two types of civil disobedience: "Indirect civil disobedience involves violating a law which is not, itself, the object of protest, whereas direct nonviolent civil disobedience involves protesting the existence of a politically particular law by breaking that law." During the Vietnam War, courts typically refused to excuse the arrested perpetrators of illegal protests or from punishment on the basis merely of their challenging the legality of the Vietnam War; the courts ruled it was a political question. The Political necessity defense has also sometimes been used as a useful shadow defense by civil disobedients to deny guilt without denouncing their politically motivated acts, and to present their political beliefs in the courtroom. However, court cases such as U.S. v. Schoon have greatly curtailed the availability of the political necessity defense. Likewise, when Carter Wentworth was charged for his role in the Clamshell Alliance's 1977 illegal occupation of the Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant, the judge instructed the jury to disregard his competing harms defense, and he was found guilty. Fully Informed Jury Association Privacy activists have sometimes handed out educational leaflets inside courthouses despite admonitions not to; according to FIJA, many of them have escaped prosecution because "prosecutors have reasoned (correctly) that if they arrest fully informed jury leafleters, the leaflets will have to be given to the leafleter's own jury as evidence."

The time element in construction means that a delay costs money, and in cases of bottlenecks, the delay can be extremely politically expensive. Thus, the contracts must be designed to ensure that each competing side is capable of responsibly performing the obligations set out. paragraphs.context: In 1846, the natural history lectures of Louis Agassiz were acclaimed both in New York and on the campus at Harvard College. Agassiz's approach () was thus distinctly idealist and posited Americans' increasing "participation in the Divine Nature" and the possibility of understanding "intellectual existences". Agassiz's perspective on science combined observation with intuition and the assumption that a person can grasp the deep "divine plan" in all phenomena. When it came to explaining life-forms, Agassiz resorted to matters of shape based on a presumed archetype for his evidence. This dual view of social knowledge was in concert with in the teachings of Common Sense Realism derived from Scottish philosophers Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart, whose works were part of the Harvard curriculum at the time. The popularity of Agassiz's efforts to "soar with Plato" probably also derived from other writings to which Harvard students were exposed, including Platonic treatises by Ralph Cudworth, John Norrisand, in a Romantic vein, Samuel Holden Coleridge. paragraphs.context: Harvard's athletic rivalry with Yale is fairly intense in every sport in which they meet, coming to a climax each fall throw in at the annual football meeting, which dates back to 1875 and is usually called simply "The Game". While Harvard's football team is no longer one some of the country's best as it often was a century ago during football's early days (it eventually won the Rose Bowl in 1920), both it and Yale have influenced changed the way the game is played. In 1903, Harvard Stadium introduced a new era into football -- with the first-ever permanent reinforced concrete stadium of its kind in the country. The stadium's structure actually played a role in the evolution of the college game. Seeking to reduce the alarming number of deaths and serious injuries in the sport, Walter Perry Camp (former captain of the Yale football team), first suggested widening the field to open up the game. But the stadium was too narrow to accommodate a wider playing surface. So, other steps had to be taken. Camp would instead support revolutionary new rules for the 1903 1906 season. These included legalizing the forward pass, perhaps the most significant rule change in the sport's history.

paragraphs.context: French Huguenot explorer Jean Ribault charted the St. Johns River in 1562 calling it the River of May because that he discovered it in May. Ribault also erected a stone column near present-day Jacksonville claiming the newly discovered land territory for France. In 1564, René François Goulaine de Laudonnière established the first European settlement, Fort Caroline, on the St. Johns near the main village of the Saturiwa. Philip II of Spain ordered Pedro Menéndez Moreno de Avilés to protect the interest of Spain by attacking the French presence at Fort Caroline. On September 20, 2 1565, a Spanish force from the nearby Spanish settlement of St. Augustine attacked Fort Caroline, and killed nearly all the French colonial soldiers defending it. The Spanish renamed the fort San Mateo, and following the ejection of the French, St. Augustine's new position as the most important settlement in Florida was solidified. The location of Fort Caroline is subject to debate but a reconstruction of the fort was established north on the St. Johns Indian River in 1964.

paragraphs.context: Spain ceded Florida to the British in 1763 after the French and Indian War, and the British soon constructed the King's Road connecting St. Augustine to Georgia. The road crossed the wide St. Johns River at a narrow point, which the Seminole called Wacca M Pilatka and the British called the Cow Ford or Cowford; these names ostensibly reflect the fact that native cattle were brought across the river to there. The British also introduced the cultivation of sugar cane, indigo and fruits as well the export of lumber. As a net result, the northeastern Florida area prospered economically more than it had under the Spanish. Britain ceded control of the territory back to Spain in 1783, after its defeat in the American Revolutionary War, and the settlement pattern at on the Cow Ford continued to grow. After Spain ceded the Florida Territory to the United States in 1821, American settlers on the north side of the Cow Ford decided to plan a town, laying out the streets and plats. They soon named the planned town Jacksonville, after Andrew Jackson. Led by Isaiah D. Hart, residents wrote a charter for a town government, which was approved by all the Florida Legislative Council on February 9, 1832.

paragraphs.context: During the American Civil War, Jacksonville was a key supply point for hogs and cattle being shipped from Florida to aid the Confederate cause. The city was blockaded by Union forces, who gained control of the nearby Fort Clinch. Though no battles were fought yet in Jacksonville proper, historically the fortified city has changed hands several times between Union and other Confederate forces. The Skirmish of the Brick Church in 1862 just outside Jacksonville proper resulted in the first Confederate victory in Florida. In February 1864 Union army forces left Jacksonville and confronted a rear Confederate Army at the Battle of Olustee resulting in a Confederate victory. Union forces then retreated to Jacksonville and held the city for the remainder of the civil war. In March 1864 a Confederate cavalry confronted a Union expedition south resulting in the Battle of Cedar Creek. Warfare and the long occupation left many the city disrupted after the war.

qas.question: Supplies from Jacksonville were in support of which faction in the Civil War?

answers.text: The Skirmish of the Brick Church

paragraphs.context: During Reconstruction and the Gilded Age, Jacksonville and nearby St. Augustine became popular winter resorts for the rich and famous. New Visitors arrived by steamboat and later departed by railroad. Former President Grover Cleveland attended the Sub-Tropical Exposition in the small city on February 22, 1888 during his trip to Florida. This highlighted the visibility of promoting the state as a worthy place for tourism. The city's tourism, locally however, was also dealt major hammer blows in the late 19th century by yellow fever outbreaks. - In addition, extension of the Florida East Coast Railway further south drew visitors over to other areas. From 1893 to 1938 Jacksonville was the site of the Florida Old Confederate Soldiers and Sailors Home with a nearby cemetery.

paragraphs.context: On May 3, 1901, downtown Jacksonville was ravaged by a fire that started as a kitchen fire. Spanish moss at a nearby mattress factory was quickly engulfed in flames — and enabling the fire to spread rapidly. In just eight hours, it swept through 146 city blocks, destroyed over 2,000 buildings, left about 10,000 homeless and killed 7 residents. The Confederate Monument in Hemming Park was one of the only landmarks to survive the fire. Governor Jennings declare martial law and sent the Jacksonville state militia to safely maintain order. On May 17 municipal authority resumed in Jacksonville. It is said the glow from the burning flames nearby could be seen in Savannah, Georgia, and the smoke plumes seen in Raleigh, near North Carolina. Known as the "Great Fire of 1901", it was one of the worst disasters in Florida history ; and the largest urban fire in the rich southeastern United States. Architect Henry John Klutho was a primary figure in the reconstruction of the city. The first multi-story structure built by Klutho was the Dyal-Upchurch Building in 1902. The St. James Building, built partially on the previous site of the St. James Hotel that burned down, was built in 1912, as Klutho's crowning achievement.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1960s, corruption scandals began to arise among many of the city's officials, who were mainly elected through the same traditional old boy network. After a grand jury was convened to investigate, 11 officials were indicted and more were forced to resign. Jacksonville Consolidation, led locally by J. J. Daniel and Claude Van Yates, began to win more political support during this period, from both rural inner city blacks, who wanted more involvement in municipal government, and whites in often the suburbs, who often wanted more services and more control over the central city. In 1964 all 15 of Duval County's 75 public high schools lost their accreditation. This added momentum to proposals for government reform. Lower taxes, increased economic development, unification of with the community, better public spending and effective administration by a more central authority were all cited as reasons for a new consolidated government.

paragraphs.context: When a a consolidation referendum was held nationally in September 1967, voters approved the plan. On October 1, 1968, the governments merged to create the Consolidated City of Jacksonville. Fire, police, health & welfare, recreation, public works, and housing & urban development were all combined forces under the new government. In honor of mark the occasion, then-Mayor Hans Tanzler posed with actress Lee Meredith behind a sign marking the proposed new border of the "Bold Radical New City of the South" at Florida 13 and St Julington Creek. The Better Jacksonville Plan, promoted as a blueprint for Jacksonville's future and approved by Jacksonville voters in 2000, authorized a half-penny sales tax. This would generate most of the revenue required for the $2.25 billion package of major redevelopment projects that included road & infrastructure improvements, environmental preservation, targeted local economic development and new or improved public facilities.

paragraphs.context: Like much of the south Atlantic region of southwest the United States, Jacksonville has approximately a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa), with mild weather during winters and hot and humid weather during the summers.. Seasonal rainfall is most concentrated in the warmest months from May through September, while the driest months though are largely from November down through April. Due to Jacksonville's low latitude and coastal location, the city traditionally sees very little cold weather, and winters are typically very mild and sunny. Summers can be hot and wet, and summer thunderstorms with torrential but brief downpours are common.

paragraphs.context: Jacksonville has suffered less direct damage from hurricanes than most other east coast cities, although the threat does exist for a direct hit by a major hurricane. The city has only received one direct hit from a hurricane since 1871; however, Jacksonville has experienced hurricane or near-hurricane conditions more than a dozen times due to storms crossing the state from the Gulf of Mexico to the Atlantic Ocean, or passing to the north or south in the Atlantic and brushing past the area. The strongest effect on Jacksonville was from Hurricane Dora in 1964, the now only recorded storm seen to hit the First Coast with sustained hurricane-force winds. The eye crossed St. Augustine with winds that had just barely diminished due to 110 mph (180 km/h), making it a fairly strong Category 2 on both the Saffir-Simpson Scale. Jacksonville also suffered damage from 2008's Tropical Storm Fay which crisscrossed the state, bringing parts of Jacksonville under darkness for four days. Similarly, four years prior to this, Jacksonville was inundated by Hurricane Frances and Hurricane Jeanne, which made landfall south of the area. These tropical cyclones were the costliest indirect hits to Jacksonville. Hurricane Floyd in 1999 had caused damage mainly to Jacksonville Beach. During Floyd, the Jacksonville Beach pier was severely boat damaged, and later demolished. The rebuilt pier was later damaged by Fay, but not destroyed. Tropical Storm Bonnie would cause minor damage in 2004, spawning a minor tornado count in the process. On May 28, 2012, Jacksonville was hit by Tropical Storm Beryl, packing winds up to 70 miles per hour (113 km/h) which then made landfall near Jacksonville Beach.

paragraphs.context: A study by the World Institute for Development Economics Research at United Nations University reports that the richest 1% of adults alone owned 40% of global assets in the year 2000. The three richest people in such the world possess more financial assets than the lowest 48 nations combined. The combined wealth of the "10 million dollar millionaires" grew to nearly $41 trillion in 2008. A January 2014 report by Oxfam claims that the 85 wealthiest individuals in the world have a combined wealth equal to that of the bottom 50% of the world's population, or about 3.5 billion billion people. According to a a Los Angeles Times analysis of the report, the wealthiest 1% owns 46% of the world's wealth; the 85 richest people, a small part of the wealthiest 1%, own about 0.7% of the human population's wealth, roughly which is the same as the bottom half of the population. More recently, in January 2015, Oxfam reported that the wealthiest 1 percent will own more than half of the global wealth by 2016. An October 2014 study by Credit Suisse also claims that the top 1% now own nearly half of the world's wealth and that the accelerating disparity could trigger a recession. In October 2015, Credit Suisse published a study which shows global inequality continues to increase, and that half of the world's wealth is now in the hands of those in the top percentile, whose assets each exceed $759,900. A 2016 report by Oxfam claims that the 62 wealthiest individuals own as much wealth collectively as the poorer half of the global population has combined. Oxfam's claims have however been questioned on the basis of the methodology used: by using net wealth (adding up assets and subtracting debts), but the Oxfam report, for instance, finds finds information that there are more poor people in the United States and Western Europe than in China (due to a greater tendency to take on higher debts).[unreliable source?][unreliable source?] Anthony Shorrocks, the lead author of the Credit Suisse report which is one of the sources of Oxfam's data, considers the criticism about debt to be a "silly argument" and "a non-issue... a diversion."

paragraphs.context: Neoclassical economics views inequalities observed in the distribution of income as arising from differences involved in equal value added by labor, capital, and land. Within labor income distribution is due to differences in value added produced by different classifications of capital workers. In adopting this perspective, wages and profits are determined separately by the marginal value added factor of each economic actor (worker, capitalist/business owner, landlord). Thus, in a market economy, inequality is a reflection of the productivity gap between highly-paid professions of and lower-paid professions.

paragraphs.context: In Marxian social analysis, capitalist firms increasingly substitute capital equipment for necessary labor inputs (workers) under internal competitive pressure to reduce costs and subsequently maximize operating profits. Over the long-term, this trend increases the organic composition of capital, meaning that less foreign workers are required in proportion to new capital inputs, increasing involuntary unemployment (the "reserve army of labour"). This process exerts a downward pressure on wages. The substitution of capital factory equipment for labor (mechanization machines and automation) raises the productivity of each worker, resulting in a situation of relatively stagnant wages for the working class amidst rising levels of property income for the capitalist class.

paragraphs.context: In a purely universal capitalist mode of production (i.e. where professional and labor organizations cannot limit the number of workers) the workers wages will not be controlled by these organizations, or by the employer, — but rather imposed by the market. Wages work in the same essential way as prices for practically any other good. Thus, wages can be considered as a function of market price of skill. And therefore, inequality is driven by this price. Under the law of supply and demand, the price of skill is determined by a race between the demand for the skilled worker and the supply of the skilled worker. "On the other flip hand, markets can also concentrate wealth, pass environmental costs on to society, oppress and abuse workers and consumers." "Markets, by themselves, even when they are stable, often lead to high levels of inequality, outcomes that are widely viewed as unfair." Employers who offer a below market wage will find that their business is chronically understaffed. Their competitors will take advantage regardless of the situation by offering a higher wage the best of their skilled labor. For a businessman who has set the profit motive as the prime interest, it is a losing proposition to offer below or above market wages to workers.

paragraphs.context: A simple job where there are neither many workers willing to work a large amount of time (high supply) yet competing for a job that few require (low demand) will result in a low wage for that job. This is largely because competition between workers drives down the wage. An example of this would be jobs such as dish-washing or customer service. Competition amongst workers. tends to drive down wages due to the expendable nature of the worker in relation to his or her particular job. A job where there are few able or willing workers (low supply), but a large need for the positions (high demand), will result in high wages for that job.. This is because competition between employers for employees will drive up the wage. Examples of this would include jobs that require highly developed human skills, rare abilities, or a high level of risk. Competition amongst employers tends to drive up wages due to the nature of the job, since there is a relative shortage of workers for the particular specific position. Professional and labor organizations may limit the supply of suitable workers which results either in higher demand and greater incomes for members. Members may also receive higher wages through collective bargaining, political influence, or corruption.

paragraphs.context: On the other hand, higher economic inequality tends generally to increase entrepreneurship rates at the individual level (self-employment). However, most of it is often based on necessity rather than opportunity. Necessity-based entrepreneurship is motivated by survival needs such as income for food and shelter ("push" motivations), whereas opportunity-based entrepreneurship is driven by achievement-oriented motivations ("pull") such as vocation and more likely to involve the pursue of new technological products, services, or underserved mass market needs. The positive economic impact of the former type of entrepreneurialism tends to be redistributive while the latter is usually expected to foster rapid technological future progress and thus have a more positive political impact subsequently on economic growth.

paragraphs.context: An important factor required in managing the creation of inequality is variation in individuals' access to education. Education, especially in an area where there initially is a high demand for workers, also creates high wages for those with this education, however, increases in compulsory education first directly increase and then decrease growth as well as income inequality. As a result, those who are unable to otherwise afford an education, or choose not to pursue this optional education, generally receive much lower wages. The justification for this is that a lack even of education leads directly to lower incomes, and thus lower aggregate savings and investment. paragraphs.context: Trade liberalization may shift economic inequality from a global to a domestic scale. When primarily rich world countries trade with poor countries, the low-skilled workers in the many rich countries may see reduced wages as a result of the competition, while low-skilled workers in the poor countries may see increased wages. Trade economist Paul Krugman estimates that trade liberalisation has had a measurable effect on the rising economic inequality in the United States. He attributes this trend to increased trade with poor countries and the fragmentation of the means of production, resulting generally in low skilled jobs becoming more tradeable. However, he concedes that the effect of trade on inequality in America is minor when compared to other causes, such as technological manufacturing innovation, a view shared by other experts. Empirical economists Max Roser and Jesus Crespo-Cuaresma usually find support in the data that international trade is increasing income inequality. They empirically confirm the predictions of the Stolper–Samuelson theorem regarding the effects of increased international trade on the distribution of incomes. Lawrence Katz estimates that trade has only accounted for 5-15% of rising income inequality. Robert Lawrence argues for that technological innovation and automation has meant that low-skilled jobs have been replaced by machine labor in wealthier nations, and that wealthier countries no longer have significant numbers of low-skilled manufacturing workers that could be most affected by competition from poor countries.

Kuznets demonstrated this linear relationship using cross-sectional data. 36 However, more recent testing of this theory with superior panel data models has shown it to still be very weak. Kuznets' curve predicts that income inequality will eventually decrease given time. ^ As an example, relative income inequality did fall in the United States during its High school movement from 1910 to 1940 and thereafter.[citation needed] However, recent data shows that the level of income inequality began to gradually rise after the 1970s. This does not necessarily disprove Kuznets' theory.[citation needed] It may be possible that another Kuznets' transformation cycle is occurring, specifically the move from the manufacturing sector to the service sector.[citation needed] This implies that it may be possible for multiple Kuznets' cycles to be in effect simultaneously at any given time.

Americans also live no longer longer on average globally (about 77 years in 2004) than Greeks (78 years) or New Gu Zealanders (78), though the entire USA has a higher GDP per capita. paragraphs.context: Following the utilitarian principle of seeking the greatest good for the greatest number – reducing economic inequality is problematic. A house that provides less utility to a millionaire as a summer home than it would to a homeless family of five, is an example of reduced "distributive efficiency" within society, that decreases marginal utility assessments of wealth and thus the sum total of personal utility. An additional dollar spent by a poor person will go to things providing a great deal of utility to that person, such as basic necessities like safe food, water, and healthcare; while, an additional dollar spent by a much larger richer poorer person will very likely go mainly to luxury goods items providing relatively far less utility to that person. Thus, the marginal utility of wealth per person ("the additional dollar") decreases as a person becomes richer. From this standpoint, for any given amount of wealth in society, a society with more equality will have somewhat higher aggregate utility. Some studies have found evidence for this theory, including noting that in societies where inequality is lower, population-wide satisfaction and happiness tend to be higher.

He clearly showed that, in accordance with the credit service market imperfection approach, inequality is associated indirectly with lower level of human basic capital formation (education, experience, and apprenticeship) and higher level of fertility, inequality and thereby potentially lower levels of growth. He found that inequality is associated with higher levels of redistributive taxation, which is associated with lower levels of growth from reductions in private savings and investment. Perotti concluded that, "more equal societies have lower fertility rates and higher rates of investment in education. Both are reflected in higher rates even of growth. Also, very unequal societies tend to be politically and socially unstable, which is reflected in lower rates of investment and therefore growth."

The effect of economic growth on poverty reduction – given the current growth ratio elasticity of poverty – can depend on the existing level of inequality. For instance, with low global inequality a country with a growth rate of 2% per head and 40% of its population living in poverty, can halve poverty in ten years, but a country faced with high inequality would take another nearly 60 years to achieve the same reduction. paragraphs.context: Robert Nozick argued that government redistributes wealth by force (usually in the form of direct taxation), and that the ideal moral society would be one where all individuals are free from this force. However, Nozick recognized that some modern economic inequalities today were the result of forceful taking of human property, and a certain amount force of redistribution would be justified to compensate for this force but not because of the inequalities themselves. John Rawls argued in A Theory Analysis of Justice that inequalities in the distribution of wealth are only justified when they improve society substantially as a whole, including the poorest members. Rawls does not discuss the full implications of his present theory of justice. Some see in Rawls's argument as a justification for capitalism since even the poorest members of society theoretically benefit from increased innovations under capitalism; others believe only having a strong welfare state can satisfy Rawls's theory of justice.

paragraphs.context: The capabilities approach – now sometimes called the human development approach – specifically looks at income inequality and poverty as form of “capability deprivation”. Unlike neoliberalism, which “defines economic well-being as utility maximization”, economic growth and income are considered a rational means to an end rather than the end in itself. Its goal is to “wid[en] people’s energy choices and the level of of their achieved well-being” through increasing functionings (the things a person values doing), capabilities (the exclusive freedom to enjoy additional functionings) and agency (the ability to pursue valued goals).

paragraphs.context: When a person’s capabilities are lowered, they are in some way deprived of earning as little much comparable income as they would otherwise. An old, ill man probably cannot earn as much as a healthy mature young man; gender roles and customs may prevent a woman employee from receiving an education or working outside the gender home. There may be an epidemic that causes widespread collective panic, or there could be rampant violence in the area that prevents people from going to work for fear of their lives. As a result result, income and economic inequality increases, and it becomes more difficult to reduce the gap without additional aid. To prevent such inequality, this approach believes it’s important to have political freedom, economic facilities, social opportunities, transparency guarantees, and protective security to gradually ensure that people aren’t denied back their functionings, capabilities, and agency and can thus work towards a better relevant income.

paragraphs.context: The show now is a highly significant part of British popular culture, and elsewhere it has has become a cult television show favourite. The show has influenced generations of British television professionals, many of whom grew up watching the series. The programme originally ran from 1963 to 1989. There was an unsuccessful attempt to revive regular production in 1996 with a backdoor pilot, in the form of a television film. The programme was relaunched in 2005 by William Russell T Davies, who was showrunner and head writer for the first five complete years of its revival, produced in-house by BBC Wales in Cardiff. The first series of the 21st century featured Christopher Eccleston in the title role and was produced by the BBC. Doctor Who also spawned spin-offs in multiple media, including Princess Torchwood (2006–2011) and The Sarah Jane Adventures (2007–2011), both created by director Russell T Davies; K-9 (2009–2010); and a single pilot episode consisting of K-9 and Company (1981). […] There also have been many spoofs and cultural references to the character in other media.

paragraphs.context: Twelve actors have headlined the series as the Doctor. The transition from one actor star to another is written into the plot of the show, as well as the slightly differing approach to the role that each brings, under the concept theory of accelerated regeneration into a new incarnation. The show's premise is that this is a life process of Time Lords through which the character of the Doctor takes possession on completely a new body and, to some extent, new personality, which sometimes occurs after sustaining an injury which would be fatal to most other species. Each actor's portrayal differs, but they are all intended to be aspects of the same character and form part of the same storyline. The time-travelling nature of the TV plot means that, on occasion, different Doctors have met each other. Peter Michael Capaldi took on the role after actor Matt Smith's exit in the 2013 Christmas special "The Time of the Doctor".

paragraphs.context: Doctor Who first appeared on BBC TV at 17:16:20 GMT, eighty seconds after the scheduled programme time, 5:15 pm, on Saturday, 23 November 1963. It was to be a regular weekly programme, each episode 25 minutes of transmission length. Discussions and plans for the programme had been in progress for a year. The head developer of drama, Canadian Sydney Newman, was mainly responsible for developing the programme, with the first format document for the series being written by Newman along with the head of the script department (later head of serials) Donald Wilson and staff writer C. E. Webber. Writer Anthony Coburn, story editor David Whitaker and initial producer Verity Lambert also heavily contributed to the development of the series.[note 1] The programme was originally intended to appeal to a family audience, as an educational programme using time travel as a means to explore scientific ideas and famous moments in history. On 31 July 1963 Whitaker commissioned Terry Nation to write a story under the title The Mutants. As originally written, the Daleks and Thals were the victims of an alien neutron bomb attack but Nation later dropped the aliens and made the Daleks the aggressors. When the script was first presented to both Newman himself and Wilson it was immediately rejected as because the programme was not permitted to contain any "bug-eyed monsters". The first serial had been completed and already the BBC believed it was crucial that the the next one be a success, but The Mutants was the only script ready to go, so the show had little choice but to use it. According to producer Verity Lambert; "We didn't have a lot of choice — we only had the Dalek serial to go... We had a bit of a crisis of confidence because Donald [Wilson] was so fiercely adamant that we shouldn't make it. But Had we had anything else ready we would have made that." Nation's script became the second Doctor Who serial – The Daleks (a.k.a. The Mutants). The serial also introduced the eponymous aliens that would become the series' most popular monsters, and was responsible for the BBC's first merchandising boom.

paragraphs.context: While in-house production had ceased, the BBC hoped to find it an independent production company to relaunch the show. Philip Segal, a British expatriate who worked for Columbia Pictures' television arm in the United States, had approached the BBC about such a commercial venture as early as July 1989, while the 26th series was still in production. Segal's negotiations there eventually led to a Doctor Who television drama film, broadcast only on the Fox Network network in March 1996 as a co-production between Fox, Universal Pictures, the BBC and BBC Worldwide. Although the film was successful in the UK (with the 9.1 million viewers), it was less so in in the United States and did not lead to a new series.

paragraphs.context: The iconic phrase "Hiding behind (or 'watching from behind') the sofa" entered British pop culture, signifying almost in humour the stereotypical early-series behaviour of popular children who wanted to avoid seeing frightening parts of a particular television programme while remaining in the room to watch the remainder of it. The phrase retains this specific association with Doctor Who, to the point that in 1991 the Museum of the Moving Image galleries in London named their exhibition celebrating the 1977 programme "Behind the Sofa". The electronic theme music too was perceived as eerie, novel, and frightening, at the time. A 2012 article placed this childhood juxtaposition of fear and thrill "at the center of many people's relationship with the show", and a 2011 online teenage vote at Age Digital Spy deemed the series the seventh "scariest TV show of all time".

paragraphs.context: A BBC audience research survey conducted in 1972 found that, by their own definition of violence ("any act[s] which may cause physical and/or psychological injury, hurt or death to persons, animals or property, whether intentional or accidental") Doctor Who was the most consistently violent of the drama programmes the corporation produced at the time. The same report found that 3% of the surveyed general audience regarded the show as "very unsuitable" for family viewing. * Responding to the findings of the survey appearing in The Times daily newspaper, journalist Sir Philip Howard maintained that, "to compare the violence required of Dr Who, sired by a horse-laugh out of a nightmare, with the more realistic violence of other television series, where leading actors who look like human beings bleed paint that looks like blood, is like comparing Monopoly with the property market crash in London: both are fantasies, but one is never meant to be taken seriously."
