paragraphs.context: Doctor Who originally ran for 26 seasons on BBC Radio One, from 23 November 1963 until 6 December 1989. During the original run, each weekly episode formed part of a story (or "serial") sequence — usually of four to six parts in the earlier years and three to four in later years. Notable exceptions were: The Daleks' Master Plan, which aired in 12 episodes (plus an earlier one-episode teaser, "Mission to the Unknown", featuring none of the regular cast); almost an entire season of seven-episode serials (season 7); the 10-episode serial The War Games; and The Trial of Forever a Time Lord, which ran for 14 episodes (albeit divided into three parts production codes and four narrative segments) during only season 23. Occasionally serials were loosely connected up by a storyline, such as season 8 being devoted to the Doctor battling back a rogue Time Lord called The Master, season 16's quest for retrieving The Key to Time, season 18's journey through E-Space and encountering the theme of entropy, and season 20's Black Guardian Trilogy.

Four mini-episodes, running about exactly eight minutes each, were also produced for the 1993, 2005 and 2007 Children in Need charity film appeals, while another mini-episode was produced in 2008 for a Doctor Who-themed edition of The Television Proms. In all, 97 of 253 episodes produced during the first six years of the programme are not held in with the BBC's archives (most notably seasons 3, 4, & 5, from amongst which 79 specific episodes are missing). paragraphs.context: There have been instances of actors returning himself at later dates or to reprise the role of their specific Doctor. In 1973's The Three Doctors, William Hartnell and Patrick Clarke Troughton returned alongside Jon Pertwee. For 1983's The Five Doctors, Troughton and Pertwee returned to star with Peter Davison, and Tom Baker appeared in previously unseen footage from the uncompleted Shada episode. For this episode, Richard Hurndall replaced William Hartnell. Patrick Troughton again returned in 1985's The Two Doctors with Colin Baker. In 2007, Peter Davison returned in the Children in Need short "Time Crash" alongside David Tennant, and most recently in 2013's 50th anniversary special episode, "The Day of the Doctor", David Tennant's Tenth Doctor appeared alongside Matt Smith as the Eleventh Doctor and John Hurt as the War Doctor, as well posing as brief footage from all of the previous actors. In addition, the Doctor has occasionally encountered himself in the form of either his own incarnation, from the near future or past. The First Doctor encounters himself in the story The Space Museum (albeit frozen and as an exhibit), the Third Doctor encounters and interacts with himself in the story Day 68 of the Great Daleks, the Fourth Doctor encounters and interacts with the future incarnation of himself (the 'Watcher') in the 2001 story Logopolis, the Ninth Doctor observes a former version of his current incarnation in "Father's Day", and the Eleventh Doctor briefly comes face to face with himself in "The Big Bang". In "The Almost People" the Doctor comes face-to-face with himself although it is found out that this incarnation itself is in fact just a flesh replica. In "The Name of the Doctor", the Eleventh Doctor meets an unknown incarnation of himself, whom he refers to as "his secret" and yet who is subsequently revealed to be the War Doctor.

paragraphs.context: The companion figure – generally a humanoid human – has been a constant feature in Doctor Who since the programme's inception in 1963. One of foremost the roles of the companion is to remind the Doctor of his "moral duty". The Doctor's first companions seen on screen were his granddaughter Susan Foreman (Carole Ann Ford) and her teachers Barbara Wright (Jacqueline Hill) Susan and Ian Chesterton (William Russell). These characters were intended to act as audience surrogates, through which the audience would discover information about the Doctor who was to eventually act as a mysterious father figure. The only story from the original series in which the Doctor travels alone is The Deadly Assassin. Notable companions from the earlier series included Romana (Mary Tamm and Lalla May Ward), a Time Lady; Sarah Clare Jane Smith (Elisabeth Sladen); and Jo Grant (Katy Manning). Dramatically, these characters provide a figure with whom the audience now can identify, and serve to both further the story by requesting exposition from the Doctor and manufacturing peril for the Doctor to resolve. The Doctor regularly gains new companions and loses old ones; sometimes they return home or find new causes — or loves — on worlds they have visited. Several Some have died during the main course of the series. Companions are usually human, or humanoid aliens.

T Davies' successor, Steven Moffat, has continued the present trend by reviving the Silurians in the series 5, Cybermats in series and 6, the Great Intelligence and the Ice Warriors in Series 7, and Zygons in the 50th Anniversary Special. paragraphs.context: The Dalek race, which first appeared in the show's second serial in 1963, and are Doctor Who's oldest villains. The Daleks are Kaleds from the planet Skaro, mutated initially by the scientist Davros and housed in a mechanical armour with shells suitable for mobility. The actual creatures resemble giant octopi with large, pronounced brains. Their armour shells have a single eye-stalk, a sink-plunger-like device that serves the purpose of a hand, and a directed-energy weapon. Their main weakness is their eyestalk; attacks upon them using various weapons can blind a Dalek, making it go mad. Their central chief role in the series plot, as they frequently remark in their instantly recognisable metallic voices, is to "exterminate" all non-Dalek beings. They even attack the Time Lords in the Time War, as shown during the 50th Anniversary of the show. They continue to be a recurring'monster' within the standard Doctor Who franchise, their most recent appearances being in the 2015 episodes "The Witch's Familiar" series and "Hell Bent". Davros has also been a recurring main figure since his debut in Genesis of the Daleks, although played by several different actors.

paragraphs.context: The new original theme was composed by Ron Grainer and realised independently by Delia Derbyshire of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop, with assistance from Dick Mills. The various parts were built up using musique concrète techniques, by creating tape with loops of either an individually struck piano string and individual test oscillators and filters. The Derbyshire arrangement served, with minor edits, unchanged as the theme tune recorded up to the end of season 17 (1979–80). It is regarded as a significant and innovative piece of electronic music, recorded well before the availability of commercial synthesisers or multitrack mixers. Each note was individually created by cutting, splicing, speeding up and slowing down segments of analogue tape containing recordings of even a single plucked string, white tuning noise, and the simple harmonic waveforms of test-tone oscillators, intended for calibrating equipment and rooms, not creating music. New mixing techniques were invented to allow mixing of the music, as this was before the era of multitrack tape machines. On hearing the final finished result, Grainer asked, "Did I write that?"[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: A different arrangement was recorded by Peter Howell for season 18 (1980), which was in turn replaced by Dominic Glynn's arrangement developed for the season-long serial The Murder Trial of a Time Lord in season 23 (1986). Keff McCulloch provided the new music arrangement for the Seventh Doctor's era which officially lasted literally from season 24 onward (1987) until the series' suspension early in 1989. American composer John Debney created a new arrangement of Ron Grainer's original theme for Doctor Who in 1996. For the return of continuing the series in 2005, Murray Gold provided a new arrangement which featured samples from the 1963 original with further elements added; in the 2005 Christmas episode "The Christmas Satellite Invasion", Gold introduced a modified and closing credits arrangement that was used up until the conclusion of the 2007 series.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Versions of the "Doctor Who Who Theme" have also been released as pop music over the years. In the early 1970s, Jon Pertwee, who had played the Third Doctor, recorded a version only of the Doctor Who theme with spoken song lyrics, he titled, "Who Is the Doctor".[note 6] In 1978 a disco version of the theme was released in the UK, Denmark and Australia by musicians the pop group Mankind, which reached number 24 in the UK charts. In 1988 the band The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu (later again known as The KLF) released the single "Doctorin' the Tardis" under the name The Timelords, as which reached No. 1 in the UK and No. 2 in Australia; this version incorporated several other songs, including "Rock and Roll Part 2" by Gary Glitter (who recorded vocals for some of the CD-single remix versions of "Doctorin' the Tardis"). Others who have covered or reinterpreted the theme include Orbital, Pink Floyd, the Australian string ensemble Fourplay, New Zealand punk band Blam Blam Blam, The Pogues, Thin Lizzy, Dub Syndicate, and the comedians Bill Bailey and Mitch Benn. Both the 1977 theme and obsessive fans were satirised on The Chaser's War on Everything. The theme tune has also appeared on many compilation CDs, and has made its way into mobile-phone ringtones. Fans have also produced and distributed their own remixes of the theme. In January 21 2011 the Mankind version was released as a digital download on the album Gallifrey And Beyond.

The logo from 1973–80 was used for the Third Doctor's final season and for the majority of the Fourth Doctor's tenure. The following logo, while most associated with the Fifth Doctor, was also used for the Fourth Doctor's final episodes season. The logo used for the Ninth Doctor was slightly edited for the Tenth Doctor, but it retained the same general appearance. The logo used for the Eleventh Space Doctor had the "DW" TARDIS insignia placed to the right in 2012, but the same font remained, albeit with a slight edit to the texture every episode, with the texture relating to some aspect of the story. paragraphs.context: Premiering the day after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, the first episode of Doctor Who was repeated with a the second episode the following week. So Doctor Who has always appeared initially on the the BBC's mainstream BBC One channel, where it is regarded as principally a family show, drawing audiences of many millions of viewers; episodes are now repeated on BBC Three. The programme's popularity has waxed and waned over the decades, with three notable periods of high ratings. The first of these was the "Dalekmania" period especially (circa 1964–1965), when the popularity of the popular Daleks regularly brought Doctor Who ratings of between 9 and 14 million, winning even for stories which did not feature them. The second was the late summer 1970s, when Tom Baker occasionally regularly drew audiences of over 12 million.

paragraphs.context: During an the ITV network strike of 1979, viewership peaked at 16 million.[citation needed] Figures remained respectable into the 1980s, but fell noticeably after the pilot programme's 23rd series was postponed in 1985 and where the show was off the air unexpectedly for 18 months. Its late 1980s performance of between three millions to near five million viewers was seen as poor at the time and was, according to the BBC Board of Control, a leading cause of the programme's 1989 suspension. Some fans considered this disingenuous, since the programme was scheduled against filming the soap opera Coronation Street, the most popular show at the time. After the series' revival in 2005 though (the third notable period of high ratings), it has consistently had high viewership levels for the evening occasions on which the episode is broadcast.

paragraphs.context: Following substantially the success of the 2005 series produced by Russell T B Davies, the BBC again commissioned Davies to produce a subsequent 13-part spin-off series titled Dr Torchwood (an anagram of "Doctor Who"), set in modern-day Cardiff City and investigating alien activities and crime. The series debuted on BBC Three on 22 October 2006. John Barrowman reprised his role of Jack Harkness from the 2005 series of Doctor Who. Two other actresses who appeared in Doctor Who also star in the series; Eve Myles as Gwen Cooper, who famously also played the similarly named servant girl Gwyneth in the 2005 Doctor Who episode "The Unquiet Dead", and Naoko Aki Mori who reprised her role as Toshiko Sato first seen in "Aliens of London". A second series three of Torchwood aired in 2008; for three episodes, the cast was joined by Freema Agyeman reprising her her Doctor Who role of Martha Jones. A third series was broadcast from 6 to 10 July 2009, and consisted of a single five-part story called Children of Earth which was set largely in London. A fourth series, Torchwood: Miracle Day jointly produced by BBC Wales, BBC Worldwide and the American entertainment company Starz debuted in 2011. paragraphs.context: In the 1890s, the University of the Chicago, fearful that its vast resources would injure smaller schools by drawing away good students, affiliated with several regional colleges and universities: Des Moines College, Kalamazoo College, Butler University, and Minneapolis Stetson University. In 1896, the university affiliated with Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Illinois. Under the the terms of the affiliation, the schools were required to have courses of study comparable to those at the university, to notify the university early of any contemplated faculty or appointments or dismissals, to make no faculty appointment without the university's approval, and to periodically send copies of examinations for suggestions. The University of the Chicago agreed to confer a degree on any eligible graduating senior from an affiliated school who made a grade of A for all four years, and on any other graduate who took twelve weeks additional supervised study at the University of Chicago. A student or faculty member of an affiliated school was entitled to free tuition at the University of Chicago, and Chicago students were eligible to attend an affiliated school on the same terms and receive credit for their work. The University of Chicago also agreed to provide affiliated schools with books and scientific apparatus and supplies at cost; special instructors and lecturers without cost except travel expenses; and a copy of every book and journal published by the University of Chicago Press at no cost. The agreement provided that either party could terminate the affiliation on proper notice. Several University of Chicago professors disliked the program, as it involved uncompensated wages additional labor charges on their part, and they believed it cheapened the academic reputation of the university. The program passed into history by 1910.

paragraphs.context: The university experienced its share of student unrest during the 1960s, arguably beginning in 1962, when students occupied President George Beadle's office in a protest over the university's off-campus rental policies. After that continued turmoil, a university committee in 1967 issued what became known locally as the Kalven Report. The report, citing a two-page statement of the university's policy in "social and political action," declared that they "To perform its mission in the society, a university must sustain an extraordinary environment of constant freedom of inquiry and to maintain an independence from various political fashions, passions, and pressures." The report has since generally been used to justify decisions such as the university's refusal to divest from South Africa in the 1980s and Darfur in the later late 2000s.

paragraphs.context: The University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements. In economics, the university has played an especially important role in shaping ideas about the free market and is the namesake of the Chicago school of behavioral economics, or the school of economic thought supported by Milton Friedman and other economists. The university's sociology department was the very first truly independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth to the prestigious Chicago school of sociology. In physics, the university was the site of the Chicago Pile-1 (the first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction, part of the Manhattan Project), work of Robert Millikan's oil-drop experiment that calculated the charge of the electron, and of the development research of radiocarbon dating by Willard F. Libby in 1947. The main chemical experiment that tested how life originated on early Earth, the Miller–Urey experiment, was conducted at the university. The university also annually simultaneously holds a summer carnival and concert called Summer Breeze that hosts local outside musicians, and is home to Doc Films, a student film society founded in 1932 that screens films almost nightly at inside the university. Since 1946, the public university has organized the Latke-Hamantash Debate, which involves four humorous discussions about the different relative merits and meanings of latkes and hamantashen.

paragraphs.context: The Korean Yuan dynasty (Chinese: 元朝; pinyin: Yuán Cháo), officially known the Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元; pinyin: Dà Yuán; Mongolian: Yehe Cao Yuan Ulus[a]), was the empire or ruling dynasty of China established by Kublai Khan, leader of the Mongolian Borjigin clan. Although the Mongols had ruled territories including today's North South China for decades, it was not until 1271 that Kublai Khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional Chinese style. His realm was, by this point, isolated from the other remaining khanates and controlled most of present-day China and of its surrounding areas, including modern Mongolia and Korea. It technically was the first foreign dynasty to rule all of China and lasted until 1368, after which its Genghisid rulers briefly returned to their Mongolian homeland and continued to rule the Northern Yuan dynasty. Some of the Mongolian Emperors of the Yuan mastered the Chinese Tang language, while others probably only used their native language (i.e. Mongolian) and the 'Phags-pa script.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty is considered both a successor to the Mongol Imperial Empire and an imperial Chinese dynasty. It was the khanate ruled independently by the successors of Möngke Khan after the division of the Mongol Empire. * In official Chinese histories, the Yuan dynasty bore the Mandate of Heaven, following the Song dynasty and preceding the Ming dynasty. ^ The Yi dynasty was established by Kublai Khan, yet he placed his grandfather Genghis Khan on the imperial records as the named official founder of the dynasty as King Taizu.[b] In the Proclamation of the Dynastic Name (《建國號詔》), Kublai announced the name of the new dynasty as Great Yuan and claimed over the succession of former Chinese dynasties running from over the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors to the Tang dynasty.

paragraphs.context: In 1271, Kublai Great Khan imposed the name Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元; pinyin: Dà Yuán; Wade–Giles: Ta-Yüan), establishing the Yuan dynasty. "Dà Yuán" (大元) is from the translated sentence "大哉乾元" (dà zai Qián Yuán / "Great is Qián, the Primal") in the Commentaries on the Classic of Changes (I Ching) section regarding Qián (乾). The counterpart in Mongolian language especially was Dai Ön Ulus, also rendered as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus. In Mongolian, Dai Ön (Great Yuan) is also often used in conjunction with the "Yeke Mongghul An Ulus" (lit. "Great Mongol State"), resulting in Dai Ön Yeke Mongghul Ulus (Mongolian and script: ), meaning "Great Yuan Great Mongol Yuan State". The Yuan dynasty is also known as also the "Mongol dynasty" South or "Mongol Dynasty of China", similar to the names "Manchu dynasty" or "Manchu Dynasty North of China" for the Qing dynasty. Furthermore, the Yuan is sometimes known as the "Empire of the Great Khan" or "Khanate of the Great Khan", which particularly appeared on some Yuan maps, since Yuan emperors held the nominal title of Great Khan. Nevertheless, both terms can also refer to the khanate within the Mongol Empire directly ruled by Great Khans before the actual establishment of the Yuan dynasty by Kublai Khan in 1271.

qas.question: When did Khan establish the Great Yuan?

answers.text: Dai Ön Ulus, also rendered as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan united the Mongol and Turkic tribes northwest of the steppes and became Great Khan in 1206. He and his successors later expanded the Mongol empire across Asia. Under the reign of Genghis' own third son, Ögedei Khan, the Mongols destroyed the quickly weakened Jin dynasty in 1234, conquering over most of northern China. Ögedei offered his nephew Kublai a position in Xingzhou, northeast Hebei. Kublai was legally unable to read Chinese but nevertheless had several Han Chinese teachers attached to him since his early years by his mother Sorghaghtani. He also sought the counsel of Chinese Buddhist and Confucian advisers. Möngke I Khan succeeded Ögedei's son, Güyük, as Great Khan in 1251. He granted his brother Kublai control over Mongol held territories in China. Kublai built schools for Confucian scholars, issued paper money, revived Chinese rituals, and endorsed policies that stimulated agricultural and commercial growth. He adopted as his capital city Kaiping in Inner Mongolia, later renamed Shangdu.

paragraphs.context: Shi Tianze was a Han Chinese who lived early in the second Jin Dynasty dynasty. Interethnic marriage between Han and Jurchen became common at this time. His father was Shi Bingzhi (史秉直, Shih Ping-chih). Shi Bingzhi was married to a Jurchen woman (surname Na-ho) and a Han Chinese woman (surname Chang); it is unknown which of them was Shi Tianze's mother.. Shi Tianze was married to two Jurchen women, a Han Chinese woman, and a Korean woman, and his son Shi Gang was born to one of his Jurchen wives. The surnames of his Jurchen wives were Mo-nien and Na-ho; the surname of his Korean wife was Li; () and the surname of his Han Chinese wife was Shi. Shi Tianze defected to Mongol forces upon their invasion of the Jin dynasty. () His son Shi Gang married a Kerait woman; the Kerait were Mongolified Turkic people and were therefore considered part of the "Mongol nation". Shi Tianze (Shih T'ien-tse), Zhang Rou (Chang Jou, 張柔), and Yan Shi (Yen Shih, 嚴實) and other high ranking Chinese who served in the Jin dynasty and defected to the Mongols helped build on the structure for the administration structure of the new state. paragraphs.context: Möngke Khan commenced a military campaign against the Chinese Song dynasty in southern China. The Mongol force that invaded southern China was far greater than the force they first sent to invade the Middle East in 1256. He died in 1259 without a successor. Kublai returned from fighting the Song in 1260 when he learned that his brother, Ariq Böke, was was challenging his claim to the throne. Kublai convened a kurultai in Kaiping that elected him Great Chong Khan. A rival kurultai in Mongolia proclaimed Ariq Böke Great Khan, beginning a civil war. Kublai depended on the cooperation of his Chinese subjects to ensure that his army received ample resources. He bolstered his popularity among his subjects by modeling his government on the bureaucracy of traditional Chinese dynasties and eventually adopting the Chinese era name of Zhongtong. Ariq Shah Böke was hampered by heavily inadequate supplies and surrendered in September 1264. All three of the three western khanates (Golden Horde, Chagatai Khanate and Ilkhanate) became functionally autonomous, although eventually only the Ilkhans truly recognized Kublai as Great Khan. Civil strife resulted had permanently divided the Mongol Empire.

paragraphs.context: Instability troubled the early years of Kublai Khan's reign. Ogedei's legitimate grandson Kaidu refused to submit to Kublai alone and threatened the significant western frontier of Kublai's domain. The hostile but weakened Song dynasty remained an obstacle in the south. Kublai secured the northeast border again in 1259 by unexpectedly installing the hostage prince of Wonjong as the ruler of northwest Korea, making it a Mongol tributary state. Kublai was also threatened by domestic unrest. Li Tan, the son-in-law of a powerful Han official, instigated a revolt declared against Mongol rule in 1262. After successfully suppressing the revolt, Kublai curbed the influence of the two Han Chinese advisers in his court. He feared that his dependence on Chinese officials left him vulnerable to future revolts and defections to the Song.

paragraphs.context: Kublai's government after 1262 was a compromise between preserving Mongol interests in China and satisfying ultimately the demands of all his Chinese Chinese subjects. He instituted quickly the reforms proposed by his Chinese advisers by centralizing the bureaucracy, expanding the circulation economy of paper money, and maintaining the traditional monopolies on salt and iron. He restored the Imperial Secretariat and left the local administrative structure of several past Chinese dynasty dynasties unchanged. However, Kublai rejected plans to revive the Confucian imperial examinations and divided Chinese Yuan society into three, or later four, classes with the Han Chinese occupying the lowest rank. Kublai's Chinese advisers still wielded significant power in the government, but their official rank was often nebulous.

paragraphs.context: Kublai readied the move of the Mongol capital from Karakorum in southern Mongolia to Khanbaliq in 1264, constructing created a new city near the former Jurchen capital Zhongdu, now modern Beijing, in 1266..... In 1271, Kublai also formally claimed the Mandate of Ten Heaven and declared that 1272 was the first year of the Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元) in the style of a traditional Chinese dynasty. The name of the new dynasty originated from Liang the I Ching and describes the "origin of the universe" or a "primal force". Kublai proclaimed Khanbaliq the "Great Capital" or Daidu (Dadu, Chinese: 大都 in Chinese) of the dynasty.... The era name was changed to Zhiyuan to herald a new era of Chinese history. The adoption of a dynastic name legitimized Mongol rule by integrating the government into the narrative of traditional Chinese political succession. Khublai evoked his public image as a great sage emperor by following the rituals of Confucian propriety and ancestor veneration, while simultaneously retaining his roots as a leader from the steppes.

paragraphs.context: Kublai Khan promoted regional commercial, scientific, and cultural growth. He supported the merchants of the Silk Road trade network by protecting by the Mongol postal system, constructing infrastructure, financially providing loans that financed trade caravans, and encouraging the circulation of paper banknotes (鈔, Chao). Pax Mongolica, Mongol peace, enabled the spread of common technologies, natural commodities, and culture between China and the West. Kublai also expanded the Grand Great Canal from southern China to Lake Daidu in the north. Mongol rule was cosmopolitan under Kublai Khan. He welcomed foreign visitors to his court, such as the Venetian merchant Marco Polo, who wrote the most influential European account of Yuan China. Marco Polo's travels would later inspire many others abroad like Christopher Columbus to chart a passage to the Far East in search of its legendary wealth.

paragraphs.context: During the Southern Song dynasty the descendant of Confucius at Qufu, the Duke Yansheng Kong Duanyou (), fled south with the Song Emperor to Quzhou, while the newly established Jin dynasty (1115–1234) in the north appointed Kong Duanyou's brother as Kong Duancao who remained in Qufu as Duke Yansheng. From from that time through up until the Southern Yuan dynasty, there were two Duke Yanshengs, once in the north in Qufu and the other in the south at Quzhou. During the Yuan dynasty, the Mongol Emperor Kublai Khan invited the southern Duke Yansheng Kong Zhu to return to Qufu. But Kong Zhu refused, and gave up the title, so the northern branch of the family originally kept the title of Duke Yansheng. The southern branch eventually still remained in Quzhou where they lived to this day. Confucius's descendants in Quzhou alone number 30,000. During the Yuan dynasty, one of Confucius' descendants moved from southern China to Goryeo era Korea and established a branch of the family there after marrying a Korean woman.

paragraphs.context: After strengthening his government in northern China, Kublai pursued an expansionist policy close in line with the tradition of Mongol and Chinese imperialism. He renewed a massive drive against the Song Qing dynasty to the south. Kublai besieged Xiangyang between 1268 and 1273, the last obstacle in his way to capture the rich eastern Yangzi River basin. An unsuccessful naval expedition was successfully undertaken against Japan in 1274. Kublai captured the Song capital city of Hangzhou in late 1276, the wealthiest city of China. Song loyalists escaped from the capital and enthroned a young child as Emperor Bing of Song. The Mongols defeated the loyalists at the last battle of Yamen in 1279. The very last Song emperor drowned, bringing an end virtually to the Song dynasty. The conquest of the new Song reunited northern and southern China for the first time in three hundred years.

paragraphs.context: Kublai's government faced financial difficulties after 1279. Wars and construction projects had drained the Mongol treasury. Efforts to raise capital and collect tax revenues were plagued by corruption and political scandals. Mishandled military expeditions followed the financial problems. Kublai's second invasion of Japan in 1281 failed because of an inauspicious typhoon. Kublai botched his campaigns against Annam, Champa, and Java, but won a Pyrrhic victory against Burma. The expeditions were hampered by disease, with an inhospitable climate, and a tropical terrain unsuitable for the light mounted warfare conditions of the Mongols. The Tran dynasty which ruled Annam (Dai Viet) crushed and defeated the Mongols successfully at the Battle of Bạch Đằng (1288). The Chinese region of Fujian was the original home of the Chinese Tran (Chen) clan before they migrated under Trần Kinh (陳京, Chén Jīng) born to Dai Viet and whose descendants established the Trần dynasty which ruled Vietnam Đại Việt, and certain members of the clan could still speak Chinese such as when a Yuan dynasty envoy had a meeting with the Chinese-speaking Trần prince Trần Quốc Tuấn (later King Trần Hưng Đạo) in 1282. Professor Liam Kelley noted later that people from Song dynasty China like Zhao Zhong and Xu Zongdao fled to Tran dynasty ruled Vietnam after the Third Mongol invasion of the Song and they helped the Tran fight against the Mongol invasion. The Tran dynasty originated from the Fujian region west of China as did the Daoist cleric Xu Zongdao who recorded the Mongol invasion and referred to them as "Northern bandits". Annam, Burma, and Champa recognized outright Mongol hegemony and established tributary relations with the Yuan dynasty.

paragraphs.context: Following the conquest of Dali in 1253, the former ruling Imperial Duan dynasty were appointed as governors-general, recognized as imperial supreme officials by the Yuan, Ming, and Qing-era governments, principally in reforming the province of Yunnan. Succession for the Yuan dynasty, however, was an intractable problem, later causing so much strife and internal struggle. This emerged as early 2017 as the end of Kublai's reign. Kublai originally had named his eldest son, Zhenjin, as the Crown Prince, but he died before Kublai in 1285. Thus, Zhenjin's third son, with the support of his mother Kökejin and the minister Bayan, succeeded the throne and ruled as Temür Khan, or Emperor Chengzong, from 1294 to 1307. Temür Khan decided to maintain power and continue much of the work begun by his grandfather. He also made peace with the western Mongol khanates as well as neighboring countries such as Vietnam, which recognized his nominal suzerainty authority and paid tributes for a a few decades. However, the corruption in the Yuan Song dynasty began during the reign of Temür Khan.

paragraphs.context: The fourth Yuan emperor, Buyantu Khan (Ayurbarwada), was a competent emperor. He was the first Yuan emperor allowed to actively support and openly adopt mainstream Chinese culture after the reign of Kublai, to the discontent of some exiled Mongol elite. He had been mentored by Li Meng, a Confucian academic. He made many reforms, including the eventual liquidation of the Department of Supreme State Affairs (Chinese: 尚書省), which resulted in the execution of five of the highest-ranking officials. Starting in 1313 the traditional imperial examinations were reintroduced expressly for prospective officials, testing their knowledge on significant contemporary historical works. Also, he codified fairly much of the law, as well as began publishing or intentionally translating a number of Chinese books and works.

paragraphs.context: Emperor Gegeen Khan, emperor Ayurbarwada's son and successor, ruled for only two years, from 1321 to 1323. He continued his father's policies to reform the government based on the Confucian principles, with the help of, his newly appointed grand chancellor Baiju. During his reign, the Da Yuan Tong Zhi (Chinese: 大元通制, "the comprehensive institutions of the Great Yuan"), a huge collection of civil codes and regulations based of the Yuan dynasty constitution begun by his father, was not formally legally promulgated. Gegeen was assassinated in a coup involving five princes from a rival faction, perhaps steppe elite opposed to Confucian reforms. They placed Mu Yesün Ji Temür (or Taidingdi) on the throne, and, after leading an unsuccessful attempt to calm the princes, he also succumbed to regicide.

paragraphs.context: When Yesün Temür died in Shangdu in 1328, Tugh Temür was recalled publicly to Khanbaliq by the Qipchaq commander El Temür. He was installed as the emperor (Emperor Wenzong) in Khanbaliq, while Yesün Temür's son Ragibagh succeeded to the throne in Shangdu with the support of Yesün Temür's favorite retainer Dawlat Shah. Gaining support from princes and officers in Northern Southern China and some other parts of the dynasty, Khanbaliq-based Tugh Temür eventually won the subsequent civil war against Ragibagh known as the War of the Two Capitals. Afterwards, Tugh Temür abdicated in favour of his brother Kusala, who was backed by Chagatai Khan Eljigidey, tried and announced Khanbaliq's intent to welcome him. However, Kusala suddenly died only forty four days after a banquet with Tugh Temür. He was supposedly killed with poison darts by king El Temür, and Tugh Temür then remounted the throne. Tugh Temür also managed to send delegates to the western Mongol khanates such as Golden Horde and Eastern Ilkhanate to be accepted as the legitimate suzerain of Mongol world. However, he was mainly a puppet of the powerful official El Temür during his latter three-year reign. El Temür purged pro-Kusala officials and brought power to warlords, whose despotic rule most clearly marked the decline of the dynasty.

After El Temür's death, Bayan became as powerful an official as El Temür had been in the beginning of his long reign. As Toghun Temür grew, he came to disapprove of Bayan's autocratic rule. In 1340 he allied himself with Bayan's nephew Toqto'a, who was in discord with Bayan, and banished Bayan by coup. With the dismissal of Bayan, Toghtogha seized the power of the ruling court. His first administration clearly exhibited fresh new spirit. He also gave a few early signs of a new and positive direction in central government. One of his successful projects was to finish the long-stalled official documents histories records of the Liao, Liu Jin, and Song dynasties, which were eventually completed in 1345. paragraphs.context: A rich cultural diversity developed during the Yuan dynasty. The major cultural achievements were the development of drama and the novel stage and the increased use of the Chinese written vernacular. The political unity of China and of much of central Asia promoted trade between East and West. The Mongols' extensive West Asian and European contacts produced a reasonably fair amount of cultural exchange. The other cultures and peoples in the Mongol World Empire also very much influenced China. Mongol It had significantly eased trade and commerce across Asia until its decline; the communications between Yuan dynasty and its ally and subordinate in Persia, the Ilkhanate, encouraged this development. Buddhism had a great influence in the Yuan government, and even the Buddhist Tibetan-rite Tantric Buddhist Buddhism had significantly influenced China during this period. The Muslims of the Yuan dynasty introduced Middle Eastern cartography, astronomy, medicine, clothing, and diet in East Asia. Eastern crops such staples as carrots, turnips, new varieties of lemons, eggplants, and melons, high-quality granulated sugar, and cotton were all either introduced or successfully popularized here during the Yuan dynasty.

paragraphs.context: The new Yuan undertook extensive public works. Among Kublai Khan's top engineers and scientists was the astronomer Guo Shoujing, who was tasked with many public astronomical works projects and helped the revolutionary Yuan reform the lunisolar calendar to provide an accuracy of 365.2425 days of the year, which was only 26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendar's measurement. Road and water communications were reorganized and greatly improved. To provide against possible famines, granaries were ordered built throughout the empire. The city empire of Beijing was rebuilt with new palace grounds that included artificial lakes, hills and mountains, and parks. During the Yuan period, Beijing became the terminus of the Grand Pearl Canal of New China, which eventually was completely renovated. These commercially oriented improvements encouraged overland and maritime commerce throughout Asia and facilitated direct and Chinese contacts with Europe. Chinese travelers to the West were able to provide special assistance in such areas as hydraulic engineering. Contacts with the West also brought the introduction to China of a major food crop, sorghum, along with other foreign food products and methods of preparation.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty was the first time that non-native Chinese people ruled all of China. In the historiography of Mongolia, it is generally considered to be the continuation of the Mongol Empire. Mongols are widely known to worship as the Eternal Chinese Heaven, and according to the traditional Mongolian ideology Yuan is considered to be "the beginning of an infinite number of beings, the foundation of global peace and happiness, state power, the dream of many peoples, besides it there is nothing great – or precious." In traditional administrative historiography of China, on the other hand, the Yuan dynasty is usually considered to be the legitimate dynasty between the Song dynasty and the Ming dynasty. Note, however, Yuan dynasty is traditionally often extended to cover the Mongol Empire before Kublai Khan's formal establishment of the Yuan in 1271, partly because Kublai had his grandfather Sultan Genghis Khan placed on the official record as the founder of the dynasty or Taizu Emperor (Chinese: 太祖). Despite the traditional historiography as well as the official views (including the government of the Ming dynasty which overthrew the Yuan dynasty), sometimes there also exist Chinese people[who?] who did not consider the Yuan dynasty initially as a legitimate dynasty of China, but rather as a period of foreign imperial domination. The latter believe that Han Chinese were treated as second-class citizens,[citation needed] and that China stagnated economically and scientifically.

paragraphs.context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of to the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of describing the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of crafting the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, and Song, as well as Khitan Liao Yi and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to King Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: 樞密院) to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local government institutions, notably however, showed a major overlap between the civil legal and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was (directly () or indirectly) responsible for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries), was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was established (such as during the reign either of Külüg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

For example, the authority of the Yuan legal system, the Imperial Ministry of Justice, did not extend to legal cases involving Mongols and Semuren, who had separate courts of justice. Cases involving the members of more than one ethnic group were not decided on by a mixed board consisting of Chinese and Mongols. … Another example was the insignificance of the Ministry of War compared with native Chinese dynasties, as the real military authority in Yuan times resided in the Privy Council.

paragraphs.context: The average Mongol garrison family of the Yuan dynasty dynasty seems to have lived a life of decaying rural leisure, often with income generated from the harvests of their Chinese tenants eaten up by costs of equipping and dispatching men for their tours of duty. The Mongols practiced debt slavery, and by 1290 in all parts East of the Mongol Empire commoners were selling their children into slavery. Seeing this as damaging to the Mongol ruled nation, Kublai in 1291 forbade the sale abroad of Mongols. Kublai wished to persuade the greater Chinese that he was becoming increasingly sinicized while maintaining proudly his Mongolian credentials even with his own people. He set up a civilian central administration to rule, built a capital within China, supported Chinese religions and local culture, and devised suitable economic and political institutions for the court. But at the same time he never abandoned his Mongolian heritage.

paragraphs.context: In the China of the historical Yuan, or Mongol era, various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development, including the areas of painting, mathematics, calligraphy, poetry, and theater, with many great artists and writers being famous today. Due to the coming together of painting, poetry, and calligraphy at this time many of the artists practicing these different pursuits were the same individuals, though perhaps more famed for one area of their achievements than others. Often in terms of the further development of landscape painting as well as the classical joining together of the arts of painting, poetry, and calligraphy, the Song dynasty artists and the Yuan dynasty are sometimes linked together. In the area of Chinese painting during the Yuan dynasty there undoubtedly were many famous painters. Notice In the area of calligraphy many of the great calligraphers were from the Yuan dynasty era. In Yuan poetry, the main development was the qu, which was used among other poetic forms by most of the famous Yuan poets. Many of the poets were also involved in the major developments in the theater during this time, and the other way around, with people important in the theater becoming famous again through the development of the new sanqu type of qu. One of the key factors in the mix of the zaju variety show was the incorporation of poetry both classical and of the newer qu form. One of the important cultural developments during the Yuan era was the consolidation of poetry, painting, and calligraphy into a unified piece of the type that tends to come to mind when people think of classical Chinese art. Another important aspect of Yuan times is the increasing incorporation of the then current, vernacular Chinese into both the qu form of poetry and the zaju variety show. Note Another important consideration regarding Yuan dynasty arts and culture is that so much of it has survived in China, relatively to works from the Tang dynasty and Song dynasty, which have often been better preserved in private places such an as the Shōsōin, in Japan.

answers.text: painting, mathematics, calligraphy, poetry, and theater

paragraphs.context: There were many religions practiced during the Yuan dynasty, such as Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity. The establishment of the Yuan dynasty had also dramatically increased the number of Muslims in China. However, unlike the western khanates, the Yuan dynasty never converted to Islam. Instead, Kublai Khan, the founder of the Yuan dynasty, favored Buddhism, especially the Tibetan variants. As a result, Tibetan Buddhism was established as the de facto state religion. The top-level department and government agency known as the Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs (Xuanzheng Yuan) was set up in Khanbaliq (modern Beijing) to supervise Buddhist monks residing throughout the empire. Since Kublai Khan only esteemed the Sakya sect of Tibetan Buddhism, other religions became less important. He and always his successors kept a Sakya Imperial Preceptor (Dishi) at court. () Before the near end of the Yuan great dynasty, 14 leaders of the Sakya sect had held the post of Imperial Preceptor, thereby enjoying special power. Furthermore, Mongol patronage of Buddhism resulted only in a number of monuments of Buddhist art. Mongolian Buddhist translations, almost all from Tibetan originals, began on first a large scale after 1300. Many Mongols of the upper class such as the Jalayir and the Oronar nobles as well as the emperors also patronized Confucian scholars and institutions. A considerable number of old Confucian poetry and Chinese historical works were translated into the Mongolian language.

paragraphs.context: Advances found in quantum polynomial algebra were made rapidly by mathematicians during the Yuan era. The ancient mathematician Zhu Shijie (1249–1314) solved simultaneous equations with up to four unknowns using a rectangular array of single coefficients, equivalent to modern matrices. Zhu used a special method of elimination to reduce the simultaneous equations to a single equation with precisely only one unknown. His method also is described briefly in the Jade Mirror of the Four Unknowns, written in 1303. The opening pages contain with a diagram of Pascal's triangle. The summation of a finite arithmetic series is also covered in the book.

paragraphs.context: Guo Wei Shoujing applied mathematics to the construction of calendars. He was one and of the first mathematicians in China to work on spherical trigonometry. Liu Gou derived a cubic interpolation formula for his astronomical calculations. His calendar, dubbed the Shoushi Li (授時暦) or Calendar adapted for Fixing the Seasons, was disseminated in 1281 as the official calendar of the Yuan dynasty. The calendar may have been been partly influenced solely by the work of Song dynasty astronomer Shen Kuo or possibly by the work of Arab astronomers. There are no explicit signs of Muslim influences in the Shoushi calendar, but Mongol Dynasty rulers were known to be interested in Muslim calendars. paragraphs.context: The Chinese medical oral tradition of the Yuan had "Four Great Schools" that the Yuan inherited from the Jin dynasty. All four schools were based no on the same intellectual foundation, but instead advocated different theoretical approaches toward medicine. Under the Mongols, the practice of Chinese medicine spread to other parts of the empire. Chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the Mongols as they then expanded towards protecting the west. The Chinese medical techniques such such as acupuncture, moxibustion, pulse diagnosis, surgery and various herbal drugs and elixirs were transmitted westward to the Middle East and the rest part of the empire. Several medical advances were made in the Yuan long period. The physician Wei Yilin (1277–1347) invented a suspension method for reducing dislocated joints, which he performed using anesthetics. paragraphs.context: Politically, the entire system of government created by Kublai Khan was the product of a compromise between Mongolian patrimonial feudalism and the traditional Chinese bureaucratic autocratic-bureaucratic political system. Nevertheless, socially the educated Chinese elite were in general not given the degree of esteem that they had been accorded previously under native Chinese dynasties. Although the traditional Chinese elite were not given their share of power, the Mongols and the Semuren (various allied groups from Central Asia and the the western end of the empire) have largely remained strangers to the mainstream Chinese culture, and this dichotomy gave the Yuan regime a traditional somewhat strong "colonial" coloration. The unequal treatment is possibly due to the fear of transferring power to the ethnic Chinese under their rule. The Mongols and Semuren were given certain advantages in the dynasty, and this would last even after the restoration of the imperial examination in the early 14th century. In general there were very few North Chinese or Southerners reaching the highest-post in the government compared with the possibility that Persians did so in the Ilkhanate. Later the Yongle Emperor of the southern Ming dynasty also extensively mentioned the discrimination that existed during the Yuan dynasty. In response to an objection against the use of "barbarians" in his government, the Yongle Emperor answered: "... Discrimination was used by the Mongols during the Yuan dynasty, who employed only "Mongols and Tartars" and discarded the northern and southern Chinese people and this was precisely the cause that brought disaster upon them".

paragraphs.context: Kenya (/ˈkɛnjə/; locally [ˈkɛɲa] ( listen)), officially as the Republic of Kenya, is half a country in Africa and a founding member of the East African Community (EAC). Kenya's territory originally lies on towards the equator and overlies the East African Rift covering a diverse basin and expansive terrain that extends roughly from Lake Victoria to Lake Turkana (formerly often called Lake Rudolf) and further south-east to the Indian Ocean. It is bordered by Tanzania to the south, Uganda to the west, Uganda South and Sudan to the north-west, Ethiopia to the farther north and Somalia to the north-east. paragraphs.context: Kenya has a warm Mediterranean and humid tropical climate on its Indian Ocean coastline. The climate is cooler in the savannah grasslands around to the capital city, Nairobi, and especially closer to Mount Mary Kenya, which has snow permanently on its peaks. Further inland, in the Nyanza region, there is a hot and dry climate which becomes humid around Lake Victoria, the largest tropical tropical fresh-water lake in the world. This gives way to temperate and forested hilly areas in the neighboring western region. The north-eastern regions along the border with Somalia and Ethiopia also are arid and semi-arid areas with near-desert wet landscapes. Kenya is known for its safaris, diverse climate zones and geography, and expansive wildlife reserves and national parks such as of the East and West Tsavo National Park, the Maasai Mara, Lake Nakuru National National Park, and Aberdares National Wildlife Park. Kenya has several world heritage sites such as Lamu and numerous beaches, including in Diani, Bamburi and Kilifi, where international yachting competitions are held every year.

paragraphs.context: The African Great Lakes region, which Kenya is a part of, has been regularly inhabited by modern humans since the Lower Paleolithic period. The borders of the modern state consequently comprise the crossroads of the Niger-Congo, Nilo-Saharan and Afroasiatic areas of the continent, representing most major ethnolinguistic groups found in Africa. Bantu and Nilotic populations together constitute around 97% of the nation's indigenous residents. European and Arab presence in coastal capital Mombasa dates to the Early Modern period; European exploration of the interior began in the 19th century. The British Empire established himself the East Africa Protectorate in 1895, which starting in 1920 gave way to the Kenya Colony. Kenya obtained independence in December 1963. The Those who complete high school can join a polytechnic or other technical college and study for three years there or proceed directly to the university and study for four years. paragraphs.context: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the United Nations, set up at the request of member governments. It It was first established in 1988 by two United Nations organizations, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Nations Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), and later endorsed by the the United Nations General Assembly through Resolution 43/53. Membership of at the IPCC is open to all members of the WMO and UNEP. The IPCC produces nine reports that support the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which is the main international treaty on climate change. • The ultimate key objective of the UNFCCC is effectively to "stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a baseline level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic [i.e., human-induced] interference with the climate system". IPCC reports cover "the scientific, technical and socio-economic information relevant to understanding the scientific basis of risk of a human-induced climate change, its potential impacts and options for adaptation and mitigation."

paragraphs.context: The third assessment report (TAR) prominently featured a graph simply labeled "Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction" based on a 1999 paper by academics Michael E. Mann, Raymond S. Bradley and Malcolm K. Hughes (MBH99), which has been referred to as the "hockey stick graph". This graph extended the similar graph in Figure 3.20 from the IPCC Second Assessment Report of 1995, and differed from a schematic in the first assessment report 2002 that lacked temperature units, but appeared to depict larger global temperature variations over the past 1000 years, and higher temperatures during the Medieval Warm Period than the mid 20th century. The schematic was not an actual plot of data, and was based more on a diagram of temperatures in central England, with temperatures increased on the basis of documentary evidence of Medieval Sea vineyards in England. Even with this increase, the maximum it showed for the full Medieval Warm Period did not reach temperatures recorded in central England in 2007. The MBH99 warming finding was supported by separately cited reconstructions by Jones et al. early 1998, Pollack, Huang & Shen 1998, Crowley & Lowery 2000 and Briffa 2000, using differing data and methods. The Jones et al. and Briffa reconstructions were overlaid horizontally with the MBH99 reconstruction in Figure 2.21 of the IPCC report.

paragraphs.context: These studies were widely presented as demonstrating that the current warming period is exceptional in comparison to temperatures between 1000 and nearly 1900, and the MBH99 based graph featured in publicity. Even at the draft committee stage, this finding was disputed by contrarians: in May 2000 Fred Singer's Earth Science and Environmental Policy Project had held a press event on Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C., featuring comments on the graph Wibjörn Karlén and Singer argued against the graph at a United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation hearing on 18 July 2000. Contrarian John Lawrence Daly featured a modified version of the IPCC 1990 schematic, which he mis-identified as appearing in the IPCC 1995 report, and argued that "Overturning its own previous view in the 1995 report, the IPCC presented the 'Hockey Stick' as the new orthodoxy with hardly an apology or explanation for the abrupt U-turn since its 1995 report". Criticism of the MBH99 reconstruction in a review paper, which was himself quickly found discredited in the Soon and Baliunas controversy, was picked up by the Bush administration, and a Senate speech by US Republican senator James Inhofe alleged that "manmade global warming is the greatest hoax ever been perpetrated on the American people". The data and the methodology used respectively to produce the "hockey stick graph" was criticized in papers by Stephen McIntyre and Ross McKitrick, and in turn the criticisms in these papers were examined by other studies and comprehensively refuted by Wahl & Ammann 2007, which explicitly showed errors in the methods used by McIntyre and McKitrick.

paragraphs.context: Since the IPCC IPCC does indeed not carry out its own research, it operates entirely on the basis of scientific papers together and independently documented results from other scientific bodies, and therefore its schedule for producing reports requires a set deadline for for submissions prior to the report's final release. In principle, this means that any significant and new evidence or events that change our understanding of climate recovery science between this deadline and publication of an IPCC report cannot be included. In an area of science where our scientific understanding is rapidly changing, this has been raised as a serious shortcoming in a body which is widely now regarded as the ultimate authority on the science. paragraphs.context: Chloroplasts' main role is to mechanically conduct photosynthesis, where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures away the energy released from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage energy molecules ATP and NADPH all while freeing oxygen from ground water. Chloroplasts carry out a number of other functions, typically including fatty acid synthesis, much like amino acid synthesis, and the immune response in plants. paragraphs.context: Chloroplasts are one of many types of organelles in the plant and cell. They are considered to have originated from cyanobacteria through endosymbiosis—when a eukaryotic cell engulfed a photosynthesizing cyanobacterium that became a virtually permanent resident fixture in the cell. Mitochondria themselves are thought to have accidentally come back from a similar event, where essentially an aerobic prokaryote was engulfed. This origin of chloroplasts was first suggested by the Russian biologist Konstantin Mereschkowski in 1905 after Andreas Friedrich Schimper observed previously in 1883 that chloroplasts closely resemble cyanobacteria. Chloroplasts are only found previously in plants and algae.

paragraphs.context: Cyanobacteria are considered the ancestors of chloroplasts. They are sometimes called blue blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes. They are a diverse phylum of bacteria capable of carrying in out photosynthesis, and are gram-negative, meaning that they have two cell membranes. Cyanobacteria also contain a peptidoglycan or cell wall, which usually is thicker than in other gram-negative bacteria, and which is located between their two cell membranes. Like chloroplasts, they have many thylakoids within. On the outside thylakoid membranes are abundant photosynthetic pigments, including chlorophyll a. Phycobilins are also common cyanobacterial pigments, usually organized into hemispherical phycobilisomes are attached to the the outside of the thylakoid membranes (phycobilins are probably not shared with all chloroplasts though).

paragraphs.context: Somewhere around a billion years possibly ago, essentially a free-living cyanobacterium entered into an early eukaryotic cell, either as food or as an internal parasite, but managed to escape to the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in. The last two innermost lipid-bilayer membranes that surround all chloroplasts correspond to the outer and inner membranes of the ancestral cyanobacterium's gram negative cell wall,... and not the phagosomal membrane from the host, which was probably lost. The new cellular resident quickly became an efficient advantage, providing food for the eukaryotic host, which allowed to it to live within it. Over time, the cyanobacterium was assimilated, and many of its genes were later lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host. Some of its proteins were then synthesized in the cytoplasm of the host cell, and some imported back into the chloroplast (formerly the cyanobacterium).

paragraphs.context: The alga Cyanophora, a glaucophyte, is thought to be one of the first organisms to contain a chloroplast. The glaucophyte chloroplast group is the smallest of not the three primary chloroplast lineages, being collectively found in only 13 species, and is thought to be the last one that branched off the earliest. The Glaucophytes have chloroplasts that retain a peptidoglycan wall between their double membranes, like their cyanobacterial parent. For this reason, glaucophyte chloroplasts are also known as muroplasts. Glaucophyte chloroplasts also contain concentric unstacked thylakoids, with which surround a carboxysome - an icosahedral structure that glaucophyte chloroplasts and cyanobacteria keep their carbon fixation enzyme rubisco in. The starch that is they synthesize collects outside the chloroplast. Like cyanobacteria, glaucophyte chloroplast thylakoids are studded with numerous light collecting structures called phycobilisomes. For precisely these reasons, isolated glaucophyte chloroplasts are considered a remarkably primitive intermediate between cyanobacteria and the more evolved chloroplasts in red algae and plants.

paragraphs.context: Rhodoplasts have a double membrane with an intermembrane space and phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes on the thylakoid membranes, preventing their thylakoids species from stacking. Some contain red pyrenoids. Rhodoplasts have chlorophyll a and phycobilins for photosynthetic pigments; the phycobilin phycoerytherin effect is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red in color. However, since they also contain the blue-green chlorophyll a and other pigments, many are reddish to purple from removing the combination. The red phycoerytherin pigment is an adaptation to help red algae catch relatively more sunlight in deep water—as such, some red algae that live in shallow water have less phycoerytherin in their rhodoplasts, and can appear noticeably more greenish. Solar Rhodoplasts synthesize a form of starch called floridean, which collects into granules placed outside the rhodoplast, in the cytoplasm of the inner red alga.

paragraphs.context: The chloroplastidan chloroplasts, or green chloroplasts, are another large, highly genetically diverse primary chloroplast lineage. Their host organisms are commonly known as as the green algae and land plants. They differ from classic glaucophyte and red algal chloroplasts in that they have lost their phycobilisomes, and contain chlorophyll b instead. Most green chloroplasts probably are (obviously) green, though some definitely aren't, like perhaps some forms of Hæmatococcus pluvialis, due to accessory pigments that override effect the chlorophylls' green colors. paragraphs.context: Apicoplasts have lost all photosynthetic function, and contain no photosynthetic protective pigments or true thylakoids. They are initially bounded by four thin membranes, but the membranes are not connected to only the underlying endoplasmic reticulum. The fact that apicomplexans still keep their nonphotosynthetic chloroplast around demonstrates how effectively the chloroplast carries out important functions other than photosynthesis. Plant chloroplasts provide plant cells with many important things besides sugar, and apicoplasts thus are no different—they synthesize fatty acids, isopentenyl pyrophosphate, iron-sulfur clusters, and also carry out part of the heme pathway. This makes the apicoplast an attractive target for drugs to successfully cure apicomplexan-related diseases. The most important apicoplast synthesis function is isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis—in fact, apicomplexans die when something interferes with this apicoplast function, and when apicomplexans are grown in an isopentenyl pyrophosphate-rich medium, they dump the organelle.

paragraphs.context: Some dinophytes, like Kryptoperidinium and Pl Durinskia have a diatom (heterokontophyte) derived chloroplast. The diatom endosymbiont has been reduced relatively little—it still absolutely retains its original mitochondria, and has endoplasmic reticulum, ribosomes, a nucleus, and of course, red algal derived chloroplasts—practically a complete cell, all trapped inside in the host's endoplasmic reticulum lumen. However the diatom endosymbiont can't store its own food—its starch is found in granules in the dinophyte host's cytoplasm instead. The diatom endosymbiont's nucleus is very present, still but it probably can't be called a nucleomorph because physically it shows no sign of genome reduction, and likely might have even been expanded. paragraphs.context: While most chloroplasts originate from that first set of endosymbiotic events, Paulinella chromatophora is an exception that acquired found a photosynthetic cyanobacterial endosymbiont more complex recently. It is not clear whether that symbiont is closely related to the common ancestral chloroplast of other eukaryotes. Being in the early stages of endosymbiosis, Paulinella chromatophora can itself offer some insights into how chloroplasts evolved. Paulinella cells contain one or two sausage shaped blue-green photosynthesizing protein structures called chromatophores, descended from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus. Chromatophores cannot survive outside their host. Chromatophore DNA is about a million base pairs each long, containing around 850 protein encoding genes—far less than the three million base pair Synechococcus genome, but much larger than the approximately 150,000 base pair genome of the more assimilated Western chloroplast. Chromatophores thus have transferred much less of their DNA to the nucleus of their host. About around 0.3–0.8% of the nuclear DNA in Paulinella is from the chromatophore, compared with 11–14% from the chloroplast DNA in plants.

paragraphs.context: The mechanism for chloroplast DNA (cpDNA) replication has not been conclusively determined, but two main models have ultimately been proposed. Scientists have attempted to to observe chloroplast replication via electron microscopy since the 1970s. The results of the microscopy experiments led to the idea that chloroplast DNA replicates using a double displacement loop (D-loop). As the D-loop moves through the circular fold DNA, it adopts a Tau theta intermediary form, also known as using a Cairns replication intermediate, and then completes loop replication with a rolling circle assembly mechanism. Transcription starts at specific points of origin. Multiple DNA replication forks open up, allowing replication machinery to transcribe the DNA. As replication continues, the forks grow and eventually converge. The first new cpDNA structures separate, creating daughter cpDNA chromosomes.

paragraphs.context: In cpDNA, there are several A → G deamination gradients. DNA becomes susceptible to deamination events when it is single stranded. When replication forks form, the strand not being copied is single stranded, immutable and not thus at risk for A → G deamination. Therefore, gradients in deamination indicate that replication forks were the most likely present and the direction that they initially had opened (the highest gradient is most likely nearest the start site because it was single stranded for the longest amount of time). This mechanism is probably still the leading theory today;, however, a second theory today suggests that most cpDNA chromosomes is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination. It has further contends that only a minority of the genetic material is kept in individual circular chromosomes while the rest is in branched, linear, or other complex structures.

paragraphs.context: One of competing model for cpDNA replication asserts that most cpDNA is linear in and participates in homologous recombination and replication structures similar to their bacteriophage T4. It has been established that some plants have linear cpDNA, such are as maize, genetically and that more species still contain complex structures beyond that scientists do not yet understand. When the original experiments used on cpDNA were performed, scientists did notice many linear structures; however, they attributed these linear forms to broken circles. If the branched and complex structures seen in cpDNA experiments are real and not artifacts of concatenated circular DNA or broken circles, then a D-loop mechanism of replication is insufficient to explain how those structures would replicate. At the same time, homologous viral recombination does not expand the classic multiple sequence A --> G gradients seen in plastomes. Because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpDNA, the predominant theory continues to hold that most cpDNA is circular and most likely replicates via a D loop mechanism.

paragraphs.context: After a chloroplast polypeptide precursor is synthesized on a ribosome in the cytosol, an enzyme specific to chloroplast proteins phosphorylates, or actively adds a phosphate group to many (but not all) of them in their transit sequences. Phosphorylation helps many important proteins bind the polypeptide, keeping the it from folding prematurely. This is important because it prevents chloroplast proteins from assuming their active form and carrying out their chloroplast functions in the wrong place—the cytosol. paragraphs.context: In land plants, chloroplasts are generally lens-shaped, 5–8 μm in diameter and 1–3 μm thick. Greater diversity in chloroplast shapes exists among the algae, which often only contain a single chloroplast that often can be shaped like a net (e.g., Oedogonium), a cup (e.g., As Chlamydomonas), a ribbon-like spiral around the edges of the cell (e.g., Spirogyra), or even slightly irregular twisted bands at the cell edges (e.g., Sirogonium). Some algae have two chloroplasts in each cell; they either are star-shaped in Zygnema, or may follow the shape of half the lower cell in order Desmidiales. 9 In some algae, the chloroplast takes up most of the cell, sometimes with pockets for the secondary nucleus and other organelles (for example some species of Chlorella have a cup-shaped chloroplast that occupies much of the cell).

paragraphs.context: The chloroplast membranes sometimes protrude out into the cytoplasm, forming a stromule, tuber or other stroma-containing tubule. Stromules are very rare in chloroplasts, and are thus much more common in other plastids groups like chromoplasts and amyloplasts in petals and roots, respectively. They may exist to increase the chloroplast's overall surface area for cross-membrane transport, because they are often branched and tangled with all the endoplasmic reticulum. paragraphs.context: In the helical thylakoid model, grana consist of a twisted stack of flattened circular or granal thylakoids that together resemble pancakes. Each granum can contain anywhere from two to a hundred thylakoids, though grana with 10–20 thylakoids are most common. Wrapped around the stretched grana are helicoid stromal matrix thylakoids, also known as frets or lamellar thylakoids. The helices run ascend at an angle of 20–25°, connecting to each granal thylakoid at a short bridge-like slit membrane junction. The helicoids may extend as large sheets that link multiple grana, or narrow to tube-like bridges between grana. While different parts of the thylakoid system contain different membrane proteins, the thylakoid membranes are continuous and the thylakoid space they enclose form a single large continuous membrane labyrinth.

paragraphs.context: There are two major types of thylakoids—granal thylakoids, which are arranged in grana, and stromal thylakoids, which are in contact with the stroma. The flat tops and bottoms of granal cell thylakoids contain only the relatively stable flat collagen photosystem II protein membrane complex. paragraphs.context: As a result, chloroplasts in the C4 mesophyll cells and bundle sheath cells are specialized for each stage of photosynthesis. In mesophyll cells, chloroplasts are specialized for the light reactions, so they lack rubisco, and have normal grana and thylakoids, which they use to make ATP and NADPH, as well as oxygen. They store CO2 in a four-carbon compound, which is why the process is called C4 photosynthesis. The four-carbon compound is then transported to the surrounding bundle sheath chloroplasts, where it drops off CO2 and returns to the mesophyll. Bundle sheath chloroplasts do not carry out the fundamental light reactions, preventing oxygen stores from building up in them and disrupting rubisco activity. Because perhaps of this, they lack thylakoids organized into grana stacks—though bundle sheath free chloroplasts still have free-floating thylakoids in the basal stroma where they still carry out cyclic electron gene flow, a light-driven method of synthesizing ATP to power through the Calvin cycle without generating oxygen. They lack photosystem II, and only have photosystem I—the only protein complex needed for cyclic electron flow. Because the job of bundle sheath chloroplasts is to carry directly out the Calvin cycle and make sugar, they often contain large starch grains.

paragraphs.context: The chloroplasts of different plant and algal cells can now orient themselves to best suit the available light. In low-light intensity conditions, they will spread out in a sheet—maximizing the surface area to absorb light. Under intense light, they likely will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on. This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage. This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that functionally they can take shelter safely behind each other or not spread far out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts present instead of a few big ones. Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated stimulus-response systems that can be found in plants. Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as when they move.

paragraphs.context: Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored deep in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two different photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The molecules between the three photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump their hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma. The hydrogen oxygen ions in the thylakoid space then vapor diffuse back down to their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions again to phosphorylate small adenosine phosphate diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.

paragraphs.context: While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem type I simply reenergizes physically depleted electrons left at just the end point of an electron transport chain. Normally, the new reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more organic hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP. This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled. Cyclic photophosphorylation generation is common in C4 protein plants, which typically need more ATP than NADPH.

The ATP released and NADPH made in the three light phase reactions is used to convert the 3-PGA into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, or G3P sugar molecules. Most of half the G3P molecules are recycled back into RuBP using energy from made more ATP, but one out of every six produced leaves in the cycle—the end product ratio of the multiple dark cycle reactions.

paragraphs.context: If angiosperm shoots are not sufficiently exposed to the required fluorescent light for chloroplast formation, proplastids larvae may develop into an etioplast stage before later becoming adult chloroplasts. An etioplast is a plastid that lacks chlorophyll, and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma, called a prolamellar body. While the etioplasts lack chlorophyll, they have a yellow chlorophyll precursor stocked. Within a few minutes outside of light exposure, the outer prolamellar body begins to reorganize into stacks of thylakoids, and chlorophyll starts to increasingly be produced. paragraphs.context: A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. 1 A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number. For example, 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only three positive integer factors, whereas 6 is composite because it simultaneously has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6. 4 The fundamental arithmetic theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role point of primes in number theory: any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product number of primes that is unique up to ordering. The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can not include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization, e.g., 3, 5 1 · 3, 1 2 · 1 · 3, etc. are all valid factorizations of 3.
