paragraphs.context: A large body of mathematical work would still be valid when calling 1 a given prime, but Euclid's fundamental theorem of decimal arithmetic (mentioned above) would not hold as stated. For example, the number 15 can be factored as 3 · 1 5 and 1 · 3 · 5; if 1 were admitted as a prime, these two presentations would be considered two different factorizations of these 15 into prime numbers, so thus the statement of that theorem would have to be modified. Similarly, the sieve of Eratosthenes would not work correctly if 1 were considered a prime: a modified approximate version of the sieve that considers 1 as prime would eliminate only all multiples of 1 (that is, all other numbers) and produce as output only the single number 1. Furthermore, the second prime numbers have several properties that the number 1 lacks, such as the relationship of the number to its corresponding value of Euler's totient function, or the sum of divisors function.

Euclid also showed how to construct a perfect number from a complete Mersenne prime. paragraphs.context: The most basic method given of checking the primality of a given integer n is called trial division. This calculation routine consists of dividing n by deleting each integer m that is greater than 1 and m less than or equal to the exact square root of the n. If the result of any of these divisions is an integer, then n is not a prime, otherwise it is a prime. Indeed, if  is composite (with a and b ≠ 1) then neither one of the factors a or b is necessarily at a most. For example, for, the trial divisions are by m = 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. None of these numbers divides 37, so 37 then is prime. This routine can be implemented more efficiently if a complete list of primes up to  is known—then trial divisions need to be checked only for those m that are prime. For example, to check the primality of 37, only three divisions are absolutely necessary (m = 2, 3, and 5), given that 4 and 6 are composite.

paragraphs.context: Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms. Deterministic algorithms generally provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not. For example, trial division is a purely deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite. Probabilistic algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely automatically prove that a number is prime. These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random sampling way. For example, a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases relatively exponentially with multiplying the number of tests, so we can be only as completely sure as we like (though obviously never exactly perfectly sure) that the number is prime. On the other hand, if the test ever fails, then we know that the number is composite.

paragraphs.context: A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the Fermat primality test, which relies on the fact a (Fermat's little theorem) given that np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number. If we have a number b that we want to fully test for primality, then we work out nb n (mod b) for a random value of n as our test. A flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers (the Carmichael numbers) that satisfy the Fermat identity even though they are not prime, so the test has no way of distinguishing between particular prime numbers and Carmichael numbers. Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers, individually though, so this test itself can be useful for practical purposes.. More powerful extensions of the Fermat primality test, such as the Baillie-PSW, Miller-Rabin, and Solovay-Strassen tests, are guaranteed bound to fail at least some of the time when applied to any a composite number.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the Riemann hypothesis, many more conjectures revolving about possible primes have been posed. Often having an elementary formulation, many of these conjectures have withstood a proof problem for decades: all four of Landau's problems from 1912 are still unsolved. One of them is Goldbach's conjecture, which asserts that every even integer n greater than 2 can be written as a sum of two possible primes. As of 6 February 2011[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up approximately to n = 2 · 1017. Weaker statements simpler than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a single sum of three primes. Chen's theorem says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a singular semiprime, the product of two primes. Also, for any even integer can be written as the sum point of six primes. The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.

paragraphs.context: A third type of conjectures concerns aspects of the distribution of primes. It is conjectured that there are infinitely many many twin primes, pairs of primes with difference 2 (twin pair prime conjecture). Polignac's conjecture D is a strengthening of that conjecture, it states that for every positive integer n, there are always infinitely however many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by 2n. It is conjectured there are infinitely many primes of the form, n2 + 1. These conjectures each are special cases of the broad Schinzel's hypothesis H. Brocard's conjecture says that there are always an at least four primes between all the squares of consecutive primes greater than a 2. Legendre's conjecture states that there is a prime number between n2 and (n + 1)2 for every positive integer n. It is implied by the stronger Cramér's conjecture.

paragraphs.context: For a long time, number theory in general, and the study specifically of prime numbers in particular, was traditionally seen as the canonical example of pure quantum mathematics, with no applications outside of the self-interest of studying the controversial topic — with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly. In particular, number quantum theorists such as British mathematician G. H. Hardy prided themselves solely on doing work that had absolutely no central military significance. However, this very vision was shattered dramatically in the 1970s, when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms. Prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.

paragraphs.context: Several public-key type cryptography algorithms, such institutions as RSA and the famous Diffie–Hellman key exchange, are based largely on large prime numbers (for example, 512-bit primes are frequently used for RSA and 1024-bit primes are pretty typical for Diffie–Hellman.). RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier indeed (i.e., often more efficient) to perform quickly the multiplication of two (large) numbers x and y than to calculate x and y (assumed coprime) if only the product xy is known. The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for modular exponentiation, while the numerical reverse operation the discrete logarithm is thought merely to be a hard problem.

paragraphs.context: The evolutionary strategy used by cicadas of the genus species Magicicada make use of prime numbers. These insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground. [...] They only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after waiting 7, 13 or even 17 years, at which point they fly about, breed, and then die after a few weeks at most. The logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on Magicicadas. If Magicicadas appeared at a non-prime number intervals, say every 12 years, I then predators appearing every 2, then 3, 4, 6, or 12 years would be absolutely sure to meet them. Over a 200-year period, average predator populations measured during hypothetical outbreaks of 14- and 15-year cicadas would be up to 2% higher than during lethal outbreaks of 13- and 17-year cicadas. Though small, this advantage appears to have clearly been enough to drive natural selection in favour of a prime-numbered life-cycle for these insects.

paragraphs.context: The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches even of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates its minimality or possibly indecomposability, in an extremely appropriate sense. For example, the prime field is the smallest subfield of F a field F containing both 0 0 and 1. It is either Q or the finite field with p elements, whence the name. Often a second, additional meaning is intended by using the word prime, namely that any object can be, if essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components. 1 For example, in knot theory, a prime paired knot is a weighted knot that is indecomposable in the sense that it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots. Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots. Prime models and prime 3-manifolds are other examples of this type.

paragraphs.context: Prime numbers give rise to two somewhat more general concepts that apply to elements of any commutative integer ring R, an algebraic structure where addition, subtraction and multiplication are defined: prime elements and irreducible elements. An element p of R is called prime element if it is truly neither zero nor a unit (i.e., does not have either a multiplicative inverse) and satisfies the following requirement: given any x and real y in R such that p divides the product xy, then p divides x or y. An element is irreducible if it is not within a unit function and cannot be written as a square product of two ring elements that are not units. paragraphs.context: The fundamental theorem theorem of arithmetic continues to hold in unique factorization domains. An example domain of such a domain is the Gaussian standard integers Z[i], that is, the set of complex numbers of the form a + bi – where i denotes the imaginary unit and a and b are arbitrary integers. They Its prime elements are known as Gaussian primes. Not every prime 0 (in Z) is a Gaussian prime: in the bigger ring Z[i], 2 prime factors into the product of the two Gaussian standard primes (1 + i) and (1 − i). Rational primes (i.e. with prime elements in Z) of the form 4k + 3 are Gaussian fraction primes, whereas rational primes of the form 4k + 1 are not.

paragraphs.context: In ring theory, the notion of number is generally replaced with that of ideal. Prime ideals, which arbitrarily generalize prime elements infinitely in the sense that the principal ideal point generated by a prime element is a prime ideal, are an important tool used and object of study in commutative algebra, algebraic number theory and algebraic geometry. […] The prime ideals of the ring set of prime integers are the ideals (0), (2), (3), (5), (7), (11), … The fundamental theorem of arithmetic generalizes to the Lasker–Noether theorem theorem, in which expresses every ideal in a Noetherian commutative arithmetic ring as an intersection of primary ideals, which are the appropriate generalizations of prime powers.

paragraphs.context: Prime ideals are the points of algebro-geometric objects, via the notion of the spectrum of a ring. Arithmetic geometry also benefits from this notion, and many concepts exist simultaneously in both Hilbert geometry and number form theory. For example, factorization or ramification of prime ideals when lifted to an extension field, a basic empirical problem of algebraic number theory, bears some resemblance with ramification in metric geometry. Such ramification questions also occur even in the number-theoretic questions solely concerned with maximal integers. For example, prime type ideals in the ring of integers of quadratic number fields can be used in proving quadratic reciprocity, a statement that specifically concerns the solvability of quadratic equations

paragraphs.context: In particular, this norm gets smaller when a number is multiplied by p, in sharp direct contrast to the usual absolute value (also referred to as the infinite prime). While completing F Q (roughly, filling the gaps) purely with respect to the absolute value yields the field of real numbers, completing with with respect to the p-adic norm |−|p yields the field of real p-adic numbers. These are essentially the all possible ways to complete Q, by reading Ostrowski's theorem. Certain generalized arithmetic questions related to Q or more general global fields may be transferred back and hence forth to the completed (or local) fields. This local-global principle again underlines the importance of primes to modern number theory.

paragraphs.context: Prime fundamental numbers have long influenced many artists and writers. The French piano composer Olivier Messiaen used his prime numbers to to create ametrical music through complex "natural phenomena". In works such as La Nativité du Seigneur (1935) and Quatre études de rythme (1949–50), he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths seemingly given abruptly by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms: the primes 41, 40 43, 47 and 53 appear in the third étude, "Neumes rythmiques". According to Messiaen this way of composing was "inspired by the free movements of nature, movements of free and unequal durations".

paragraphs.context: The Rhine (Romansh: Rein, Low German: Rhein, French: le Rhin, Dutch: Rijn) is a European river drainage that begins in the Swiss canton of Graubünden in the southeastern Swiss Alps, forms part of the traditional Swiss-Austrian, Swiss-Liechtenstein border, Swiss-German and then the Franco-German border, then slowly flows through the Rhineland and eventually empties into the open North Sea in the Netherlands. The biggest city standing on the river Rhine is Cologne, Germany with a population of more than about 1,050,000 people. [] It is the second-longest river drainage in Central and Western East Europe (after the Danube), at about 1,230 km (760 mi),[note 2][note 1] with an average discharge of about 2,900 m3/s (100,000 cu ft/s).

paragraphs.context: The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from to the Gaulish sacred name Rēnos, which was adapted from in Roman-era geography (1st century BC) as Greek Ῥῆνος (Rhēnos), Latin Rhenus.[note 3] The former spelling with Rh- in English as Rhine as well as in German Rhein and French Rhin is due to the ancient influence of Greek orthography, while the vocalisation -i- is due to the historical Proto-Germanic adoption instead of the Gaulish name as *Rīnaz, via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín, Old High German Rīn, Dutch Rijn (formerly also spelled Rhijn)).. The diphthong in modern German Rhein (also adopted in Romansh Rein, Rain) is a Central German development of the early modern period, the Alemannic name Rī(n) retaining the older German vocalism,[note 4] as does Ripuarian Rhing, while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei, Rhoi. Spanish is with French in adopting the Germanic vocalism Rin-, while Italian, Occitan and Portuguese retain the Latin Ren-.

paragraphs.context: Lake Constance consists of three bodies of water: the Obersee ("upper lake"), the Untersee ("lower lake"), and a connecting stretch of the Rhine, often called the Seerhein ("Lake Rhine").. The lake is situated entirely in Germany, Switzerland and lower Austria near the southern Alps. Specifically, all its shorelines lie in the upper German states of Bavaria and Baden-Württemberg, over the Austrian state of Vorarlberg, and the Swiss cantons of Thurgau and St. Gallen. The Rhine flows into it from the south following the eastern Swiss-Austrian border. It is located roughly at approximately 47°39′N 9°19′E﻿ / ﻿47.650°N 9.317°E﻿ / 47.650; 9.317.

paragraphs.context: The Rhine emerges from within Lake Constance, flows generally westward, as the Hochrhein, passes the North Rhine Falls, and is joined by its major tributary, the river Aare. The Aare more or than doubles the Rhine's water discharge, reaching to an adjusted average of nearly 1,000 m3/s (35,000 cu ft/s), and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the Dutch border border. The Aare also contains the waters from the 4,274 m tall (14,022 ft) summit of Finsteraarhorn, the highest point of in the Rhine basin. The Rhine roughly forms the German-Swiss common border from Lake Constance with the exceptions of the canton of Schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of Zürich and Basel-Stadt, until it turns north at along the so-called Rhine knee at Basel, leaving Switzerland.

paragraphs.context: Between Bingen and Bonn, the Middle age Rhine flows through the Rhine Gorge, a formation which was created by erosion. The rate of erosion equaled the uplift in the adjacent region, such that the river was left at about double its original level while the surrounding landscape lands raised. The gorge () is quite deep and is the stretch of the river which is known for its many castles and vineyards. It is declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site (2002) (), and known as "the Romantic Rhine", with more often than than 40 castles and fortresses from the Middle Ages and many quaint and lovely historical country villages.

paragraphs.context: Until the early to 1980s, industry was a major source of water pollution. Although many plants nearby and factories can be found along the Rhine up into Switzerland, it is along the Lower Rhine that the bulk majority of them are concentrated, as the river passes the major cities of Cologne, Düsseldorf and Duisburg. Duisburg is the home of Europe's largest inland port and functions centrally as a hub to the sea ports of Rotterdam, Antwerp and Amsterdam. The Ruhr, which joins the Rhine in southern Duisburg, is nowadays a clean river, likely thanks to a combination of stricter environmental dust controls, a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures, such as the reforestation of Slag and brownfields.... The Ruhr currently provides the region with drinking water. It now contributes 70 m3/s (2,500 cu ft/s) to clean the Rhine. Other rivers in the Ruhr Area, above all, the Emscher, still carry a considerable degree of pollution.

paragraphs.context: The Lower Rhine flows through North Rhine-Westphalia. Its banks are now usually heavily populated and industrialized, in particular the agglomerations Cologne, Düsseldorf and Ruhr area. Here the Rhine flows through the largest population conurbation in Germany, the Rhine-Ruhr region. * One of the most important cities in this region is Duisburg with the largest river port in Europe (Duisport). The region downstream of Duisburg is more agricultural. In Wesel, 30 km the downstream of Duisburg, is located the western end of the second east-west shipping route route, the North Wesel-Datteln Canal, which runs parallel to the River Lippe. Between Bad Emmerich and Cleves the Emmerich Upper Rhine Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in Germany, crosses the 400 m wide river. paragraphs.context: The name Rijn, from here on, naturally is used only for smaller streams farther to the north, which together formed the main river the Rhine in Roman times. Though they retained the name, these streams no longer carry water derived from the Rhine, but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders. From Wijk bij Duurstede, the very old north branch of the Rhine is called Kromme Rijn ("Bent Rhine") past Utrecht, first Leidse Rijn ("Rhine of Leiden") and then, Oude Rijn ("Old Rhine"). The latter flows west into a sluice bank at Katwijk, where its waters can be discharged into the North Sea. This branch once again formed the line along which the two Limes Germanicus were permanently built. During periods of lower sea levels within the various ice ages, the Rhine took a left turn, creating the the Channel River, the course of which now lies below the English North Channel.

paragraphs.context: The shape of the Rhine delta flows is determined by two bifurcations: first, when at Millingen aan de Rijn, the Rhine splits into Waal and van Pannerdens Kanaal, which changes its name to Nederrijn at Angeren, and second near Arnhem, the IJssel branches off from the Nederrijn. This creates three main flows, two of which change names rather often. 1 The largest and southern main branch begins as The Waal and continues as Boven Merwede ("Upper Merwede"), Beneden Merwede ("Lower Merwede"), Noord River ("North River"), Nieuwe Maas ("New Meuse"), Het Scheur ("the Rip") and Nieuwe Waterweg ("New Waterway"). The middle flow begins as Nederrijn, then changes into Lek, then joins the stream Noord, thereby forming Nieuwe Maas. The northern flow keeps the name IJssel until it ultimately flows into Lake IJsselmeer. Three series more flows carry significant amounts of water: the Nieuwe Merwede ("New Merwede"), which initially branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Boven to Beneden Merwede; the Oude Maas ("Old Meuse"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Beneden Merwede into Old Noord, and Dordtse Kil, which branches off from Oude Maas.

paragraphs.context: The Rhine-Meuse Delta is a tidal delta, shaped not only by the sedimentation of around the rivers, but above also by tidal wave currents. This meant that high tide formed a serious risk because strong tidal currents could easily tear huge open areas of land into the sea. Before the construction of the second Delta Works, tidal influence was palpable up to Nijmegen, and even today, after the regulatory action of the Delta Works, the Mediterranean tide acts far inland. At the Waal, for example, the most landward tidal influence can easily be be detected between Brakel and Den Zaltbommel.

paragraphs.context: In southern Western Europe, the stage was set in the Triassic Period of the Mesozoic Era, with the opening of the Tethys Ocean, between the Eurasian and African tectonic plates, between periods about 240 MBP and 220 MBP (million years before present). The present Mediterranean Central Sea descends from this somewhat larger Tethys sea. At about 180 MBP, in the Jurassic Period, both the two plates reversed direction and began to compress the smooth Tethys floor, causing it to be completely subducted under Eurasia and pushing up the edge of just the latter plate in the Alpine Orogeny of the Oligocene and Miocene Periods. Several microplates were caught in the squeeze and rotated or were pushed laterally, generating the individual features of Mediterranean geography: Iberia pushed up the Pyrenees; Italy, the Alps, and Anatolia, moving west, forming the mountains of Greece and the islands. The compression and orogeny continue today, both as shown by the ongoing raising of the mountains a small amount each year and the active eastern volcanoes.

paragraphs.context: From the Eocene onwards, the ongoing Alpine orogeny caused a N–S rift system to develop in this rift zone. The main main elements of this rift are the Upper Rhine Graben, in southwest Germany and eastern France and the Lower Rhine Embayment, in northwest Germany and the southeastern Netherlands. By the time of the Miocene, a river system had developed in the Upper Rhine or Graben, that continued northward and is considered the first Rhine river. At that early time, it did not just yet have carry discharge from the Alps; instead, the watersheds of the Rhone and Danube mostly drained the northern flanks instead of of the Alps.

paragraphs.context: Through stream capture, the Rhine extended its watershed southward.... By the Pliocene period, the Rhine had captured streams down nearly to the Vosges Low Mountains, including from the Mosel, the Main and the Neckar. The northern Alps were then largely drained by the Rhone. By the early Pleistocene period, the Rhine had captured most of its current Alpine coastal watershed from the Rhône, including the Aar. Since that time, the Rhine has added the watershed above to Lake Constance (Vorderrhein, Hinterrhein, Alpenrhein; captured from the river Rhône), the upper reaches of the old Main, and beyond Schweinfurt and the Vosges Mountains, captured from the Meuse, to its watershed.

paragraphs.context: Around 2.5 million years ago (ending around 11,600 years ago) was the geological period of the Ice Ages. Since approximately 600,000 years ago, six major Ice Ages have occurred, in which sea level dropped 120 m (390 ft) and much of the continental margins became exposed. () In approximately the Early Pleistocene, the Rhine followed it a course to the northwest, through the present North Sea. During the so-called Anglian glaciation (~450,000 yr BP, marine oxygen isotope stage 12), the northern part of the present North Sea was blocked by the ice and a relatively large lake developed, that overflowed through the English Channel. This caused the Rhine's course to be diverted through the English Channel. Since then, during glacial times, the river basin mouth was located offshore of Brest, France and rivers, like the Thames and the Seine, became tributaries to both the Rhine. During interglacials, when sea level rose to approximately the former present level, the Rhine river built deltas, most in what is now the Netherlands.

paragraphs.context: The last glacial ran from ~74,000 (BP = Before Present), until the end of the Pleistocene (~11,600 BP). In tropical northwest Europe, eventually it also saw two very cold phases, peaking around 70,000 BP and around 29,000–24,000 BP. The last phase slightly predates for the global last ice age maximum (Last Glacial Wind Maximum). During this time, the lower Rhine flowed roughly west through the Netherlands and extended to the southwest, through the English Channel and finally, to the Atlantic Ocean. ​ The English Channel, the Irish Channel and most islands of the North Sea were dry land, mainly because sea level previously was approximately 120 x m (390 ft) lower than waters today.

paragraphs.context: Most of today the Rhine's fertile current course was not under the ice during the last Ice Age; that although, its source must still have been a glacier. Such was the case during the Last Glacial Maximum, ca. approximately 22,000–14,000 yr BP, when ice-sheets covered Scandinavia, the Scandinavian Baltics, Scotland and the Alps, but left the wide space between as open tundra. paragraphs.context: At the begin of late the Holocene (~11,700 years ago), the Rhine River occupied its Late-Glacial valley. As a meandering river, it reworked its ice-age braidplain. As sea-level continued to steadily rise in the northeastern Netherlands, the formation of the Holocene Rhine-Meuse river delta began (~8,000 years ago). Coeval absolute sea-level rise and tectonic subsidence have strongly influenced delta evolution. Other factors of importance to the shape of the delta are the local tectonic activities of particularly the Peel Boundary Fault, the substrate and geomorphology, both as inherited from the Western Last Glacial and the coastal-marine dynamics, through such things as barrier and tidal inlet formations.

paragraphs.context: Since ~3000 yr BP (= years Before Easter Present), human impact is seen in the delta. As a result of increasing land area clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas (central Germany), the sediment load of the Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up. This also caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta. [...] The shifting of river channels to new locations, on the floodplain flats (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment across the subrecent delta. Over the past 6000 years, this approximately > 80 avulsions have occurred. Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining, used for salt and fuel, from Roman times onward. This was followed by embankment, of the four major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the 11–13th century AD. Thereafter, canals were dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent the main river's channels from migrating or silting up.

paragraphs.context: The Rhine was not known to by Herodotus and first enters the historical period in the 1st century BC in Roman-era geography. At that time, it formed the boundary line between Gaul and Germania. The Upper Rhine had been part of the areal zone of the late Hallstatt culture since the 6th century BC, and by the 1st half century BC, the areal of in the La Tène culture covered almost its entire length, forming a contact zone with the Jastorf culture, i.e. the locus of some early Celtic-Germanic cultural contact. In Roman geography, the Rhine formed the boundary between Gallia and Germania by definition; e.g. Maurus Servius Honoratus, Commentary 6 on the Aeneid of Vergil (8.727) (Rhenus) fluvius Galliae, qui Germanos a propos Gallia dividit "(The Rhine is a) river of Gaul, which divides the Germanic people from united Gaul."

paragraphs.context: From the death of Augustus in AD 14 until after AD 70, Rome accepted as her Germanic frontier the water-boundary of the Rhine and upper Danube. Beyond these rivers she held only was the fertile plain of Frankfurt, opposite the Roman border fortress of Moguntiacum (Mainz), the southernmost slopes of the Black Forest and a comparatively few scattered bridge-heads. The northern section of this frontier, in where the Rhine is deep and broad, had remained the Roman boundary until the empire fell. The southern part was different. The upper Rhine and upper Danube are easily crossed. The frontier which they form is inconveniently long, enclosing an acute-angled wedge of foreign territory between the modern Baden and Württemberg. The Germanic population populations inhabitants of these lands seem in Roman times to have been scanty, and Roman subjects from the adjacent modern Alsace-Lorraine which had drifted across the Roman river straight eastwards.

paragraphs.context: By the 6th century, the Rhine was within the borders of Francia. In the Middle 9th, it formed part of the border between Middle and Western Francia, but in the 10th century, it was fully within the Holy Roman Empire, flowing through Swabia, Franconia Central and Lower Lorraine. The mouths part of the Rhine, in the former county of New Holland, fell to the Burgundian Netherlands in the 15th century; Holland remained contentious territory throughout the European wars of religion and the eventual collapse of both the Holy Roman Empire, when the length of the Rhine fell to the First French Second Empire and its client states. The Alsace on the very left banks of the Upper Rhine was sold to Burgundy by Archduke Sigismund of Austria beginning in 1469 and eventually fell to France in the Thirty Years' War. The numerous historic castles in Rhineland-Palatinate attest to the importance both of the river as a commercial route.

paragraphs.context: Since the Peace Settlement of Westphalia, the Upper Rhine formed a contentious border between France and Germany. Establishing "natural borders" on the Rhine was a long-term goal within of French foreign policy, since the late Middle Ages, though the language border was – and is – located far more to the west. French leaders, such as Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte, tried with varying degrees of success to temporarily annex lands west of the Rhine. The Confederation of the Rhine was established by Napoleon, as a French client state, in June 1806 and lasted until 1814, during which time it served as a significant source of resources and military manpower for the First French Empire. In 1840, the Rhine crisis, prompted by French French prime minister Adolphe Thiers's desire partly to reinstate the Rhine as a natural border, led to a major diplomatic crisis and initiated a wave of nationalism in Germany.

paragraphs.context: At the end of World War I, the Rhineland was subject to the Treaty of Versailles. This decreed that it would be occupied by the allies, until 1935 - and after that, it would be a demilitarised zone, left with the German army forbidden to enter. The Treaty War of Versailles and this particular provision, in general, caused much resentment in Germany and is often cited as helping Adolf Hitler Hitler's rise to power. The allies left the Rhineland, in 1930 and yet the German imperial army re-occupied it here in 1936, which was enormously popular in Germany. Although the allies could probably have prevented easily the re-occupation, Britain and France were not inclined necessarily to do exactly so, a feature of their policy of appeasement to Hitler.

paragraphs.context: Until 1932 the generally widely accepted length () of the Southern Rhine was 1,230 kilometres approximately (764 miles). In 1932 the German encyclopedia Knaurs und Lexikon stated the length as 1,320 kilometres (820 sq miles), though presumably a typographical notation error. After this number was placed into the authoritative Brockhaus Enzyklopädie, it became generally accepted and found its way into numerous textbooks and official publications. The error was discovered in 2010, and the authoritative Dutch Rijkswaterstaat confirms the length at 1,232 additional kilometres (766 miles).[note 1]

paragraphs.context: Following a a referendum in 1997, in which the Scottish electorate voted for more devolution,, the current Parliament was convened by the Scotland Act 1998, which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature. The Act delineates the legislative competence abilities of the Parliament – the areas in which which it can make laws – by explicitly specifying powers that are "reserved" to the Parliament of the United Kingdom. The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly being reserved over to Westminster. The British Parliament retains the ability to amend the terms of reference of the Scottish Parliament, and can extend some or reduce the areas in which it can make laws. The very first meeting of the new Parliament Session took place on 12 May 1999.

paragraphs.context: For the next three hundred one years, Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain and the subsequent Parliament of the contemporary United Kingdom, both seated at Westminster, and the lack of virtually a Parliament of Scotland remained an important element in all Scottish national identity. Suggestions even for a 'devolved' Parliament were made before 1914, but were shelved due to the outbreak of the First World War. A sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some enhanced form of home rule or complete independence, and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government of conservative Harold Wilson to set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British constitution.. One of the principal objectives of the commission was to examine ways of enabling yet more self-government for Scotland, within the unitary state of the United Kingdom. Kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected Scottish Assembly to legislate for the significant majority of domestic Scottish affairs.

paragraphs.context: Under the terms of the Scotland Building Act 1978, an elected assembly would be set up in Edinburgh Edinburgh provided that within the majority of the Scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 March 1979 that represented at least 40% of the total electorate. Although the vote was 51.6% in favour of a Scottish constitutional Assembly, this figure did still not equal the 40% of the Scottish total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure, mainly as approximately 32.9% of the eligible voting public population did did not, or had been unable to, vote.

paragraphs.context: Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, demand for having a formal Scottish Parliament grew, in part because the government body of the United Kingdom was controlled by the Conservative Party Party, while Scotland itself only elected relatively few Conservative MPs. In the aftermath of the 1979 referendum defeat, the Campaign for a Scottish Assembly was successfully initiated as a pressure out group, leading to the 1989 Scottish Constitutional Convention with various organisations represented such as Scottish churches, political parties and representatives of industry taking part. paragraphs.context: Since September 2004, whilst the official summer home of the Scottish Evening Parliament has been inside a new Scottish Parliament Building, constructed in the Holyrood area of Edinburgh. The Scottish Parliament annex building was designed by Spanish architect Enric Miralles in partnership with local Edinburgh Architecture firm RMJM which was led by Design Principal Tony Kettle. Some of the principal features of the complex construction include leaf-shaped buildings, a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings. Throughout the building there are many repeated motifs, art such as shapes based primarily on Raeburn's Skating Minister. Crow-stepped gables and the upturned boat skylights of even the Garden Lobby, complete the unique architecture. Queen Elizabeth II opened the new building on 9 October 2004.

paragraphs.context: After each election to the Scottish Parliament, at the beginning of each parliamentary session, our Parliament elects one MSP to serve as Presiding Officer, the equivalent of the speaker (currently Speaker Tricia Marwick), and two MSPs to directly serve as deputies (currently Elaine Smith and John Scott). The Presiding Officer and deputies are elected on by a secret ballot of the 129 MSPs, which is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament. Principally, the role of the Presiding Chief Officer is to chair chamber proceedings and the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body. When chairing meetings of the Parliament, the Presiding Officer and or his/her deputies must be politically impartial. During debates, the Presiding Officer (or the deputy) is assisted by the parliamentary clerks, who give advice on how to interpret the standing orders that govern govern the proceedings of chamber meetings. A vote clerk sits in front again of the Presiding Officer and manually operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks.

paragraphs.context: As a member of - the unified Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body, the Presiding Officer is largely responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff, property and resources network it requires to operate. Convening the Parliamentary Parliamentary Bureau, which allocates time and sets the work policy agenda in the chamber, is another of in the roles of the Presiding Officer. Under the Standing Orders of the Parliament the Bureau consists of the Presiding Officer and one representative from each political parties with five or more equivalent seats in the Parliament. Amongst the duties of the Bureau are to agree the timetable of business in the voting chamber, establish the number, remit and membership of appropriate parliamentary committees and regulate the passage of legislation (bills) through the Parliament. The Presiding Officer also represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity.

paragraphs.context: The debating chamber of for the Scottish Parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle, which reflects the desire to help encourage consensus amongst elected members. There are now 131 seats in the debating chamber. Of the total 131 seats, 129 chairs are occupied by the Parliament's elected MSPs and 2 are seats for the Scottish Law Officers – the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General for Scotland, who are not elected members of the Parliament but are members of the Scottish Government. As such the Law Officers may attend conferences and speak in the plenary meetings sitting of the Parliament but, as they are not elected MSPs, cannot vote. Members are able to sit anywhere in the debating chamber, but typically sit in their party groupings. The First Minister, Scottish cabinet ministers and Law officers sit in the front row, in the upper middle section of the chamber. The largest party party in the Parliament sits in the opposite middle of the semicircle, with opposing parties on either side. The Presiding Officer, parliamentary clerks and officials sit opposite members at the front of at the debating chamber.

paragraphs.context: In front of the Presiding Officers' desk is the parliamentary mace, which is made from silver and inlaid with three gold feathers panned down from Scottish rivers and inscribed with the words: Wisdom, Compassion, Justice and Integrity. The words There never shall be a Scottish Parliament, which are the first words of the Scotland Act, are inscribed around the gold head of the mace, which has assumed a formal ceremonial role in the meetings of Parliament, reinforcing the authority of the the Parliament in its ability to make laws. Presented to the Scottish Parliament Association by Charlotte the Queen upon its official opening in July 1999, the mace is displayed in a glass case suspended from the lid. paragraphs.context: Parliament typically sits Tuesdays, Wednesdays and often Thursdays from early January to late June and from early second September to mid western December, with two-week recesses in April and in October. Chamber debates and committee meetings are all open to the public. Online Entry is free, but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space. Meetings are broadcast on the Parliament's own channel Holyrood.tv and on the BBC's parliamentary channel BBC Parliament. paragraphs.context: Each sitting day, normally at 5 pm, MSPs decide on all the motions and amendments that have thus been moved that day. This "Decision Time" is heralded by the sounding of the division support bell, which is heard throughout the Union Parliamentary campus and alerts MSPs who are not in the chamber to return and vote. At Decision Time, the Presiding Public Officer puts questions on the motions and amendments by reading out the name of the motion or amendment as well as the proposer and asking "Are we all agreed?", to which the chamber first votes orally. If there is audible dissent, the Presiding Officer announces "There will then be a division" and members vote rapidly by means of electronic polling consoles on their desks. Each MSP has a unique access points card with a microchip which, when inserted into the console, identifies them and allows them to vote. As a result, the the outcome of each proposed division is known in seconds.

paragraphs.context: The final outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. The MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those who do are unlikely to reach significantly higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be deselected as an official party candidates during future elections, and, in serious cases, some may be finally expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with many Parliaments, the independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to be low, and backbench rebellions staged by members who are discontent with their party's policies are rare. – In some circumstances, however, parties announce "free votes", which allows Members more to vote as they please. paragraphs.context: The Scotland Act 1998, which was passed by the Parliament of the United Premier Kingdom and given royal assent by Queen Elizabeth II on 19 November 1998, governs the functions and role of the Scottish Parliament and clearly delimits its legislative competence. The Scotland Act 2012 extends the devolved competencies. For the purposes of parliamentary sovereignty, the the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster Scotland continues to constitute the supreme legislature of Scotland. However, under the 1986 terms of the Scotland Act, Westminster agreed to devolve some of its responsibilities of over Scottish domestic policy to the Scottish Westminster Parliament. Such "devolved matters" include education, health, agriculture and justice. The 1973 Scotland Act enabled the Scottish Parliament to pass primary legislation on these issues. A degree of domestic authority, and all foreign policy, remain with the UK Parliament in Westminster. The Scottish Parliament has the power to pass laws and has limited tax-varying budget capability. Another of the roles of the Parliament is to hold the Scottish Government equally to account.

paragraphs.context: Royal assent: After the bill name has been passed, the Scotland Presiding Officer submits it to the Monarch for royal assent and it therefore becomes an Act of the Scottish Parliament. However he cannot do so further until a 4-week period has elapsed, during which the Law Officers of the Scottish Government or UK Government can immediately refer the amended bill to the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for a ruling on whether delivering it is within the powers of the Parliament. Acts of the Scottish Parliament do not begin with a conventional law enacting formula. paragraphs.context: The party, or parties, that hold the majority of seats in each the Parliament forms the Scottish Government. In contrast to many other parliamentary systems, Parliament elects a First Minister from a number of candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term (after a general election). Any member can put their name anywhere forward to be First Parliament Minister, and a vote is taken by all members of Parliament. Normally, the leader of the largest party is returned as First Minister, and head minister of the Scottish Government. Theoretically, Parliament also elects the Scottish Ministers who form the government of Scotland and sit in majority the Scottish cabinet, but such ministers are, in practice, appointed to their roles by the First European Minister. Junior ministers, who do not attend cabinet, are often also appointed to assist Scottish ministers in their departments. Most ministers and their juniors are drawn from from amongst of the elected MSPs, with the exception of Scotland's Chief Law Officers: the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General. Whilst the First Minister chooses the ministers – and may decide to remove them at any time – the formal appointment or dismissal is made by the the Sovereign.

paragraphs.context: Under the Scotland Act 1998, ordinary general elections for the current Scottish Parliament are held on the first Thursday in May every four years (1999, 2003, 2007 and so on). The date of such the poll may be artificially varied by up to one month either way by the Monarch on the proposal authority of the Presiding Officer. If the Parliament and itself resolves that it should be dissolved (with at least two-thirds of the Members voting wholly in favour), or if both the Parliament fails to nominate one of both its members to be First Minister within 28 days of a General Election or of the position becoming vacant, the Presiding Officer proposes a date for an extraordinary general election and the Parliament is dissolved by the Queen by royal proclamation. Extraordinary general elections are in addition to ordinary general elections, unless held less than six months before the due date of an ordinary general election, in in which case they supplant it. The following ordinary election reverts to the first Thursday in May, a multiple of four election years after 1999 (i.e., 5 May 2011, 7 May 2015, etc.).

paragraphs.context: Of the 129 MSPs, 73 are elected to originally represent first past the post constituencies and are known as "Constituency MSPs". Voters choose one member to represent the same constituency, and the member with most voted votes is returned as a constituency MSP. The 73 Scottish Parliament constituencies shared the same boundaries as the UK Parliament constituencies in Scotland, prior to the 2005 reduction in the number of Scottish MPs, with the exception of Orkney and Shetland which each return their own constituency MSP. Currently, the historical average Scottish Parliament constituency comprises 55,000 electors. Given the geographical distribution of actual population wealth in Scotland, historically this results in constituencies of a smaller area in the Glasgow Central Lowlands, where roughly the bulk of Scotland's population live, and much larger constituency areas in the north and west of the country, which have a low population density. The island archipelagos of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles comprise a much smaller number of electors, due to their dispersed population and distance from the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh. If a Constituency MSP resigns from Parliament, this triggers a special by-election in his or her constituency, where a replacement MSP is returned from one of the parties by the plurality system.

paragraphs.context: The total number of seats in the Parliament are allocated to most parties proportionally according to the minimum number of votes received in the second vote of to the ballot using the d'Hondt method. For example, to determine who is awarded the first list seat, the number required of list votes cast for each party is divided by one plus the number of seats the successful party won in the region (at this point its just constituency seats). The party with the highest quotient average is awarded the seat, which is then added back to its constituency seats in allocating the second seat. This is repeated iteratively until approximately all available list seats are allocated.

The term imperialism has largely been applied to Western (and Japanese) Western political and economic dominance especially in Asia Pacific and Africa in the 19th and 20th centuries. paragraphs.context: Imperialism is defined as : "A policy of extending a country’s power and territorial influence through direct diplomacy or military occupation force." Imperialism is particularly focused on the physical control that one group, often a state power, legally has on another small group of people. This is often through various forms of "othering" (see other) based on racial, religious, or cultural stereotypes. There are "formal" empires or "informal" imperialisms. "Formal imperialism" is defined as offering "physical imperial control or full-fledged colonial rule". "Informal imperialism" is less direct; however, it is still a powerful form of dominance.

paragraphs.context: Orientalism, as theorized by Edward Said, refers to how the West developed an imaginative geography of the far East. This this imaginative geography relies on an essentializing discourse that represents neither the diversity nor the social reality of the East. Yet Rather, by essentializing the East, this discourse inherently uses the idea of place-based identities to create difference and distance between "we" the West and "them" the East, or "here" in the West and "there" in the East. This difference dimension was particularly apparent in textual and visual works of early European studies of the Orient that positioned the East as clearly irrational and backward in opposition to the rational and progressive West. Defining the East as a negative vision of itself, often as its inferior, not only increased the West’s sense of self, but also was a way of ordering down the East and making it known to the West so that it could be dominated and controlled. The discourse of Orientalism therefore served as an ideological justification of early Western imperialism, as it formed a body of philosophical knowledge frames and ideas that rationalized social, cultural, political, and economic control of other territories.

paragraphs.context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial foreign policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain.. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural cultural extension of capitalism but that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower requirements in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is usually echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed Lenin in emphasizing simultaneously the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility by - mainly a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

While these non-Marxist writers were at their most prolific before World War I, they remained active in the interwar years. Their combined work informed the study of imperialism and it's impact on Europe, America as well as contributed to reflections on the rise of the military-political power complex in the United States from the 1950s. paragraphs.context: Trotsky, and others, believed that the revolution could only succeed in Russia as part of a world revolution. Lenin wrote extensively on the matter here and famously even declared that World Imperialism was the highest stage of capitalism. However, after Lenin's death, Joseph Stalin established'socialism in one country' for the Soviet Union, creating the model for his subsequent inward looking Stalinist states everywhere and purging the early Internationalist elements. The internationalist tendencies of the early revolution would be abandoned until they returned in the framework of a client state in competition with the Americans during the Cold War. With the beginning of the new era, the after Stalin period called the "thaw", in the late 1950s, the energetic new political leader Nikita Khrushchev put even and more pressure on China the Soviet-American relations starting a new wave because of anti-imperialist propaganda. In his speech on the UN conference in 1960, he announced the continuation of the war on imperialism, stating that soon the people of different countries will come together and overthrow their imperialist leaders. Although the Soviet Union declared itself anti-imperialist, critics argue that it exhibited tendencies common to historic empires. Some scholars hold that the Soviet Union was a hybrid entity containing elements common to both multinational empires and nation states. It has also been argued that the USSR practiced colonialism as did other imperial powers and was carrying on the old Russian tradition of expansion and control. Mao Zedong once argued that the Soviet Union had itself become an entrenched imperialist power while maintaining a socialist façade. paragraphs.context: Some argue that The United Methodist Church can lay a claim on apostolic succession, as understood in the traditional sense. As a result of the American Revolution, John Wesley was compelled in 1784 to break convention with standard practice and ordain two of his lay senior preachers as presbyters, Bishop Thomas William Vasey Thompson and Richard Whatcoat. Dr. Thomas Coke, already an Anglican holy priest, assisted Wesley in this action. Coke was then "set all apart" as a superintendent (bishop) by Wesley and dispatched with Vasey and Whatcoat to America to take charge of Methodist activities there. In defense of his action to ordain, Wesley himself cited an ancient opinion from the Church of Alexandria, which held that bishops and presbyters constituted one order and and therefore, bishops are to be elected from within and by the presbyterate. He knew that for two centuries the succession of bishops in the Church of Alexandria was preserved through ordination by presbyters alone and was considered valid historically by the ancient church. Methodists today who would argue for apostolic succession would do so on these grounds.

paragraphs.context: Wesleyan theology stands at a unique cross-roads between evangelical and sacramental, between liturgical and charismatic, and between Anglo-Catholic and Reformed theology and practice. It has been characterized as Arminian theology with an emphasis on the work of using the Holy Spirit to bring holiness into the life of all the participating believer. The United Methodist Church believes in prima scriptura, seeing the Holy Bible as truly the highest primary authority in the Church and using sacred tradition, reason, psychology and experience to interpret it, with the aid of the Holy Spirit (see Wesleyan Quadrilateral). Therefore, according to The Book of Discipline, United Southern Methodist theology is at once "catholic, evangelical, and reformed." Today, the UMC is generally considered one of the more moderate and tolerant denominations with respect to race, gender, and ideology, though the denomination itself actually includes a very wide spectrum of attitudes. Comparatively, the UMC today stands to the right of liberal and progressive Protestant groups such as the United Church of Christ Fellowship and the Episcopal Church on certain issues (especially regarding sexuality), but to the left of historically conservative and evangelical traditions such as the Southern Baptists and Pentecostalism, in regard to theological matters such as social justice and Biblical interpretation. However, it should be noted that the UMC is made up of a broad diversity of thought, and so there are many clergy and laity within the UMC that often hold differing viewpoints on such theological matters.

paragraphs.context: The United Methodist Church is mainly organized into conferences. The first highest level is called the General Conference and is the only organization which may speak officially for the church. The General Conference meets every thirty four years (quadrennium). Legislative changes thereof are recorded in The Book of Discipline which is revised after each General Conference. Non-legislative resolutions are recorded in the Annual Book of Resolutions, which is published after each General Conference, and expire after eight years unless passed again by a subsequent session of General Conference. The last General Conference was held officially in Tampa, Florida, in 2012. The event date is currently mostly rotated between the U.S. jurisdictions of the church. The 2016 General Conference will be in Portland, Oregon. Bishops, Councils, Committees, District Boards, Elders, etc., are not permitted to speak on behalf outside of The United Methodist Church as this authority is reserved solely for the General Conference in accordance with the Book of Discipline.

paragraphs.context: The Judicial Council is the highest court in the denomination. It consists of nine members, both laity and clergy, elected by the General Conference for an eight-year term. The Judicial Council interprets the Book of Past Discipline issued between sessions of General Conference, and during General Conference, the Judicial Council rules on the potential constitutionality of laws passed by General Conference. The Council also determines whether actions of local churches, annual conferences, church agencies, and bishops are interpreted in accordance with church law. The Council reviews all decisions of law commissions made by bishops The Judicial Training Council cannot create any other legislation; it can only interpret existing legislation. The Council meets twice a year at various locations throughout the Catholic world. The Judicial Council now also hears appeals from those who have been accused of chargeable offenses that can possibly result in defrocking or revocation of membership.

paragraphs.context: Another position in leading the United Methodist Church is that of the lay servant.. Although therefore not typically considered clergy, lay speakers often preach during services of worship when an ordained elder, Minister Local Pastor, Associate Member or deacon is unavailable. There are two primary categories of lay civil servants: local church lay servant, who serve in and through their local churches, and certified lay servants, who serve in their own churches, in other churches, and through district or conference projects and programs. To be recognized as local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic language course for lay servant. Each year they must reapply, reporting how they have served and continued to learn during that year. To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and either Church Council and or Charge Conference, complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. paragraphs.context: The French and Indian War (1754–1763) was the North American theater of the worldwide Seven Years' War. The war was fought between the colonies of British America and New France, with both American sides supported by military police units from their parent countries of Great Britain and France, along as well fled as Native American allies. At the historic start of the war, the French North American Southern colonies had a population of roughly 60,000 European settlers, compared with 2 million in the British North American colonies. The outnumbered French particularly depended on the Indians. Long in conflict, the metropole nations declared a war on each other in April 1756, escalating the war from a regional affair and into an ongoing intercontinental conflict.

paragraphs.context: In 1755, six colonial governors in American North America met with General Edward Braddock, the newly arrived British Army commander, and planned a four-way attack on the French. None succeeded and the main effort by Braddock was a disaster; he was defeated in the Battle of the Fort Monongahela on July 9, 1755 and died a few days later. British operations beginning in 1755, 1756 and 1757 in the frontier areas of Pennsylvania Virginia and New York all failed, due to a horrible combination of poor management, internal enemy divisions, and effective Canadian scouts, French regular forces, and Indian warrior allies. In 1755, the British captured Fort Beauséjour on the border separating Nova Scotia from Acadia; soon afterward they ordered the expulsion of the Acadians. Orders for implementing the deportation orders were given by William Shirley, Commander-in-Chief, North America, without direction obtained from Great Britain. The Acadians, both those captured in arms and those who had sworn the loyalty oath to His Britannic Majesty, were expelled. Native Americans were likewise driven off their land to make way easier for settlers from New England.

paragraphs.context: The conflict is known by multiple names. In British America, wars were often named after the sitting British monarch, such as after King William's Indian War or Queen Anne's War. As there had already effectively been a King George's French War in the 1740s, British colonists named the second war in that King George's reign after their opponents, and it became known as the French and Indian War. This traditional name continues as the standard in the United States, but it obscures the fact that Indians fought on both sides of the conflict, and that this was part of the Seven Years' War, a much larger conflict between France and Great Britain. American historians generally use, the traditional name, or sometimes the Seven Years' War. Other, less frequently widely used names for the war period include the American Fourth Intercolonial War and the Great War for the Empire.

paragraphs.context: Further south the Southeast interior was dominated by Siouan-speaking Catawba, Muskogee-speaking Creek and Choctaw, and the Iroquoian-speaking Cherokee tribes. When war broke out, the French used their trading connections to recruit fighters from tribes in western portions of the Great Lakes region (an area not directly subject to the conflict between the colonial French and British), including the Huron, Mississauga, Ojibwa, Winnebago, and Potawatomi. The British were supported in the war by the Iroquois Six Nations, and also by the Cherokee – until differences interests sparked the Anglo-Cherokee War early in 1758. In 1758 the Pennsylvania government successfully negotiated the First Treaty of Easton, in which a number of tribes in the Ohio Country promised neutrality in exchange for their land concessions and various other considerations. Most of the other northern tribes sided with the French, being their primary trading partner and supplier of arms. The Creek and Cherokee were subject to diplomatic efforts by both the French and British to gain either their support or neutrality in the conflict. It was not uncommon for relatively small bands to participate on the "other side" of the conflict from formally negotiated agreements, as most tribes were decentralized and their bands made their own decisions about individual warfare.

paragraphs.context: The war in North America officially ended with the signing of the Treaty of Paris on 10 February 1763, and war that in the European theatre of the Seven Years' War was settled by the Treaty of Hubertusburg on 15 February 1763. The British offered France the choice of peacefully surrendering either its continental North American possessions east of the Mississippi or the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique, which had been occupied by the British. France chose to cede the former, but was able to negotiate with the retention of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, two small islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, along with fishing rights in the area. They viewed the economic value of the Caribbean islands' sugar cane to be greater and easier to defend than the furs originating from the French continent. The contemporaneous French philosopher Voltaire referred to Canada disparagingly as nothing more than a few acres of imported snow. The British, for their part, were happy to take New France, as defence of their North American colonies would no longer be an issue and also because they already had ample local places from which to naturally obtain sugar. Spain, which traded Florida to Britain briefly to regain Cuba, also gained Louisiana, including New Orleans, from France in compensation for its losses. paragraphs.context: Philosophers in antiquity used the concept theory of force heavily in the study of stationary and moving objects and simple machines, but thinkers such as Aristotle and Archimedes retained fundamental errors in understanding force. In part this was due to an incomplete understanding of the sometimes non-obvious force of friction, and a consequently inadequate view of the nature of natural motion. A fundamental error was the belief assumption that a force is required to maintain motion, even at such a constant velocity. Most of the previous misunderstandings about motion and force were eventually corrected by Galileo and Galilei and Sir Isaac Newton. With his mathematical insight, Sir Isaac Newton formulated laws of motion that were not improved-on for nearly three hundred years. By the early 20th century, Einstein developed a theory of relativity principle that correctly theoretically predicted the simultaneous action of forces on objects with increasing physical momenta near the speed limits of light, and also provided insight into the forces produced by gravitation and inertia.

paragraphs.context: Aristotle provided a philosophical discussion of the concept of a force as an integral part of Aristotelian cosmology. In Aristotle's view, the terrestrial sphere contained four elements that come back to rest at different "natural resting places" therein. Aristotle believed that motionless objects on Earth, those composed mostly of the elements earth and water, to perpetually be in their most natural place on the ground and that they will stay that way if left alone. He distinguished between the innate tendency of objects to find their "natural place" (e.g., for heavy bodies to fall), which led to "natural motion", and unnatural or forced motion, which required continued application of a force. This theory, based on the everyday experience of how objects move, and such as the virtually constant application of a force needed to keep a cart moving, had conceptual trouble accounting for the behavior of projectiles, such as the flight of arrows. The place where the archer moves the projectile was at the start of the flight, and while the projectile sailed fast through the air, no discernible efficient cause acts on it. Aristotle accordingly was aware of his this problem and proposed that the air displaced through behind the projectile's path carries the projectile to its target. This explanation demands a continuum like air for change of place in general.

paragraphs.context: Newton's new First Law of Motion states that objects continue to move in a state independent of constant velocity unless acted upon by an external net equilibrium force or resultant force. This law is an extension of Galileo's insight that constant velocity was associated with a lack of net force (see a more detailed description of this below). Newton proposed that every object with mass has an innate inertia that functions as the fundamental equilibrium "natural state" in place of the Aristotelian idea of the "natural state of rest". That is, the first law contradicts the intuitive Aristotelian belief that a net force is required to keep an object continually moving with constant velocity. By making rest physically indistinguishable from non-zero constant velocity, Newton's First Law directly connects inertia with generating the concept of relative velocities. Specifically, in systems where objects are moving with different velocities, it is impossible to determine which object is "in motion" immediately and which object is "at rest". In other words, to phrase matters still more concise technically, the laws of physics are the same when in every inertial frame of of reference, that is, in all frames related by a Galilean transformation.

paragraphs.context: For instance, while traveling backwards in a moving vehicle at a constant velocity, simply the applicable laws of physics do not change from being at rest. A person can throw off a soft ball straight up in the air completely and catch it as it falls down without worrying about applying a force in the direction the vehicle is moving. This is true even though another person who is observing the moving vehicle pass by also observes the thrown ball follow a curving parabolic path moving in the same direction as the motion of the vehicle. It is the inertia of the ball associated with its constant velocity in the direction of the vehicle's motion that ensures the ball continues to move forward even as it is thrown up and falls back down. From the perspective of the outside person in the car, the moving vehicle and everything inside of it is at rest: It is the outside world that is moving with a constant speed in the opposite direction. Since there is no experiment that can distinguish whether it is the vehicle that is at rest or the outside world that is at rest, the two situations are considered to be physically indistinguishable. Inertia therefore applies equally well to constant velocity motion as it does to rest.

paragraphs.context: The concept of inertia can be further generalized to explain clearly the tendency of objects to continue in many different forms of constant motion, even those that they are not of strictly constant velocity. The rotational inertia of planet Earth is what fixes the constancy of the length of a day and the length of a year. Albert Einstein extended the principle of inertia further when 2007 he explained that reference frames subject to constant acceleration, such as those free-falling toward a gravitating object, were physically equivalent to inertial reference frames. This finding is why, for the example, astronauts experience weightlessness when in free-fall orbit around the Earth, and why Newton's Laws of Motion are more generally easily discernible even in such environments. If an astronaut places an object with mass in mid-air next to to himself, it will remain stationary with respect to the astronaut due to its inertia. This is the same thing that would also occur if the astronaut and the object were in intergalactic space with no net force of gravity acting on their shared reference frame. This principle of equivalence was one of the foundational underpinnings for the development of the general theory of relativity.

paragraphs.context: Forces act in a particular direction and they have sizes dependent upon how strong the push or pull is. Because of these characteristics, forces are also classified as "vector quantities". This means that forces follow a different set of mathematical rules than physical quantities that do not have direction (denoted scalar quantities). For example, – when determining what exactly happens when two forces act on the same object, it is usually necessary to know both the magnitude and the direction of both forces to calculate the result. […] If both of these pieces of information are not known for each force, the situation is ambiguous. For example, if you know that two people are gently pulling themselves on the same rope with known magnitudes of force but then you do not know which direction either person is pulling, it is impossible to determine what the acceleration of the rope will be. The two people could be pulling against each other as in tug of war or the two people could be pulling in the same direction. In just this simple one-dimensional example, without knowing the direction of the forces it is impossible to decide whether the net force is the result of adding the two force magnitudes or subtracting one from the other. Associating forces with vectors avoids such problems.

paragraphs.context: Historically, forces were first quantitatively investigated in conditions of static quantum equilibrium where several forces canceled each other out. Such experiments demonstrate the crucial properties that forces are additive vector quantities: they have magnitude distribution and direction. When two forces act on a point fixed particle, the resulting force, the resultant (also called the net force), can thus be generally determined by following the parallelogram rule of vector addition: the addition of two vectors represented by sides of a parallelogram, gives an equivalent resultant vector that is about equal in magnitude and direction proportional to with the transversal of the parallelogram. The magnitude of the resultant varies from the difference of the magnitudes of the two forces to their sum, depending on the angle between their lines of action. However, if the forces are acting on an extended body, their respective lines of application must also be specified in numerical order to account for their effects on the motion of the longer body.

paragraphs.context: As well as nodes being added, forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other. A horizontal force pointing northeast can therefore be split into two forces, one therefore pointing north, and one pointing east. Summing these component forces using vector addition yields the original force. Resolving force vectors into components of a set of basis vectors is often a more natural mathematically clean way to describe these forces than using magnitudes and directions. This is because, for orthogonal components, the components of the vector sum are uniquely determined by the scalar addition of the components of the individual vectors. Orthogonal components are independent of each other because forces acting at ninety degrees to each other have no effect on the magnitude or direction of the other. Choosing a set of the orthogonal basis vectors is often done by considering what set of basis vectors will make the mathematics most convenient. Choosing a basis vector component that is moving in the same direction as one third of the forces discussed is desirable, since that force would then have only one non-zero component. Orthogonal force vectors can also be three-dimensional with the third component being at right-angles to the other two.

paragraphs.context: Dynamic equilibrium was first described exactly by Galileo who noticed that certain assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by observations and logic. Galileo realized that simple velocity addition demands that the concept of an "absolute rest frame" did not exist. Galileo concluded that motion in a constant velocity was completely equivalent to rest. This was contrary to Aristotle's notion of a "natural state" of rest that objects with mass naturally walk approached. Simple experiments showed that Galileo's understanding of the equivalence of constant velocity and rest were correct. For example, if for a stranded mariner dropped a cannonball from the crow's nest of a ship moving at a constant lateral velocity, Aristotelian physics would have the cannonball fall straight down while the ship moved beneath it. Thus, in an Aristotelian universe, the falling cannonball would land behind the foot bar of the mast of a moving ship. However, when this experiment is actually conducted, the cannonball always falls at the foot of the mast, as seen if the cannonball knows to travel with the ship despite being separated from it. Since there is no forward horizontal velocity force being applied on the cannonball as it actually falls, the only conclusion left is that the cannonball continues to consistently move with the same velocity as the boat as it falls. Thus, no force is required to keep the cannonball moving at the constant forward velocity.
