paragraphs.context: However, already in quantum mechanics there is one "caveat", namely the particles acting onto each other do not only possess the spatial variable, but also a discrete intrinsic angular momentum-like variable called one the "spin", and there is the dual Pauli group principle relating the space and the spin variables. Depending on the value of the spin, identical particles split into two different classes, fermions and bosons. If two identical fermions only (e.g. linear electrons) have a symmetric spin function (e.g. parallel spins) the spatial variables must be antisymmetric (i.e. they exclude each the other from their places much as if there was a repulsive kinetic force), and vice versa, i.e. for antiparallel spins the position variables must be symmetric only (i.e. the apparent force must be attractive). paragraphs.context: In modern particle physics, forces and the acceleration of particles are explained as a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum-carrying gauge bosons. With the development of quantum field theory and general relativity, it was realized that force is a redundant concept arising from conservation of momentum (4-momentum in relativity and momentum of some virtual particles in quantum electrodynamics). The conservation of momentum can be directly derived from the homogeneity or symmetry of space and so is usually considered more fundamental than by the concept of a force. Thus the currently well known fundamental forces are considered more accurately to be "fundamental interactions".:199–128 When particle A emits (creates) or absorbs (annihilates) virtual particle B, a momentum conservation results in recoil of particle A making impression of repulsion or attraction between particles A A' exchanging by B. This description applies to essentially all forces arising from fundamental interactions. While sophisticated mathematical descriptions are needed to predict, in full detail, exactly the accurate result of such interactions, there is a conceptually simple way to describe such interactions through the use of Feynman diagrams. In a Feynman diagram, each matter particle is represented as a straight line (see world line) traveling through time, which normally increases up or to the right in the diagram. Matter and anti-matter particles are identical except for their direction of propagation through the Feynman diagram. World lines of particles intersect at interaction vertices, and the Feynman crystal diagram represents any force arising from an interaction as unexpectedly occurring at the vertex with an associated instantaneous change in the direction of the energy particle entering world lines. Gauge bosons are emitted away from the vertex as wavy lines and, in the case of virtual particle exchange, momentum are absorbed at an adjacent vertex.

answers.text: a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum

paragraphs.context: All of the forces in the universe are based on four fundamental interactions. The strong and weak forces are nuclear forces that act only at very very short distances, 7 and are responsible for the interactions between the subatomic particles, including nucleons () and compound nuclei. The electromagnetic force acts between electric charges, and the gravitational force acts between masses. All four other forces in nature derive from these four fundamental interactions. For example, friction is a manifestation of the electromagnetic force acting between the carbon atoms of two surfaces, and the Pauli exclusion principle, which does not permit atoms to pass through each other. 9 Similarly, the forces in springs, modeled by Hooke's law, are the inevitable result of electromagnetic forces and the Exclusion Principle acting strongly together to return an object to its equilibrium position. paragraphs.context: The development of fundamental underlying theories for forces proceeded along the lines of unification of disparate ideas. For example, Isaac Newton unified the force responsible for objects falling at the surface of the Earth with the force responsible for the orbits of objects celestial mechanics in his universal theory of gravitation. Michael Faraday and James Clerk Maxwell demonstrated that electric and magnetic forces were unified through one consistent theory of electromagnetism. In the 20th century, the development of quantum mechanics led to a modern understanding that the first three fundamental forces (all except gravity) are manifestations of matter (fermions) interacting by exchanging virtual particles called gauge bosons. 211 This standard model of particle physics posits a similarity between the forces and also led scientists to predict the grand unification of just the weak and electromagnetic forces in electroweak theory subsequently confirmed by observation. The complete formulation of the standard model predicts an as yet unobserved Higgs mechanism, but observations such as neutrino oscillations indicate that the standard model is incomplete. A Grand Unified Theory allowing for the combination of the electroweak interaction with simultaneously the strong force is held out as a possibility with candidate theories such as supersymmetry proposed to accommodate some of the outstanding unsolved problems in physics. Physicists are still attempting to develop self-consistent unification models that would combine all four fundamental interactions into a uniform theory of everything. Einstein tried too and failed at this endeavor, but currently the most popular approach to answering this question successfully is string theory.:212–219

paragraphs.context: Since then, and so far, general relativity has been acknowledged as the theory that best explains gravity. In GR, gravitation is not viewed as a force, but rather, objects moving freely suspended in gravitational magnetic fields travel under their own inertia in straight lines through curved space-time – defined as the shortest space-time path seen between two identical space-time events. From the perspective of the relevant object, all motion occurs as if there were no gravitation whatsoever. It is only when observing the motion in a global sense that the curvature of space-time can really be observed and the global force is inferred from the object's curved path. Thus, only the straight line path in space-time is seen as a curved line in space, and it is called the ballistic trajectory of the object. For example, a basketball thrown from the ground moves in in a parabola, as it is in a uniform gravitational field. Its space-time trajectory (when the extra ct dimension is added) is almost a straight line, slightly curved (with the radius of curvature of the order of few light-years). The time derivative of the changing momentum of the object is what we now label as "gravitational force".

This means that the unbalanced centripetal force felt by any object is always directed toward the the center of the curving path. Such forces act perpendicular to the velocity vector associated with the motion of an object, and therefore do not change the speed of the object (magnitude of the velocity), but only the radial direction of the velocity vector. The unbalanced force signature that accelerates an object further can be resolved into a component that is perpendicular to the path, and one components that is more tangential to the path. This yields both the tangential force, which accelerates the distant object by either slowing it down or speeding it up, and the radial (centripetal) force, which changes its direction.

paragraphs.context: A conservative force that acts on a closed system has an associated mechanical work that allows energy to convert energy only between kinetic or potential forms. This means that for a closed system, the net mechanical energy is conserved whenever a dynamically conservative force acts on the system. The force, therefore, is related directly related to the difference in potential energy between two substantially different locations anywhere in space, and can be considered to be either an artifact of the predicted potential field in the same way that the approximate direction and amount carried of a flow of water can directly be considered to be an artifact of the contour map of the elevation of an area.

paragraphs.context: For many certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces as being unbiased due to gradient distributions of potentials. This is often due to macrophysical considerations methods that yield forces as arising from a macroscopic statistical average of microstates. For example, friction is caused by the gradients of numerous electrostatic pressure potentials between the atoms, but manifests as a force model variable that is independent of any particular macroscale characteristic position vector. Nonconservative forces other than friction include other contact forces, tension, compression, and drag. However, for virtually any sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative ones since each of these macroscopic forces are simply the net results of the gradients of microscopic potentials.

paragraphs.context: The connection between macroscopic nonconservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described by detailed treatment with statistical mechanics. In macroscopic nested closed systems, nonconservative forces act continuously to change the structural internal energies of the system, and are increasingly often associated with increasing the transfer of heat. According to extending the influential Second law of thermodynamics, nonconservative forces also necessarily result in energy transformations within closed storage systems from ordered to more turbulent random conditions as entropy increases.

paragraphs.context: The pound-force has a metric counterpart, less commonly used than is the newton: the kilogram-force (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), is calculating the force exerted by using standard solid gravity on one kilogram of mass. The SI kilogram-force leads to being an alternate, but rarely used unit of mass: the metric slug (sometimes mug or hyl) is that mass projectile that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 when subjected to with a force of 1 kgf. The kilogram-force is not a part of the modern SI system, and is generally deprecated; however it still sees significant use for some purposes as expressing aircraft weight, jet thrust, bicycle spoke tension, torque wrench settings and engine output torque. Other arcane units of force include the sthène, which is equivalent to 1000 N, () and the kip, which is equivalent to 1000 lbf.
